Tweet: The comments can "improve the quality of work as writers learn more about their readers..." But not David Brooks who has admitted that he cannot deal with his readers' comments. There is a "Gresham Law" that applies to comment sections of various media whereby, over time, low quality or offensive comments drive away high quality commentators unless the media works hard to protect the quality of their comment section. The NYT is one of the few that successfully does it. The majority of comment sections deteriorate into the equivalent of debased currencies.
Wiki: the document discusses how comments on articles can be beneficial for writers, as they can learn more about their readers. however, david brooks has admitted that he cannot handle his readers' comments. the "gresham law" applies to comment sections, where over time, low-quality or offensive comments drive away high-quality commentators unless the media works hard to protect the quality. the new york times (nyt) is one of the few that successfully does this. in general, comment sections often deteriorate into the equivalent of debased currencies.

Tweet: Is there zero personal accountability in today's society? It is my understanding that if a person ingests fewer calories than are expended over a consistent period of time said individual will lose weight. In other words, don't eat a pound of double stuff Oreos everyday.

Tweet: Look, there are issues to be debateed. Do we need as much brick and mortaror public shelf space as we have? I use libraries a lot. I download audible books frequently, but I don't use my local northern NY library system to do it, I use the NY City Library. If I do want a book I locate it on Amazon (since its presentation of the book: description, professional and reader reviews is much better than the libraries) then I order it (on-line) from my local library system. When I get the e-mail notice that the book is ready I finally pay a visit to my library to pick the book up. Using this process I wonder why my library has publically displayed bookshelves at all.
Wiki: the document discusses the debate over the necessity of having as much physical public shelf space in libraries. the author uses their own experience as an example, stating that they frequently use libraries, but they download audible books and use the new york city library instead of their local northern new york library system. they also prefer to locate and order books from amazon because of the better presentation of the book, including the description, professional and reader reviews. they then pick up the book from their local library when it is ready. the author questions the need for publicly displayed bookshelves in libraries if people are accessing books through digital means.

Tweet: I have a salt sensitivity and have not been able to eat some foods at prepared by the chef. I use just the right amount of salt at home to season dishes. It's a necessary seasoning in most dishes, it just doesn't need to be used in excess. Guess my message is: put those salt shakers on the table for those who enjoy extra salt on their dishes. Please don't have a heavy hand in the kitchen....I'd like to be able to enjoy what I order.
Wiki:
the document is about a person with salt sensitivity who has trouble eating certain foods prepared by chefs because of the amount of salt used. they mention that they use just the right amount of salt at home but understand that it is a necessary seasoning in most dishes, as long as it is not used in excess. they suggest placing salt shakers on the table for those who enjoy extra salt on their dishes and ask chefs not to use a heavy hand in the kitchen, so they can enjoy what they order.

Tweet: I have lived in many cities in the U.S. and in Europe. One of the first things I did with each move was obtain a local library card. At present I have access to both a county library and a nearby city's facility. Both libraries are always crowded with people when I visit them, many using the free computer services, some reading out of town newspapers, others browsing in the video and recorded book section. In my community, the libraries also provide free access to private community rooms where people can meet for many different reasons. Finally, my computer is great, but when I want to relax and read I want a good old fashioned book. Libraries are wonderful places and we need them.
Wiki:
the document discusses the importance and benefits of having access to local libraries. the writer emphasizes the value of libraries, sharing experiences of using the free computer services, reading newspapers, and browsing video and recorded book sections. the writer also mentions the availability of private community rooms provided by the libraries. the document stresses the importance of libraries as a place for relaxation and access to traditional books. the writer advocates for the necessity of libraries in communities.

Tweet: Real names don't really help. As many other commenters have pointed out, they actually make it easier for online harassment to turn into offline harassment. What does make a difference is long-term accountability. Have pseudonyms tied to an email account that has to be verified periodically (e.g. once a year), and give pseudonyms a reputation score based on moderation (either by paid moderators as the Times does, or by other readers). Those with a high reputation score get perks like their comments being shown earlier, while those with a low reputation score get demoted to the bottom sections that almost nobody sees. That helps clear out the trolls or at least make them invisible.
Wiki:
the document suggests that using real names in online comment sections does not help prevent harassment and may actually make it easier for harassment to continue offline. instead, the document proposes implementing long-term accountability measures such as tying pseudonyms to verified email accounts and giving them reputation scores based on moderation. these reputation scores can determine the visibility of the comments, with high scores receiving perks and low scores being demoted to less visible sections. this system aims to reduce trolling and harassment in online comment sections.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- e.g. - for example
- pseudonyms - false names used to conceal a person's identity
- trolls - individuals who deliberately provoke or harass others online
- hashtags - used to categorize and group content on social media sites
- the times - refers to a specific news publication

Tweet: During those 3 decades of service under disparate presidents our country has bumbled into one after another military fiasco serving corporate interests more than American security. Tweet: Interesting article. Is Amazon trying for a monopoly on publishing as well? For a writer (like myself) the opportunity of Amazon is the most appealing in regards to finacial benefits. Publishing companies demand, in my opinion, a ridiculous about of royalties. Amazon lets the author keep almost all of the royalties and also the money. The only downside would have to be advertisment and publicity. Publishing companies get the word out far. Amazon pretting much leaves you on your own. So, depending on how good your book is, the profit could fluctuate in each circumstance. If the book is good, I'd publish it through Amazon. If the book was semi-good, I'd go to a publisher. Simple. The Semi-Child
Wiki:
the writer of the document is considering the possibility of amazon trying to dominate the publishing industry as well. they find the financial benefits of amazon very appealing, as the company allows authors to keep almost all of the royalties and profits, unlike publishing companies that demand a high percentage of royalties. the downside of amazon is that they provide limited advertisement and publicity, leaving the author to promote their own work. the writer suggests that if their book is good, they would publish it through amazon, but if it's only semi-good, they would go to a traditional publisher. they also mention that the profit could fluctuate depending on the quality of the book. the document suggests the title 'the semi-child' with reference to amazon.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- finacial benefits: financial benefits
- amazon lets the author keep almost all of the royalties and also the money: amazon allows the author to keep almost all of the royalties and profits
- i'd: i would

Tweet: Yes we need libraries. Public libraries provide so much more than just internet access, though that is an important service. Many libraries assist with literacy training, host book clubs, provide after school activities for children, give senior citizens on fixed incomes a place to borrow books they otherwise could not afford to read. Many libraries do dual duty as de facto community centers. Using the internet at home to do research is fine, Wikipedia is not a peer reviewed source that is accepted as a reference for many schools and universities. Scholarly databases that provide access to academic journals are available at libraries and are usually not affordable for most people. I could go on, but in short YES - we NEED libraries in our communities!
Wiki: the document emphasizes the importance of public libraries, stating that they offer much more than just internet access. libraries provide services such as literacy training, book clubs, after-school activities for children, and a borrowing service for senior citizens on fixed incomes. they also function as de facto community centers. while it is possible to research at home using the internet, it is noted that wikipedia is not a peer-reviewed source accepted by many schools and universities. libraries offer access to scholarly databases and academic journals that are not affordable for most people. in conclusion, the document argues that libraries are crucial for communities. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document were expanded into complete phrases and sentences.

Tweet: Several years ago when I was working with a Christian NGO in a largely Muslim area of Northern Kenya I asked a female colleague why she covered her head completely in the same way as Muslim women. She was surprised at my question and responded that it was a sign that she was a mature married woman. This gave me a new perspective on a symbol I had always seen as a sign of strict adherence to Islam. I later watched an interview with a young woman barber in Indonesia, where most Muslims are highly tolerant of other faiths (five are officially recognized by the government) and virtually all Muslim women wear the local style of hijab. When she was asked how she reconciled her profession with Muslim restrictions on contact with men, she replied in a matter of fact way that if she followed this rule she wouldn't be able to work and support her small daughter, and that wouldn't be good for anyone. One can only hope for a world where common sense prevails over the cultural loadings attached to these symbolic acts.
Wiki:
the document discusses the different perspectives on the hijab in different cultural contexts. it mentions that in a largely muslim area of northern kenya, a christian ngo worker learned from her colleague that covering her head was a symbol of maturity and marriage, rather than strict adherence to islam. similarly, in indonesia, a young woman barber explained in an interview that she wore the local style of hijab out of practicality and necessity, rather than strict religious adherence. the document expresses hope for a world where practicality and common sense prevail over cultural expectations related to symbolic acts like wearing the hijab.

abbreviations: ngo (non-governmental organization)
slang: none
hashtags: none

Tweet: I can't believe this is a serious topic of debate. I am less than a decade out of college, and certainly had access to Google when I was writing research papers, but no quality college-level research paper can be done without consulting at least several thorough books. If anything, such research papers are more critical now than ever, because people of all ages (not just young people) tend to defer to Wikipedia and other such sites as conventional wisdom, when in fact they are often simplistic accounts of complicated questions.
new_topic: a useful excercise for college students
Wiki:
the document argues that despite the availability of information on the internet, including search engines like google, college students still need to consult thorough books for quality research papers. it emphasizes the importance of consulting multiple sources, especially in today's age where people tend to rely on simplistic information from sites like wikipedia. this highlights the necessity for college students to critically analyze and evaluate information from various sources for a useful exercise in their academic pursuits.

- "quality college-level research paper" -> well-researched and scholarly research paper at the college level
- "people of all ages (not just young people)" -> individuals of all age groups (not only young individuals)
- "wikipedia and other such sites

Tweet: While do like the 99 cent rack on my kindle book store, there's a 50/50 chance that what I look at is self-published because before digital publishing, no one would touch it- and for good reason. Tweet: It works like this: 1) Read headline. 2) Skim first paragraph (optional) 3) Access fixed mental sound byte of some fanatical pet obsession which has slight relevance to minor side note of headline 4) Pen rant advocating said fixed opinion as absolute truth; include sound bytes cribbed verbatim from major opinion leaders with identical opinion; make sure to exclude any external support, evidence, facts, citations, links, etc. 5) Await reply from equally fanatical reader with completely opposite opinion 6) Repeat rant, including extensive insults to all who disagree.
Wiki: the document describes the behavior of individuals in the comment section of online articles or posts. it outlines a pattern of behavior, where people quickly form strong opinions based on personal biases, without considering evidence or facts. they tend to engage in heated arguments with others who hold opposing views, using insults and aggressive language. the document criticizes the lack of rational discourse and the prevalence of close-mindedness and aggression in online comments. it highlights the need for more constructive and respectful discussions on the internet.

Tweet: Birthright citizen cannot be found in the US Constitution or the XIV-th Amendment. Ms. Stock may be a lawyer, but she demonstrates no understanding of A1S8P4 or the 14th. Anchor babies born 40 years ago are still not citizens and that issue has not be adjudicated.
Wiki:
the document argues that the concept of birthright citizenship, which grants citizenship to anyone born in the united states, cannot be found in the us constitution or the 14th amendment. it criticizes ms. stock, who may be a lawyer, for not showing any understanding of article 1, section 8, paragraph 4 or the 14th amendment. it also claims that "anchor babies" born 40 years ago are still not considered citizens, and that this issue has not been legally resolved.

the abbreviation a1s8p4 refers to article 1, section 8, paragraph 4 of the us constitution, while the 14th refers to the 14th amendment. "anchor babies" is a slang term for children born in the us to non-citizen parents.

Tweet: Obesity is NOT a "life-style choice." I have not eaten in a fast food restaurant in over 5 years. I eat no sugar at all -- no baked goods, no candy, no sodas, no jam or honey, no syrup (let alone "a pound of double stuff Oreos every day"). I eat no red meat -- just fish and lean, skinless poultry. I eat no flour, just whole grains. I eat fresh leafy vegetables and fruits. I eat very little dairy. I limit my calories to between 1500 and 1800 a day. I exercise. And yet, at 5' 7", I weigh 215 pounds, and have for many years. Those of you who accuse me of a lack of "self-discipline" or of "gluttony" are ignorant bigots who should be ashamed of yourselves.
Wiki: the document argues that obesity is not solely a result of lifestyle choices. the writer has not eaten at a fast food restaurant in over 5 years and avoids sugar, red meat, and flour, while consuming fresh vegetables and fruits and limiting calorie intake. they also exercise regularly. despite all of these efforts, they weigh 215 pounds at 5'7" and have been that weight for many years. they challenge those who accuse them of lacking self-discipline or being gluttonous, calling them ignorant bigots who should be ashamed of themselves.

Tweet: Today's hyper-enhanced CGI extravaganzas are not movies, they are video games, where the effects themselves are the featured attraction. It is sensory overload-----pacing, story, character development take a back seat to this new aesthetic. One can easily imagine some twenty- or thirty-something director, succored from birth on the slash-and-burn intensity of video games----and in the case of the very youngest in Hollywood, on MOVIES that have already been styled on such games-----working themselves into a frenzy on a computer, overdosing on special-effects software and whiz-bang CGI. One even imagines that it is the CGI that comes first------waking up in the middle of the night with an 'Oh, wow, that would be AWESOME!' kind of idea, they then build a movie around it only afterward. It is a new language, a new vernacular, of the filmmakers art. Whether anyone but the youngest speak this tongue is a moot point. As the saying goes, if you have to ask, you can't afford it. In this case, if you don't 'get' this new sensibility, you're not relevant in the first place.
Wiki: the document argues that modern cgi-heavy movies are more similar to video games than traditional films. it suggests that the focus is on the visual effects, with less emphasis on pacing, story, and character development. the author speculates that younger directors who grew up with video games and cgi-heavy movies may prioritize special effects over other aspects of filmmaking. they believe that the new aesthetic values cgi as the main attraction, with storytelling taking a backseat. the document emphasizes that this shift represents a new language and vernacular in the world of filmmaking, and implies that those who do not embrace this change may be irrelevant in the industry. it also suggests that understanding and appreciating this new sensibility is a sign of being "in the know," using the slang "if you don't 'get' this new sensibility, you're not relevant in the first place."

Tweet: Restricting access is essential since the world population has exploded and the a significant fraction of the National Park visitors are foreigners. Tweet: This is scapegoating at its best. How could it be murder if it wasn't premeditated? In a society where ordinary people do not fear the police or the law, you will have nothing but crime and chaos -- like in any of those 3rd world countries in Africa or Central America. The media's manipulation and exaggeration these incidents, turning each into yet another race victimhood incident rather than what it really is, another case of embolden criminal resisting arrest, will only further embolden more criminals while further tying the hands of the police. Tweet: Not being from New York, maybe this discussion isn't meant for me, but I have to weigh in. I grew up in the country, on a farm, with a man for a father. He taught me to be like him: wake up early, work hard, eat a good meal, go to bed, repeat. He taught me that it is the responsibility of the strong to stand up for the weak, to do the right thing because it's right and not because someone is watching, to treat everyone with respect even if you loath them. He taught me how to shoot a gun, how to hunt, and the responsibilities that each of those carry with them. He raised me to be better than him, because that is the mark of a good man: leaving things better than you found them. So, to me, if a man does all of these things, he's a manly man even when he's getting a manny peddy. (don't know if I spelled that right because I've never had one.)
Wiki:
the document conveys the perspective of someone who was raised on a farm and taught traditional values of hard work, responsibility, and respect by their father. they were taught to be strong, to stand up for the weak, to do the right thing, and to treat everyone with respect. their father also taught them practical skills like shooting a gun and hunting, as well as the responsibilities that come with those activities. the author believes that a "manly man" is someone who embodies these values, regardless of whether they engage in traditionally masculine activities or not. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags translated:
- "manny peddy" = manicure and pedicure 
- "don't know if i spelled that right" = i'm not sure if i spelled that correctly 
- "he's a manly man" = he embodies traditional masculine qualities

Tweet: Sorry, machines are not people, in most work places new ideas, expressions of thoughts and sharing of information will lead to a solid work enviroment. Machines don't do that, they just answer you as getting it right or wrong. Number one thing happening in India, where our President was quoted as "Out working our American Students" was the lack of cognitive thinking and reading comprehension. Meaning "They can't think for themselves!"

Tweet: No matter what libraries offer in the way of books, recordings, or automation, libraries are public places that are part of our commons. In a sense, loitering is allowed, people can meet, sit and think, study, and browse through a collection of books or recordings that most of us could never privately own and that can be actually borrowed for a period of time for personal use. A library is one of the few places left in our society where we can go and be in public these days, in which there is no commercial coercion to buy something. I have been a librarian for almost 40 years and have observed how valuable such places are for everyone, regardless of social class, religious affiliation, age, or political opinion. Where else, now, in America can we find that kind of free, universally accessible public space?
Wiki: the document highlights the importance of libraries as public spaces that are part of the commons, where people can gather, study, and access a wide range of books and recordings. the author, a librarian with almost 40 years of experience, emphasizes the value of libraries as places where people can be in public without being pressured to make commercial purchases. the author also emphasizes the inclusivity of libraries, as they are accessible to everyone regardless of social class, religious affiliation, age, or political opinion. the document underscores the significance of libraries as one of the few remaining free, universally accessible public spaces in america.

Tweet: I've been a national critic of film, music, photography, books and cultural issues in general. I've always preferred the term "writer about . . ." to "critic" or "reviewer" (as in "writer about movies or "writer about dance"). A cultural subject - a live performance, a book, a painting, a film - is simply a complex occasion for writing well about something. A piece of "criticism" is worthwhile not because of its particular opinion, but because it is entertaining, provocative, and illuminating not just of the particular work but of the work's place in a larger historical, artistic and social context. Ultimately, any "critic" stands or falls on self-revelation: the subject under scrutiny is as much his or her particular prejudices, enthusiasms and acuity as the work under discussion. Professional critics are crucial to cultural vitality in many ways - as champions of unfamiliar works, as stimulators of curiosity, as goads to clearer, deeper thinking about an artistic experience, to name a few. Unlike the casual opinionators who crowd the Internet, the best professional critics become longtime companions - passionate, prickly friends with whom one can agree, laugh and argue over many shared experiences.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of being a professional critic in the cultural sphere, emphasizing that a cultural subject is an opportunity to write well about something complex. it argues that a piece of criticism should be entertaining, provocative, and illuminating, not just for the particular opinion it presents, but for its ability to contextualize the work within a larger historical, artistic, and social framework. the document also suggests that a critic's personal biases and insights are just as important as the work under discussion. it maintains that professional critics play a crucial role in cultural vitality by championing unfamiliar works, stimulating curiosity, and fostering deeper thinking about artistic experiences. it also makes a distinction between professional critics and casual opinionators who populate the internet, arguing that the best professional critics become longstanding companions with whom one can engage in passionate discussions and arguments over shared cultural experiences.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- "writer about" to "writer about movies" or "writer about dance"
- "critic"

Tweet: Biology plays a role in an individual's perception of how salty something tastes. If a chef insists on making the decision of how to properly salt a dish, then some will perceive it as over salted and some as under salted. It's a lot easier to add more salt than to remove salt from food. I always prefer a restaurant to go easy on the salt, and allow me to add what I feel is necessary for my tastes. Otherwise a number of diners are forced into eating food that they might enjoy more, if allowed to have input on how it's salted.
Wiki:
in this document, it is discussed that an individual's perception of how salty something tastes is influenced by biology. this means that people have different preferences for the amount of salt in their food. the document also mentions that it is difficult to adjust the salt level in a dish once it has been prepared, and therefore it is easier to add more salt than to remove it. the author prefers restaurants to use less salt in their dishes and allow diners to add salt according to their own preferences. this is because some diners may find the food over-salted, while others may find it under-salted. therefore, giving individuals the option to adjust the salt content according to their own taste preference can enhance their dining experience.

Tweet: Our kids are addicted to screens: facebook, texting, video games, TV-- Their parents often work, and the evening is too often a time when each weary family member retreats to his or her screen of choice. Human interaction, the ability to deal with conflict, the necessity to adapt to people who are different from oneself, not responsive at the push of a button, and essential to the development of real social skills, becomes less and less for these kids--and for us adults, too. This lack manifests itself in a cut-off relationship with other people, indifference to neighbors, absence of the learning that generations have formerly passed on to the young--societal coldness and narcissism abound. And a terrible need to be heard, and seen, and cared for by real human beings is rampant among the young. This is Facebook's appeal; the young people are crying out, "See me! Here I am!" in a world that seems to want to farm them out to machines and programmed experiences. Money and technology are not substitutes for the love and recognition of real human beings, and for many students, teachers are their primary sources of those gifts.
Wiki:
the document highlights the negative effects of excessive screen time on children and parents, leading to a lack of human interaction and social skills. it emphasizes the importance of real human connections for the emotional and social development of young people, especially in a world dominated by technology. in the context of online classes, it is important to recognize the need for genuine human interaction and emotional support for students, as teachers are often their primary source of love and recognition.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document:
- facebook (fb)
- tv (television)
- young people are crying out, "see me! here i am!" in a world that seems to want to farm them out to machines and programmed experiences.

overall, the document emphasizes the importance of real human connections and emotional support, as opposed to relying solely on technology and digital experiences, especially in the context of online classes.

Tweet: Both of my parents wer native born Americans and of course wrote and spoke English fluently. Very sad.

Tweet: When I lived in France, the prevailing attitude there was that the cook isn't supposed to add salt; that's up to the taste of the person at the table. Also, low blood pressure runs in my family and doctors have told me that I can either add salt to my food or take salt pills. I'll take the salt on my food, thanks. Personally, I also like the way the salt tastes on my meat just after I've sprinkled it on. How is that possibly disparaging to the cook? I'll side with the French on this one.
Wiki: the document emphasizes the cultural attitude in france that the cook should not add salt to the food, leaving the decision to the person eating. the author personally prefers to add salt to their food due to low blood pressure and enjoys the taste it adds to their meat. they also express that this preference is not meant to criticize the cook. they mention that doctors have advised them to either add salt to their food or take salt pills, and they prefer the former option. they also express a preference for the way that salt tastes on their meat after they've sprinkled it on. in conclusion, they express agreement with the french attitude on this matter.

Tweet: Students are not in a position to rate professors. Students are in the classroom to learn. I can't see how any professor who has a Ph.D. and knows his subject area cannot be a help to students whose work it is to learn. Yes, some profs are inspired teachers, great entertainers, dynamic lecturers. But some are boring, unimaginative, plodding. That's the way things are in the university and in life. A twenty-year-old who has a whole lot to learn about life should not be able to negatively affect the career of a prof. because he doesn't like that prof or the way he/she runs a class. Try giving out lots of Cs and see how you rate ( a grade, by the way that most students based on my experience deserve). If, as it happens, a particular prof is a terrible teacher, and a few are, word of mouth will determine the degree of success in his/her career. But the university should not invite criticism of its teachers by people who have only just learned to do their own laundry and fry an egg for themselves. Let the students work hard to learn what is being offered them.
Wiki:
the document argues that students should not have the authority to rate professors. it states that students are in the classroom to learn and that a professor with a ph.d. should be able to help them regardless of their teaching style. it acknowledges that some professors are better teachers than others, but believes that a young student's opinion should not be able to negatively impact a professor's career. the document suggests that if a professor is truly a terrible teacher, word of mouth will determine their success, and that the university should not invite criticism of its teachers by inexperienced students. it encourages students to work hard to learn and not to be quick to judge their professors.

complete phrases and sentences expansions:
- ph.d.: doctor of philosophy
- profs: professors
- cs: average grades
- hashtag: a word or phrase preceded by the hash sign (#) used on social media to identify messages on a specific topic
- i can't: i cannot
- prof.: professor

Tweet: The fact that comments sections can be abused is not a logical argument for getting rid of them but an argument for moderating them (as the NYT does). Yes, nobody wants to read teenage trolls. I have been following the Tesla 3 launch. The articles have been lamentable (either the journalists are ill informed or the fix is in) but the comments have been highly informative
Wiki:
the document suggests that while comments sections can be misused by trolls, this is not a valid reason to remove them. instead, the recommendation is to moderate them, as the new york times does. the writer acknowledges that no one wants to read comments from teenage trolls, but they do value reading intelligent comments. in fact, the document states that many believe the comments are often more insightful and informed than the articles themselves. an example is given of following the tesla 3 launch, where the articles were found to be lacking, but the comments were highly informative.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
nyt - new york times
tesla 3 - tesla model 3

Tweet: I would cancel my online subscription without comments. That said, I believe the Times, if not censoring, is unduly influencing the impact of their news by not only moderating comments, but by not allowing comments on all stories and by varying the time that comments are open. The story about Amazon's work environment comes to mind. They were quite literally pilloried by the comment section being opened for several days and 5000 comments. Rarely are comments open for more than a day for most stories.
Wiki: the document highlights the frustrations of the author about the comment section on the online subscription to a news outlet. they feel that the news outlet, referred to as "the times", is not allowing comments on all stories and is moderating comments in a way that unduly influences the impact of their news. the author recalls a specific story about amazon's work environment, where the comment section was open for several days and received 5000 comments. they find it rare for comments to be open for more than a day for most stories. the author is considering canceling their online subscription due to these issues.

Tweet: Conventional agriculture in the Midwest allows its fertilizers to wash into the neighboring streams. Conventional animal husbandry pollutes the Mississippi with manure. This waste of nitrogen and phosphorous has caused a loss of oxygen in a vast area of the Gulf of Mexico, killing off all the fish and the fishing industry in that dead zone. Please explain exactly how this is an efficient use of resources, especially of phosphorus, an increasingly difficult to obtain mineral. Organic farming strengthens the soil with compost, reducing runoff, and unites the animal and herbal branches. Finally, the reckless use of antibiotics, purely to promote growth, has been proven to foster antibiotic resistant bacteria. The impunity and political power of the farm lobby is displayed in the refusal to tally the quantity of any particular drug bought by a farm to the FDA. Many people will die of disease thanks to these farmers.

Tweet: I suspect that the cat is not too happy about being neutered either, but we do that for obvious reasons. If a cat is going to be exclusively an indoor kitty, and the alternative is the destruction of most of your furniture, then this seems a reasonable choice to me as a last resort. My parents left me with an entire house full of badly scratched furniture (including a Steinway grand piano!) thanks to not wanting to get their cat de-clawed. In their later years the cat often scratched them as well. The only caveat I would have is that if the cat ever gets out and runs away, it is probably doomed with no defense against wildlife, dogs, whatever. My own cats can go outside, and of course have their claws intact.
Wiki:
the document discusses the decision to declaw a cat as a last resort, especially if the cat is going to be indoor-only and is causing damage to furniture. the author mentions that their parents' decision not to declaw their cat led to significant damage to their furniture and even resulted in the cat scratching them in their later years. they also express concern about the safety of a declawed cat if it were to escape outside.

the abbreviation "i suspect" can be expanded to "i have a feeling," "i think". the author's use of "kitty" could be expanded to "cat". 

the slang phrase "run away" could be expanded to "escape". 

the hashtag "de-clawed" can be expanded to "having the claws removed".

Tweet: Ms. Shalala works in the corporate-university complex that is driving the cost of post-secondary education through the roof. No doubt, she's extremely well paid for promoting the on-campus life-style to gullible consumers. But why do the other contributors and comments miss the boat on this topic? University has become very expensive and middle-class families should not be running up the bill by sending students away to school. The vast majority of Americans live within commuting distance of universities. People are saddling themselves with ridiculous amounts of debt in pursuit of a fantasy. They should stay home, work and save during the summer and graduate debt-free.

Tweet: Unpaid internships are a bit like a "friend with benefits" relationship; a mutually advantageous arrangement with the potential to evolve. While a college upperclassman I cold-called Senators for several sessions in an effort to land an un-assisted (mom & dad didn't make any calls trying to influence anyone) and unpaid internship. Perhaps it is a simple example of "even a blind hog finds an acorn once in a while", but the next session I was hired as the Senator's aide when the Sr. aide elected to return to graduate school. I held that paid position four years until I too left to pursue my next educational objective. The result for me was: a) a paid position upon receipt of my undergrad degree; b) acceptance to a graduate program otherwise out of reach for many and; c) my decision to mentor and host interns for the past 30 years. Take the internship; you might just snuffle-up an acorn too.
Wiki:
the document suggests that unpaid internships can be beneficial, comparing them to a "friend with benefits" relationship with the potential to evolve. the author shares their own experience of landing an unpaid internship through cold-calling senators, which ultimately led to a paid position after graduation and acceptance into a graduate program. the author also mentions their decision to mentor and host interns for the past 30 years. the message is to take advantage of unpaid internships, as they can lead to valuable opportunities in the future.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- "un-assisted"  unassisted (mom & dad didn't make any calls trying to influence anyone)
- "sr."  senior
- "i too"  i also
- "undergrad"  undergraduate
- "30 years"  thirty years
- "snuffle-up"  find or acquire

Tweet: I am always amazed at the number of people I see in a library. At the college where I teach, students pack the large computer center, use the stacks of books and study (just as I did 40 years ago) at the tables. The addition of small, private meeting rooms in our new facility allow students to congregate in study groups without disturbing others. Public libraries are also a hive of activity as people who struggle through the recession use the lending of books, movies and music to remain entertained at virtually no cost. Benjamin Franklin would be proud of this American legacy, yet so often it is the first to lose public funding. How sad that we take these institutions for granted and yet we refuse to provide for their necessary functions in our lives.
Wiki:
the document discusses the significance of libraries and how they continue to be a valuable resource for people. it mentions the large number of people who use the library for various purposes such as studying, using computer facilities and gathering in study groups. it also highlights the importance of public libraries in providing free entertainment and the struggle they face during economic downturns. the author expresses disappointment at the lack of public funding for these institutions, despite their essential role in society.

Tweet: The low rates quoted by the Administration don't include total cost, which in the case of the lowest cost policies include high deductibles and co-pays. Tweet: I am extremely grateful for the moderators at NYT, and I shudder to think of the things they must have to read through. The NYT comments are the only ones I currently read. I follow many comment writers here, both agreeing and disagreeing with them. Some I look forward to, if only to have my own world view challenged. It would be too easy to read only those opinions that I share, and have myself devolve into a participant in the echo chamber that seems to feed too many steadfastly held beliefs out there. As for the anonymity, I never really thought that I might be hiding behind my user name. It goes way back to 1999 when I first subscribed. I am Tom Tyson, and I live in Sheboygan, Wisconsin. You can call me Tom.
Wiki: the document expresses gratitude for the moderators at the new york times (nyt) and discusses the importance of reading and engaging with a variety of comments and opinions in the comment section. the author values the challenge of having their own worldview challenged and recognizes the potential for echo chambers in only reading opinions they agree with. they also mention using an anonymous username since 1999. the abbreviation nyt stands for new york times, slang like "call me" and "way back" refer to using the phone for communication and something that happened a long time ago. the hashtag #echochamber refers to an environment in which one only encounters opinions and information that align with their own, reinforcing their existing beliefs and potentially leading to close-mindedness.

Tweet: The parents have chosen not to have their children attend public school, which the law allows. Having rejected the education at public schools, they now want to participate in a part of the systems which is superfluous to that educational purpose. They may pay taxes like everyone else, but the school does not receive state funding for their kids, but will have to expend very limited extracurricular funds on non-students. If they are allowed to participate, the family should pay for the privilege. Clearly these folks believe in having your cake and eating it too.
Wiki:
the document discusses how the parents of home schoolers have chosen not to send their children to public school, which is their legal right. however, they now want their children to participate in extracurricular activities that are funded by the state, even though they do not contribute to the funding through state taxes. it suggests that if they want to participate, they should pay for the privilege, as it is unfair for them to benefit from state-funded programs without contributing. the document also implies that the parents of home schoolers are trying to have the best of both worlds, by rejecting public education but wanting to participate in activities funded by the state.

Tweet: I have seen the video. It doesn't make sense as to why the policeman decided he had to use deadly force to stop Mr. Scott from running away. Tweet: At this very moment I have access to a myriad to foreign language, mathematics, history, or programming courses that I can take in my free time and increase my knowledge of virtually any area of life I choose. Am I doing it? Absolutely not. Schooling involves so much more than simply logging on, watching a video or two and reading a few dozen pages of prepared materials. Learning involves interaction not only with students but with peers. By understanding where you stand among peers and listening to their interpretations of the subject, a person learns far more than the simple course material. They learn how to think, how to interact with peers and teachers, and to have some sense of the larger world. Home schooled children tend to test well but how many of them have gone on to really grow in a career? How many of them have a real understanding of what it means to be part of a group? Online resources are a wonderful supplement to traditional education but they will never hold a candle to the socialization that occurs in a classroom setting.
Wiki:
the document discusses the availability of numerous online courses in various subjects like foreign languages, mathematics, history, and programming that can be taken to increase one's knowledge. however, it highlights the fact that simply accessing these courses and studying on one's own is not enough. it emphasizes the importance of interaction with peers and teachers in a traditional classroom setting, as it allows for a deeper understanding of the subject, as well as the development of critical thinking skills and the ability to work in a group. the document also raises questions about the long-term success and socialization of home-schooled individuals who primarily rely on online resources for education. it suggests that while online resources can complement traditional education, they cannot fully replace the social and interactive aspects of learning in a classroom setting.

abbreviations:
- myriad: a countless or extremely great number
- am: verb indicating present tense
- i: first person singular pronoun

slang:
- absolutely not: definitely not
- peers: people

Tweet: This response reflects my views as well. Polls are a political tool for politicians, not a democratic vehicle where people can voice their opinions and know that it will matter. It is much easier for a pollster to get a higher rate of return with simple questions that require yes/no answers. Thus, should an interviewer encounter someone with a more nuanced view or deeper understanding, those responses are far less likely to be included, let alone even documented. Interviewers generally get paid by the number of completed surveys. Thus polls would tend to reflect the attitude of the least educated and least critical thinkers among us. Sorry if that sounds condescending. By then reflecting - after the usually poorly worded and biases questions are asked - those opinions, the polls then contribute to the dumbing down of America.
Wiki:
the document indicates that polls are often used as a political tool for politicians, rather than as a true representation of democratic voices. pollsters may prioritize getting a high response rate by asking simple yes/no questions, which may not accurately capture the nuanced or informed perspectives of respondents. interviewers are often paid based on the number of completed surveys, which may incentivize them to prioritize quantity over quality. as a result, polls may reflect the opinions of the least educated and least critical thinkers. the document suggests that this process contributes to the 'dumbing down' of america.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- "views" refers to personal opinions or beliefs
- "polls" are surveys or questionnaires used to gather public opinion
- "once" is indicating a specific point in time
- "by" means the process of, or through the actions of
- "us" refers to the united states
- "sorry if that sounds condescending" expresses an apology for appearing

Tweet: Information has moved from print to digital. That does not mean it is free or that it is easily located. Stop equating libraries with print. The point of most libraries never was to serve as a storage space. Unless you are a librarian or work at a library, you probably don't realize that everything in a library, including computers, wifi, online journals, and ebooks, is there as a carefully curated collection created to meet the needs of the people who use it. What you do realize is that when you walk into a library, or go there online, you find what you need and don't need to think very much about how that happened. Libraries serve the same purpose today that they have always served... to make information accessible to everyone through resources and services.
Wiki:
the document discusses the shift of information from print to digital, emphasizing that this does not mean it is free or easily accessible. it argues that libraries should not be equated with print and that their main purpose is to make information accessible to everyone through resources and services. it points out that libraries are carefully curated collections created to meet the needs of their users, including computers, wifi, online journals, and ebooks. it also highlights that the role of libraries today remains the same as always, which is to provide accessible information to the public.

the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document are:

1. wifi (wireless fidelity): a technology that allows electronic devices to exchange data wirelessly
2. ebooks (electronic books): digital or electronic version of a traditional printed book
3. #libraries: the use of the hashtag "libraries" indicates a social media reference to the topic of libraries and their importance.

expanding these abbreviations, slang, and hashtags into complete phrases and sentences

Tweet: This is sad: basically, the argument presented here is that public opinion polls help our representatives understand how we feel on a particular issue. The truth is, politicians use poll results to craft their campaign rhetoric - and once elected, ignore the polls and focus on the needs of the powerful which they obtain at dinner parties, on the golf course and through lobbyists. Just look at the numerous polls showing broad public support for policies which the rich veto: a national health plan, increased Social Security benefits, increased taxation of wealth, ending austerity etc.
Wiki:
public opinion polls are supposed to help our representatives understand how we feel about certain issues. however, the argument presented in the document is that politicians actually use poll results to shape their campaign messaging, but once they are elected, they tend to ignore the polls and prioritize the needs of the powerful. this is often achieved through interactions at dinner parties, on the golf course, and through lobbyists. the document points out that despite numerous polls showing strong public support for policies such as a national health plan, increased social security benefits, increased taxation of wealth, and ending austerity, these policies are often vetoed by the wealthy. 

the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document are expanded to provide a clearer understanding of the text.

Tweet: Turner's argument that Obamacare is inherently flawed and cannot be made to work overlooks some important counterexamples, including the success of the Swiss (and to a lesser extent the Dutch) healthcare system. Furthermore, the same basic premise (guaranteed coverage across a large risk pool without adverse selection) is working well even in America, in large employer-subsidized group plans. A responsible market-oriented conservative would be asking why Obamacare isn't working as well as those plans, not seeking to bury it without any serious analysis.
Wiki: the document argues that turner's assertion that obamacare (affordable care act) is inherently flawed and cannot be made to work is not entirely accurate. there are important examples that counter this argument, such as the success of the swiss and dutch healthcare systems. additionally, the basic premise of guaranteed coverage across a large risk pool without adverse selection is working well in america, particularly in large employer-subsidized group plans. the document suggests that instead of seeking to bury obamacare without any serious analysis, a responsible market-oriented conservative should be asking why obamacare isn't working as well as those plans. it calls for a more thorough examination of the reasons behind obamacare's perceived shortcomings.

Tweet: I don't like using unpaid interns, because i think that it is a form of elitism. I could never have afforded to work anywhere for free. Only students from families who can support them can afford to work for free, which excludes all of the students who are just scraping by to go to school and paying for it themselves. These students make the best employees. They take learning and work seriously. The problem is that graduates are now coming to the work force with far fewer skills and previous job experience than in previous generations. Many graduates have never held ANY job, be it baby sitting, dog walking or waitressing. I have found it preferable to hire graduates or students who are committed to working for more than a semester at a low wage with the understanding that due to their lack of experience, I will teach them, but they are more committed to stick around once they have learned and make great employees as their salaries go up with their abilities.
Wiki:
the document expresses a disapproval of using unpaid interns, as it is seen as a form of elitism. the author believes that only students from wealthy families can afford to work for free, excluding those who are struggling to pay for their education. these students are considered to be the best employees, as they take learning and work seriously. the author prefers to hire graduates or students who are willing to work for low wages for an extended period, with the understanding that they will be taught the necessary skills. this helps to address the issue of graduates entering the workforce with limited skills and job experience. the author finds that these individuals are more committed and make great employees as their abilities improve and their salaries increase.

abbreviation example: "graduates" = individuals who have completed their college education
slang example: "stick around" = remain in a place for an extended period 
hashtag example: none given

Tweet: If they dress like robo-cop warriors they will want to act that way. Polite, no. Intimidating, yes! When we visited China the first thing I noticed was that their visible police were UNARMED! It is simply not their job to routinely threaten to shoot anyone who violates their orders. Only a SWAT or military unit can respond to any violence. Thus there is far less confrontation with deadly force. Disarm the regular beat cops. Let them go back to friendlier dress and personal presence to see that the law is respected.
Wiki:
the document suggests that police officers should not be dressed in intimidating and militarized attire, as this may lead them to act aggressively. the writer observed during a visit to china that police officers there do not carry weapons and are not routinely threatening to shoot people. instead, only specialized swat or military units can respond to violent situations, leading to less use of deadly force. the document proposes that regular beat cops should be disarmed and return to a friendlier and less intimidating appearance in order to ensure that the law is respected.

abbreviations:
- unarmed: not carrying weapons

slang:
- robo-cop: a term for a police officer who is heavily armed and intimidating 

hashtags:
- none

Tweet: As an adult without children, the writer is entitled to believe whatever she wants as long as she doesn't endanger others. But this is just the kind of thinking -- with or without God -- expressed by parents of unvaccinated children, who put their entire neighborhood and beyond at risk because they _believe_ they are doing the right thing. There was just news, for example, that the measles outbreak has now spread into Canada tied to the first transmission in Disneyland. There should be no exemptions in the public sphere for parents who believe in magical thinking, no matter what their alleged divine source. And if we learn of a child at risk of serious injury or death because his/her parents _believe_ they are doing the right thing, I hope the state will step in like it would any other form of child abuse. There should be no exemption for carelessness or stupidity.

Tweet: There is nothing in the Fourteenth Amendment that permits birthright citizenship to non-citizens. In 1866, Senator Jacob Howard, co-author of the citizenship clause of the Fourteenth Amendment wrote: "Every Person born within the limits of the United States, and subject to their jurisdiction, is by virtue of natural law and national law a citizen of the United States. This will not, of course, include persons born in the United States who are foreigners, aliens, who belong to the families of ambassadors or foreign ministers accredited to the Government of the United States, but will include every other class of persons...only thru expatriation, which could be accomplished thru law alone, and not thru any immigrant acting on his own outside the law-and certainly not by any act of birth alone-could an alien become a citizen...[the] Constitution as now amended, forever withholds the right of citizenship in the case of accidental birth of a child belonging to foreign parents within the limits of the country."
Wiki:
the document argues that the fourteenth amendment does not allow birthright citizenship for non-citizens. senator jacob howard, one of the authors of the citizenship clause of the fourteenth amendment, stated in 1866 that only those born within the us and subject to its jurisdiction are citizens. this does not include foreign-born persons, aliens, or the families of ambassadors. he also emphasized that only through expatriation, accomplished through law, could an alien become a citizen. the constitution, as amended, permanently denies citizenship to children born to foreign parents within the us. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document have been expanded:
- 'thru' into 'through'
- 'expatriation' is the process of renouncing one's citizenship and becoming a citizen of another country
- 'alien' refers to a person who is not a citizen of the country in which they live
- 'us' stands for the united states
- 'amended' refers to

Tweet: I had a great aunt who was a Christian Scientist; her little daughter died of an easily treated illness because of those beliefs. There is, in fact, very little room for debate. Belief systems that can result in suffering or death may be adopted by adults. To impose them upon children is, and should be treated as, criminal neglect and abuse. I believe that my very nice, kind aunt should have been prosecuted. Better yet, she should have been prevented by clear legal mandate from withholding medical care from her little girl in the first place. It's an absurd and deadly misconstruction of religious freedom.
Wiki:
the document discusses the case of a child who died because her christian scientist parents withheld medical care due to their beliefs. the author argues that belief systems that lead to suffering or death should not be imposed on children, and that such actions should be considered criminal neglect and abuse. the author believes that in this case, the parents should have been prosecuted and that clear legal mandates should prevent the withholding of medical care from children. the author also criticizes the misconstruction of religious freedom that led to this tragic outcome.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- #christianscientist: christian scientist
- #legalmandate: clear legal mandate
- #withholdingmedicalcare: withholding medical care

Tweet: What about those who apprentice or simply work for free in order to fulfill an opportunity to prove oneself worthy of future paid work? I worked for free and at night on low budget feature films until I proved myself skilled and worthy of joining the union. In recent past I've worked with so many unpaid or low paid interns, some of them great and some of them terrible. Regardless, they're on for a short period of time, those who do well are worthy of staying on in a paid position or being recommended somewhere else. They're coming to the table with virtually no experience and an apparent positive attitude. Some live up to it, some end up flailing. What was it Darwin said?
Wiki:
the document discusses the issue of unpaid internships and working for free in order to gain experience and prove oneself worthy of future paid work. the author shares their own experience of working for free on low budget feature films until they proved themselves skilled enough to join the union. they also mention working with unpaid or low paid interns, some of whom performed well and others who did not. the author highlights the potential for unpaid interns to prove themselves and potentially secure paid positions or recommendations. they reference charles darwin's idea of survival of the fittest in this context. 

the abbreviation "unpaid internship" stands for a period of work experience in which a person is not paid for their labor. the slang term "coming to the table" refers to someone bringing something of value or importance to a situation. 

the hashtag "flailing" refers to the concept of someone struggling or failing in a particular situation.

Tweet: A lot of the anxiety of the commentariat when it comes to the issue of online comments simply reflects the precipitous decline in deference afforded the once proud professional pontificator. They used to provide the final word. Now more often then not if they do their job right they are at best conversation starters. And what a conversation it has become, I often can't wait to get to the comments after reading an article eager to sift through the non sequiturs and sophomoric sonambulism to find the real analytical gems so often to be found there. Like the saying goes "sometimes you have to kiss a lot of frogs" ... As to trolls meh. They can be dealt with. I for one am fully in favour of moderated comments that remove the venom and bile that can sometimes be spewed by the web yet retain the wonderful crowd sourced intelligence, wisdom and wit of fellow readers. I've read these comments. I know these comments and trust me the people writing these aren't "punching up" they're elevating the intellectual quality of the whole experience. Now let's have a discussion on moderation.
Wiki: the document discusses the anxiety of commentators about online comments, which reflects the decline in deference given to professional opinion writers. they used to have the final word, but now they are at best starting conversations. the author enjoys reading comments after articles, sifting through the irrelevant and immature comments to find insightful ones, and believes in the value of moderated comments that remove negativity while keeping intelligent and witty contributions. the author trusts the comments and believes they elevate the overall intellectual quality. the author also calls for a discussion on moderation in the comment section. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document, such as "meh" and "punching up", are expanded into complete phrases and sentences for better understanding.

Tweet: In the Canadian legal system - and I suspect the American one is the same - a reasonable apprehension of bias is considered to be as pernicious as an actual bias. Indeed, the test has always been whether a party can establish the former, and not the latter. While few are so naive as to think that justices have no views, it is incomprehensible to me that a justice would enter the fray this way. It is unhelpful generally, and it is detrimental to the Court. It is unhelpful in that I doubt those who lean toward Mr. Trump place much weight on Judge Ginsburg's views to begin with - so she is unlikely to change anyone's mind (especially considering the widely-held anti-elites sentiment that has become so prominent this year). And it is detrimental to a Court that has struggled so much in recent years to combat the view that the Court is every bit as entrenched and political as the rest of the political system is. Judge Ginsburg has given 40-50% of the people every reason to write her off, which ultimately just hurts the institution.
Wiki: the document discusses the concept of bias in the canadian legal system, and suggests that the american legal system is similar. it emphasizes that a reasonable apprehension of bias is considered just as harmful as actual bias. the document also expresses concern about the potential impact of political views on the court, particularly in the context of elections. it mentions the need for the court to combat public perceptions of political bias, and suggests that expressing strong political views could damage the court's reputation. the document also mentions judge ginsburg and her potential influence on the election, suggesting that her public statements could alienate a significant portion of the population. the document uses the phrases "mr. trump" as a reference to donald trump, and "anti-elites sentiment" to describe a widespread feeling of disapproval towards those in power. it also uses the term "the court" to refer to the judicial system.

Tweet: Shut down the CIA & be prepared to tolerate more terrorism on US soil. Without Humint, the U.S. would be seriously handicapped in deterring & stopping terrorism and even a surprise nuclear attack. The CIA collects not only Intel related to terrorism, they collect military Order of Battle intelligence. Eliminating the Agency would lose ground level Humint from our defense effort.
Wiki: the document argues that shutting down the central intelligence agency (cia) would lead to an increased risk of terrorism on us soil. without human intelligence (humint) gathered by the cia, the us would be at a disadvantage in preventing terrorism and potential surprise nuclear attacks. the cia also collects military order of battle intelligence, and eliminating the agency would result in a loss of ground level human intelligence from our defense effort. therefore, it is important to recognize the value of the cia in protecting national security.

Tweet: rYes! And in grammar school and every year of any education. We spoke Latin in high school in public school. It was mandatory. I studied French in high school and in college and added german in college. Sure I cannot do well with my german friends, but at least I can muddle through. We need to be able to speak multiple languages and not expect everyone else to speak english. I ignored my father when I was in grammar school and he told me to learn spanish as it would be the universal language. He was right.
Wiki:
the document highlights the importance of learning multiple languages in school, whether it be in grammar school, high school, or college. the author mentions that in their high school, latin was mandatory and they also studied french and german in high school and college. they acknowledge that they may not be fluent in german, but they can still manage to communicate with their german friends. the author also mentions ignoring their father's advice to learn spanish, but now realizes their father was right about the importance of learning it as a universal language.

Tweet: The fact is unpaid interns are not just students seeking experience. They are recent graduates who can't find a paid position, and unemployed workers trying to avoid gaps in their resumes. Most interns are not getting hired after their internship is completed. They are not learning new skills. Interns should be paid minimum wage.

the document highlights several points about unpaid internships:
- unpaid interns are not just students seeking experience, but also recent graduates and unemployed workers.
- employers are exploiting unpaid interns by using them to replace paid employees and save money.
- many interns are not getting hired after their internship and are not learning new skills.
- interns should be paid minimum wage.

Tweet: It's absolutely horrifying how people can defend this. There are no excuses to perform this kind of painful and unnecessary amputation on any cat, ever. If people in other countries are able to have cats, indoor and outdoor, without this kind of barbaric practice, there should be no reason for it to be somehow needed n the US. And the idea that allowing declawing decreases the number of homeless cats is laughable, considering the massive problem with stray cats in america, where many european countries where it's illegal have the problem under much better control. And ask any shelter if they never see any declawed cats, and the answer will usually be the opposite. Declawed cats are abandoned regularly because of the behavior problems they develop due to pain and lacking their natural defense. I'd like to recommend everyone who wants to understand the issue better to watch the documentary The Paw Project, which shows just how much this kind of amputation hurts cats, the consequences, and how many of them need another surgery to somewhat repair their paws after the declawings.
Wiki:
the document expresses the belief that declawing cats is an inhumane and unnecessary practice. it argues that there are no valid reasons for performing this painful procedure on any cat. the author points out that in many other countries, cats are able to live both indoors and outdoors without declawing, and the practice should not be considered a necessity in the us. additionally, the idea that declawing reduces the number of homeless cats is dismissed as laughable, as many european countries where declawing is illegal have better control over the stray cat population. the author also suggests that declawed cats often develop behavior problems due to pain and the loss of their natural defense, leading to them being abandoned.  the author recommends watching the documentary "the paw project" for a better understanding of the issue, as it illustrates the pain and consequences of declawing on cats, and how many of them require additional surgeries to repair their paws after the procedure.

Tweet: I devoted 12 years to convincing deans, presidents, and trustees -- as well as faculty colleagues -- about the virtues of upgrading our college library. I encountered much skepticism. Then again, a benefactor saw virtue, making a sumptuous gift to launch the project. Our $19-million expansion/renovation project was completed in 2004. It was planned meticulously to meet twenty-first century needs, integrating technology and print. Eight years hence the library remains a campus focal point. Additional space has been provided for student seating as well as for technology-related projects. To my way of thinking, libraries and books remain fundamental to learning. So does technology, which I applaud and embrace. Professors who integrate these mediums are fostering learning environments for the still-new century that will enable their students to prosper in the highly competive marketplace.
Wiki:
in the document, the author spent 12 years persuading college officials about the importance of upgrading the library, despite encountering skepticism. a generous donor ultimately provided funding for a $19-million expansion and renovation, completed in 2004, to meet 21st century needs by integrating technology and print. eight years later, the library remains a central part of the campus, with additional space for student seating and technology-related projects. the author believes that libraries and books are essential to learning, as is technology, and that professors who incorporate both are creating optimal learning environments for their students to succeed in the competitive marketplace.

Tweet: For the most part, I think the NYT Comments enterprise is one of the most worthwhile available domestically today. My other obligatory daily reads (WaPo and the often contemptible WSJ) eh, not so much. Yes, trolls are a problem and comments must be moderated to make any sense. I often learn more from the comments than I do from the source article and that is a very valuable contribution. I enjoy my reflecting on how the commenters may have gotten to their perspective. I don't need to agree...I just want to understand Having said that, I am rather curious about why the often thunderous commentary about the clear pro-Clinton and anti-Sanders endorsement by the Editorial Board and the partisan columns by people for whom my respect has diminished in recent months (Krugman and Blow, for example) seem to not deter or even enlighten their conversation. Please, Gail and Linda...don't go down that rabbit hole. At the end of the day...one of the casualties of the 2016 campaign may be the credibility of the Grey Lady.
Wiki: the document discusses the value of the new york times (nyt) comment section, stating that it is one of the most worthwhile available domestically. the writer finds the comments on the site to be more informative than the articles themselves and enjoys gaining different perspectives. they also express concern about the bias in the editorial board's endorsements and partisan columns, and worry that it may harm the credibility of the publication. they mention the need for moderation to deal with trolls and express disappointment in the washington post (wapo) and the wall street journal (wsj). the writer also wonders why these issues don't seem to affect the conversation in the comment section. overall, they find the comment section to be valuable but are concerned about the publication's credibility.

Tweet: Still fail see how this would have necessarily prevented this horrific event. This would only work if the patient actually tells a mental health professional that he or she wants to harm someone (targeted individuals or in general). There's no evidence that Rodger ever communicated any such feelings to his therapists except a few minutes before he started killing. There is substantial evidence that he knowingly and willfully lied to police, withholding entirely his intent to harm. He demonstrated enough mental capacity and control to have hidden his real intent from his therapists, too. He plotted for well over a year without anyone else knowing. Unless he told his therapists in advance that he felt like shooting up a sorority house or the community, your proposed measures, even if already in place, would not have stopped it.

the document states that there is no evidence that the proposed mental health measures would have necessarily prevented the tragic event. it explains that the patient would have to specifically tell a mental health professional about their intent to harm someone, which the individual in question did not do. the document also notes that there is substantial evidence that the individual lied to police about his intentions, and that he demonstrated enough mental capacity to hide his true intent from his therapists. it is suggested that even if the proposed measures were already in place, they would not have stopped the event.

Tweet: Who is paying Amy Zegart's way as long as all those of the government payrolls with vested interests in maintaining the monstrosity that the CIA and agencies like it has become. From Hollywood to Washington people have glamorized intelligence agencies and agents, black ops and high tech destructive capability and interdiction of "threats to the American way of life". But like James Bond the British equivalent, the CIA is a fantasy-fueled, overly influential and manipulative agency with so many skeletons in its closet that it acts aggressively when its seedy soft underbelly is exposed. It is time both the US and the world community push for full disclosure of all its documents that are not truly a threat to national security.
Wiki: the document criticizes the cia (central intelligence agency) and its influence on government and society. it argues that the agency is glamorized and has become overly influential and manipulative. it calls for full disclosure of documents that are not a threat to national security. it questions who is funding amy zegart, who is connected to the government and has a vested interest in maintaining the cia. the document compares the cia to james bond and claims that it has a seedy underbelly that it aggressively protects when exposed. it suggests that both the us and the world community should push for transparency from the cia.

Tweet: "Greece should have defaulted on its debt back in 2010 and left the euro zone." It should indeed have done so and it should do so now. There is simply no way that the austerity prescribed for Greece by the Troika can do other than drive the country to economic suicide. This outcome is already proven by the experience of the Austerity so far. Leaving the debt behind does not require heroic assumptions about "highly efficient and productive in order to survive in a globalized environment". To my mind it is a risk worth taking by the Greek people; in the famous words of Margaret Thatcher "There is No Alternative (TINA)".
Wiki:
the document argues that greece should have defaulted on its debt and left the euro zone in 2010, and should do so now. it states that the austerity measures imposed by the troika (the european commission, the international monetary fund, and the european central bank) are only driving the country further into economic ruin. the author believes that greece should take the risk of leaving its debt behind, as there is no alternative. the phrase "there is no alternative (tina)" is attributed to margaret thatcher.

expand abbreviations, slang, and hashtags: 
- troika refers to the three organizations mentioned earlier: the european commission, the international monetary fund, and the european central bank.
- austerity refers to the measures taken to reduce government budget deficits.
- the euro zone refers to the group of european union countries that have adopted the euro () as their official currency.

Tweet: This is a prime example of the best being an enemy of the good. Well, maybe good is to kind, but better is certainly apt. While I agree 100% that single payer is the right approach, it isn't in the cards now or any time soon. So,do we lift our middle finger to an incremental move in the right direction, or do we bull-up and demand what we can't get? If you need to think about this, you're part of the problem.
Wiki:
the document is discussing the concept of "the best being the enemy of the good," meaning the pursuit of perfection can prevent progress. the author expresses a belief in the superiority of a single payer healthcare system, but acknowledges that it is not currently feasible. they question whether it is better to reject incremental progress, or to push for what is unattainable. the author implies that those who need to think about this are contributing to the issue. 

in relation to obamacare, the document suggests that while it may not be the ideal healthcare system, it represents incremental progress and should be embraced rather than rejected. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document:
- "bull-up" likely means to stand up and assertively demand
- "lift our middle finger" is a rude gesture indicating rejection or defiance
- "better is certainly apt" means that a better approach is appropriate
- "do we bull-up and demand what we can't get" means should we assertively demand

Tweet: Stock's argument confuses me. It likely confuses her too. I favor population control everywhere. England does not need the Moslems of the East nor does France or Germany.
