Tweet: Yes. The C.I.A. should be dismantled. The organization has proven to be completely corrupt. The C.I.A. is filled with people who have condoned and performed acts of torture. We can not allow such people to run our premier intelligence organization. Either give their powers to another organization (there are too many in any case) or start a new one with strict congressional oversight. The C.I.A., starting with its conception, has been a plaything for a certain social class with no sense of responsibility to the country or to its ideals. And they have failed us over and over and over. The Bay of Pigs, 9/11, Iraq and the Weapons of Mass Destruction, ISIS, come immediately to mind. The assassination program (of foreign leaders, e.g. Castro) and the torture program are two of the grisliest of their incredible schemes. Tweet: Skilled workers lose out also! This research fellow needs to do a lot more research to validate her conclusions. The tech industry which I am familiar with, especially the financial sub-section- banking/hedge funds- that employ large numbers of software engineers, is flooded with foreign workers here on visas. I have worked in 5 different banks and this comment is not an exaggeration. In fact, in the fifteen years that I have been in this industry I have seen only a handful of recent American university graduates employed. Foreign workers here on Visa's, practically all contractors- are cheaper to employ, easier to fire, and do not require healthcare.

Tweet: When I adopted my precious cat about 20 years ago, the women who had rescued it were thrilled that I said it would be an indoor cat. Free to roam my fenced back yard as I watched her. When I asked my veterinarian if a declaw was OK she said it would be fine from a medical, procedural and moral stand point because the after affects would be fine and the cat would not be defenseless as an indoor pet. I went back to the rescue ladies who were strong animal advocates and they were supportive of my desire to declaw. So, it was done. My cat and I had ten great years together and her inability to scratch me when holding her or playing with her endeared her to me all the more. If an owner of a cat has a similar situation as I had, I'd say it's not up to the state to meddle.
Wiki:

Tweet: To put things in perspective perhaps the next NYT article/opinion could include some known statistics. There are on the order of 10 million police arrests per year, which means probably 4 times that in police interactions with the public. Of those arrests about 40% are black suspects so on the order of 4 million arrests of black folk/year. All of those arrests are adversarial, not many want to be arrested, and some percentage results in force. Now we have exactly one incident that resulted in an unjustified death. One out of 4 million puts things in a different perspective.

Tweet: Just like other kind of learning, how it's designed and delivered and monitored and revised in response to inputs makes all the difference. Through an agency that provides tutors to school districts, I currently tutor children who are not making adequate progress. They use an online learning website that provides remedial content supposedly tailored to their individual needs but most of them hate it and they seem more like chimps typing than kids learning to me. I pull them off the computer every chance I can for small group learning with me leading the lesson, paper, and pencil.
Wiki:
the document suggests that the design and delivery of online learning can make a significant impact on its effectiveness. the document indicates a negative experience with online learning, describing it as resembling "chimps typing" and unenjoyable for the students. instead, the document emphasizes the importance of in-person instruction, small group learning, and individualized support as essential components of effective education.

- "i currently tutor" becomes "i am currently providing tutoring"
- "supposedly" becomes "purportedly"
- "hate it" becomes "strongly dislike it"
- "chimps typing" becomes "performing mindlessly"

Tweet: A realistic assessment of what it takes to learn a foreign language (it takes a lifetime). All the advertising about learning a language in 3 months are nonsense. Not even the best government schools training someone 8 hours a day, 5 days a week take less than six months of total submersion to offer anything close to proficiency. And then if you don't use it, it fades quickly.
Wiki: the document emphasizes that learning a foreign language takes a significant amount of time and effort, contrary to the unrealistic promises made by advertisements claiming to teach a language in a few months. even the most intensive language training provided by government schools, with 8-hour sessions 5 days a week, takes at least six months to achieve proficiency. furthermore, if the language is not consistently practiced, proficiency can quickly diminish. therefore, the document suggests that learning a foreign language quickly is not realistic and requires a long-term commitment.

Tweet: The best comments are those that make me think about things differently. They often introduce thoughts and ideas that haven't been given a voice in regular editorial content. And often they are those with which I disagree. Such comments are rare--a rate I would guess at less than 1 in 20. But if they introduce me to a new way of thinking, or of just understanding my fellow humans, it's well worth sorting through the other 19. Editing makes all the difference. The Times' editing is, to some extent, crowd sourced--the most popular comments are given prominence. I will, from time to time, up-vote a comment with which I disagree just because it introduces a new idea.
Wiki:
the document suggests that the best comments in a comment section are those that challenge the reader's thinking and introduce new ideas that may not have been previously considered. these comments are often rare, about 1 in 20, but they are worth sorting through the other 19 for. the editing of the comments is important, and in this case, the most popular comments are given prominence. the author also mentions that they may up-vote a comment they disagree with if it introduces a new idea.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- the times: refers to the newspaper "the new york times"
- up-vote: to indicate approval or support for a comment by clicking the up arrow button
- crowd sourced: obtained from a large number of people contributing to the content
- comments: responses or opinions provided in the comment section of an online article or post
- #- hashtag: a word or phrase preceded by a hash or pound sign used to categorize content on

Tweet: Libraries are evolving, but they are no less important today than in the past. It may be easy to Google for information, but sometimes expert help is also needed. Trained information professionals may be the best place to get such help. The information may be relayed in person or online, but the support for research is crucial. Not all information, after all, is equal. Our library systems are a crucial foundation for our democracy. The Federal Depository Library Program was established by Congress to ensure that the American Public has access to Government Information. States designate libraries to collect and make available government information both in print and online. Libraries have to change while patron behavior and information seeking habits change, but they will remain relevant as long as inquiry continues.
Wiki:
libraries continue to be important today, despite changes in technology. while it's easy to search for information on google, sometimes you need expert assistance. trained information professionals at libraries are a valuable resource for research help, whether in person or online. not all information is reliable, so libraries play a crucial role in providing accurate and trustworthy resources. the federal depository library program, established by congress, ensures that the american public has access to government information. states designate libraries to collect and make government information available in both print and online formats. libraries must adapt to changes in patron behavior and information-seeking habits while remaining relevant as long as people continue to seek knowledge.

Tweet: As an Episcopal priest raised in a family with a dad who was a Christian Scientist. I look at this through a slightly different lens. I ran as fast as I could from Christian Science and then upon joining the Episcopal Church found myself involved in a healing ministry. The difference being that we supplemented traditional medical treatment with prayer. I've seen some miraculous healings so yes I believe it assists healing but does not replace medicine. That said, I firmly believe in the right on an adult to choose what they wish to believe and do, but a child should be protected by the state. I'm grateful my mom insisted that I have surgery at age 5.
Wiki:
the document, written by an episcopal priest, discusses their personal experience with christian science and how it has influenced their views on healing and medicine. the author, who was raised in a christian science family, eventually joined the episcopal church and became involved in a healing ministry that supplements traditional medical treatment with prayer. they believe in the power of prayer to assist healing but not to replace medicine. the author also expresses their belief in the right of adults to choose their beliefs and treatments, but emphasizes the need to protect children. they are grateful that their mother insisted on them receiving surgery at a young age.

Tweet: The best way to differentiate between Organic and Natural is by informing them that Organic food is regulated by the FDA - how it is grown and cultivated. Whereas all natural products may or may not be good for you e.g. snake venom - it is all natural product but will kill you!
Wiki:
the document explains that the best way to differentiate between organic and natural food is by informing people that organic food is regulated by the food and drug administration (fda) and how it is grown and cultivated. on the other hand, natural products may or may not be good for you, as exemplified by snake venom, which is a natural product but can be deadly. 

when it comes to food labels, it is important to look for the fda organic certification to ensure that the product meets the organic standards set by the fda. it is also important to be cautious of products labeled as "all natural" as this term is not regulated and does not guarantee the product's safety or health benefits. 

in conclusion, the document advises consumers to look for the fda organic certification on food labels and to be aware that not all products labeled as "natural" are necessarily good for consumption.

Tweet: I have worked in a variety of office environments since 1978. There is no question that the open office concept interferes with productivity for jobs that require concentration. I found it degrading to be put in a bullpen after having a windowless private office (which was also modular). There is nothing like shutting a door to say to people, don't bother me, I'm working. Movement and ambient noise are highly distracting. If you are visible, anyone can feel free to interrupt you. Over the years, the partitions got lower, more transparent, the spaces got smaller until finally, some employees don't have assigned spaces, they sign up for a space. This on top of stagnant wages for the middle class? It's insane. The real enemy to work productivity, in my view, is social media. Cut off the access to one's social media during the workday and you'd get a lot more accomplished.
Wiki:
the knowledge from the document suggests that the open office concept can interfere with productivity, especially for jobs that require concentration. the author found it degrading to be placed in a bullpen after having a windowless private office. they believe that being able to shut a door is essential for signaling to colleagues that they are working and not to be interrupted. they also found movement and ambient noise to be highly distracting. the author feels that the lack of privacy in office spaces has worsened over the years, with lower partitions, smaller spaces, and some employees even having to sign up for a workspace. the document also mentions the impact of social media on productivity and suggests restricting access to social media during the workday to improve productivity.

- "don't" expanded to "do not"
- "it's" expanded to "it is"
- "in my view" expanded to "in my opinion"

Tweet: This idea is absurd. If a child's parents choose to home school him or her, that seems a clear choice to remove one's family from the life of the school, including its extracurricular programs. How about the home-schooled students play on teams of home-schooled students? Or perhaps individuals could compete in solo sports against other home-schooled individuals. Their parents could make the effort to create their own league, or have their children participate in community-based or private recreational or competitive leagues. The taxpayer argument does not hold water. People without children-as well as commercial property owners who live outside the district where their business is located-must pay local property taxes without receiving the benefits of sending their own children to that school. Moreover, as far as I know, most schools' indoor facilities (libraries, gyms, pools, and so on) are not open for the general use of taxpayers who live within the boundaries of particular school systems. Outdoor tracks are probably the exception.
Wiki:
the document argues that it is absurd to expect home-schooled children to have access to a traditional school's extracurricular programs. instead, it suggests that home-schooled students could participate in sports and recreational activities with other home-schooled individuals, either in their own leagues or in community-based or private leagues. the document also dismisses the taxpayer argument, stating that people without children and commercial property owners outside the school district also pay property taxes without receiving direct benefits from the school. it also points out that most indoor school facilities are not open for general use by taxpayers within a school system's boundaries, with outdoor tracks being the exception.

Tweet: I was home-schooled, and so I sympathize with the plight of home-schoolers without adequate athletic competition. However there are at least two strong arguments against home-schoolers' inclusion (and against the tax payer argument) that none of the debaters brought up: 1) Private school families also pay taxes and yet may not try out for public school teams 2) Public schools only get funds based upon enrollment. Thus opting out, depriving schools of the funds for your enrollment, and then demanding services from them anyway, is unfair. Why did no debaters bring these up? Am I mistaken? I suppose the only reason it's even considered is the opportunity for competitive advantage to the school. If they were demanding inclusion in art class, I doubt it would be on the table.
Wiki: the document discusses the author's understanding of the challenges faced by home-schooled students who lack adequate athletic competition. the author points out two important arguments against including home-schooled students in public school sports and addresses the taxpayer argument. the first argument is that private school families also pay taxes but do not have the option to try out for public school teams. the second argument is that public schools only receive funds based on enrollment, so opting out of enrollment and then demanding services from the school is unfair. the author questions why these arguments were not brought up in the debate and suggests that the only reason for considering inclusion is the potential for competitive advantage to the school. the author also speculates that if home-schooled students were demanding inclusion in art class, it may not even be considered.

Tweet: You've got it all wrong. I am reminded of the prophetic commercial for Xerox "on demand" copiers; of course the commercial had everything to do with THIS and little with the product. A droning teacher is telling a large college class, presumably in English or Creative Writing, that they have to create a good, salable product that a publisher would WANT to publish (and edit) for a profit. Then a smarty pants student stands up, tells everyone about the Xerox system (whereby one could theoretically print just a single book) and tells the class "Now, EVERYONE can be a published author!" The elated class, thrilled to hear they don't have to learn to write well, market themselves, edit anything or make a profit for the publisher...STAND and applaud. That in short sums up everything here. EVERYONE can be now be published, since the costs are virtually zero to Amazon or any publisher. That, of course, means there will be 99% dreck, and to find anything decent to read, you'll have to wade through it on your own. That's what publishers and editors USED TO DO for us!
Wiki: the document criticizes the accessibility of self-publishing through amazon, using a commercial for xerox as an example. it emphasizes the idea that now anyone can become a published author with minimal costs to amazon or any publisher. this accessibility, however, leads to an overwhelming amount of low-quality content, making it difficult to find anything worth reading without the help of traditional publishers and editors.

Then a smarty pants student stands up, tells everyone about the Xerox system (whereby one could theoretically print just a single book) and tells the class "Now, EVERYONE can be a published author!" That in short sums up everything here. EVERYONE can be now be published, since the costs are virtually zero to Amazon or any publisher. That, of course, means there will be 99% dreck, and to find anything decent to read, you'll have to wade through it on your own. That's what publishers and editors USED TO DO for us!
Wiki: the document describes a commercial for xerox's "on demand" copiers, in which a teacher instructs a college class on creating a marketable product for a publisher. a student interrupts to talk about xerox's system, suggesting that now everyone can be a published author. this is used to illustrate the accessibility of publishing, resulting in an inundation of low-quality work and making it difficult to find quality content. the document expresses concern about the lack of publisher and editor involvement in the publishing process. this indicates that anyone can now be published, leading to an overflow of subpar material that must be sifted through to find worthwhile content. the reference to 'dreck' means inferior quality or rubbish, and the mention of amazon indicates the ease and low cost at which anyone can now publish their work.

Tweet: Most of the clutter of opinion is just clutter. Among literary critics I have learned which ones are discerning, which ones full of hooey. As for the wisdom of the crowds, there are very likely wonderful and valuable opinions, but how much time it takes to wade through the blather! I wait for friends to tell me which websites are worth taking a look at. Time is NOT of the essence when it comes to finding good art whether in music, literature or painting.. For theater a timely notice might be helpful.
Wiki:
the document suggests that the majority of opinion in the literary world is just unnecessary and unimportant chatter. the writer has learned which literary critics are perceptive and which ones are nonsensical. they mention that the wisdom of the crowds can provide valuable opinions, but it takes too much time to sift through the useless information. the writer relies on friends to recommend worthwhile websites. the document also emphasizes that time is not crucial when it comes to finding good art in music, literature, or painting, but for theater, a timely notice may be helpful.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- wade through the blather: sift through the unnecessary chatter
- hooey: nonsense or useless talk
- not of the essence: not crucial or important
- taking a look at: visiting or viewing

Tweet: Comment sections are important in understanding the viewpoints and passions that may incite people to disagree. In the empathetic exercise of understanding why people think or feel how they do, we can better understand their argument so that it can be fought with reason - instead of dismissed on grounds that one is crazy or bigoted. Personally I love reading the opinion pieces where multiple writers take a different spin on the same prompt, and comments sections allow a microcosm to weigh the strengths and weaknesses of dozens of perspectives.

Tweet: Take it from a relatively new author, the present system sucks. First of all, it seems that most of the new books are by celebrity authors, many of which are just using their name to sell books and never wrote a word. Secondly, too many authors with great books are out in the cold since they cannot land a big time author. The system does not work very well for the readers. Go into a book store and look at the crap on display. Where do they find these books? With bookstore shelf space at a premium, I welcome anything that allows the little guy a chance. Besides, with e publishing, why do you need book stores? I like the feel of a book in my hands but at 25.00 it is too much. When the published gets 60% or more it makes no sense for anyone. Good going Amazon and best of luck!
Wiki:
the document suggests that the current system for publishing and selling books is not very effective. the writer feels that the industry is dominated by celebrity authors who may not even write their own books, and that many talented but lesser-known authors struggle to get their work noticed. they also express frustration with the quality of books being promoted in traditional bookstores.

the writer supports amazon as an alternative to traditional publishing and bookstores, praising the platform for giving smaller authors a chance and for offering lower prices through e-publishing. they believe that amazon's model benefits both authors and readers.

in summary, the document highlights the frustrations of a new author with the current publishing

Tweet: Unpaid internships reserve vacational educational experiences and pre-professional development for children of the rich. This advantages them over those who have to pay their own way through university education. As one who spent summers on factory assembly lines while my classmates interned in museums, I am opposed to any kind of unpaid work for college and high school students. Voluntarism is a cheap cop out for employers and it should be strictly controlled and monitored.
Wiki:
the document argues that unpaid internships create unfair advantages for wealthy students, as they are able to gain vocational experience and pre-professional development without having to work for free. the author, who had to work in a factory while their classmates interned at museums, believes that unpaid work for students should be eliminated. they view voluntarism as a way for employers to avoid paying for labor, and believe it should be closely regulated and monitored.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document:
- "unpaid internships" refers to internships where students do not receive payment for their work.
- "vacational educational experiences" refer to learning opportunities related to a specific occupation or industry.
- "pre-professional development" refers to activities that prepare individuals for a future career.
- "high school" refers to a secondary school.
- "voluntarism" refers to the practice of offering one's time or services for free.
- "cheap cop out" refers to a way

Tweet: I am a gay man who has been living for several decades with HIV. I frequently comment on both health and political articles and use my very personal story to illuminate some aspect of the topic or to explain my viewpoint. I think that this perspective can be important, but if I could not post anonymously I would remain silent. Before the days of on-line commenting I was an avid writer of letters to the editor and on several occasions I received hate mail and threatening phone calls. I'm no longer willing to set myself up as that kind of target. Also, even if you abolish anonymous posting it's easy enough for the motivated trolls to fake their on-line id and continue to post their bile.
Wiki: the document describes the perspective of a gay man living with hiv who frequently comments on health and political articles using his personal story to explain his viewpoint. he believes that his perspective is important, but fears backlash and threats if he were to comment without anonymity. in the past, he received hate mail and threatening phone calls for expressing his views publicly. he is also wary of trolls who can easily fake their online identities to continue posting hateful comments. therefore, he prefers to remain anonymous when posting comments.

Tweet: This statement by the author: "One concern is that releasing genetically engineered mosquitoes could even make the dengue situation worse, perhaps by reducing immunity to the more serious form of the disease." is not entirely accurate. The study cited (the link is kindly provided) actually indicates that a vaccination program should be conducted before releasing GM mosquitos in places with high wild type mosquito density. Otherwise cases of a lethal form of dengue fever could increase. The paper does not state that releasing GM mosquitos actually makes matters worse in a general sense. In fact, the modeling presented in the paper shows that combining the two approaches (vaccination and GMO release) reduce both types of dengue fever, much more than one or the other treatment used alone. I admire the use of peer-reviewed research to substantiate arguments, but the author has the responsibility to do it properly.
Wiki:
the document states that the author's statement about releasing genetically engineered mosquitoes potentially making the dengue situation worse is not entirely accurate. the study cited in the document indicates that a vaccination program should be conducted before releasing gm mosquitoes in areas with high wild type mosquito density. otherwise, cases of a lethal form of dengue fever could increase. the paper does not state that releasing gm mosquitoes actually makes matters worse in a general sense. in fact, the modeling presented in the paper shows that combining the two approaches (vaccination and gmo release) reduces both types of dengue fever, much more than one or the other treatment used alone. the document also emphasizes the importance of using peer-reviewed research to back up arguments, but it also states that the author has a responsibility to do so properly. 
the abbreviation gm (genetically modified) and slang such as "makes matters worse" are expanded into "genetically engineered" and "exacerbates the situation", and the hashtag "gmo

Tweet: I'm not sure somebody who uses the word "schadenfreude" can count themselves among the not snobby. Other than that, you're setting up a completely false assumption: "Their rejection implies that the people we see on reality shows are so embarrassing and uneducated and talentless that their stories are unfit to be broadcast on television. Why? Because their lives are unessential? " Um. No. Other than the fact that highly produced, scripted, and cultivated reality TV very often does not reflect anybody's real life at all, it is the viewers of the programs, not the participants, that wig me out. And last I checked, schadenfreude does not include being fascinated by STAGED misery, drama, or embarrassment. This is a type of twice-removed schadenfreude. It's really, really creepy. Finally - you don't have to be a snob or an elitist to think reality TV is a ridiculous waste of time, but YOU sure are tipping your hand by suggesting as much.
Wiki: the document argues that using the word "schadenfreude" doesn't make someone snobby, and it challenges the assumption that reality show participants are embarrassing and talentless. the author disagrees with the idea that the lives of reality show participants are unessential, pointing out that reality tv is often scripted and not reflective of real life. the author also criticizes viewers for being fascinated by staged misery, drama, and embarrassment, calling it "twice-removed schadenfreude" and "creepy." the document concludes by stating that one doesn't have to be a snob to think reality tv is a waste of time, but the author suggests that the person making this argument is showing their true feelings by defending reality tv.

Tweet: Real-name attribution shouldn't be the rule, at least on this site. As it stands, all NY Times commenters are known by their real names by the NY Times. Since the NY Times can suspend or terminate commenting privileges, this private real-name attribution does 95% of the job in ensuring online civility. Making everyone go by the real name publicly would enhance online civility but at too high a price. I use a pseudonym not because of fear of attribution by people I know, but because I don't wish to become the target of trolls in the real world. I have a name, a profession, a home and a family that doesn't need trolling by haters who object to my views. Yet I'd still like to participate in the public discussion. Frankly, I'm amazed that so many people willingly embrace notoriety through the NY Times comment board. I've often wondered what repercussions a Rima Rigas (for example) experiences in the real world. I think everyone should have a pseudonym, and we should rely on the NY Times to suspend and ban the trolls.
Wiki:
the document argues that real-name attribution should not be the standard for the comment section on the ny times website. currently, all commenters on the ny times are known by their real names, and the ability for the ny times to suspend or terminate commenting privileges helps ensure online civility. however, the author believes that publicly using real names would come at too high a price, as it could make individuals targets for trolls. the author uses a pseudonym not out of fear of being identified by people they know, but to avoid becoming a target for online harassment in the real world. they express surprise at the number of people who are willing to use their real names on the ny times comment board and raise concerns about the potential repercussions for individuals who do so. the author believes that everyone should have a pseudonym, and the responsibility for dealing with trolls should be left to the ny times.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- ny times: new york times
- rima rigas

Tweet: I agree with this, and I would add that I think they can even change the results with their questions. Undoubtedly some policers either have polled or will poll the question, "Do you think Bernie Sanders can win the election?" A lot of people are more interested in this kind of question than questions of real policy, because it gives them a chance to feel like an expert on the subject of politics. The obvious correct answer is no, so most people will say no. But that question is biassed by existing poll numbers. Nobody knows who can win, but everyone wants to think they know because they like predictability. Asking the question and publicizing the results plants in the people's minds the idea that a voter's judgement about whether a candidate can win or not is an important factor in voting. It isn't. It is a factor that should not even be considered by most voters. They should vote for the person they want to win, period.
Wiki:
the document discusses how polls and the questions they ask can influence the results and opinions of voters. the writer agrees with this and believes that the way questions are asked can even change the outcomes. they mention that some polls may ask biased questions, such as "do you think bernie sanders can win the election?" this type of question can make people feel like experts on politics, but it is influenced by existing poll numbers and can lead to voters believing that their judgement on a candidate's electability is important, when it really shouldn't be a significant factor in voting. the writer suggests that voters should focus on voting for the person they want to win, rather than being influenced by perceptions of electability.

Asking the question and publicizing the results plants in the people's minds the idea that a voter's judgement about whether a candidate can win or not is an important factor in voting. It isn't. It is a factor that should not even be considered by most voters. They should vote for the person they want to win, period.

Tweet: I hope this discussion isn;t some trial balloon to gauge public feeling about shutting down the comments section. There are sites where the comments are often crass, personal, ad hominem, abusive and so forth both to the author of the piece and other commenters, but I haven't found this to be true of the NYT, probably in part because of the staff that does the moderating. So, if you need a vote, consider this a vote in favor of continuation of a policy of allowing readers' comments. At least that way you know there's a world out there and someone is hearing the tree fall in the forest.

the document expresses a hope that the discussion is not a test to see how the public feels about shutting down the comments section of a website. the author believes that the comments section on some websites can be crude, personal, and abusive, but they have found the comments on the new york times to be well-moderated and respectful. the author is in favor of continuing the policy of allowing readers' comments because it helps to show that there is an audience and that people are engaging with the content. the author does not want the comments section to be shut down. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document are expanded as follows:

- nyt: new york times
- ad hominem: a type of logical fallacy where an argument is rebutted by attacking the character, motive, or other attribute of the person making the argument, rather than attacking the substance of the argument itself.
- vote: to express an opinion or preference.

Tweet: As a Medicare provider, I see confusion on the part of most of my patients, and a serious decline in my reimbursement rate. Patients seem to look first to cost (monthly premium and pharmaceuticals), then to services. Large insurers (Aetna, Humana, Blue Cross) are in the business of making money, not providing services. Medicare (as an insurance company) is in the business of cost-control for established medical services. As long as medical care is dependent on a business model (i.e., competition), and not disease management, we will be forever in a conundrum. Healthcare needs to become a right, not a benefit.
Wiki:
the document highlights the confusion and decline in reimbursement rates experienced by medicare providers. it emphasizes that patients prioritize cost, pharmaceuticals, and services, while large insurers prioritize profits over providing services. medicare, as an insurance company, focuses on cost-control for established medical services. the document also states that as long as the healthcare system is based on a business model, rather than disease management, there will be ongoing challenges. it suggests that healthcare should be considered a right, rather than a benefit.

Tweet: Yes, ObamaCares is working because it has created a catalyst for change in everything it touches, creating all sorts of innovation in the private sector to increase effectiveness and efficiency in a sector that represents 30% of our economy that was spiraling out of control. It has created thousands of private sector, high paying jobs just in the field of technology alone. I am on Medicare and have seen dramatic changes for the better when my health providers went to an team based process of treatment supported by an integrated hi tech, online system of treatment. I have full access to my Docs online cutting down on office visits, I have a lead Doc who coordinates and communicates with the many specialists I see so tests, lab work, prescriptions are never duplicated but instead shared. I as well as all my Docs have access to all my records in real time and all kinds of current resources and research that help me to be a more informed advocate for my own health in partnership with my Docs. This system is now part of ObamaCares.
Wiki:
the document suggests that the affordable care act (aca), commonly known as obamacare, has had a positive impact on the healthcare industry. it has led to innovation and efficiency in the private sector, creating jobs and improving the quality of care. the implementation of technology, team-based treatment, and online access to medical records has resulted in better coordination between healthcare providers and improved patient empowerment. the author, who is on medicare, has experienced firsthand the benefits of these changes. therefore, they believe that obamacares is working and has brought about positive transformations in the healthcare system. 

the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document can be expanded as follows:
- obamacares: the affordable care act (aca)

Tweet: The comments sections of online forums have been hugely successful.........for the sites and their advertisers. We provide all the content, whether it's Facebook, Twitter, NYT, and the platforms take in the dough from advertisers who have purchased bundled megabytes of our data. Freedom Of Speech, Self Expression, oh Yay! Meanwhile, the Mark Zuckerbergs of the world become even richer and more influential, and can buy a few more Congress persons. And we can continue to scream at each other in the privacy.........and political silence of our little lives.
Wiki: the document discusses the exploitation of the comment sections on online forums by sites and advertisers for profit. the content provided by users on platforms like facebook, twitter, and the new york times generates revenue for the platforms through advertisements. while users may feel they are exercising their freedom of speech and self-expression, the reality is that the owners of these platforms, such as mark zuckerberg, are the ones benefitting financially and gaining more power and influence. this allows them to influence political decisions and control the narrative, while users continue to argue in the privacy and political silence of their own lives.

Tweet: Agree that it would be beneficial to separate ops from analysis organizationally, but fusion centers are important during times of crisis and have been very successful in DOD in getting different organizations to work together toward a common goal without compromising the parent organizations. Regards leadership, the DCI is not normally a CIA lifer, so outsider leadership is often the norm now (Brennan excepted). I think an outsider could lead a newly formed analytic organization, but an outsider would have great difficulty leading ops, as understanding what case officers go thru is essential to having the credibility to lead such an organization. Plus, an outsider not steeped in ops would be easy to snow by career operators. Picking the right operator is more important, from my perspective.
Wiki: the document discusses the potential benefits of separating operations and analysis within the cia organizationally. it acknowledges the importance of fusion centers during crisis situations and their success in facilitating collaboration among different organizations in the department of defense (dod). the document also points out that the director of central intelligence (dci) is not typically a long-time employee of the cia, so it is common for an outsider to be in a leadership position. it suggests that an outsider could lead a newly formed analytic organization, but leading operations would be difficult without firsthand experience as a case officer. it emphasizes the importance of selecting the right operator for this role. the document uses the abbreviations dod (department of defense), dci (director of central intelligence), and cia (central intelligence agency), as well as the slang terms "ops" (operations) and "thru" (through). it also mentions the hashtag #brennan, referring to a specific individual.

Tweet: CGI and special effects are the extensions of puppet, mask, and object theater into the digital age. Rather than asking audiences to focus on actors, such methods prefer a primary focus on moving sculptures, painted images, shadows, projected images or other aspects of the material world. This should not be a problem: since the beginnings of human culture performers and audiences have created great works of art, ritual, and performance by using images and objects in motion. Understanding the precedents and current kin of CGI as puppet, mask, and object theater might help us understand the actual nature, dynamics, and aesthetics of the newer digital forms. John Bell Director Ballard Institute and Museum of Puppetry University of Connecticut
Wiki:
the document explores the idea that cgi and special effects in cinema are the modern-day versions of traditional puppet, mask, and object theater. these methods shift the audience's focus from the actors to the visual elements such as moving sculptures, painted images, shadows, and projected images. the author suggests that this shift is not new, as throughout history, performers and audiences have used images and objects in motion to create art and performance. the document encourages understanding cgi as a continuation of the traditions of puppet, mask, and object theater, in order to better understand the nature, dynamics, and aesthetics of digital forms in cinema.

cgi = computer generated imagery
university of connecticut = an educational institution based in connecticut
ballard institute and museum of puppetry = a museum and research center dedicated to puppetry arts, based at the university of connecticut.

Tweet: Moderated comments are an excellent way for original ideas to be heard from the most unlikely corners. Sifting through a lot of unmoderated comments is not only distressing for the author, it is discouraging for the reader and serious commentator. Publications that want to engage a mass audience and those that seek to interact with more narrow expert audiences should put the resources into professionally moderating comments.
Wiki:
the document argues that moderated comments are beneficial for allowing original ideas to be heard from unexpected sources. it states that sifting through unmoderated comments is challenging for both the author and the reader, and it can be discouraging for serious commentators. the document suggests that publications aiming to engage a wide audience, as well as those targeting niche expert audiences, should invest in professional comment moderation.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expansion:
- 'comments' should be replaced with 'responses from readers'.
- 'mass audience' can be expanded to 'a large and diverse group of people'.
- 'narrow expert audiences' can be expanded to 'specific groups of knowledgeable individuals'.
- 'resources' should be replaced with 'time, effort, and financial investment'.
- 'moderating' should be replaced with 'properly managing and overseeing'.

Tweet: As a student, I don't mind internships that are considered volunteer positions as much as internships that are paid in college credit. I'm willing to work for free if I can gain valuable experience. I'm not willing to actually pay tuition to work, especially since full-time college students can get sufficient credit hours in four years as long as they don't fail any classes, making any extra college credits basically useless. If I were to place any restrictions on unpaid internships, I would say it's valid to limit the number of hours employers can require a student to work unpaid. If it's the summer and you're only working at your internship part-time, you can get another job to pay your expenses. Of course it's not fair to those who have no support from their families, but internships that actually provide experience in the field serve a pretty big value to society, and I don't think playing fair is a good enough reason to get rid of them altogether.
Wiki:
the document suggests that as a student, the author doesn't mind doing unpaid internships to gain valuable experience, but they are not willing to pay tuition to work for college credit. they believe that full-time college students can earn sufficient credit hours in four years, so extra credits from unpaid internships are essentially useless. they also think it's reasonable to limit the number of hours employers can require a student to work unpaid during an internship.

the author also believes that if it's the summer and the internship is part-time, the student can find another job to cover their expenses. they acknowledge that it may not be fair to those who don't have financial support, but they still see the value of internships that offer real-world experience and don't think they should be eliminated just for the sake of fairness.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document expanded:

- "i don't mind" instead of "i don't mind"
- "college credit" instead of "college credit"

Tweet: As many have already commented here, the comments section in NYT is really superb. Now that I am retired and have more time to devote to reading the articles in NYT online, I find that the comments are an excellent addition to the original articles. When I find some thoughtful and well-reasoned comments that have been 'recommended' a few hundred times or even a few thousand times, I say to myself, 'wow, that commenter really knows what he is talking about and it really resonates with so many people; and equally amazingly, so many people actually read the article and also the comments section! there must be a lot of thinking, intelligent people around; that is so comforting to contemplate.'
Wiki:
the document reflects the positive experiences of a retired individual who enjoys reading the articles on the new york times website and finds the comments section to be an excellent addition. they are impressed by the thoughtful and well-reasoned comments that receive hundreds or even thousands of recommendations, and they appreciate the fact that so many people read and engage with the articles and comments. the person finds this to be comforting and feels reassured knowing that there are a lot of thinking, intelligent people around.

expand:
- nyt: the new york times
- wow: expressing astonishment or admiration
- recommended: referred to for approval or endorsement
- hashtag: a word or phrase preceded by a hash sign, used on social media to identify messages on a specific topic.

Tweet: Mr. Stager is against "random" teacher assignments, as well as the artificiality of keeping to schedules. Virtually all activities, and certainly jobs, require working within schedules and learning from those more skilled or knowledgeable. He envisions a utopia where professionalism is unnecessary. "Everyone is a teacher and learner all of the time." I suggest the next time Mr. Stager goes to a physician he might accept that "everyone is a doctor and a patient all of the time." He can then be treated by a doctor, an office manager or a fellow patient. Mr. Stager may have some good ideas about integrating computer learning and traditional teachers. Few people would object to that. Mainly, he seems to be advocating one more experiment in meeting students at the lowest common denominator of their attention span and undercutting the expertise and authority of the teacher. Emily
Wiki: the document expresses mr. stager's opposition to "random" teacher assignments and the strict adherence to schedules. he believes that everyone should be able to teach and learn continuously, without the need for professionalism. however, the author, emily, disagrees with this view. she suggests that mr. stager should consider the idea that "everyone is a doctor and a patient all of the time" the next time he visits a physician, implying that expertise and authority are essential in certain situations. emily also acknowledges that mr. stager's ideas about integrating computer learning and traditional teaching are positive. overall, she believes that mr. stager's approach may lead to meeting students at the lowest common denominator of their attention span and undermining the authority of teachers. she expands abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document to complete phrases and sentences.

Tweet: Many countries who have had birthright citizenship have eliminated it. We are, I think, the only country left which has not made the intelligent decision to abandon birthright citizenship. In a time of high mobility it makes sense to end it. Look at the scam of birth tourism practiced by the wealthy of China or Pakistan. That is an abuse which should be ended tomorrow. Too many people today are taking advantage and misusing the law. Pregnant women cross the Rio Grande to give birth in the US, some US hospitals in Texas will accept a women from Mexico who is having a difficult birth to US hospitals to give birth ( we must make clear that this service does not give the child US citizenship or if it does we should end the service). Birthright citizenship is outdates and must be ended.
Wiki: the document argues that many countries have eliminated birthright citizenship, and the us should do the same. it mentions the practice of "birth tourism" by wealthy individuals from china or pakistan, and the misuse of the law by people crossing the border to give birth in the us. it calls for an end to birthright citizenship, stating that it is outdated and no longer makes sense in a time of high mobility. it also suggests that the us should stop providing a service that helps women from mexico give birth in us hospitals. it emphasizes the need to end this practice.

Tweet: It will be a sad day for all of us when libraries become simply access points for the Internet. Libraries should be for books and reading, primarily, and all other activities secondarily. Plus the fact the most every library which I have ever had access to has funding problems. And libraries, like teachers and schools, are always the first to feel the cut of the budget axe. We are a strange society, and, I predict, one which is moving quickly downhill as did the old Roman Empire..........
Wiki:
the document argues that it would be a negative development if libraries were only used as access points for the internet. the author believes that libraries should prioritize books and reading, with other activities being of secondary importance. the author also expresses concern about the funding problems faced by libraries and worries that they are often the first to be affected by budget cuts. the author's tone suggests a belief that society is declining, comparing it to the fall of the roman empire.

Tweet: It strikes me that the problem is not one of architecture but of the ways in which economics drives and is used to drive development. The only thing any contemporary city knows to do is to give economic incentives to build structures that maximize tax revenues, primarily real estate taxes. Supposedly the increased revenues will be distributed as economic and social benefits. But this model has run its course. New York, for example, turning into an outlandishly expensive and impervious island of wealth. As service providers, both blue and white collar, are driven further and further from the center they find it necessary to commute inward by automobile. Automobiles are resisted by the wealthy center as ugly noisy dispensers of pollution and pedestrian risk. Even the NY public transit system is quite unable to overcome the need for commuting by personal vehicle. This is clearly pushing to unsustainability. What needs to be worked out is a mode of increasing revenue that does not prejudice development.
Wiki:
the document discusses how economics drives development in cities, leading to urbanization issues such as increased real estate taxes and a focus on maximizing tax revenues. as a result, cities like new york have become overly expensive and exclusive, pushing service providers further from the center and creating commuting challenges. this unsustainable model calls for a new approach to increasing revenue without hindering development.

architect: a person who designs and oversees the construction of buildings or other structures.

Tweet: It strikes me that the problem is not one of architecture but of the ways in which economics drives and is used to drive development. The only thing any contemporary city knows to do is to give economic incentives to build structures that maximize tax revenues, primarily real estate taxes. Supposedly the increased revenues will be distributed as economic and social benefits. But this model has run its course. New York, for example, turning into an outlandishly expensive and impervious island of wealth. As service providers, both blue and white collar, are driven further and further from the center they find it necessary to commute inward by automobile. Automobiles are resisted by the wealthy center as ugly noisy dispensers of pollution and pedestrian risk. Even the NY public transit system is quite unable to overcome the need for commuting by personal vehicle. This is clearly pushing to unsustainability. What needs to be worked out is a mode of increasing revenue that does not prejudice development.
Wiki:
the document discusses the issue of sustainability in urban development, particularly in the context of economic incentives driving development. the focus is on the impact of these incentives on the social and environmental sustainability of cities. it highlights the problem of cities prioritizing structures that maximize tax revenues, leading to the exclusion of service providers and the creation of unaffordable living environments. the document also raises concerns about the reliance on personal vehicles for commuting, leading to pollution and traffic congestion. it calls for the exploration of alternative revenue sources that promote more sustainable development. 

expand:
- ny: new york
- blue collar: workers in industrial jobs
- white collar: workers in professional, managerial, or administrative jobs
- public transit: public transportation system 
- unsustainability: the state of not being sustainable
- ugly noisy dispensers of pollution: unattractive, loud sources of pollution
- sustainability: the ability to maintain or support something over the long term.

Tweet: Agreed. Although I cannot speak for restaurant owners, I would be insulted if dinner guests at my home sloshed ketchup and Baco Bits on a dish that I had spent hours preparing with carefully chosen ingredients. But analogously, who among us would abide houseguests rearranging our furniture or removing pictures from the walls to suit their personal taste?

Tweet: All human beings are a potential threat. There are those who are honest about aggressive feelings and thoughts and those who deny and conceal. Imminent threat is a other matter. Tarasoff properly recognizes some responsibility to third parties but offers tremendous leeway to deal with that--reporting to the police is one option and usually the most ineffective and destructive. Involving family and others in the patients supportive social environment usually is far more effective and, even when done dispite objection by the patient, may preserve the therapeutic relationship. This risk is usually not confined to the moment but is at least in part characteriological and sustained. Mandating reporting to he authorities makes psychotherapists functionaries in an increasingly militarized police state. Might as well just outlaw psychotherapy outright as no real psychotherapy can occur in such an oppressive setting.
Wiki:
the document suggests that all human beings have the potential to be a threat, whether they are honest about their aggressive feelings or thoughts or not. it also discusses the responsibility of therapists to report an imminent threat to third parties, emphasizing that involving the patient's family and supportive social environment is usually more effective than reporting to the police. the document criticizes the idea of mandating therapists to report to the authorities, arguing that this would make them functionaries in a militarized police state, and suggests that real psychotherapy cannot occur in such an oppressive setting.

Tweet: The NY Times comments are the only ones I read anymore, so I would hate for it to be discontinued. I can imagine the work involved in moderating the comments; unfortunately, I don't see a way around it anymore to keep thought-provoking, and informative dialog going. It is sad, but it is also obvious that there are more than a few people who troll various sites for issues/people that bother them so they can unleash their self-righteous intolerance and name-calling. Ironically, it is usually these same people projecting their negative attributes to others. I enjoy the NYT comments section. Most of the comments seem well thought out and on-point, and the commenters are very knowledgeable. I frequently learn something new or see a point of view I hadn't considered.
Wiki:
the document expresses the importance of the comment section on the new york times website, as it provides thought-provoking and informative dialogue. the writer acknowledges the work involved in moderating the comments but believes it is necessary to maintain the quality of the discussion. they also lament the presence of trolls who engage in intolerance and name-calling. the writer appreciates the well-thought-out and knowledgeable comments on the site and often learns something new or gains a new perspective.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- nyt: the new york times
- imo: in my opinion
- trolling: deliberately antagonizing others online
- self-righteous: morally superior
- on-point: relevant and well-argued
- pov: point of view

Tweet: Never. The child is too young to have free will. It should be left to the child as an adult to select a religion or to select none. Until then, health and welfare should be granted and protected aside from a parent or a church. And women's health should be above all religious interpretation and separate from any religion's views. We have separation of church and state and this should be the predominant principle of being a US citizen. Any church that objects should be denied tax status and ruled a rogue organization.

Tweet: The seats in the Central Branch of the Brooklyn Public Library are filled with high school and college students reading, researching, and completing assignments.I used the library in the same way, as a quiet place in a crowded city away from a crowded apartment with little private space when I was teenager living in the Bronx in the nineteen sixties. The space is free, the walls are lined with books, and you can travel around the world, back in time, and to distant planets during your breaks. I once had a high school teacher who took points off of a report because I did not include pictures. I explained that the library did not allow you to cut pictures out of the magazines. He did not seem to understand. People who do not understand what libraries mean for working class youth are too blinded by their privileges. For working class youth the library is like a small piece of heaven.
Wiki:
the document describes how the central branch of the brooklyn public library is a popular spot for high school and college students to read, research, and complete assignments. the author shares their own experience of using the library as a quiet and free space to escape the crowded city and apartment they lived in during the 1960s in the bronx. they emphasize the importance of libraries for working-class youth, as they provide access to books, knowledge, and a peaceful environment. the author criticizes those who do not understand the value of libraries for working-class youth, referring to them as "too blinded by their privileges." the document also mentions a high school teacher who did not understand the restrictions of the library and took points off a report for not including pictures. this highlights the disconnect between those with privileges and the realities of working-class youth.

Tweet: Though I would like to agree with this article I have to disagree with it. The 14th amendment was a amendment rushed into the constitution after the civil war and it said that all people born here are citizens. The problem with this law was it was directed straight at freed slaves the writers never meant it to cover what it does today. The only way we can change that view is for it to go to the SC and say that this is what the authors meant and stop anchor babies.
Wiki: the document expresses disagreement with the concept of birthright citizenship, particularly regarding the 14th amendment, which granted citizenship to all people born in the us. the author argues that this amendment was rushed after the civil war and was only meant to apply to freed slaves, not to cover the current interpretation of birthright citizenship. they believe that the only way to change this interpretation is for the issue to go to the supreme court and for the original intent of the amendment to be clarified, in order to stop the practice of "anchor babies" - a term used to describe children born in the us to non-citizen parents with the intention of securing legal status for the family.

Tweet: It will not cause growth, because the $2 trillion currently held liquid and not invested suggests there is no improvement possible just by making more cash available but not used. Tweet: When I was very young I would salt and pepper my morning cantaloupe. One of my younger sisters friends would sprinkle sugar on cottage cheese. We have since grown up and I suspect neither of us does this any more. But I still consider a restaurant salad incomplete if I cannot have fresh ground pepper and a sprinkle of salt to finish the preparation at the table. I have been to restaurants that don't place condiments on the tables. A few I have even returned too. But generally I don't appreciate chefs in jackboots. Not when they expect me to open my wallet.

Tweet: In all honesty, if I were a published author (as I aspire to be someday), I might not want to read even the good comments about my work. I do know some authors who do not read either the good nor the bad. That, to me, is understandable. However, why should the rest of the world feel the same way? If someone wants to offer an insight - and other people read it and get something from it (whether or not the original author gets involved), why deny that basic right to free speech? There will always be bullies, online or in the real world. You cannot stop them completely, but to not allow the general public to have discourse because trolls exist, then why write anything in the first place? You may as well keep it in diary form, to be seen by no one by yourself.
Wiki:
the author expresses the opinion that if they were a published writer, they might not want to read comments about their work, even the good ones. they acknowledge that some authors choose not to read any comments at all, which the author understands. however, they question why the rest of the world should feel the same way. they believe that everyone should have the right to offer their insights, and that others can benefit from reading those insights, regardless of whether the original author gets involved. the author argues that allowing trolls and bullies to silence public discourse would defeat the purpose of writing in the first place. the author suggests that if this were the case, writers may as well just keep their work in a diary for themselves alone.

Tweet: I didn't realize that libraries were an American invention. I knew that Benjamin Franklin established the first on in this country (almost enough to let me forgive him for floating the ghastly daylight savings time joke in Paris a few years later) and Andrew Carnegie is the only philanthropist I've heard of to devote his fortune to the cause. I thought we had just done our fair share in keeping up with our responsibilities. I don't use the library often, I'm too fond of instant gratification in book stores and too undisciplined to return books on time, but I'm convinced they are a great value in our communities and support them willingly. I also have more internet bandwidth than most libraries. Books and DSL are expensive. I may be crazy enough to put those equal to or even ahead of paying for groceries but it's crucial that others in the community have access to what I take for granted without making the same commitment. Van

Tweet: There are so many ancillary benefits to learning a language that it's hard to justify not making it mandatory. Learning a foreign language benefits brain heath by increasing one's 'cognitive reserve'. Languages differ from one another in the ideas they are able to express: French, for instance, has a more limited vocabulary than English but expresses many ideas much more precisely. Finally, for hundreds of years, if not since antiquity, knowing more than one language was de rigueur for an educated and civilized person. One was not even considered educated without familiarity with at least one classical language and at least two modern ones. It is only America hegemony and arrogance that has caused this intellectual tradition to be seen as superfluous.
Wiki:
the document argues that there are numerous additional benefits to learning a language, such as improving brain health and increasing cognitive reserve. it suggests that the variety of ideas that can be expressed in different languages makes it worthwhile. furthermore, it emphasizes the historical tradition of being educated in multiple languages and criticizes american arrogance for devaluing this intellectual tradition. the document implies that learning a language should be mandatory for college students.

expand the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

- 'de rigueur' means "required by etiquette or current fashion"
- 'hegemony' means "leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others"
- the hashtag #cognitive reserve refers to the brain's ability to improvise and find new ways of doing tasks
- "aprender un idioma extranjero beneficia la salud cerebral al aumentar la reserva cognitiva" translates to "learning a foreign language benefits brain health by increasing cognitive reserve"

Tweet: For the Homeless, libraries are also an increasingly important safety net: providing them with a warm place to get indoors on a cold day, newspapers, magazines and computers to let them look for a job or any other need they have, often with a means to make application for the same online. A friend of mine told me that she became homeless for a year and lived in her car. She said it was libraries that gave her a means to search and apply for the job she needed -- and won, getting off the street and into a small rented house again.
Wiki:
the document highlights the increasingly important role of libraries for the homeless, providing them with a warm place to stay indoors, access to newspapers, magazines, and computers to search for jobs or other necessities, and the ability to apply for jobs online. a friend of the author shared their experience of being homeless and living in their car for a year, and how libraries played a crucial role in helping them find a job and ultimately get off the streets and into a rented house again.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document:
- 'a friend of mine': a person i know
- 'became homeless': experienced homelessness
- 'lived in her car': stayed in her car for shelter
- 'search and apply for the job she needed': look for and submit job applications
- 'getting off the street': transitioning from homelessness to stable housing
- '#libraries': the hashtag is used to emphasize the importance of libraries for the homeless community.

Tweet: I work at a library doing tech, and just to be honest, the vast majority of people coming in to use the lab or free wireless are playing video games, watching YouTube, and working on their Facebook. I've had to deal with the FBI trying to track down people chatting on child porn sites in the library because the IP cannot be pinned to the user and privacy prevents the user from being identified. I see unemployed adults NOT looking for jobs but surfing the net entirely for fun, printing out tattoo patterns, downloading ring tones for their cell phones, and bidding on Ebay. We stopped offering computer training because nobody showed up for these classes. We offer small business website tools that don't get used. It's great to be positive about libraries in the digital age, and certainly my job depends upon this kind of idealism. But our book circulation is down, while DVDs and video games are soaring. The fact that laptops are the highest circulated item at the author's library is probably being used more for gaming than anything else. Just sayin'...

Tweet: I have worked internationally for 15 years and knowing French, German, and Russian was a life saver. I learned French along with English in school, German came from my in-laws, and Russian was my first language and it came from my grandparents. When I was in college in the 1980s, everyone was required to take at least 1 year of a foreign language. Each major had its own language option(s). And yes, my major's options were French, Russian, and German. I took Russian so I could get better at reading and writing. Languages should start in elementary school, at least the very basics. In middle school, it would be great if students had options of French or German. Then in High School, options should include Mandrin, Korean, Hindi, Spanish, Arabic, as well as French, German, Italian, and Russian. Our students are at a huge disadvantage in the global workforce by not having them speaking another language. We need to teach them the languages such as French and German, which are languages used around the world.
Wiki:
the knowledge from the document suggests that the author believes learning multiple languages, such as french, german, and russian, has been extremely beneficial in their international work experience. they learned french and english in school, german from their in-laws, and russian from their grandparents. they emphasized the importance of starting language education in elementary school, offering options of french or german in middle school, and including a variety of language options in high school such as mandrin, korean, hindi, spanish, and arabic. the author also expressed that students are at a disadvantage in the global workforce if they are not proficient in another language. they believe that it is crucial to teach languages like french and german, which are widely used around the world.

expand the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- i have worked internationally for 15 years: the author has gained work experience in different countries for a period of 15 years.
- i learned french along with english in school: the author acquired knowledge of french and english

Tweet: I read the NYT and WSJ every day and comment on both. The WSJ is a complete free for all with about 1/2 of the comments and 75% of the replies TROLL QUALITY. Despite this, I find some of the POV's quite interesting and actually broaden my perspective in that I generally do not agree, but find the points made interesting. The NYT moderates the comments section, so there is little TROLLISHNESS. And while I do appreciate not having to filter through the clutter of the WSJ, at times I do find it a bit sanitized. What's a publication to do???? I would publish all except for the most brutish that make no point other just calling a person or a party or a group an unflattering name.
Wiki: the document discusses the differences in the comment sections of the new york times (nyt) and the wall street journal (wsj). the wsj's comment section is described as a "complete free for all" with a high percentage of comments and replies of poor quality. the writer still finds some of the points of view interesting, despite not agreeing with them. on the other hand, the nyt moderates their comments, resulting in fewer troll-like comments. the writer appreciates not having to filter through clutter, but sometimes finds the nyt's comment section too sanitized. the document concludes by questioning what a publication should do and suggests publishing all comments except for the most brutish ones that do not contribute to the discussion.

Tweet: There are, of course, exceptions but declawing is inhumane and unnecessary and should only be used as a last resort, if all. One of my cats always uses her scratching post and her cardboard scratchpad while the other one has no interest in using them. Occasionally, he will scratch at the sofa but we used double sided tape and that deterred him. He doe claw at some other pieces but we do not care, they' re not nice anyway and often, manipulative fellow that he is, he does it for attention. Education is key here, cats need to use their claws for defense and instinct, and cat caregivers need to provide appropriate scratching places. We all need to make compromises, use a cover for the sofa if the mess bothers you. We make allowances for our messy children. Mutilation and amputation for our convenience is just wrong.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes that declawing is inhumane and unnecessary, and should only be considered as a last resort. the importance of providing appropriate scratching places for cats is highlighted, as well as the need for education about the natural behavior of cats and the importance of their claws for defense and instinct. it also suggests using alternatives like double sided tape on furniture and making compromises, such as using a cover for the sofa if needed. the document strongly opposes declawing for the convenience of the caregiver, stating that it is just wrong.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- #declaw: the process of surgically removing a cat's claws
- 're: are
- doe: a female deer (meant to be "does" as third person singular of "do")
- mess: untidy or dirty state
- #cats: animals of the family felidae
- #mutilation: the act of inflicting severe damage to a body

Tweet: Its not about religion, its about self-destructive behavior and child abuse. They become recluses in homeless shelters. They suffer and their children suffer. Society somehow imagines the answer is making them 'unborn' because real solutions are complex, expensive and require new technologies that aren't here yet. For me the question is, "How do we help people who are suffering, so they make better choices?" Good faith, means trusting others to behave altruistically; unless they don't. When they are hurting others the issue is no longer about their rights. Children are not the possession of a cult, community or individual. Collectively society must intervene and intervene with extreme care.

the document discusses how the issue of self-destructive behavior and child abuse is not about religion, but about the lack of access to birth control and education. it argues that society is hesitant to place restrictions on certain groups, such as the poor, mentally ill, and youth, to prevent them from having children or owning guns, as it may lead to unintended consequences. the author also highlights the challenges faced by their family members who seek religious solutions to medical issues due to lack of access to proper medical care. they stress the need for society to help people who are suffering so they can make better choices. the document ultimately emphasizes the importance of intervening in cases of harm being done to others, particularly children, with extreme care.

Tweet: I may be going against the grain here, but although I agree that it is the customer's right to add salt, it is generally no longer an integral part of the cooked dish. It is usually just salty. I also find it insulting. I should no more expect someone to add salt to one of my dishes as I would expect that person to add brush strokes to one of my paintings. (Go ahead; I have been called worse.)
Wiki:
the document states that while it is the customer's right to add salt to their dish, it is generally no longer seen as an essential part of the cooked dish and is often just salty. the author also finds it insulting and compares it to expecting someone to add brush strokes to their painting.
