Tweet: A well groomed man is not un-manly. A real man does not need to look like big foot and act like a neanderthal to be manly. Manliness is stepping up to ones responsibilities without question, being courteous, gracious and fair. A real man is not afraid to be gentle, kind and helpful. A real man is confident enough in his manliness to not care if anyone thinks he is manly enough!
Wiki:
the document argues that a well-groomed man is not un-manly and that modern men do not need to conform to the stereotype of being like "big foot" or a "neanderthal" to be manly. it defines manliness as stepping up to responsibilities without question, being courteous, gracious, and fair. it also states that a real man is not afraid to be gentle, kind, and helpful, and is confident enough in his manliness to not care if anyone thinks he's manly enough.

in modern times, it means that men do not have to adhere to outdated stereotypes of masculinity, such as being rugged and rough. rather, they can embrace traits like grooming, kindness, and gentleness as part of their identity. the use of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags is limited in the document, but the language used emphasizes a more modern and inclusive understanding of masculinity.

Tweet: Police operate under stress. True. However, what is becoming more apparent is that officers for whatever reason are increasingly just too afraid of their job to be trusted with firearms. Rather than engaging a suspect with less than lethal force and running some risk of injury, police officers are becoming ever more reliant on deadly force to eliminate the risk. People are being shot in circumstances in which a cop of a generation ago never would have unholstered his weapon. Police are perpetually saying they feared for their life in circumstances where no such risk was apparent. In effect, they resort to killing people because they are not tough enough to handle the situation with less violence. If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen
Wiki: the document discusses how police officers are increasingly relying on deadly force out of fear, rather than using less lethal options in potentially dangerous situations. it suggests that officers are too afraid to handle their jobs properly and are resorting to killing people because they are not capable of handling situations with less violence. it highlights instances where police officers unnecessarily unholster their weapons and claim to fear for their lives when there is no apparent risk. the document suggests that officers who cannot handle the pressure of their job should find a different profession. (#police #lesslethalforce #deadlyforce #fear)

Tweet: I live within 35 miles of Yosemite, and prior to retiring here operated a small tour company that provided visits for elderly groups by bus every year. Yes, Yosemite is overcrowded but there has been a steady decline in the number of private tours such as mine. Reason? The Park system restrictions on private motorcoach travel making it difficult for the elderly and the very young to experience the great outdoors. It doesn't make any sense at all, as motorcoach travel is beneficial in reducing the numbers of private cars
Wiki:
the author of the document lives near yosemite and used to run a tour company for elderly groups. they have noticed a decrease in private tours to the park, which they attribute to restrictions on private motorcoach travel. they believe these restrictions make it difficult for the elderly and young to experience the outdoors and that allowing motorcoach travel would reduce the number of cars in the park. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- miles: geographical distance measurement
- park system: the organization managing national parks
- motorcoach: a large bus used for tours
- elderly: older adults
- hashtags: words or phrases preceded by the pound or hash symbol used for social media tagging and categorizing.

Tweet: Oh my goodness...absolutely KEEP THE QUEEN!! She is popular, she was heroic during WW2, and most importantly: how horrible to have Camilla, the mistress, up there on the throne! And, not just because Camilla was the "3rd person in the marriage", as poor Diana tearily rambled on about in that awful tv interview before her death -- The main reason to not have Charles and Camilla on the throne is because many people throughout the world believe they may have had a part in Diana's death...(Something not so outlandish, if you know the history of British monarchy and the Bond-ish M-i5)... And, whether true or not, just the fact that a certain percentage of the world's population believes those 2 are murderers really should take them out of the running for that seat....Since the seat is, after all, now just a public relations job to bring in tourism and maintain a positive image of an out-dated monarchy... The face of your public-relations campaign should not be two adulterers and murder suspects....
Wiki:
the document supports keeping queen elizabeth ii on the throne, citing her popularity and heroic actions during world war ii. it also expresses concern about having camilla, the mistress, as queen, especially due to the suspicion surrounding her involvement in princess diana's death. the document suggests that the monarchy's main purpose is now public relations and tourism, and having adulterers and possible murderers as the face of the monarchy is not appropriate. therefore, the document recommends keeping queen elizabeth ii on the throne.

- the "3rd person in the marriage": this is a reference to camilla, who was involved with prince charles while he was married to princess diana.

- queen: this refers to queen elizabeth ii, the current monarch of the united kingdom.
- #keep

Tweet: *There are many college graduates working at low-paying jobs for which their education is unrelated, and can't pay off their student loans. If a university contends that the content of what it teaches will enhance the earning power of the graduate sufficiently to pay off that cost, then let that university self-finance the student debt. Otherwise, accept that what is being taught has a cost that is not commensurate to improved ability to pay it. Get the government and the taxpayer out of it.
Wiki:
the document suggests that many college graduates are working in low-paying jobs that are unrelated to their education, making it difficult for them to pay off their student loans. it proposes that universities should be responsible for financing their students' debt if they claim that their education will lead to higher earnings. otherwise, it suggests that the cost of education does not align with the ability to pay it off, and the government and taxpayers should not be involved. 

i think this means that the government should not have to pay for student debt if the education is not directly leading to higher earning power. it also suggests that universities should take on the responsibility of financing their students' debt if they claim their education will lead to higher earnings. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expansion:
- hasn't: has not
- can't: cannot
- let that: allow that to happen
- commensurate: proportional or corresponding to
- government and the taxpayer: the government and the people who pay

Tweet: I spent all day Sunday helping harvest 85 chickens, 10 turkeys, and 4 ducks. And yes, they were ALL free range. No hormones,no antibiotics, no being stuck 10 to a cage, with their beaks cut off, crapping all over the chickens stacked 10 cages high. Just happily scratching and chasing grasshoppers in the sun, until the final moments of their life. Kosher or Halal killed to ensure a stress free and quick demise as possible. I prayed and thanked them all for giving us sustenance. I'll enjoy the first of my 4 chickens on the smoker tonight. And I'm sure it'll be the best tasting chicken I've ever had! I also look forward to enjoying raw milk from a cow share I'm involved with. Oh, and did I mention the garden?
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the practice of humane animal husbandry, as the author describes helping to harvest 85 chickens, 10 turkeys, and 4 ducks, all of which were free range and raised without hormones or antibiotics. the animals were not kept in crowded cages and were allowed to roam and forage freely. the author also mentions that the animals were killed in a stress-free and quick manner according to kosher or halal practices. they expressed gratitude for the animals' sacrifice and were looking forward to enjoying the meat and raw milk. overall, the document promotes ethical and respectful treatment of animals in agriculture.

abbreviations and slang expanded:
- kosher: relating to the dietary laws of judaism
- halal: adhering to islamic dietary laws
- raw milk: unpasteurized milk
- cow share: a program where individuals can purchase shares in a cow and receive raw milk in return
- smoker: a device used for smoking and cooking meat
- garden

Tweet: There are bad cops just like there are bad soldiers. Tweet: After the Bay of Pigs fiasco and the lies that accompanied it, President Kennedy's wish -- regrettably unfulfilled -- was to "splinter the C.I.A. into a thousand pieces and scatter it to the winds." In the nearly 54 years since then, there's precious little evidence that this was a bad idea.
Wiki: after the bay of pigs fiasco and the lies that accompanied it, president kennedy's wish - regrettably unfulfilled - was to "splinter the central intelligence agency (cia) into a thousand pieces and scatter it to the winds." in the nearly 54 years since then, there's precious little evidence that this was a bad idea. this statement highlights the dissatisfaction and lack of trust in the cia's conduct and its role in the bay of pigs fiasco. president kennedy wanted to disband the cia, distribute its components across multiple entities, and eliminate its centralized power. this reflects a desire for more transparency and accountability in the intelligence community.

Tweet: As a former computer teacher, I must endorse much if what was said here. All too often computer classes are nothing but a print textbook put onto a computer. Wiki: the document suggests that computer classes often fail to fully utilize the potential of technology, instead simply replicating a traditional textbook format on a computer. this approach can limit the benefits of individualized attention from a live teacher. when applied to online classes, this perspective implies that simply posting a pdf of a textbook online is not enough. the instructor should make use of the interactive and multimedia capabilities of the online platform to enhance the learning experience for students. additionally, the document indicates that online classes should strive to provide the same level of individualized attention and support that a live teacher would offer in a traditional classroom setting. #onlineclass

Tweet: Big Brother my left petunia cheek. What does Mr. Kurlansky think the average consumption of salt in the US population is? My mother recently passed from cronic heart failure. I tracked her usage, desperately, in the preceding years. 1200mg was the recommendation. I've seen the epidemiology and statistics, been trained, consulted with the best and brightest-- and knew, that was too much. Unless I was fighting her tooth and nail, she was at 2200 or 2500mg. One component of lunch could be 1500mg. KFC or Pizza Hut? There goes 1800mg in one part of a sitting. If I went away for a few days? 4500mg or 6000mg. Aimed at a dying heart. Mr. Kurlansky's deception and irresponsibility in writing the above, should be criminalized.
Wiki: the document criticizes mr. kurlansky's views on the average consumption of salt in the us population. the author's mother passed away from chronic heart failure, and the recommended salt consumption was 1200mg, but she often consumed 2200 or 2500mg. lunch alone could contain 1500mg of salt, and meals from fast food restaurants could have up to 1800mg. when the author was away, their mother's salt intake could reach 4500 or 6000mg. the document calls for mr. kurlansky's writing to be criminalized for deception and irresponsibility. #bigbrother #saltconsumption #chronicheartfailure #mrkurlansky #governmentsaltguideline

Tweet: The veggie and fruits at the supermarket have been scrubbed, plucked and waxed to be cosmetically perfect. And before landing in the produce section display cases they have been riding around in refrigerated tractor trailers for days and in some cases weeks --slowly oxidizing and losing precious nutrients. Why the devil would you want to eat this stuff? Buy local produce from the farmer's market instead.
Wiki: the document argues that the fruits and vegetables at supermarkets undergo a process of scrubbing, plucking, and waxing to make them look perfect. they also spend days or weeks in refrigerated tractor trailers, causing them to lose nutrients. the author suggests buying local produce from farmer's markets instead. this is because buying local produce is healthier and more environmentally friendly. additionally, it supports local farmers and the community. the document does not directly mention anything about expenses, but it implies that buying local produce may be a better investment in one's health and the environment, even if it might be slightly more expensive.

Tweet: When publications allow totally anonymous comments, chaos follows. One gets the feeling that comments are posted by dirty old men in the basement, or 14-year-old dropouts. The NY Times does it right, despite some obvious flaws, such as rewarding quick posting regulars who often set the tone for subsequent commentary. Yet on issues such as North Carolina's egregious HB2, comments from around the world are illuminating and revealing, which adds context, flavor and perspective to the original article. That's a good thing.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the impact of allowing totally anonymous comments on publications. it suggests that when comment sections are open to any user to post anonymously, it can lead to chaos and low-quality comments. the new york times is praised for managing its comment section well, despite some flaws. however, it also highlights the value of having a diverse range of comments from around the world, as it can add context, flavor, and perspective to the original article. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
ny times - new york times
hb2 - north carolina's house bill 2
hashtags - these are words or phrases that are preceded by the # symbol and are used on social media platforms to make it easier for users to find messages with a specific theme or content

Tweet: Many decades before bookstore chains like Borders and B&N, who welcomed browsers and readers with less overt pressure to buy than to spend time, we had local libraries and their branches and bookmobiles. While specialty coffees and teas were not part of the experience, a quiet spot to read, to think, to consider without pressure either to buy or move on was what library patrons most welcomed and appreciated. Perhaps one day this invaluable resource will succumb to virtual access alone: but that presents a clear disadvantage to many people for whom the local / regional / state / national library is an experience irreplacable by any virtual counterpart. Libraries are the life-blood of our communities' intellectual growth: until we have a more equitable access to literacy, we should not be talking about the demise of library culture.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the value of local libraries as an irreplaceable resource for the community's intellectual growth. it compares the experience of browsing and reading at libraries to bookstore chains like borders and b&n, highlighting the lack of pressure to buy and the opportunity to spend time in a quiet and contemplative environment. it also expresses concern about the potential shift towards virtual access to libraries, noting that many people rely on the physical presence of local, regional, state, and national libraries for an experience that cannot be replicated virtually. the document suggests that libraries are essential for promoting literacy and should not be at risk of being replaced by virtual counterparts.

- b&n: barnes & noble

- coffees and teas: specialty coffee and tea beverages

Tweet: "Rate My Professors helps me narrow down my choices. It tells me what my peers think of the various instructors." Wouldn't it be better to get this information directly from other students? A negative opinion from someone who complains about everything should not carry the same weight as a negative opinion from someone who is generally reasonable. If you're getting your "reviews" from your friends, roommates, etc, then you know how much weight to put their opinion - but you don't have it with the reviewers on Rate My Professor. I see RMP as primarily a tool for transfer students and online students -studetns who are on the outskirts of the student community - where information about professors flows freely. If you're a full-time second year student, however, your classmates, whose credibility you can assess, seem like a better resource.
Wiki:
the document discusses the effectiveness of using rate my professors to narrow down choices for instructors. it suggests that getting information directly from other students would be better because a negative opinion from someone who complains about everything should not carry the same weight as a negative opinion from someone who is generally reasonable. it also points out that if you're getting reviews from your friends or roommates, you know how much weight to give their opinion, but this credibility assessment is not present with the reviewers on rate my professors. the document sees rate my professors as a tool for transfer students and online students who are on the outskirts of the student community, where information about professors may not flow freely. however, for full-time second year students, classmates whose credibility can be assessed, seem like a better resource.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document are as follows:
- rmp: rate my professors
- stduetns: students
- '#' (hashtag): not

Tweet: The problem I find, is many times there are things said in articles that are wrong. This puts a compulsion in many of us, that requires us to make sure the record is straight. Otherwise many will read something with no discussion and think the article is valid, when it's not. People often feel connected to an article and take it personally when something needs to be stated in a more clear fashion. I have often learned things from comment sections that added value or clarified issues that were not address in the article but should have been. The solution for bigotry and vitriol is not taking the voice from people. Censorship should never be allowed. There are several way to address this issue when it comes to forums. Hell, just hire a low level student editor that cuts his teeth on forum controls. Much better to pay someone $15/hr than isolating the very people you are trying to reach by taking away their voice.
Wiki:
in the document, the author discusses the problem of incorrect information being shared in articles and the need for readers to correct the record. they also highlight the importance of clear communication and the value of comment sections in adding perspective and clarity to issues not addressed in the article. the author argues against censorship and suggests hiring a low-level student editor to manage forum controls as a solution. they emphasize the importance of not isolating individuals by taking away their voice. 

important phrases, abbreviations, and slang in the document: 
- "compulsion" means a strong urge or impulse
- "vitriol" means cruel and bitter criticism
- "forum controls" refers to the management and regulation of online discussions
- "low level" refers to someone at an entry-level position 
- "$15/hr" means $15 per hour, a reference to hourly wage
- "hashtag" is a term used to categorize content on social media platforms

expansions of abbreviations, slang,

Tweet: This is an excellent column and just underscores the need for better training and supervision. The Philadelphia police superintendent, Charles Ramsey, who used to be in charge of Washington D.C. police, recently asked the Justice Department to review the Philly police and make recommendations. Ramsey saw that better procedures and training in D.C. ended up dramatically reducing firearms use by police and saving lives. The whole incident in South Carolina also just underscores the need to have cameras wherever police are operating, because the word of police officers simply cannot be trusted when their career or promotion is on the line. Despite the oath, police officers are human beings and no more or less likely to tell the truth.

Tweet: Another problem faced by students is that of getting college credit. A lot of unpaid internships make up for the lack of a salary by offering to cooperate with colleges to give credit for the hours worked. Except that to get credit, it's up to the student to pay tuition fee attached to it. In effect, we have a system where students are paying out of their pocket (or taking out a bigger loan) in order to work. Not to mention that many colleges limit the amount of credit that can go to fulfilling something useful like a major.
Wiki: many college students face the problem of not being able to receive college credit for their unpaid internships. some internships offer to work with colleges to provide credit for the hours worked, but the student is responsible for paying the tuition fee attached to it. this means that students have to pay out of their own pocket or take out a larger loan to cover the cost of working. additionally, many colleges limit the amount of credit that can go towards fulfilling a major. overall, college students are facing the challenge of having to pay for the opportunity to work and gain experience through internships.

Tweet: "Just as there are good and bad refrigerators, there are good and bad professors." Really? Anonymous on-line evaluations have been shown to be spurious. This is supported by published research and personal experience. Student evaluations of courses are strongly correlated to grade. Glaringly obvious when most variables are removed; e.g., comparing physics course sections covering identical material, taught by the same professor, in the same semester, and with the same assessment measures. NB, physics has the advantage that grades are based on scores, not potentially subjective measures, hence it was not the case that students' grades were influenced by the instructor's impression of them. More accurate measures are evaluations by trained, paid, identified peers and students. Education is a big investment - use evaluation tools that are robust, not junk.
Wiki:

Tweet: "If governments reward such success with a regulatory straitjacket, we will pay a steep price." Oh please. When has a long term monopoly EVER been good for the market? Uhhh...never. Yes, Apple, Google and Facebook owners deserve to get rich for creating unique products and markets, but in the last years they are expending more and more money on flimsy patent fights and trying to raise the bar for market entry too high for competition. It has happened with *every* firm that has had a monopoly. The "regulation" scare is bogus.

Tweet: Earlier in the last century the theater set designer Edward Gordon Craig dreamed of the 'er-marionette' so that he could create a more unified stage picture. This concept has been rolling around in the back of the minds of many designers and directors since then but has never really been achievable until recently. However , for better or worse it has also become extremely easy to do, anyone who can work a mouse can pretty much do it now, no skill needed (don't let anyone tell you that this is not a fact). The effect houses are moving offshore and will soon be the the animation sweatshops in the third world. I think the floodgates are just opening time to head for higher ground.
Wiki: the document discusses the concept of the 'ber-marionette' proposed by edward gordon craig, a theater set designer in the early last century. this concept aims to create a more unified stage picture and has been a topic of interest for designers and directors. recently, advancements in technology have made it easier to achieve this concept, but it has also become more accessible to anyone, with no skill required. this has led to the outsourcing of animation work to third world countries, turning them into animation sweatshops. the ease of creating animations has led to a flood of low-quality content being produced for minimal cost and high profit. the document suggests that this trend is just beginning and it's time to find higher ground.

Tweet: Why no mention of the great communal living alternative, near-campus co-op housing? All the benefits of living in groups (diverse population and late night discussions included) and lower costs thanks to the residents taking on much of the upkeep of the building, cooking of the communal meals, etc. There are small co-op houses of under 20 and large ones with closer to 200 students. The best are part of co-op systems where the houses can benefit from economies of scale, residents are actually owners during their time at the house, and afford to hire some professional staff -- but students can have a good experience even with less-formalized independent group houses that are run co-operatively though they may technically be rental houses.
Wiki: the document discusses the benefits of near-campus co-op housing as a great communal living alternative for students. this type of housing offers a diverse population and opportunities for late-night discussions, as well as lower costs due to residents taking on the upkeep of the building and cooking communal meals. co-op houses can be small (under 20 residents) or large (closer to 200 students), and the best ones are part of co-op systems where residents are owners during their time at the house. some co-op houses can hire professional staff, but even less-formalized independent group houses can provide a good experience for students if run cooperatively, though they may technically be rental houses. students can benefit from a sense of community, lower living costs, and the opportunity to take on ownership and responsibility during their time in co-op housing.

Tweet: 1) Except for updates and corrections to the story, authors who get involved in the comments section of their articles are not doing themselves any service. 2) It may come as a surprise, but authors of articles are not omniscient. Comment sections usually bring out pertinent points and perspectives that the author omits. 3) It is important, especially for social and politics issues to understand not only the content of an article but what the opinion of the public is toward the article that can be particularly important, and more relevant than any poll. 4) The internet is, by nature, interactive. If you present topics of current interest and don't give people the ability to interact with them, people will go elsewhere to where they can. 5) Most people want to have a discussion about issues that of importance to them, few simply want to sit and be lectured to.
Wiki: authors should refrain from getting involved in the comments section of their articles, except for updates and corrections to the story. this is because authors of articles do not know everything, and the comment sections often bring out important points and perspectives that the author may have omitted. it is particularly important for social and political issues to understand not only the content of an article, but also the public opinion towards the article, which can be more relevant than any poll. the internet is interactive by nature, so if you present topics of current interest and don't give people the ability to interact with them, they will go elsewhere. most people want to have a discussion about issues that are important to them, rather than simply being lectured to.

Tweet: Having worked in the public library sector in Australia for over 20 years, I am a strong advocate of life-long learning and equity in access to information, thus I support the Open Access movement. In May 2012 I started in a fixed-term contract position at a University Library, my first foray into academic librarianship. As such, the topic of digital libraries and institutional repositories is of personal interest to me. The Open Access movement and institutional repositories have openly challenged the traditional scholarly communication system, supporting a new model for scholarly communication. Indeed, it is possible for academic libraries to alleviate the conflict between these two paradigms. Institutional repositories (by their very nature) exert pressure on journal publishers to permit as much free online access to their content as economically possible. The library and information sector plays an important role in providing public access to networked information. Public libraries worldwide are a significant component; by ensuring that there is equity in access to information (for both educational and recreational purposes) through the provision of quality library services for all citizens.
Wiki:
this document discusses the author's experience working in the public library sector in australia for over 20 years, and their advocacy for life-long learning and equity in access to information, as supported by the open access movement. they also mention their transition into academic librarianship and their personal interest in digital libraries and institutional repositories. the open access movement and institutional repositories are seen as challenging the traditional scholarly communication system, and it is suggested that academic libraries can play a role in alleviating the conflict between these two paradigms. institutional repositories are noted to put pressure on journal publishers to allow as much free online access to their content as possible. the document also emphasizes the important role of the library and information sector in providing public access to networked information, with public libraries playing a significant role in ensuring equity in access to information for all citizens.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- open access (oa) movement
- quality library services

Tweet: There is nothing in this excellent comment with which I would want to disagree. However, I also want to add that a place with books, whether it is my house or a library, is a vital resource that brings benefits not to be found on the Internet (I am a technologist, by the way). Our local library was been closed for a couple of years for a major renovation and to save money (no good alternative was offered or created in the community). Not having a library is like losing the heart of the community. I find libraries superior to the Internet for what most people believe they get best online: random access to information and facts. Online, I don't come across things for which I am not searching. In a library, it is all there before me, waiting. Just walking through the reference room can lead to unexpected discoveries, diversions and, on occasion, new directions. We need both books and electronic information. Whoever imagined we needed to choose?
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of libraries as a vital resource that brings benefits not to be found on the internet. the author, who is a technologist, believes that libraries offer superior random access to information and facts compared to the online environment. they express a concern about the closure of their local library for renovation, stating that not having a library is like losing the heart of the community. they also highlight the value of unexpected discoveries and diversions that come from walking through the reference room. the author ultimately emphasizes the need for both books and electronic information, questioning the idea that a choice between the two is necessary.

expanded phrases and sentences:
- "no good alternative was offered or created in the community."
- "i am a technologist, by the way."
- "whoever imagined we needed to choose?"

the document expresses the opinion that comments are valuable and should not be removed because they add depth and variety to the discussion surrounding an article. it also recognizes the challenges of monitoring comments for inappropriate content. it states that the decision to eliminate comments would be a mistake due to the valuable input that commenters provide. overall, the document makes a case for the importance of comments sections.

Tweet: The research on this issue is clear, which the Yale provost might read ---picking up a second language in college is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, for adult learners ---that is not to say that there are students who do have a talent for second language acquisition, but most of us do not. Now having said that, the odds of learning a second language increase dramatically at the elementary level. We have a habit, when discussing educational matters, of aiming curricular reforms at high school and colleges, when, we should be focused on the age groups where learning a second language is optimum---so, instead of Yale, we should be looking at enlarging dual language programs at the K - 8 system.
Wiki:
the document states that the research is clear and that picking up a second language in college is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, for adult learners. although there are some students who have a talent for second language acquisition, most do not. however, the odds of learning a second language greatly increase at the elementary level. therefore, instead of focusing on college-level language education, the document suggests enlarging dual language programs at the kindergarten to 8th-grade system. this means that mandatory college-level language education may not be as effective as focusing on language learning at earlier ages.

expansion of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- yale: yale university
- k - 8: kindergarten to 8th grade
- hashtag: symbol used on social media to mark keywords or topics; used here to indicate a key point or concept

Tweet: Among the many services that libraries have traditionally provided, perhaps the most important are access to physical copies of published works, and access to information. As the publishing industry transforms, not surprisingly the borrowing of physical books from libraries is likely to decline. However, the need for access to information is likely to grow. This access to information is provided not only by devices and infrastructure but also is supported by the library staff who provide invaluable assistance. They assist with the tools, and serve as guides and navigators around the rapidly growing sources and forms of online information. Looking further into the future, as educational institutions become transformed by the widespread availability of free online courses, and distributed learning becomes the norm, there is another potential role for libraries as learning centers. In this case the facility not only provides the access devices, but can also host tutors and local study groups. As access to steadily growing amounts of information becomes more important for all members of society perhaps the role and services of libraries might actually increase rather than decline.
Wiki:
libraries traditionally provide access to physical copies of published works and information. while the borrowing of physical books may decline as the publishing industry changes, the need for access to information is likely to grow. library staff are invaluable in providing assistance and guidance in navigating online information sources. in the future, libraries may serve as learning centers, hosting tutors and study groups as educational institutions adopt distributed learning. as access to information becomes more important, the role and services of libraries may actually increase rather than decline.

abbreviations:
- # = hashtag
- info = information

slang:
- gonna = going to

complete phrases and sentences:
- hashtag
- access to information
- going to
- information

Tweet: I've never studied James Naismith but I have a better idea of his thinking than you. In 1891 he was thinking that the average height of a full-grown male was about 5-1/2 feet. He invented the game for kids at the YMCA, not for those on some alien planet. His thinking was that the ball would be thrown UP to the basket, not dropped in from above.
new_topic: that you don't need to be tall to play basketball

Tweet: Our hands offer a unique pathway to our brains. Using a pencil, pen or stylus to write appears to allow the brain to trigger different storage mechanisms, I am an educator with a son healing from a severe brain injury. We have spent years in Occupational ttherapy but even more time at home struggling. Cursive writing as well as drawing appear to trigger different brain functions and memory. We do not have to return to the 50's Palmer method perfection.It has been my observation that our brain functions have a unique stamp over some universal packaging, My son responds to music therapy more than other s while I enjoy writing and know I write better on paper than at the keyboard. Our children need to be taught some form of cursive writing, the elements of drawing and the power of our hands. The hand has an HOV pathway to our brain. We should not let that roadway fall into disrepair.
Wiki: in summary, the document emphasizes the importance of using the hands for writing and drawing to trigger different brain functions and memory storage. the author, who is an educator with a son healing from a severe brain injury, has observed that cursive writing and drawing have had a positive impact on her son's brain functions. it is noted that the brain responds differently to music therapy and that the power of the hands should not be overlooked in education. the document suggests that students should be taught some form of cursive writing, the elements of drawing, and the significance of using their hands for learning. the author also emphasizes the unique pathway that the hands offer to the brain, and the importance of not neglecting it. complete phrases for abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document are: occupational therapy (ot), hands-on-visual (hov) pathway.

Tweet: Perhaps the reason more students pass online courses is the content and standards are less rigorous than in a traditional classroom. Tweet: Imagine that I were the first person to discover that water molecules are made up of two hydrogen atoms covalently bonded to an oxygen atom. Should I be allowed to patent the molecular formula for water? Should everyone who uses water after that point or does research on water have to pay me a nickel? See how absurd that sounds? To me, the gene debate is no different. If I assemble a new molecule that did not exist before, like the buckyball, I own the rights to it. But if I merely discover what the molecule looks like, I can't claim ownership of that.
Wiki: the document is explaining that making a discovery, such as the molecular structure of water or a new molecule, does not entitle someone to patent or own the rights to that discovery. just as the discovery of water's molecular formula doesn't mean everyone using or researching water owes the discoverer money, discovering a molecule doesn't give the discoverer ownership over it. this knowledge applies to companies in that new discoveries or inventions can be patented, but simply discovering something does not mean a company has ownership over it. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document have been expanded into complete phrases and sentences for clarity and understanding.

Tweet: Imagine that I were the first person to discover that water molecules are made up of two hydrogen atoms covalently bonded to an oxygen atom. Should I be allowed to patent the molecular formula for water? Should everyone who uses water after that point or does research on water have to pay me a nickel? See how absurd that sounds? To me, the gene debate is no different. If I assemble a new molecule that did not exist before, like the buckyball, I own the rights to it. But if I merely discover what the molecule looks like, I can't claim ownership of that.

the knowledge from the document is that the discovery of the molecular formula for water, made up of two hydrogen atoms covalently bonded to an oxygen atom, should not be allowed to be patented. the comparison is made to the gene debate, stating that if someone assembles a new molecule, like the buckyball, they own the rights to it. however, if someone merely discovers what the molecule looks like, they cannot claim ownership of it.

in regards to 'gene', it suggests that the molecular structure of a gene should not be able to be patented, as it is a natural discovery rather than something newly created. this is similar to the argument against patenting the molecular formula for water.

Tweet: I'm an attorney and frequently appear in Family Court. The court has substituted audio recording for live reporters in most proceedings. The resultant recordings are then transcribed manually by someone listening to the audio record if transcript is ordered. The transcripts that are typed from the audio recording of the proceeding are invariably terrible. Parts of the transcript are virtually always missed and marked as 'inaudible.' Other parts are garbled. The transcripts are frequently worse than nothing at all. There is no real substitute for a transcript produced by a competent reporter and not having a reporter may sacrifice justice for the sake of saving a few dollars.
Wiki:
the document discusses the use of audio recordings in family court proceedings to replace live reporters. it highlights the problems with the accuracy and reliability of transcripts typed from these recordings, stating that they are frequently terrible and may miss important parts of the proceedings. the author believes that there is no substitute for a transcript produced by a competent court stenographer and that not having a stenographer may compromise the pursuit of justice in exchange for cost savings.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded into complete sentences:
- 'court stenographer' refers to the professional who uses stenographic machines to transcribe spoken words in court proceedings.
- 'transcript' is a written record of the court proceedings, typically produced by a court stenographer.
- 'inaudible' is used to denote parts of the recording where the speech is not clear or understandable.
- 'garbled' refers to sections of the recording where the speech is distorted or muddled.
- 'justice' pertains to fairness

Tweet: The publication cited by the author as evidence supporting his position that cats must be declawed is filled with so many errors I don't know where to begin. The Loss article has been routinely and thoroughly debunked as unreliable (statistical assumptions on estimates from dated studies, extrapolating those estimates, lack of accountability for population density in cat ownership in rural, suburban and urban environments where existence of land birds is diverse due to variation of vegetative coverage in human dominated environments, dominant predation territorial variation of wildlife in general, the unethical monetary support of the authors by organizations who support killing cats without a rational basis, etc.) in other words highly biased. As stewards of our environments, we must change our focus and pledge do no harm and we must adapt and change rather than exterminate or maim domesticated animals which simply is not rational or humane.
Wiki:
the document argues that the publication cited by the author in support of declawing cats is unreliable and filled with errors. the article has been debunked for making statistical assumptions based on dated studies, extrapolating those estimates, and not accounting for population density in different environments. it also criticizes the unethical monetary support of the authors by organizations that support killing cats without a rational basis. the document calls for a change in focus to do no harm to domesticated animals and to adapt and change rather than exterminate or maim them.

abbreviations expanded:
- etc. = and so on
- stewards = caretakers
- no harm = not cause any damage or negative impact
- pledge = promise or commit
- exterminate = kill off completely
- maim = physically harm
- rational = logical or reasonable
- humane = compassionate or kind

Tweet: There are numerous reasons why Birthright Citizenship makes no sense and virtually no arguments in its favor other that "it has been done that way". Here are the arguments against: (1) It was never intended to apply to kids born to tourists and illegal immigrants. (2) No developed countries other than the US and Canada observe it and both countries are currently discussing eliminating it. (3) It incentivizes illegal immigration. (4) It incentivizes illegal immigrants having kids and the US taxpayer directly or indirectly pays for the maternity. (5) It allows children of illegal parents to qualify for the full array of US entitlements, that in most cases a legal immigrant family would not receive. (6) Over time, the Birthright Citizens, who only exist here because of the illegal entry and presence of their parents, become sufficiently numerous they can influence our politics and try to extort legalization for their parents. (7) It complicates deporting illegal immigrant parents because of the "separating families" caterwauling. Ending Birthright Citizenship must be a core part of immigration reform.
Wiki: birthright citizenship, the practice of granting citizenship to anyone born within the borders of a country, makes no sense for several reasons. it was never intended to apply to children born to tourists and illegal immigrants. it is only observed in the us and canada, and both countries are considering eliminating it. birthright citizenship incentivizes illegal immigration and having children, with the us taxpayer covering the costs of maternity. it also allows children of illegal parents to qualify for us entitlements, giving them an advantage over legal immigrant families. over time, these "birthright citizens" may try to influence politics and demand legalization for their parents. it also complicates the process of deporting illegal immigrant parents. therefore, ending birthright citizenship needs to be a fundamental part of immigration reform.

Tweet: When I am confronted by religious practitioners passionately arguing for absolute religious freedom I have lately started to pose questions of them rather than argue. For example, how should we deal with a religious group that practices cannibalism? Among those societies that have practiced it, there has been a sacred and even reverential set of beliefs built around sharing in the admirable qualities of the person whose flesh is shared. Supposedly wine becomes blood and bread becomes flesh during Communion. I am met with incredulous stares when I mention this. It could never happen, I am told. When I press on further and ask about female genital mutilation, which IS practiced in certain cultural/religious cultures today, I am met with silence. My point is that there are limits to religious freedom even if we don't codify them. These limits seem to be that religious freedom ends when harm to others starts and no amount of sincere, passionate belief in some deity can overcome them. We know intuitively what we as a society are willing to accept and harming children is not among them. What we do to ourselves as adults is one thing. Losing a child unnecessarily harms us all.
Wiki:
the document explores the limits of religious freedom, arguing that religious freedom should not extend to practices that cause harm to others. the author poses questions to religious practitioners about how they would deal with religious groups that practice harmful actions, such as cannibalism and female genital mutilation. the author makes the point that society intuitively knows where the limits of religious freedom should be and that harming children is not acceptable. the document suggests that while adults have the freedom to practice their religious beliefs, this freedom should not extend to practices that harm others, particularly children.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document expanded: 
- is: which is 
- #freedom: hashtag freedom 
- #religious: hashtag religious 
- #believers: hashtag believers 
- #cultural: hashtag cultural 
- #practicing: hashtag practicing 
- #society: hashtag society

Tweet: In 1866, Senator Jacob Howard clearly spelled out the intent of the 14th Amendment by stating: "Every person born within the limits of the United States, and subject to their jurisdiction, is by virtue of natural law and national law a citizen of the United States. This will not, of course, include persons born in the United States who are foreigners, aliens, who belong to the families of ambassadors or foreign ministers accredited to the Government of the United States, but will include every other class of persons. It settles the great question of citizenship and removes all doubt as to what persons are or are not citizens of the United States. This has long been a great desideratum in the jurisprudence and legislation of this country."
Wiki:
the document explains the intent of the 14th amendment regarding birthright citizenship. senator jacob howard stated that every person born within the limits of the united states and subject to their jurisdiction is a citizen by virtue of natural and national law. this does not include foreigners, aliens, or the families of foreign ambassadors. the amendment settles the question of citizenship and removes doubt about who is a citizen. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags have been expanded into complete phrases and sentences to provide a clearer understanding of the document.

Tweet: Obesity is a complex problem that cannot simply be reduced to eating too much. Genetics, some mental illnesses and medications are often factors. There are other factors that we do not yet know about. Obesity seems to be the last great bastion of acceptable prejudice in our society. Derision and prejudice that is now unacceptable (and rightly so) for blacks, gays, the disabled and other minority groups apparently is still okay for our obese citizens. Maybe we should think about that.
Wiki:
the document highlights that obesity is a complex issue that is not solely caused by overeating. genetics, mental illness, and medications also play a role, along with other unknown factors. the author notes that obesity is still subject to prejudice in society, despite derision and prejudice being deemed unacceptable for other minority groups. the document suggests that society should consider the prejudice against obese individuals in the same way they think about prejudice against other minority groups. 

abbreviations/slang: 
- 'our obese citizens': our citizens who are obese
- '#obesityprejudice': hashtag obesity prejudice

Tweet: Unpaid internships are a bad idea for another reason. The ability to spend time during or after studies engaging in unpaid work is something not every student can afford to undertake. Many students need to work through school to support their studies, and many others will need paid work to begin paying off student loans. Unpaid internships, then, become a stepping stone that only the well-off can afford.

Tweet: I wonder of what use my comments would be without that I stood by them. Do I honestly have any crucial wisdom to impart upon the world that would be of such benefit that even doing so anonymously would be of service to the community? Or does it just make me feel good to spew? But truthfully - the reaction given by the readership here - anonymous or not - has got to be a reasonable barometer of the feelings of the community, whether or not an individual feels comfortable posting as a person, or only as a glyph. And there is value in that for us all.
Wiki:
the document is reflecting on the value of anonymous comments in a comment section. the author questions whether their comments have any real wisdom to offer, and whether posting anonymously serves any real purpose. they also acknowledge that the reaction from the community, whether anonymous or not, is important and valuable, and can provide insight into the feelings of the community as a whole.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- "do i honestly have any crucial wisdom to impart upon the world that would be of such benefit that even doing so anonymously would be of service to the community?" expands to "do i truly have any important knowledge to share with the world that would be so beneficial that even sharing it anonymously would help the community?"
- "spew" expands to "express or discharge (a substance) in a copious flow."
- "the reaction given by the readership here - anonymous or not" expands to "the feedback given by the people reading the comments, whether posting anonymously or not"

Tweet: Moderate and block if necessary. Without readers comments the Times would be greatly diminished. I'm as interested in them as I am in my most respected reporters and columnist. Comments sections that are not moderated get no attention from me. The Times is to be commended for supporting readers comments even though they are often managed arbitrarily as Margaret Sullivan's last column's comments were and are. Where probably hundreds of readers positive remarks were not posted. it was an important column from an admired writer.

Tweet: I think questions about the queen abdicating in favor of her son are grounded in sexism. Would there be noise about abdication if the current monarch were a king? Would he be pressed to abdicate in favor of a daugther? Elizabeth II would be the only British monarch ever to abdicate, except for the ignoble Prince of Wales who abdicated to marry Wallis Simpson and lives in disgrace in the British consciousness as a result. The throne of England is a position for life; it is an investiture. Furthermore, Queen Elizabeth is doing her job quite well; why should she give it up?

Tweet: While there are clearly individual patterns to acknowledge- from OCD driven behaviors, to self-soothing retreat from chaotic emotional environments - there is also a kind of personal omnipotence associated with computer life. Whether gaming or surfing or texting- one can feel powerful and important. And the 'withdrawal' (required for asserting addiction) symptoms are known to all of us. Who hasn't felt a twinge of panic or background unease & irritability when our routers crash or email service is lost ? TV was the boomers vice--mesmerized kid zombies & couch potatoes. How are we doing ?

the document discusses the phenomenon of internet addiction, highlighting how it presents itself in individual behaviors such as ocd-driven actions or retreat from emotional chaos. it also points out how using the internet can give individuals a sense of power and importance, leading to withdrawal symptoms when connectivity is disrupted. the document also compares internet addiction to the television addiction of previous generations.

Tweet: It is much easier today to be a celebrity. Today, as amazing as it seems in our world, people find celebrities like Charlie Sheen and his antics, orgies, rants, etc. entertaining. Tweet: I'm a big fan of comments sections. All to often opinion pieces are no more than the space where a publication gets to spout it's own talking points and perspectives. Worse, it sometimes seems that the journalistic slant in articles are intended to reinforce the 'opinion' which the Editorial Board later gives it's blessing to on the op-ed pages. The fact is, many of the very best insights and most honest disagreements manifest only in the comments of readers. Views that the Publisher or editorial board of a publication do not necessarily agree with.
Wiki: the document expresses a positive view of comment sections, noting that opinion pieces often just reflect the publication's own agenda. it suggests that the most valuable insights and honest disagreements come from the comments of readers, which may not align with the publisher or editorial board's views. the author is in favor of comment sections as a space for diverse perspectives and genuine conversations. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags should be expanded to complete phrases and sentences for clarity and formality.

Tweet: I must be terribly uncultured, but I believe that salt and pepper on the table should be available for patron use. However, I do cringe when I see individuals immediately douse their entire plates in salt and/or pepper when the plates are presented, before even a bite of food is taken. If I was a chef, that would wound me much more than seeing a patron thoughtfully taste a dish, then add their desired amount of seasoning. In the end, isn't it about your patron enjoying your food, even if they have to adjust the seasoning to their own personal taste?
Wiki:
the document discusses the use of salt and pepper on the table in a restaurant. it suggests that while it is important for patrons to have access to these seasonings, it is cringe-worthy to see them immediately douse their entire plates with salt and/or pepper before even tasting the food. the author believes that it would be more respectful to the chef to taste the dish first and then add seasoning as needed. ultimately, the priority should be the patron's enjoyment of the food, even if they need to adjust the seasoning to their personal taste. 

also, the document emphasizes that these seasonings should be available for patron use but it is not desirable to use them excessively before even tasting the food. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags that were expanded into complete phrases and sentences include: cringe (to feel disgust or embarrassment), and patron (a customer of a restaurant or other establishment).

Tweet: The main problem with Rate My Professor as a reliable guide to the quality of the instructor is statistical: the proportion of students who post anything is tiny; and they are not necessarily representative. Those who post ratings are more likely to be those with strong views. They may even have a specific purpose in posting, such as boosting or trashing the instructor. Yet given the total number of students most professors teach (about 1000 over ten years), the responses of a few dozen are a poor guide to anything.
Wiki:
the main issue with rate my professor as a reliable guide to the quality of the instructor is statistical. the proportion of students who post anything is very small, and they are not necessarily representative. those who post ratings are more likely to have strong views and may have a specific purpose, such as boosting or trashing the instructor. given the total number of students most professors teach (about 1000 over ten years), the responses of a few dozen are not a good guide to anything.

rate my professor (rmp) is not a reliable guide to instructor quality because only a small proportion of students post ratings and they may not be representative. those who do post are more likely to have strong views and may have a specific purpose in doing so. given the large number of students most professors teach, the responses of a few dozen are not a good guide to anything.

Tweet: Knowing that a combination of 33 pesticides are sprayed on the average apple makes me feel ill. An apple a day will keep the doc away from eating the apple! Tweet: The lede to the story asks, "Are murder charges against a patrolman an aberration or an example of how police use deadly force too easily?" The premise is wrong, setting up a false dichotomy. It is not a case of either this or that. Rather, it is a case of this and that. The murder charge itself is an aberration. At the same time, the police use deadly force too easily.
Wiki:
the document questions whether murder charges against a patrolman are an abnormality or a reflection of how police use deadly force too readily. however, the premise is flawed as it is not an either/or situation, but rather both. the murder charge may be an anomaly, but at the same time, the police do use deadly force too easily.

- the lede (the opening sentence or paragraph) to the story asks, "are murder charges against a patrolman an aberration or an example of how police use deadly force too easily?"
- it is not a case of either this or that. rather, it is a case of this and that.

Tweet: A lot of these comments criticize the use of RMP because students who don't like to do work and want to be entertained tend to like the easier professors. This is too shallow a view of RMP. RMP has extremely valuable information because people actually type in information. When you read over and over that the teacher fails to adequately explain material so that everyone is confused at test time, that's important information for a student. When you read again and again that the teacher doesn't like taking questions and instead prefers to stick to her outline, that's important information. When you read numerous reviews saying the students came away from the class with a new love of the material, that's important information. It's also really easy to see which professors are well-liked for being easy--which is also important information for a student who either needs a filler class to round out an otherwise brutal semester, or needs stronger instruction in that subject, in which case he can avoid the easy teacher. It's not about who has five stars versus one, there's much more to it than that.
Wiki: the document emphasizes the value of rate my professors (rmp) despite criticism that it only attracts students who want an easy, entertaining class. it points out that the reviews on rmp provide valuable information, such as teacher's ability to explain material, willingness to take questions, and the impact on students' interest in the subject. it also mentions that rmp makes it easy to identify professors who are well-liked for being easy, which can be important for students looking for a filler class or stronger instruction in a subject. the document argues that rmp is more than just a rating system, and instead provides nuanced and useful information for students. it states that rmp stands for rate my professors, and also expands the slang and hashtags to complete sentences.

Tweet: I'm saddened that cursive is not considered important. Both my school-age boys (8th and 10th grade) have horribly illegible printing habits. They sometimes cannot read cursive. I'm more appalled to read here that SPELLING is not required in the Common Core standards! Are you serious? I'd noticed a lack of focus on spelling as my kids have gone through school, but I didn't realize that we nationally did not consider it an important skill. Spell-check isn't a good substitute, people! It is frequently wrong. And my kids seem to believe that if spell-check says something might be wrong, that it IS wrong - causing them to make more errors than they would have. (Besides, if spell-check is the reason spelling isn't crucial anymore, then why didn't we skip teaching spelling once dictionaries were invented?) Between lousy spelling and lousy handwriting, the future is bleak.
Wiki:
the document expresses concern over the lack of emphasis on cursive writing and spelling in school curriculum, as well as the negative impact it has on students. the author is disappointed that cursive writing is not considered important, as their school-age boys have illegible printing habits and struggle to read cursive. they are also shocked to hear that spelling is not required in the common core standards, and think that spell-check is not a good substitute for learning spelling. they believe that spell-check often provides incorrect suggestions and leads to more errors. the author is worried about the future because of the combination of poor spelling and handwriting skills in students.

expansion:
are you serious? - are you seriously suggesting this?

spell-check - automatic spelling and grammar checking function

#lousy - awful or unsatisfactory

the future is bleak. - the future looks very negative.

Tweet: Yes,America needs an effective intelligence agency in these times when their are large threats, continual crises, and highly technical developments to keep up with. We don't necessarily need the exact agency we have now. Give some of its staff and actions back to State and DOD. Require what remains to be absolutely disconnected from politics and totally law abiding. The director and his highest assistants should be prepared to resign the moment they are asked to partake of an illegal action, or one unjustified in defense of the country. Legal action for offenders would be mandatory. We don't need an agency to spy on other branches of the government and even the Congress in its own interest and then declare itself immune from prosecution. The present CIA is too big and too deeply entrenched in politics and Washington power blocs.
Wiki: the document argues that the united states needs a capable intelligence agency due to the existence of major threats, ongoing crises, and rapid technological advancements. however, it suggests that the current central intelligence agency (cia) may not be the best fit, proposing that some of its staff and responsibilities should be transferred back to the state department and the department of defense (dod). the document also calls for the remaining cia to be completely separate from political influences and to strictly adhere to the law. it emphasizes the importance of the director and top officials being willing to resign if asked to engage in illegal or unjust actions, with legal consequences for those who violate these standards. the document expresses disapproval of the cia spying on other branches of the government, including congress, for its own benefit and expecting immunity from prosecution. ultimately, the document concludes that the current cia is too large and too deeply entrenched in the political landscape of washington.

Tweet: Wearing a hijab for whatever reason - religious, aesthetics, solidarity is not by itself wrong and I fail to see why it is such a big issue. - sarees: a traditional indian garment

Tweet: Jane Black's findings, that people still do eat poorly even when they have easy access to better foods and the means to afford them, is telling. We always want the easy way out. Tweet: While I understand the desire to protect those addicted to gambling, the simple truth is that gambling addicts are already gambling online, without any oversight or regulation. Tweet: I think the issue that we ought to be able to agree on, is that birth right citizenship has to end. The motivation for immigration can vary, but poverty and lack of opportunity in the country of origin seems like its often a cause. And international policies that worsen prospects for a better life would have to be seen as a contributing factor as well. Yet, openly rewarding illegal immigrants with automatic birthright citizenship is incentivizing the disregard of the host country's own laws. This continuing conversation over immigration going on in the US, mirrors that going on in Europe today. It's the same issue. Do we fix the world first, and hope the desperation driving illegal immigration abates over time? Or absorb those flows of people from those troubled regions seeking a better life now? I think its better, and more fair to all concerned, to have a managed process for documented labor, visitation and immigration, than a mad lawless rush across borders. Civilization and civilized behavior breaks down in the face of desperation. Accepting unlimited immigrants from around the world would not improve the lives of those left behind. Who is responsible for helping them?
Wiki: the document argues that birthright citizenship should be ended, as it incentivizes illegal immigration and disregards the host country's laws. it recognizes that poverty and lack of opportunity in the country of origin are often driving forces for immigration, and acknowledges the role of international policies in worsening prospects for a better life. the document also points out the ongoing debate over immigration in the us and europe, questioning whether the focus should be on fixing the world first or absorbing flows of people seeking a better life. it suggests that a managed process for documented labor, visitation, and immigration would be more fair to all concerned than a lawless rush across borders. it also highlights the breakdown of civilization and civilized behavior in the face of desperation, and raises the question of who is responsible for helping those left behind.

Tweet: I comment reasonably frequently and also read a lot more than I would otherwise because of the comments. Mostly I feel the Times does a decent job moderating the comments, although I often notice the same pro-Hillary bias in many of the NYT picks as opposed to the Reader's Picks. (Anecdotally, this bias in the picks seems to be diminishing.) I also agree that many commenters are predictable, but because of their status, make it to the front of the line. I wonder if more courageous columnists might be willing to directly take on points that commenters raise. I feel that there is an awful lot of repetition of memes by columnists that have been discredited, such as Sanders's supposed pro-gun positions, when in fact he has a D minus rating from the NRA. Often it is commenters who bring these up, and columnists never address them. While I know you can't write a column by committee, I think a columnist that occasionally addressed specific, thoughtful reactions to his/her columns could bring in a lot of readers, and make readers feel they are listened to by the Times.
Wiki:
the author of the document comments frequently and reads more because of the comments. they feel that the times does a decent job moderating the comments, but they often notice a pro-hillary bias in the nyt picks compared to the reader's picks. they also suggest that more courageous columnists should directly address points raised by commenters and address repetition of discredited memes by columnists. they believe that addressing specific, thoughtful reactions to columns could bring in more readers and make them feel listened to by the times.

Tweet: I can't speak to the ways the student vote affects national politics, but it can have a ruinous effect on the local community. The politically liberal university city I live near is dominated -- and made barely functional -- by both the votes of both current college students and the never-grow-up graduates who stick around after leaving school. Too many of the students vote for what they think sounds cool. They don't think about or care about the consequences. It's easy to vote for a new tax or bond when you aren't the ones paying for it. It's just so cool to vote for a city or county politician who advocates for free everything -- more subsidized housing and shelters for the homeless and drug treatment centers and...on and on -- when every summer you return to your mom and dad's comfortable home in a leafy suburb far, far away. Voting should be tied to one's legal address, period. And for dependent children, that legal address should be where mom and/or dad, or legal guardians, live.
Wiki:
the document argues that the college student vote can have a negative impact on the local community. it mentions that the politically liberal university city nearby is controlled by both current college students and graduates who stay in the area. it criticizes students for voting for what they think sounds cool without considering the consequences. it also suggests that voting should be tied to one's legal address and that dependent children should vote where their parents or legal guardians live.

abbreviations and slang expanded:
- "i can't" -> i am unable to
- "mom and dad's" -> mother and father's
- "far, far away" -> distant
- "should be tied to" -> should be connected to
- "on and on" -> continuously
- "voting should be tied to one's legal address, period" -> voting should be linked to an individual's legal address, without exception
- "for dependent children" -> for children who are reliant on others 
- "legally guardians

Tweet: Nick, homeschooled kids are part of society. They just don't go to public school, same as private school kids. In my state, the state athletic organization that oversees high school sports created guidelines for homeschooler participation in high school sports. They must meet academic and other requirements that enrolled kids must meet, but as long as they do, they are eligible. The overseeing organization realized that excluding homeschoolers was indeed discriminatory, and set about creating a system within which they could participate. In other states, there are laws on the books that require schools to allow homeschoolers to participate in school activities. My daughter was very involved in sports, and very talented at it, and she took advantage of both elite leagues and her high school teams (she was an enrolled student, not a homeschooler). The elite leagues are available to those who can make the teams, true, and most serious athletes participate in them. It's the lack of programs for the average kid after the age of 14 that's a problem. Also, even those who can make the elite teams can't always afford the fees.
Wiki: the document discusses the inclusion of homeschooled children in society and specifically in high school sports. it explains that in some states, homeschoolers are allowed to participate in high school sports as long as they meet academic and other requirements that enrolled students must meet. the document highlights that excluding homeschoolers was seen as discriminatory, leading to the creation of guidelines for their participation. in addition, some states have laws allowing homeschoolers to participate in school activities. the document also mentions the challenges for average children over the age of 14 in finding sports programs and the financial barriers for those who can make elite teams. overall, the document emphasizes the importance of creating opportunities for homeschooled children to participate in school and sports activities.

Tweet: The notion of manhood traits aroses from primal times when manhood connoted the ability to ensure the survival of oneself and then of family and community. So manhood became associated with the warrior, the hunters, the frontiersman, the guard and the provider. Woman complemented primarily by being the homemaker, while her man was out in the wild or at war. But ancient threats and dangers are gone, society is relatively safe and women are quite capable of providing for themselves, thank you. But modern threats have taken new forms but the underlying gnawing inner emotions of fear, insecurity, doubt, hopelessness etc still exist. So the new role of a man is to inspire faith where there is fear, courage where there is doubt, hope in despair and love in the midst of hate. all this talk of rough edged muscles, sweatiness instead of perfume, ability to light fires and chop wood are nothing more than sexual fantasies and turn ons - which of course is still necessary for good relationships and survival of the species.
Wiki:
the document discusses how the traditional notion of manhood, which originated from primal times and was associated with being a warrior, hunter, provider, and protector, is no longer relevant in today's society. women are now capable of providing for themselves and modern threats have taken on new forms. the new role of a man is to inspire courage, faith, hope, and love in the face of fear, doubt, and despair. the emphasis on rough masculinity and traditional gender roles is seen as outdated and unnecessary for healthy relationships and the survival of the species. the document also highlights that the underlying emotions of fear, insecurity, doubt, and hopelessness are still present in modern society, and men should strive to address these emotions in new and constructive ways.

Tweet: I agree wholeheartedly. It's true that I was in college a long time ago, but living in a dorm was mostly a great experience. And the parts that weren't great were good for my maturing process. As Dr. Shalala said, there's community in a dorm; I was a shy girl, but made friends easily in the dorm atmosphere. I would have been lonely off-campusin an apartment. Also, cooking, cleaning, shopping for food take time, time that I was able to devote to studying. Especially when I came back as a 26-yr old to live in a graduate dorm for a year, it was a huge relief to let someone else cook, and just show up to eat. And again, I made new friends, people I'd never have met had I lived in an apartment.
Wiki: the document expresses the author's positive experience living in a dorm during college. they agree that living in a dorm was a great experience and even the challenging parts helped them mature. the author found it easier to make friends and fight off loneliness while living in a dorm, compared to living in an apartment. they also appreciated the convenience of not having to worry about cooking, cleaning, and shopping for food, which allowed them to focus on studying. overall, they believe that living in a dorm contributed to their overall college experience in a positive way.

As Dr. Shalala said, there's community in a dorm; I was a shy girl, but made friends easily in the dorm atmosphere. I would have been lonely off-campusin an apartment. Also, cooking, cleaning, shopping for food take time, time that I was able to devote to studying. Especially when I came back as a 26-yr old to live in a graduate dorm for a year, it was a huge relief to let someone else cook, and just show up to eat. And again, I made new friends, people I'd never have met had I lived in an apartment.
Wiki:
the document describes the positive aspects of living in a dorm during college. the writer acknowledges that while there were some challenging moments, overall, the dorm experience was beneficial for their personal growth. they agree with dr. shalala's view that there is a sense of community in a dorm, and this helped them overcome their shyness and make friends easily. they also mention that living in a dorm saved time on cooking, cleaning, and shopping, allowing them to focus on studying. additionally, they found it comforting to have meals prepared for them when they lived in a graduate dorm as a 26-year-old. they also emphasize that living in a dorm provided opportunities to make new friends that they would not have met if they had lived off-campus.
