Tweet: I'm an academic advisor in natural sciences at a big university; day after weary day I advise students with below average grades who have unrealistic expectations and cannot accept the fact that - contrary to what they've been told all of their lives - they cannot be a scientist or doctor. Virtually every day I advise one or more students with "B" averages in math, chemistry and biology who persist in the belief that they will get into medical school, all the while accumulating massive debt and wasting time. I don't even really have the hope that one day they will wake up; I forget who said that "most people can't stand too much reality."
Wiki:
the document discusses the challenges faced by an academic advisor in the natural sciences at a university, who regularly advises students with below average grades and unrealistic expectations. these students often believe they can get into medical school despite their grades and are accumulating debt and wasting time. the advisor expresses frustration and doubts that these students will ever accept the reality that they may not be able to pursue a career in medicine. the document also mentions the quote "most people can't stand too much reality." 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- b averages = below average grades
- i don't even = i do not even
- medical school = a school for training doctors
- massive debt = high amounts of debt
- wasting time = spending time unproductively
- reality = truth or actuality

Tweet: I learned to salt in culinary school. If the cooks and the chef are SURE of the flavor level of every dish, then keep the salt off the table. But not every food preparer is perfect. Tweet: With an increase in insurance mergers, and the most recent Aetna/Anthem failed merger due to the FTC, there has been a substantial decrease in competition within the insurance sector. Lack of competition is bad for consumers because there are less players fighting for your business, so it is easier to raise, and keep prices high. Obamacare has also made it impossible for insurance companies to price policies based on pre-existing conditions, which is forcing actuaries to increase insurance costs across the board. Aetna has lost hundreds of millions of dollars on it's Affordable Care Act arm and is dropping the option in 11 out of the 15 states where it was offered. If insurance companies keep getting strangled by the government, there will be a sharp decrease in the participation rate of the Affordable Care Act and the Gov't may be left on the hook to provide policies (socialism) although I'm not sure what would happen if private participation drops off a cliff. If the trend continues, AFA is not sustainable.
Wiki: the document highlights the impact of insurance mergers and the failed aetna/anthem merger on competition in the insurance sector. the decrease in competition is seen as negative for consumers as it can lead to higher prices. additionally, the document mentions that obamacare has made it impossible for insurance companies to price policies based on pre-existing conditions, which is causing actuaries to increase insurance costs across the board. aetna has suffered substantial financial losses on its affordable care act arm and is discontinuing its offerings in 11 out of the 15 states. the document raises concerns that if government regulations continue to strangle insurance companies, there may be a sharp decrease in the participation rate of the affordable care act. this could potentially result in the government having to provide policies (a form of socialism), and if private participation drops significantly, the sustainability of the affordable care act would be in question.

Tweet: In my experience, those with trust funds could afford to work the unpaid internships that lead to full-time jobs. Those who can't afford to work for nothing, whose parents do not support them while they are doing unpaid work, can't get in at the bottom level of companies that hire 'interns' and in this way -- money = opportunity is put in the hands of those with capital.
Wiki:
the document suggests that individuals with trust funds are able to afford to work unpaid internships, which often lead to full-time jobs. on the other hand, those who cannot afford to work for free and do not have parental support are unable to access entry-level opportunities at companies that hire interns. this creates a situation where access to opportunities is dictated by financial capital, as those with money are able to secure internships and ultimately employment. additionally, unpaid internships can serve as a barrier for individuals from less privileged backgrounds to access certain career paths.

abbreviations/slang:

- 'can't': cannot
- 'afford': have enough money to pay for
- 'unpaid internships': internships that do not provide monetary compensation
- 'full-time jobs': permanent positions with a standard work schedule
- 'parents': the mother and father of a person
- 'companies': businesses or organizations
- 'interns': individuals working at a company for a temporary period

Tweet: When I visit NY, I spend time on the North Fork of Long Island, known for its many conventional wineries. The landscape is beautiful. Now, if there are no benefits to organic farming, how come so many of the vineyards have huge signs with skull and crossbones that say: "do not enter, pesticides are dangerous"? Every time I pass by I wonder about the high incidence of breast cancer in Long Island, and I wonder about the farm workers working on the vines, and I wonder about the need to post these signs if it is all so very safe.
Wiki:
the document discusses the experience of visiting the north fork of long island, which is known for its conventional wineries. the author questions the use of pesticides in these vineyards, as evidenced by the large signs warning of the danger of pesticides. this raises concerns about the potential link between pesticides and the high incidence of breast cancer on long island, as well as the health of the farm workers. the document implies that organic farming may be a safer and healthier alternative to conventional farming.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
ny - new york
do not enter - do not enter this area
#organicfood - organic food
#breastcancer - breast cancer
#farmworkers - farm workers

Tweet: If my coreligionists, let's say religion XYZ, was seen everyday, everywhere, as perpetrators of massacres and other inhuman brutality, and here in the US I went about displaying all the outward signs that I am proud of my religion no matter what, it is all but natural and logical that other people not belonging to my religion, XYZ, will look askance at me, even possibly hate me and harm me. This is not rocket science - why do the hijab-wearers find it so difficult to understand? I have often seen immigrant women, possibly from Ghana, Nigeria, etc., go about in very colorful non-western dresses and I almost always admire them. And I believe most people admire these colorfully-dressed people even though they are obviously non-Caucasian immigrants from Africa. And the reason is simple: when we see these different-looking people, we do not immediately associate them with some sub-human brutes in other parts of the world. Tweet: These are good points, but in our current climate they remain academic. Duty to protect statutes are a first step, but they are only as good as the individuals who enforce them. Mental health agencies could launch public awareness campaigns to teach communities about warning signs, but that costs money. Add to this the fact that mental illness still carries a huge stigma, making it unlikely that young people will seek the right kind of help. College campuses are also ill-equipped or unwilling to address serious issues on their campuses. It all adds up to a ticking time bomb. As long as the mentally ill and those who treat them are marginalized, we can't expect to make much headway with regard to prevention.

Tweet: Mr. Kornbluth asserts that CIA agents are dedicated individuals whose only goal is to serve and defend the country. That statement is as empty as a whiskey barrel at an Appalachian stomp festival. How does one serve the country? Do you serve the country by violating its fundamental principles with torture, even if it yields, which it didn't, helpful information? Are you defending the country by inciting terrorist groups who use your crimes as recruiting tools? The CIA missed the collapse of the Soviet Union. It missed the 9/11 attack; it led us into a war with Iraq by supporting false intelligence; it missed the upheavals in Egypt, Libya and Syria. In the end, it is probably true that the CIA has the interests of the country as their objective. The question is: How do they define those interests? It seems very clear their definition is consistent with the Barry Goldwater/ Neocons/Dick Cheney dictum: Excess in defense of liberty is no vice. And this, of course, profoundly and utterly misses the point.
Wiki: in the document, the author criticizes the claim that cia agents are dedicated individuals whose sole purpose is to serve and defend the country. they argue that this statement is meaningless and questions how one can truly serve the country. they point out that actions like torture and inciting terrorist groups only harm the country's fundamental principles and security. the document also highlights the failures of the cia, such as missing the collapse of the soviet union and the 9/11 attack, as well as supporting false intelligence in the iraq war and missing upheavals in other countries. the author suggests that the cia's definition of the country's interests aligns with a belief in excessive defense of liberty, which they believe misses the true purpose of defending the nation. the cia stands for the central intelligence agency, and the author references barry goldwater, neocons, and dick cheney, who are all political figures.

Tweet: The Stanford study revealed many issues. Having read newspaper articles about it ,brought me to the conclusion like many issues we pursue with herd mentality, Organic products may have just been a good marketing scheme. I kind of compare it to Drug manufacture advertising, after FDA approval, as if we all of a sudden we have a simple solution to complex problems. Drugs like organic produce, usually turn out to be questionable. Both cattle and humans are full of Antibiotics, problem is we consume meat from cattle. If feed lots don't protect cattle from disease they would cost us more as many would be sick and bring less profit when butchered. Point is Organic food is all about making money. Few people have the space or time to grow anything. We delegate those duties to corporate farming so it shows up nicely packaged at the supermarket with a label few can understand. I found people were not fooled by organic foods and drug raised cattle and chickens just confused many times.
Wiki:
the document discusses the findings of a stanford study on organic food and highlights the issues associated with it. the author believes that, like many other trends, the popularity of organic products is driven by herd mentality and good marketing. they also compare the promotion of organic products to the advertising of drugs after fda approval, suggesting that both may not always live up to their claims. additionally, the document points out that both cattle and humans are exposed to antibiotics, raising concerns about the health implications of consuming meat from these animals. the author also expresses skepticism about the authenticity of organic food, suggesting that it is primarily a profit-making venture. the document concludes that people are not easily misled by organic food and are often confused by the practices of raising cattle and chickens for consumption.

Tweet: Due respect to my colleague in academia, no one who frequents RMP would ever mistake it for a venue for constructive criticism. It serves mainly as a venting outlet for unprepared or underperforming students looking to punish their professors for actually enforcing standards - something many of them are experiencing for the first time in college, as K-12 muddles deadlines, caves to parent tantrums and teaches only to multiple-choice tests. Tweet: I teach college students. I am rated. I don't mind at all. In fact, when I was going to grad school, I checked the ratings, and even added my own rating of especially good profs. Students actually do know who is a good teacher and who is not. It's not always who gives the easy A. Those teachers are often dismissed just as easily. The teachers who are valued are still -- even now -- the ones who actually teach and stretch the minds and abilities of students. These will alway be considered the best teachers. Always. Students are not as clueless as you may think.
Wiki: the document discusses how as a college teacher, the author is rated by their students, and they are not bothered by it at all. in fact, the author believes that students can accurately determine who is a good teacher and who is not, and it is not always based on who gives easy a grades. the teachers who are valued and considered the best are the ones who actually teach and challenge their students. the author also mentions that they used online rating systems when they were in graduate school and even rated their particularly good professors. additionally, the author asserts that students are not as clueless as some may think when it comes to evaluating their teachers. they often dismiss teachers who give easy a grades and value the ones who stretch their minds and abilities.

Tweet: William Donovan-head of the OSS during WWII, which was the predecessor to the CIA, had doubts about continuing the agency in peacetime. he was right. one of the problems with the CIA's covert activities is that they are usually only covert to the American people. those on the receiving end of these activities know perfectly well what is going on. the American people had no idea that the CIA was overthrowing the elected govt of iran in 1953, but the Iranians knew it. when there is blowback the American public's reaction is-why do they hate us. we didn't do anything to them
Wiki:
the document discusses how william donovan, who was the head of the office of strategic services (oss) during world war ii, had concerns about continuing the agency in peacetime. the oss was the predecessor to the central intelligence agency (cia). the document suggests that donovan's doubts were justified, as one of the problems with the cia's covert activities is that they are usually only covert to the american people. those on the receiving end of these activities are often aware of what is going on.

the document also mentions that the american people were unaware of the cia's involvement in overthrowing the elected government of iran in 1953, while the iranians were well aware of it. it suggests that this lack of transparency can lead to blowback, and that the american public's reaction to blowback is often confusion, such as asking "why do they hate us?" and claiming "we didn't do anything to them."

the abbreviations and slang used in the document include: 

- oss

Tweet: Unpaid internships=unpaid, period. They only benefit rich kiddies whose parents can pay their way, and squeeze out other people. When I was in law school, I was offered an "unpaid internship" at a large quasi-governmental agency. The train fare alone out to Virginia each day would have cost me $7.50 each day each way roundtrip, and I wouldn't even get reimbursed for that. When I had to turn them down, I got chided for "throwing away a great learning opportunity." Zoom fast forward to the dotcom days, where I had to compete against "unpaid interns" (usually heavily tattooed/pierced partners of others in the firms). Cleaning up their messes was always a treat...NOT. Tweet: Unpaid internships=unpaid, period. They only benefit rich kiddies whose parents can pay their way, and squeeze out other people. When I was in law school, I was offered an "unpaid internship" at a large quasi-governmental agency. The train fare alone out to Virginia each day would have cost me $7.50 each day each way roundtrip, and I wouldn't even get reimbursed for that. When I had to turn them down, I got chided for "throwing away a great learning opportunity." Zoom fast forward to the dotcom days, where I had to compete against "unpaid interns" (usually heavily tattooed/pierced partners of others in the firms). Cleaning up their messes was always a treat...NOT. The ONLY internships that should be allowed are those that are done for real academic credit at an accredited university, with hours that take the student's class into account. Everything else is just exploitation.
Wiki:
the document expresses the view that unpaid internships only benefit wealthy individuals whose parents can financially support them and unfairly disadvantage others. the author recounts personal experiences of being unable to afford the costs associated with an unpaid internship, and of having to compete against unpaid interns who were not contributing positively to the workplace. the author argues that the only acceptable internships are those that offer real academic credit at an accredited university and take into account the student's class schedule. the document emphasizes that any other type of internship is exploitative and should not be allowed.

abbreviations, slang and hashtags:
- 'kiddies' = young individuals
- 'dotcom days' = the period of time when internet-based businesses were booming
- 'not' = used to emphasize a negative statement
- 'zoom fast forward' = an expression indicating a sudden shift in time or perspective

Tweet: Sorry, I'd feel uneasy if I had to use my real name for EVERYTHING online. People could find me fairly easily, maybe even track me down at work. Tweet: As a former psychologist and career counselor, I am interested in encouraging forms of expression that reinforce good mental health. On line commenting has been over taken, sabotaged, and abused with a high percentage of mentally unhealthy abusive speech. This one negative aspect is significant enough to justify abolishing commenting. This unhealthy behavior does not serve as a safety valve but rather encourages self destructive ruminating that can explode in violence. Time to bite the bullet and give up on both moderated and unmoderated online comments!
Wiki:
the document suggests that online commenting has become overrun with abusive and unhealthy speech, leading to negative effects on mental health. the author, as a former psychologist and career counselor, is advocating for the abolishment of commenting altogether due to its detrimental impact on mental well-being. the document proposes that online commenting does not serve as a safety valve but rather encourages self-destructive ruminating which can potentially lead to violence. therefore, the suggestion is to give up on both moderated and unmoderated online comments.

the document refers to online commenting as 'online commenting' and uses phrases like 'mentally unhealthy abusive speech' instead of abbreviations or slang. there are no hashtags in the document.

Tweet: Until recently I was a frequent contributor to the comment section of my local newspaper. When I began contributing I had hoped for intelligent and meaningful discussion and debate concerning the subject. What I had found was a medium consisting of contributors who, by appearances, thrive on belittling and disparaging attacks on those who don't share their beliefs. After a few years, I removed my profiles due to the increasing belittlement and disparagement of posters who may disagree with ones opinion. These forums appear, to me, nothing more than an electronic school yard full of anonymous bullies who have little to offer to any debate or discussion. I welcome the moderation the NY Times offers the readers and contributors to the online comments. Regards, Dan
Wiki:
the author used to be a frequent contributor to the comment section of their local newspaper, hoping for intelligent and meaningful discussion. however, they found that the contributors were more interested in belittling and disparaging others who didn't share their beliefs. after a few years, they removed their profiles due to the increasing negativity. they view these forums as nothing more than an electronic schoolyard full of anonymous bullies. they appreciate the moderation provided by the ny times for their online comments. regards, dan.

expanded: until recently, i was a frequent contributor to the comment section of my local newspaper. when i began contributing, i had hoped for intelligent and meaningful discussion and debate concerning the subject. what i had found was a medium consisting of contributors who, by appearances, thrive on belittling and disparaging attacks on those who don't share their beliefs. after a few years, i removed my profiles due to the increasing belittlement and disparagement of posters who may disagree with one's opinion.

Tweet: Yes. That is what I think most women want. Personally, I can easily adapt to a man's appearance, be he a well-coiffed girly man or a gorilla guy. Who cares? It's not how he looks but how he treats me that really matters. To me, real manliness is a guy who takes responsibility, who supports and protects his wife and children, who stands up for others, who does the right thing in the face of difficulties, who doesn't whine and complain about his life but instead carries on with dignity and compassion for others....someone who walks his talk. In other words ... he has a code.
Wiki:
the document indicates that modern women are looking for a man who treats them well and takes responsibility. the appearance of a man is not important to most women, but his behavior and treatment towards his partner and others is. a real man, according to the document, is someone who supports and protects his family, stands up for others, does the right thing in difficult situations, and carries himself with dignity and compassion for others. this idea of "real manliness" includes having a code of behavior. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- be he a well-coiffed girly man or a gorilla guy = whether he is a well-groomed effeminate man or a very masculine man
- real manliness is a guy who takes responsibility = being a real man means taking responsibility
- who stands up for others = who defends and supports others
- who doesn't whine and complain = who doesn't complain and express dissatisfaction
- someone who walks his talk

Tweet: Obviously i am not using my legal name. I only comment on the NY Times which supposedly is moderated. I did at one time use my real name with no problems. One day, however, a man said "I would like to break your arm" in response to my comment. How that comment slipped through i have no idea. I decided it would be smart to drop my name and start over. There are enough nuts out there as it is and i don't want to be hassled online or even receive a visitor who wanted to "deal with me." I live alone and i just feel better doing this. Besides, i kind of like my "new" name.
Wiki:
the document is about a person who used to comment on the ny times website using their real name, but received a threatening comment in response. they decided to start using a different name to protect themselves from potential harassment. the person feels safer and more comfortable using their new name. 

abbreviations/slang/hashtags expanded: 
- ny times: the new york times
- i: i
- won't: would not
- hassled: harassed
- hashtag: # 
- "deal with me": confront me or take action against me

Tweet: Another false corporate effort, like the bleats from the oil companies about how much they spend (sic) to save the environment or the periodic efforts of fast food chains to convince us they have healthy menus for us before they turn around in the next advertising cycle and again propose we eat cheese, bacon and grease/fat sandwiches. Blame refrigerators/freezers that allow us to buy and store all the junk purveyed. When people ate day to day they didn't gobble down so much. Half of our burgeoning national medical bill is sourced to the diseases of obesity. Eat up, America!
Wiki:
the document criticizes the false corporate efforts of oil companies and fast food chains to save the environment and promote healthy menus. it blames refrigerators and freezers for allowing people to buy and store unhealthy junk food. the document also points out that obesity-related diseases are responsible for half of the national medical bill. the message is a warning against overconsumption of fast food and unhealthy food choices in america.

Tweet: Do we need libraries? I'm shocked that such a question is being asked at all. There has never been a time when the library is more relevant and in demand. Internet, digital books, multi-media com, culture, meeting point, making friends, quiet haven, working corner, coffee breaks, workshops, forums, seminars, newspaper and magazine reading, fiction collection, etc etc. In fact I would venture to suggest that the library should be open 24/7. A well-designed library should be the HUB of every city, no less.
Wiki:
the document asserts that libraries are highly relevant and in demand, and that there has never been a time when they are more necessary. it emphasizes the various functions of libraries, such as providing access to the internet, digital books, and multimedia, as well as serving as a cultural and social meeting place. it also suggests that libraries should be open 24/7 and be the central hub of every city.

the document expands the abbreviation 'etc' into 'etcetera', slang such as 'com' into 'communication', and 'coffee breaks' into 'designated breaks for coffee'. it also expands the hashtag '#libraries' into 'hashtag libraries' and 'hub' into 'central gathering point'.

Tweet: I recall when 15 Muslim girls were burned to death in a fire in their school in Mecca. A pox on all of them.

Tweet: Thank you, Mr Johnson. I would remind people that "New Does Not Equal Better." People often make the mistake of assuming everything that is new is better. In fact, we can think of many new things that are worse at the deepest levels on out souls: chain stores, etc. And late 19th Century architecture, for example of the Belle Epoque, is unspeakably superior to architecture put out by the reprehensible "starchitects" of today. And one need only look to the universally hopeless and laughable car designs of the 21st Century to realize that cars of the 1960s and 1950s, designed by our "uncool" fathers and grandfathers and great grandfathers, were far superior and "cooler" than those designed by people today who think they are so cool. There is a movement in this civilization towards degradation of the soul, propagated by the 21st Century American corporation, which has been described as having emptiness and degradation at its heart. If publishing loses to Amazon, this will be another manifestation of the reality of the current march towards a world of aesthetic, and therefore spiritual, degradation. That is a future we have to look forward to.
Wiki:
the document "thank you, mr johnson" warns people not to automatically assume that new things are better. it argues that some new things, like chain stores and modern architecture, are actually worse at a deep level. the document criticizes the 21st century car designs, saying that cars from the 1960s and 1950s were superior. it also claims that there is a movement towards degradation of the soul, driven by 21st century american corporations, and warns that if publishing loses to amazon, it will contribute to a world of aesthetic and spiritual degradation. 

abbreviations/slang/hashtags expanded: 
- etc. => et cetera
- belle epoque => a period in european history that is typically dated as starting in 1871 and ending when the first world war began in 1914.
- starchitects => slang for a famous and influential architect
- "uncool" => not considered popular or fashionable
- 21

Tweet: In previous times the Virginia High School League did not let black high school students play sports. Tweet: The dirty little secret is that health care providers have consolidated since the ACA was passed. There is less competition for service and the idea that the government or an insurance company can dictate the fees to a handful of competent providers is failing even for the private option called Medicare, Medicaid, Indian health and the VA. Not only do we have less competent providers, many of them will no longer accept Medicare payments.
Wiki: the document discusses how the healthcare industry has consolidated since the passage of the affordable care act (aca), resulting in less competition for services. it also highlights the failing ability of the government or insurance companies to dictate fees to a limited number of competent providers, especially for programs like medicare, medicaid, indian health, and the va. the document also mentions a decrease in competent providers and a growing number of them refusing to accept medicare payments. this suggests that obamacare has led to a decline in competition and competent healthcare providers, particularly for government healthcare programs.

Tweet: For every dollar the state of So Carolina gained from video poker revenues we spent a minimum of four dollars cleaning up the mess it left behind. Some of the messes I witnessed as both a Mental Health counselor and an Addictions counselor: A client going through a $26,000 dollar inheritance in one weekend. An untold number of families whose only paycheck was blown the same day its owner was paid. An infant left in a car in July for hours by his mother while she played video poker, oblivious to the passing of time. The infant died. Two enterprising young men crowing about the $7,000 jackpot they won after putting twice that much in the machine. (The crack addict, at least has something material in his hand, momentarily anyway, when he blows his wad.). The question isn't about individual liberty. It's about the material and spiritual costs to a community when it chooses to go this route. Do we really want to sully out souls by being a part of this?

Tweet: The problem that I'm having at this moment is that there is a saying, "those that control the vote controls the election." So, if you control the vote,you control the election, and if you control the blog and the comment section more than likely you control the final thought process .

Tweet: And here we all thought the trick of citizenship was to be born in the United States. Instead it appears the constitution and its amendments appear to be more like Alice in Wonderland where words are never stable but mean what the master wants them to mean, in this case the master would be the Supreme Court and behind them the supreme court of public opinion.
Wiki: the document highlights the perception that birthright citizenship, the principle that a person is a citizen of the country in which they were born, is not as straightforward as commonly believed. it suggests that the interpretation of the constitution and its amendments is subjective and can change based on the supreme court's discretion and public opinion. the comparison to alice in wonderland implies that the meaning of legal terms is unstable and can be manipulated to fit the prevailing attitudes. in this context, birthright citizenship is not a guaranteed right but rather a concept subject to reevaluation and reinterpretation.

Tweet: There are layers upon layers of sports organizations that accommodate home schooled kids - high school varsity should not be one of them. These kids have the opportunity to compete athletically in local recreation leagues, travel teams, AAU teams, and elite regional teams. High school sports should be about building athletic excellence and also about developing a sense of pride and comraderie in a placef that's that's truly the center of their existence for 4 short years. After all, should we then allow kids in private schools, boarding schools, or local religious schools to compete for varsity spots in their local public school? After they all pay taxes, but what do the school colors really mean to them?
Wiki: the document argues that home-schooled kids should not be allowed to participate in high school varsity sports. instead, they have many other opportunities to compete in athletic activities such as local recreation leagues, travel teams, aau teams, and elite regional teams. high school sports are meant to focus on building athletic excellence and creating a sense of pride and camaraderie within the school. the document also questions whether allowing kids from private, boarding, or religious schools to compete for varsity spots in public schools is fair. it raises the point that all these students pay taxes, but may not have the same connection to the school as those who attend it. therefore, the document argues that home-schooled kids should not be allowed to compete in high school varsity sports. (aau stands for amateur athletic union)

Tweet: This is my fifth read pertaining to this article and I will give credit to Schlossman for having the most mature and evolved view. Lets not forget the man of yesterday was less likely to help out in the house with regards to children and chores (a 70 to 90 hour a week job if left solely to women). To wish for the man of yesterday is myopic - times have changed and the having the costume of a man does not equal being more responsible and courageous. Schlossman states to just be "...honest, kind, tolerant, open, intrepid, self-aware, inquisitive, etc..." - that works for me and for societies sake, should work for everyone else too.
Wiki:
the document discusses the changing role of men in society. the author praises schlossman for having a mature and evolved view on the topic. they argue that the traditional idea of a man, who was less likely to help with household chores and childcare, is outdated. the author believes that simply adopting the outward appearance of a man does not make someone responsible or courageous. they agree with schlossman's advice to be honest, kind, tolerant, open, intrepid, self-aware, and inquisitive. they believe these qualities are important for everyone in society. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- "pertainig" = pertaining
- "70 to 90 hour a week job" = a job that requires 70 to 90 hours of work per week
- "myopic" = short-sighted or narrow-minded
- "etc..." = et cetera, meaning "and so on"
- "works for me" = is suitable for me

Tweet: Why exactly should the government be responsible for "creat[ing] genuine opportunity for millions of rural people"? People who live in rural areas are entitled to the same welfare and food stamp benefits as people in cities. There are certainly areas of deep poverty in rural areas, but why single these areas out for special treatment? Furthermore, I wonder if "genuine opportunity" will ever exist in many sparsely populated areas. What sorts of opportunity would you recommend? Cities exist for a reason; they allow people to gather so that commerce can occur. Unless everyone in rural America intends to rely solely on farming, I fail to see much possibility for economic opportunities. The government should not subsidize a system that is fundamentally unworkable and that will always be dependent on such subsidies for survival.
Wiki:
the document questions the government's responsibility for creating genuine opportunities for rural people. it criticizes the idea of providing special treatment to rural areas, stating that people in rural areas are entitled to the same welfare and food stamp benefits as those in cities. it expresses doubt about the possibility of genuine opportunity in sparsely populated areas and suggests that economic opportunities are limited in rural america, apart from farming. the author believes that the government should not subsidize a system that is fundamentally unworkable and will always be dependent on subsidies for survival. the document also questions what sorts of opportunities would be recommended for rural areas. it emphasizes the importance of cities in allowing commerce to occur and suggests that people in rural america should not rely solely on farming. finally, it wonders whether genuine opportunity will ever exist in many rural areas. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded into complete phrases and sentences:
- "welfare" expanded to "government assistance programs for those in need"
- "genuine opportunity"

Tweet: I am against the practice, however outlawing it, I can't agree. I've clipped cats claws for years and trained all my cats to avoid the furniture. However, my Mom's pet was declawed at the advice of our Vet. This cat would scratched his face and nick his eye. I sucessfully healed four very bad eye ulcers. So bad the vet didn't expect us to get them healed. Before he injured his one of his eye's to the point of it being removed, the vet recommend we declaw him. Outlaw it and you remove options for good pet owners with highly unusual situations.
Wiki:
the document shares the perspective of someone who is against the practice of declawing cats but does not support outlawing it. the writer has successfully trained their cats to avoid furniture by clipping their claws, but their mother's cat had to be declawed because he was scratching his face and eye, leading to serious ulcers. the vet recommended declawing as a last resort before the cat's eye had to be removed. the writer argues that outlawing declawing would remove options for good pet owners in highly unusual situations.

Tweet: There seems to be that general misunderstanding that Germany wants to lead Europe. Most Germans want Germany to be a big Switzerland and to be left alone (maybe together with the actual Switzerland), and not to be invaded by Russia, or France, or the UK. The EU is a project of the intellectual left, who believes in international unity, and of the political classes who see it as a chance to enlarge their influence and their job pool.
Wiki: the document suggests that there is a common misconception that germany wants to take the lead in europe. however, most germans actually want germany to be like a large version of switzerland, remaining neutral and not being invaded by russia, france, or the uk. the european union (eu) is seen as a project of the intellectual left, who believe in international unity, and the political classes, who view it as an opportunity to expand their influence and job opportunities.

Tweet: Exactly a month after JFK was assassinated, Harry Truman wrote an op-ed in the Post stating that had he known the shenanigans the CIA were going to pull, instead of simply providing information to the President, he never would have signed it into law. (Allen Dulles had the piece pulled after the morning edition.)
Wiki: in the document, it states that harry truman wrote an op-ed in the post a month after jfk was assassinated, expressing his regret for signing the law that created the central intelligence agency (cia). he stated that if he had known about the questionable actions the cia would take, instead of solely providing information to the president, he would never have approved the legislation. the op-ed was pulled by allen dulles after the morning edition. cia stands for central intelligence agency.

Tweet: I once got a summer job near the House of Seven Gables, in Salem, in the hall of records, deciphering and keying in old deed books, from the 1700's. At the end of the summer, they threw away my work, because no one had the patience to read ancient cursive and copy it, when they realized they could instead just scan. Cursive writing, through most of history, was very far removed from your beautiful, cherished, letters. It was used by underpaid recorders, of other people's transactions. The novelty of the letter 's' written as 'f', etc., wears off quickly. However, Kate Gladstone's arguments for teaching children to read cursive, and to write hybrid, which takes little time, can confer big benefits later in life. Those who have gone through these steps learn better how to summarize, as they take notes, even if eventually on only keyboards. A side benefit is that they can appreciate cursive, and the history it sometimes cradles.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of teaching children to read cursive and write hybrid, which can bring big benefits later in life. the author shares their experience of working in the hall of records, deciphering old deed books from the 1700's, only to have their work discarded when scanning became a more efficient option. the author argues that learning cursive can help students learn how to summarize and take notes, even if they eventually only use keyboards. another benefit is that it can help students appreciate cursive and the history it holds.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- 'etc.': "et cetera"
- 'f': "the letter 's' written as 'f'"
- 'salem': "in salem"
- 'kate gladstone's': "kate gladstone's arguments"
- 'keyboard': "on only keyboards"
- '#cursive': "hashtag cursive"

Tweet: The average woman on Planet Earth is not a white European North American. Women in Africa, Indo-Pacific, Asia, Central and South America are being very fertile and fruitful. With a billion humans lacking access to clean fresh drinking water, another billion persons not having sanitary sewage waste disposal and 800 million persons starving or malnourished there are more of us than ever before and we are living longer than ever. Infectious diseases still work to limit population growth. As animal predation and killing on and of humans fades, war has become less deadly in absolute and relative numbers.
Wiki:

Tweet: It would be much easier to dismantle or close down the C.I.A. instead of reforming a humongous bureaucratic para-military-intelligence organization that has lost its basic mission statement. That is, collect and analyze material/information from foreign countries, friends or foes, and provide the political leadership with useful intelligence material to defend and protect the national security of the United States. The CIA involved in war crimes and torture comes at no surprise to any person over 40 living in Africa, Asia and Latin America. During the cold war, the agency was the main instrument of foreign policy used by the White House to destabilize unfriendly third world governments or fight proxy wars against the Soviet Union. Torture techniques were honed during that time. What to do with the CIA? downsize that humongous dysfunctional organization, retrain its personnel to do real intelligence data collection to protect the national security of the US. That is all.
Wiki:
this document suggests that it would be easier to dismantle or close down the central intelligence agency (cia) rather than trying to reform it. the cia has lost its original purpose of collecting and analyzing information from foreign countries to defend and protect the national security of the united states. the document also mentions that the cia has been involved in war crimes and torture, particularly during the cold war when it was used to destabilize unfriendly governments and fight proxy wars against the soviet union. the suggestion is to downsize the organization and retrain its personnel to focus on real intelligence data collection for national security. 

expand:
cia - central intelligence agency
#cia - hashtag for central intelligence agency

Tweet: My company pays interns $10 an hour, and they often are required to do very menial work. That said, interns who show eagerness and promise may be offered full time positions with the company. For-profit companies should absolutely pay their interns. The small investment is an incredible bargain when you consider it a screening tool for potential employees. Several full-time members of my department started out as interns. I can say from experience that it's a far better screening tool than a job interview, and worth every penny. I think unpaid internships are fine, but in limited circumstances--for example, if the student is still in college and can get academic credit. In this case, though, you'd want to make sure that the student is getting training and is not forced to do menial tasks. I had some internships like this in college and they were very beneficial. I also think that non-profit organizations should be able to offer limited unpaid internships. In all other circumstances, internships should be paid, and interns should at least receive minimum wage. If for-profit organizations can hire unpaid interns, there's too much potential for abuse.
Wiki:
the document suggests that for-profit companies should definitely pay their interns, as it is a great investment as a screening tool for potential employees. it also mentions that unpaid internships may be acceptable in limited circumstances, such as when the student is still in college and can receive academic credit. in these cases, it's important to ensure that the student is receiving training and not being forced to do menial tasks. the document also suggests that non-profit organizations should be allowed to offer limited unpaid internships. however, in all other circumstances, internships should be paid and interns should receive at least minimum wage to avoid the potential for abuse. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- $10 an hour
- full time positions
- for-profit companies 
- minimum wage

Tweet: My company pays interns $10 an hour, and they often are required to do very menial work. That said, interns who show eagerness and promise may be offered full time positions with the company. For-profit companies should absolutely pay their interns. The small investment is an incredible bargain when you consider it a screening tool for potential employees. Several full-time members of my department started out as interns. I can say from experience that it's a far better screening tool than a job interview, and worth every penny. I think unpaid internships are fine, but in limited circumstances--for example, if the student is still in college and can get academic credit. In this case, though, you'd want to make sure that the student is getting training and is not forced to do menial tasks. I had some internships like this in college and they were very beneficial. I also think that non-profit organizations should be able to offer limited unpaid internships. In all other circumstances, internships should be paid, and interns should at least receive minimum wage. If for-profit organizations can hire unpaid interns, there's too much potential for abuse.
Wiki:
the document advocates for paid internships, stating that for-profit companies should absolutely pay their interns. it highlights the value of paid internships as a screening tool for potential employees, citing examples of interns who were eventually offered full-time positions. the author also acknowledges the potential benefit of unpaid internships in limited circumstances, such as for college credit or at non-profit organizations. however, they emphasize that in all other cases, interns should be paid at least minimum wage to prevent potential abuse. the author also mentions their personal experience with internships, stating that some were very beneficial, but also noting that interns should not be forced to do menial tasks in unpaid positions. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- the abbreviation 'interns' is expanded to 'interns'

Tweet: I love libraries! They are a great place to just hang out and be in touch with history and knowledge of the present and past. Often they offer classes and lectures and great places to study. And, sometimes the librarians are real cute as well! I use them differently today than in the past, however. I actually belong to several libraries now as a full time RVer so that I can access books on my Kindle. Yes! That most remarkable Amazon device that has allowed me to build my own library with nearly 1000 mostly free books in my Kindle Fire. At age 76, I look upon this as my personal treasury, a repositary of the wisdom of the ages. In summary, I think it's great that we have physical libraries as well as devices like the Kindle that allow us to access books from anywhere on the globe with relative ease. It's great that libraries have adapted and made changes in this computer age that benefit their surrounding communty. Bravo to libraries and librarians!
Wiki:
the document expresses a deep appreciation for libraries as a great place to be in touch with history and knowledge, offering classes, lectures, and a great place to study. the writer, a 76-year-old full-time rver, belongs to several libraries in order to access books on their kindle and has built their own library with nearly 1000 mostly free books. they view their kindle as a personal treasury, a repository of wisdom. the writer praises the adaptation of libraries to the digital age and the benefits it brings to the community. they express gratitude towards libraries and librarians.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- rver = recreational vehicle traveler
- kindle = amazon e-reader device
- kindle fire = amazon tablet device
- bravo = an expression of approval or praise
- #libraries #knowledge #community #adaptation #wisdom

Tweet: The books, the computers, the storytimes, even the staff expertise are only elements of the emerging (or, more properly, continuing) role of the public library. The library is a community focal point and a community development agency. For decades, my colleagues in the field rode the wrong bus. Libraries and librarians sold themselves as information agents. Then we were blindsided by the development of do-it-yourself information tools. We forgot that our mandate is broader -- much broader -- than information. We are a place where people gather to connect to other people, to culture, to information, to works of art and works of the imagination. From an individual's perspective, that's enriching. From a community's perspective that's vital to the sustenance of vitality and diversity in the polity.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes that the public library is not just a place for books and computers, but also a community focal point and a community development agency. it points out that libraries and librarians have, in the past, focused on selling themselves as information agents, but their role is actually much broader than just providing information. they are a place where people gather to connect with others, culture, information, and works of art and imagination. from an individual's perspective, this is enriching, and from a community's perspective, it is vital for the sustenance of vitality and diversity in the community.

#publiclibrary #communitydevelopmentagency #culture #communityfocalpoint
#informationagents #diyinformationtools #connection #communityvitality

Tweet: This entire conversation gives me heartburn. I am a college teacher who, yes, has entries on Rate My Professor and who works for a college that overtly cites the website when lauding the success of its best teachers. So I pay attention to the public discussions of student evaluations. The heartburn comes not from fear that my rating index is too low but rather in the assumptions of both sides. The potential for abuse of these ratings is not based on students unqualified to evaluate their teachers (false, anyone can distinguish a poor product from a quality one) but rather on the methodology of Rate My Professor and other similar sites. As mentioned by at least one commenter, ratings suffer from selection bias and from a failure to use common terms. Those with strong opinions for or against are more likely to evaluate an instructor and what raters see as strict or smart or easy or dumb is so subjective that any two raters may have opposite definitions of the same word used in a rating. Not a good combination: an unrepresentative sample using uncommon terms to rate a product.
Wiki:
the document discusses the concerns of a college teacher regarding the use of student evaluations on rate my professor and similar websites. the teacher is worried about the potential for abuse of these ratings due to selection bias and the use of subjective and uncommon terms. they believe that the ratings do not accurately represent the quality of teaching and are not a reliable measure. the teacher also mentions that their college uses the website to praise its best teachers, which adds to their discomfort with the system.

expansion of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

- yes: affirmative
- unqualified: not having the necessary skills or knowledge
- raters: individuals who evaluate
- common terms: words or phrases that are widely understood
- selection bias: the tendency of certain types of people to be more likely to participate in a study or evaluation
- hashtags: a word or phrase preceded by the pound sign, used on social media to identify messages on a specific topic

Tweet: After the cold war we reduced the number of agents, and the presence of the CIA. Tweet: Like most people my age, I was taught to write in cursive, and like most people today, I don't use it much. Tweet: How about children who live in the district but attend private schools? Should they be allowed to play? What if their private school doesn't have a football team, or they don't make the team? Should home-schooled children get to participate in the spelling bee, robotics club, science olympiad? in Michigan, public schools receive a certain amount of money for each child who enrolls, not a lump sum based on how many parents pay taxes. Tweet: "The Obama administration has only itself to blame for this mess - jamming the bill through Congress and ignoring warnings of these predictably disastrous results." Hah! Tweet: The author, in her zeal to protect the insurance companies from public wrath, has just made a splendid argument for Medicare for All. The Obama administration, naive in the extreme, though it had bought the support of Mark Bertolini and the other captains of the health insurance industry, when it had only rented them for a limited time. Now Mr. Bertolini, having failed in his effort to extort from the Justice Department a decision not to do its duty and raise anti-trust objections to AETNA's effort to create, through merger, a non-competitive insurance market, has taken his revenge on the American people. In view of the number of mergers sought and suspiciously similar requests for increases in ACA health care costs, perhaps the Justice Department should initiate an investigation of price fixing and collusion among health insurance companies. The writer, who fails to address the anti-trust issue, appears to favor Repeal and Don't Replace. How about "Are There No Poor Houses?" (Dickens)

Tweet: Besides agreeing with many of the critical comments here, I woul dadd that a fundamental problem is that the ratings never seem to go away--a bad rating in 2005 or 2007 is stiil there in 2015, though it may no longer have any relevance--either because the teacher has improved or simply moved on--and some of the comments can be very personal and stinging, bad enough in the short term but sickening to see present 10 years after the fact of teh class. Tweet: The status quo ante prior to Obamacare was that healthcare was a complete perversion of the free market and open competition. This country allowed insurance companies to corner the market on healthcare via insurance, to price medical treatment beyond the range of any individual to pay without insurance, and therefore to deny care and coverage to anyone with impunity. Obama has restored the balance by taking away the insurance companies' ability to block consumers from receiving medical care. He did it without the social violence that, by rights, should have accompanied such a revolutionary change. Obama actually initiated a return of healthcare to a free market, competitive status. But it required an acknowledgement that basic healthcare is a right that cannot be abridged.
Wiki:
the document argues that before the affordable care act (obamacare), the healthcare system in the united states was a distortion of the free market and open competition. insurance companies had a monopoly on healthcare, setting high prices that made medical treatment unaffordable for many people without insurance. as a result, they could deny care and coverage to individuals without consequences. according to the document, obama addressed this imbalance by preventing insurance companies from blocking consumers from accessing medical care. this change, it states, was revolutionary but was implemented without social unrest. the document contends that obama's actions have helped to bring healthcare back to a fair and competitive market. it also argues that obama's reforms acknowledge that basic healthcare is a right that cannot be infringed upon.

expand abbreviations and slang:
- obamacare: the affordable care act 
- #healthcare: healthcare
- 'obamacare': the affordable care act

expand hashtags:
- #healthcare: healthcare

Tweet: No one knows whether a "real-looking" name on a comment is authentic, nor do they agree on even what makes a name "real-looking". Furthermore, there is actually very little agreement on whether an idea is offensive merely because of the way it is expressed, or whether certain ideas should be considered so offensive that they may never be expressed in even the most cultivated verbiage. The writer's premise that anonymity produces bad ideas and vulgar expression appears highly doubtful. I submit that the quality of the idea being discussed is the only thing that matters, and that there will never be a consensus on that evaluation. If quality is too low (as in the bulk of what appears on Twitter), individuals are free to consider the idea poor or the manner of expression deficient. Openly airing all ideas still appears preferable to me to confining discourse to speakers who only express the right ideas, and who do so with a prescribed minimum of elegance. It's a superstition, but I'll stick with Justice Brandeis' axiom that "sunshine is the best disinfectant."
Wiki: the document discusses the uncertainty surrounding the authenticity of names in comment sections and the lack of agreement on what makes a name "real-looking". there is also disagreement on whether certain ideas are offensive solely based on their expression, and whether some ideas should never be expressed. the writer doubts that anonymity leads to bad ideas and vulgar expression, and believes that the quality of the idea is the most important factor, though there may never be a consensus on its evaluation. they argue that open discussion of all ideas is preferable to censoring those that may be deemed offensive or lacking in elegance. the writer references justice brandeis' axiom that "sunshine is the best disinfectant" as support for their belief. in addition, the document contains abbreviations and slang such as "i'll" and "the bulk of what appears on twitter", as well as the hashtag "#commentsection", which have been expanded into complete sentences.

Tweet: I find a lot of valuable information in the comments sections on the NYTimes. For the most part, the comments remain civil, and they are worth reading. Some commenters have even built up quite a following for their well-thought-out remarks. My Boston Globe subscription, not so much. The online comments are often vulgar and I usually don't bother reading them. Some of us aren't on social media -- I don't have a facebook or twitter account, and haven't seen the appeal of starting now. So the comment sections are still quite relevant to me!
Wiki: the document discusses the value of comment sections on news websites, specifically the new york times and the boston globe. the author finds valuable information and civil discussion in the comments on the nytimes, and some commenters have gained a following for their thoughtful remarks. however, the boston globe's comment sections are often vulgar and not worth reading. the author also notes that they are not on social media (#facebook, #twitter) and finds the comment sections to be relevant and useful as a non-social media user.

Tweet: Although leaving Euro would be difficult, that seems to be the only way left for Greece. If they don't leave Euro, the ECB will never realize how important it is to maintain a country's infrastructure and tradition. As a currency Euro is a badly conceived currency. It has got the economic power but not the political power or control. As everyone knows, economic power without political power is like putting the cart before the horse. It frustrates everyone and ends up into a blame game. Greece would be wise to leave Euro and implement some what harsher economic policies than what they have got.
Wiki:
the document argues that greece should leave the euro because it is the only way for the european central bank (ecb) to realize the importance of maintaining a country's infrastructure and tradition. the euro is criticized for having economic power but lacking political power or control, leading to frustration and a blame game. the document suggests that greece should implement harsher economic policies if they were to leave the euro.

expanded phrases and sentences:
- ecb: european central bank
- euro: european currency
- harsher economic policies: more stringent economic measures
- blame game: a situation where people shift blame onto each other instead of taking responsibility

Tweet: Reasonable public health measures must not be subjected to religious exemption. The measles problem in California is the direct result of permitting parents to opt out of vaccinations for religious reasons or because of reliance on long-disproved flawed medical studies. A parent should not have the right to insist that their child be permitted to be a potential carrier of a dangerous communicable disease. The other tragedies discussed here--a consequence of effective lobbying by the Christian Science Church--should be within the power of the states to prevent.
Wiki: the document argues that reasonable public health measures should not be open to religious exemption. it points out that the measles problem in california is due to allowing parents to opt out of vaccinations for religious reasons or because of reliance on discredited medical studies. the document asserts that parents should not have the right to insist that their child be allowed to potentially carry a dangerous communicable disease. it also discusses tragedies that have resulted from effective lobbying by the christian science church, and suggests that states should have the power to prevent such occurrences.

Tweet: Let me begin by saying that I grew up in farm country (cash grain - corn/soybeans) and I own farm land and annually receive farm subsidy payments. I would make a few points. First, most of the people who expound about farmers and farming have no idea what they are talking about. Second, I have heard about giant farms who receive huge subsidies all my life, so I presume it must be true, but it simply doesn't exist in the corn/soybean area I am familiar with. Third, there have been dramatic boom/bust cycles in crop prices the past few years, but this has been driven by speculators in the commodities markets, and currency manipulation (China). Fourth, farm products such as corn and soybeans are one of the few items that this country still exports in large amounts, so you had better be careful what you do. Finally, having said that, there has not been a recession in farm country - the farmers are doing quite nicely, and there is no reason that crop payments for corn and soybeans should continue.
Wiki:
the document provides insights about farm subsidies from the perspective of someone who grew up in a farm country and receives annual farm subsidy payments. the author believes that many people who talk about farmers and farming do not understand the reality of the situation. they also argue that the perception of giant farms receiving huge subsidies does not match their experience in the corn and soybean farming area. the author attributes the dramatic boom/bust cycles in crop prices to speculators in the commodities markets and currency manipulation by china. they highlight the importance of farm products like corn and soybeans as major exports for the country and warn against potential consequences of disrupting this trade. finally, the author asserts that despite economic downturns in other sectors, farm country has not experienced a recession and farmers are still doing well, indicating that crop payments for corn and soybeans should continue.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- "cash grain" is clarified as "cash grain farming, particularly corn/soybeans"
- "expound

Tweet: Comments are a useful and frequently informative part of online news; they should be encouraged but much more closely monitored. For openers, commenters should be allowed only one comment per article to avoid these ubiquitous back and forth , witless arguments which often clog the comments section. Obscene, vulgar and personal attacks should be edited out, but care must be exercised. Many subjects almost demand strong comments which some may find offensive, but do not really cross the line. Some are clearly at the far left, right, or some other extreme, but often bring out ignored, but important points of view. In addition, many articles and editorials contain claims that are either wrong or at best distorted, despite usually high standards of editorial review. Comments are essential for correcting these problems. Some blogs, like Prof Juan Cole usually contain thoughtful, informed and useful information. Others seem to call forth the the worst forms of trolls, bullys, idiots and haters. Proper monitoring, I believe can correct the abuses and allow a very important part of the internet to thrive.
Wiki:
the document discusses the value of comments in online news and the need for stricter monitoring. commenters should only be allowed one comment per article to avoid endless arguments. obscene, vulgar, and personal attacks should be removed, but controversial opinions should be allowed as long as they do not cross a certain line. comments are important for correcting misinformation in articles and editorials. some blogs, like those by professor juan cole, offer valuable insights, while others attract negative behavior. the document advocates for proper monitoring to prevent abuse and allow the comment section to thrive.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- prof juan cole: professor juan cole
- trolls: people who intentionally provoke others online
- bullys: individuals who intimidate or mistreat others
- idiots: people who behave foolishly or irresponsibly
- haters: individuals who express strong negativity or resentment
- #'s: hashtags
- prof: professor
- clog: block or congest
- back and forth:

Tweet: The problem is how nasty, vulgar, and hate filled many of those unmoderated comments can be. Until the web provided unfiltered commentary, an editor always moderated publication. What we have in unmoderated commentary is often not the correcting of misstatements, or the expanding of the conversation, but commenters attacking other commenters, hurling insults, changing the subject to beat the commenter's drum. We get lots of Obama hate even when the subject isn't Obama. If we had a culture of common courtesy before this, it's been severely jeopardized by coarse talk in comment sections. We even see that coarseness celebrated now as a good thing.
Wiki:
the document discusses the issue of unmoderated comments in online comment sections. it emphasizes that prior to the internet, editors always moderated publications, but now there is a lack of filtering in online commentary. instead of correcting misstatements or expanding the conversation, commenters often attack each other, hurl insults, and change the subject to promote their own agenda. the document also points out that there is a lot of hate towards obama, even when the topic is not related to him. it also raises concerns about the erosion of common courtesy due to the use of coarse language in comment sections, which is now even celebrated as a good thing.

- # obama - obama
- coarseness - the use of coarse language
- unmoderated - not moderated

- misstatements - incorrect statements

Tweet: What is most disturbing about the troll menace is how a (presumably) small minority of posters can trash an entire thread of discussion. That could never happen in a public square (or Trump rally). So it seems that civic-minded people must not give in to the trolls. Otherwise, we are letting them restrict our freedom to share thoughtful opinion with others. A way must be found to vote out the trolls. For example, comments could be rated by readers as constructive or destructive. The more destructive the rating, the lower that comment falls to the bottom of the heap. Only the thoughtful, constructive posts, as rated by the community of readers, would remain at the top. It could be automated, thus, reducing the cost of hiring moderators. Do others see a flaw in this proposal?
Wiki: the document discusses the problem of trolls in online comment sections, noting that a small minority of posters can disrupt an entire discussion. it suggests that civic-minded individuals should not give in to trolls, as doing so restricts their freedom to share thoughtful opinions. the document proposes a solution of allowing readers to rate comments as constructive or destructive, with more destructive comments falling to the bottom of the thread. this system would prioritize thoughtful, constructive posts, as rated by the community of readers, at the top of the discussion. it also suggests that this process could be automated to reduce the cost of hiring moderators. the document asks if there are flaws in this proposed solution. #trollmenace #publicsquare #trumprally

Tweet: I am fully insured on my own and help finance Obamacare too. And I don't regret. Such obligations are imperative for a civilized society and a nation. These obligations pale in comparision with,( like all citizens do),the benefits, advantages and rights I enjoy at the same time. In fact, what I want is a far less complicated, straight-forward, far more liberal and universally applicable health care system that is at least comparable to what are obtaining presently in France,UK and Scandinavia.I don't mind the personal costs,no one should, I believe.It is the basic minimum that any nation should render to its citizens.And it could prove to be quite cheaper than whatever provided by any insurance company and far more efficient, if wisely administered. Anyway, I personally believe, ofcourse buttressed by my own calculations and ratified by my intellectual friends, that the rich are indeed the free loaders in any society, extracting far higher benefits from it than what they themselves contribute.But they make the maximum noise and grossly distort the reality for denying the middle class and the poor what they richly deserve-- through rational logic and by canons of progressive civilizations.
Wiki: the document expresses support for obamacare and the idea of universal healthcare. the author feels that having mandatory insurance and helping to finance obamacare is necessary for a civilized society. they believe that the benefits and rights they receive from this obligation outweigh the costs. they also advocate for a simpler, more liberal healthcare system that is comparable to those in france, uk, and scandinavia. the author believes that the rich benefit more from society than they contribute, and that they unfairly deny the middle class and poor what they deserve. #obamacare is a program that provides affordable healthcare coverage for all americans.

Tweet: As a former teacher and long-time first grade volunteer in a low income school district, I regularly use the CLEVNET system to get books for our class that compliment our curriculum or that are about subjects in which the kids express interest. We develop a reading list of the books shared each year, and let kids know they have access to them all through our local library. For communities in which books are an unaffordable luxury, libraries level the playing field, giving access to unlimited literary riches to all. In our community, they also provide much needed parenting help through story times and reading activities for caregivers and young children every week. Many families without computers at home get access to the internet at the library for homework help, employment and tax information. While libraries may be redundant for more affluent families, they provide a window into a different present and future for those of lesser means.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of libraries, particularly in low income communities. the author, a former teacher and long-time first grade volunteer, uses the clevnet system to get books for their class that complement the curriculum or align with the children's interests. they create a reading list of the shared books each year and let the kids know they can access them through their local library. the author believes that libraries level the playing field by providing access to unlimited literary resources for everyone, especially in communities where books are unaffordable. additionally, libraries offer parenting help through story times and reading activities for caregivers and young children, as well as access to the internet for families without computers at home for homework help, employment and tax information. the author suggests that while libraries may be seen as unnecessary for more affluent families, they provide an essential resource for those with fewer means.

explanation:
- clevnet: this refers to a library consortium in northeast ohio, where the author likely borrows books from.
- red

Tweet: The penmanship my children (now ages 10 and 13) have been taught in school will suffice. It is neat, efficient and legible. There is no need to require them to become proficient in a second, archaic form of handwriting. Requiring children to learn how to read and write cursive at this point in history seems about as useful as requiring them to learn Fraktur or calligraphy. Once elementary school children have mastered standard penmanship a more effective use of school time would be to provide instruction and practice in using a keyboard.
Wiki:
the document argues that the penmanship taught in schools, which is neat, efficient, and legible, is sufficient for children. it questions the need for learning cursive, calling it archaic and comparing it to learning fraktur or calligraphy. it suggests that once children have mastered standard penmanship, it would be more beneficial for them to learn how to use a keyboard effectively instead. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags used in the document:
- ages 10 and 13: 10-year-old and 13-year-old
- there is no need: there is no necessity
- requiring: making it necessary for
- fraktur: a style of blackletter typeface used in the past
- #keyboard: keyboard use
- #penmanship: the art of writing by hand

Tweet: The top two reasons cats are turned into shelters are house soiling and aggression (biting). It is a well-known fact that declawed cats are deprived of their main form of defense (claws), and resort to biting. Additionally, it is painful for many declawed cats to dig in a litter box. Hence, house soiling. Shelters I have volunteered at have quite a few declawed cats come in due to these reasons, declawing being the source of these issues. Pet owners who want to declaw a cat should not have a cat--period. If you want to protect your furniture, do not own a cat. Cats naturally scratch. If dog owners don't want their animal to jump on their couches or beds, do they remove a dog's leg? If dog owners don't want a dog to bark, is debarking humane? It's the same thing as declawing a cat. Just don't have one.
Wiki: the main reasons why cats are surrendered to shelters are house soiling and aggression, particularly biting. declawed cats often resort to biting as they cannot defend themselves with their claws, leading to these issues. many declawed cats also find it painful to dig in a litter box, which contributes to house soiling. shelters often receive declawed cats for these reasons, which are ultimately the result of declawing. people who want to declaw a cat should not have one at all. if someone wants to protect their furniture, they should not get a cat, as cats naturally scratch. this is similar to removing a dog's leg to prevent it from jumping on furniture, or debarking a dog to stop it from barking. these practices are not humane, just like declawing a cat. it is better to simply not have a cat if someone is considering declawing it.

Tweet: Mr. Perry makes a very reasonable argument, but I think there are very few Spud Webbs out there anymore. Most of the pros are probably a good 6 inches taller than they were even 20 or 25 years ago, let alone 100, so you would think raising the rim is a reasonable alternative. I do appreciate his concern about the amount of time to adjust to the change, but I suspect that really talented and conditioned atheletes will find a way to make it work pretty rapidly.

Tweet: I look forward to reading comments in the NYT's and for the most part, I'm on board and learn from many of the commenters both regular and occasional. On occasion, I've attempted to read comments on other news sites and find that many of them contain back and forth banter for lack of a better word between two people with little input from others. This gets old rather quickly. I choose to read the intelligent and well thought out comments both from the left and right. I do lean more to those comments that lean more to the left. I subscribe to the paper but do check out the editorials and opinion pieces on line just to see what some of my favorite commenters have to say.
Wiki: the author enjoys reading comments in the new york times (nyt) and learns from both regular and occasional commenters. they prefer intelligent and well thought out comments from both the left and right, but lean more towards those that lean to the left. they subscribe to the paper and also check out the editorials and opinion pieces online to see what their favorite commenters have to say. they find that comments on other news sites often contain back and forth banter between two people and little input from others, which they find tiresome.

Tweet: As a restaurant owner & operator the idea of selling reservations is problematic, made only worse by the idea that a third party might me making money from the popularity that a restaurant has generated. But as JJ points out, the public has no problem paying less for dining during less desirable hours, why should they be opposed to paying more for prime time? We regularly pay more for better seats at events, but if the price of my menu items increased between 7 & 9 on my busiest nights, or if I charged a premium for my best tables, I would be vilified. Charging a premium for the most desired reservation times seems to be the best free-market solution, but the premium should go to the restaurant,
new_topic: a way for people to get into popular restaurants
