Tweet: "Congress should stop Obamacare before it starts, and focus on common-sense solutions that can reduce health care costs for all Americans." Except that we never seem to see what these "common-sense solutions" might actually consist of. As a liberal who opposed Obamacare because it's not what we really need--which is socialized medicine, by whatever name you might want to call it--I'm certainly all ears for other solutions. But I never see anything viable coming from the modern Right, just some mealy-mouthed phrases that camouflage their intent to do nothing at all. And why should we? The heart of Obamacare, the individual mandate, originated at the Heritage Foundation. Obama enacted a tweaked version of the GOP plan for healthcare reform and no one hates it more than the GOP.
Wiki: the document argues that congress should abandon obamacare and focus on finding practical solutions to reduce healthcare costs. the writer, described as a liberal who prefers socialized medicine, criticizes the lack of concrete alternatives proposed by the modern right. they also highlight the irony that the core of obamacare, the individual mandate, originated from the heritage foundation and was similar to the gop's healthcare reform plan. the writer questions why the gop would now oppose a plan they once supported. they express frustration with the lack of clarity and substance in the gop's criticisms and proposals, referring to their language as "mealy-mouthed phrases." the writer is open to hearing other solutions, but believes the gop has not presented any viable alternatives to obamacare.

Tweet: In my experience as a college department chair, it was frequently the professors with the fewest assignments and highest average student grades who received the most glowing reviews. Professors who set more challenging but reasonable standards were on the avoid list. Given the generally subjective nature of online reviews one should not be surprised at this. But neither should one claim that such reviews offer a fair evaluation of the product.
Wiki:
the knowledge from the document suggests that in the experience of the college department chair, professors with fewer assignments and higher average student grades tended to receive more positive reviews on the website 'rate my professor'. on the other hand, professors who set more challenging but reasonable standards were often avoided. the document also implies that online reviews, such as those on 'rate my professor', are generally subjective and may not offer a fair evaluation of the professor.

Tweet: Well, I looked up the statistics on policemen being shot. Turns out that were about 100 in the year 2013. That's among more than 1.1 million full time and 40,000 part time officers. Tweet: This is definitely a fluff 'issue', but very entertaining. My hypothesis is that people partner best with someone who's relatively compatible on the maintenance spectrum. As a low-maintenance type of gal, the sort who can get ready for an evening out in under 20 minutes (and that includes the shower), I would not be able to tolerate a guy who had 'manny-pedis' and facials. The very idea would make me cringe. Many years ago in my 20s I went on a few dates with a guy who had more hair grooming products than I did; it just didn't work out. I've been married 15 years now to a handsome guy who is clean but doesn't primp or spend time worrying about grey hair or wrinkles. The only scent he gives off is from his deodorant and soap, and that's fine by me.
Wiki: in the document, the author argues that people partner best with someone who is relatively compatible on the maintenance spectrum. the author, who is low-maintenance, would not be able to tolerate a man who spends a lot of time on grooming and personal care. she shares a personal anecdote about dating a man who was very into hair grooming products, which did not work out. she is now married to a man who is clean and groomed, but not overly concerned about his appearance, and she is happy with that. the author's perspective suggests that modern men who are overly concerned with grooming and personal care may not be a good match for low-maintenance partners. #maintenance #manny-pedis #grooming #grey hair #wrinkles #deodorant #soap

Tweet: Oversalting in the kitchen is the best way to kill a dish. Some chefs have a salty pallate. Tastes good to them but tastes like a salt bomb to others. There are plenty of chefs that fall into this category. Those chefs will continue cooking even after they see dishes getting sent back to the kitchen. If there's a salt shaker at the table they know they can add less salt than they would prefer and let the diner adjust the salt at the table. May the salt shaker remain.
Wiki:
the document highlights the issue of oversalting in the kitchen, emphasizing that it can ruin a dish. it mentions that some chefs have a preference for salty flavors, which may be enjoyable for them but overwhelming for others. it also suggests that chefs with a tendency to oversalt may continue doing so despite dishes being sent back to the kitchen. the document proposes a solution where salt shakers are provided on tables so that diners can adjust the salt to their taste. overall, it emphasizes the importance of not oversalting dishes and allowing diners to adjust the seasoning themselves.

expand:
- oversalting: adding too much salt to a dish
- pallate: the sense of taste
- salt bomb: a dish that is excessively salty
- may the salt shaker remain: expressing a desire for salt shakers to be available for diners to use

Tweet: In our community, the most elegant, welcoming and practical buildings are our libraries. In the 9 years I have lived here, two libraries have been built and one redesigned and refurbished. Like the comments about the need for internet access among the poor, libraries ARE so much more. They have become a cultural, community hub for education, community activism, art, music, video and social interaction. One library has attracted the local gardening society to create and maintain a butterfly garden with many native plants that are marked for people to learn about them. Another group has offered to create a meandering walking path around the expanse of the building for reflection and a chance to walk in beauty outdoors. In many ways, I see our libraries becoming a sort of secular ministry -- feeding the souls as well as the minds of people. They are far from obsolete -- they are becoming more relevant and essential than ever before!
Wiki:
libraries are considered the most elegant, welcoming, and practical buildings in our community. over the past 9 years, two libraries have been built and one has been redesigned and refurbished. it is noted that libraries fulfill a broader role than just providing internet access to the poor. they have become a cultural and community hub for education, community activism, art, music, video, and social interaction. for example, one library has a butterfly garden maintained by the local gardening society, and another group has created a walking path around the building for reflection and enjoyment of the outdoors.

the author sees libraries as a type of secular ministry, feeding the souls as well as the minds of people. they are not becoming obsolete; in fact, they are becoming more relevant and essential than ever before.

expanded phrases:

- are: are becoming
- #libraries: libraries
- #internet: internet
- #community: community

Tweet: A national birth registry would be unnecessary if birthright citizenship were restricted to those in the country legally. Under this system, in order to obtain a birth certificate for a state, the mother would be required to provide the equivalent of an I-9 form showing her presence in this country legally.
Wiki: the document suggests that a national birth registry might not be necessary if birthright citizenship were limited to those who are legally present in the country. under this system, in order to obtain a birth certificate for a state, the mother would need to provide the equivalent of an i-9 form, which shows her legal presence in the country. this approach aims to address concerns about birthright citizenship being granted to those who are in the country illegally.

Tweet: I don't think the drug reform or criminal justice reform movements would be where they are right now if not for the power of online comments. The media status quo have in the past supported the Drug War without question and played respectability politics to keep drug reform arguments out of the public eye. That's one of the things that got us into mass incarceration in the first place. A big reason why we are moving out of that period now is because various people outside the media elite who have their facts together on drug and criminal justice reform were able to use comments sections to communicate arguments about race and drug enforcement and criminal justice policy that the media status quo wasn't ready to play in prime time. This wound up educating the media status quo and now the way the media cover drug policy has changed completely. This is a victory for democracy and for online comments.
Wiki:
the document suggests that the drug reform and criminal justice reform movements have been heavily influenced by the power of online comments. the media, in the past, supported the drug war and excluded drug reform arguments from the public eye. this contributed to mass incarceration. however, people outside the media elite used comments sections to share well-researched arguments about race and drug enforcement, which eventually educated the media and led to a change in how drug policy is covered. this is seen as a victory for democracy and for the power of online comments. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

- drug reform: the movement to change drug policies and laws
- criminal justice reform: the movement to change policies and laws related to the criminal justice system
- media status quo: the traditional and established media outlets
- mass incarceration: the significant and disproportionate imprisonment of a large number of people
- prime time: the time when mainstream media is widely watched or listened to
- #drugwar: the campaign against

Tweet: A SINGLE PAYOR Plan such as they have in Germany, England and France, holds the potential for being a functional alternative for the US. But we are stuck with a crazy quilt of 50 different states each vying for its own version of Obamacare, anti-Obamacare or whatever else title they wish to dream up. You don't hear great upheavals from those receiving Medicare. It works. It's imperfect. Anything human is imperfect. That's evidence that a single payor program is already working here and can be expanded upon.
Wiki: the document suggests that a single payer healthcare system, similar to those in germany, england, and france, could be a viable alternative for the united states. it criticizes the current situation in the us, where each state has its own version of the affordable care act (aca), and supports the idea of a unified, national healthcare system. the document also mentions the success of medicare and asserts that it is evidence that a single payer program could work in the us. it emphasizes that while medicare is imperfect, it is a functioning example of a single payer system and could be built upon.

Tweet: This is from the study that this writer Christie Wilcox cited about Organic farms being less "efficient." "We found crop yields to be 20% lower in the organic systems, although input of fertilizer and energy was reduced by 34 to 53% and pesticide input by 97%. Enhanced soil fertility and higher biodiversity found in organic plots may render these systems less dependent on external inputs." With the reduction in energy and pesticides they seem pretty efficient to me. All organic practices are not equal. Organic systems that "stack" crops like growing mushrooms beneath orchards or ducks and fish being raised along side rice patties are way more "efficient" than conventional. Science does prove organics are healthier and safer. The irony of that recent Stanford paper is that it showed there are less antibiotic resistant bacteria on organic meat and less pesticide residue on produce. Produce grown in biologically active soil, which is achieved using organic soil building methods, does have more testable ultra-trace minerals. Scientists are only now understanding how important these minerals are to human health. The holes in Christie Wilcox's argument are far and wide.
Wiki:
the document mentions a study cited by christie wilcox which found that organic farms have lower crop yields but also use less fertilizer, energy, and pesticides. the study suggests that organic farms may be less dependent on external inputs due to enhanced soil fertility and higher biodiversity. it also mentions more efficient organic practices, such as crop stacking, and highlights that organic produce has less antibiotic resistant bacteria and pesticide residue. additionally, it states that produce grown in biologically active soil has more testable ultra-trace minerals, which are important for human health. the document also criticizes christie wilcox's argument, stating that there are flaws in her reasoning.

With the reduction in energy and pesticides they seem pretty efficient to me. All organic practices are not equal. Organic systems that "stack" crops like growing mushrooms beneath orchards or ducks and fish being raised along side rice patties are way more "efficient" than conventional. Science does prove organics are healthier and safer. The irony of that recent Stanford paper is that it showed there are less antibiotic resistant bacteria on organic meat and less pesticide residue on produce. Produce grown in biologically active soil, which is achieved using organic soil building methods, does have more testable ultra-trace minerals. Scientists are only now understanding how important these minerals are to human health. The holes in Christie Wilcox's argument are far and wide.

Tweet: I am a frequent comment contributor to this NY Times Comments section, and an even more frequent reader of comments by others here. Please, keep this comment service! I usually read an article that interests me, then immediately read the NY Times selection of representative comments with great relish, because I know that there is a community of bright, well meaning, and responsible comment writers who will provide perspectives missing from the original article. Such good writers many of the commenters are! I regularly have my opinion affected by the comments in the NY Times. That said, the comment sections from virtually all other publications I have encountered are unfortunately dominated by people venting often foolish, badly written, negative comments. Such publications should either upgrade their comment section by adding adequate pre-publishing review, or I would sadly agree that those comment sections should be dropped.
Wiki:

Tweet: Germany might want to remember that after WWII 90% of Germany's outstanding debt was forgiven. the western allies recognized that the crushing reparations imposed after WWI were a mistake and they needed Germany as an ally against the soviet union. this was to a country that started the war and murdered millions of innocent people. Greece cant pay. it is never going to be able to pay all of its debt. if it were a company it would be in chapter 11 and its unsecured creditors would get next to nothing. yes it needs some reforms, largely in the elimination of the enormous amount of tax evasion that previously existed. let it pay a portion of the debt and the balance as income based repayment over time based on increase in GDP.
Wiki:

expansion:
- wwii: world war ii

- gdp: gross domestic product

Tweet: Muddled thinking here. Muslims so often point out with alacrity that specific clothing (i.e., covering) is not defined in the Koran, yet here we are exposed to a Islamocentric defense of rules of female dress that are designed to restrict a woman's freedom. There's nothing feminist at all about the three Abrahamic religions, which, together with their oppression of women, are used to justify so much violence today.

the document highlights the contradiction in muslim thinking regarding clothing, as the koran does not specify clothing rules but there are strict rules for female dress. the author finds these rules oppressive and offensive to those who oppose religious tyranny, but acknowledges that they must be tolerated. the author also rejects the idea that these rules are feminist, as the abrahamic religions are seen as oppressive to women and used to justify violence. the author's stance is critical of the restrictions imposed on women's clothing in the name of religion and does not see it as a feminist act.

Tweet: Goofy beyond belief. Religious beliefs are just that...beliefs. To whatever degree a religious practice is benign, it should be allowed. When the practice impinges upon public health or safety, it must be curtailed for the benefit of the entire society. Our tradition is not to concern ourselves with how people worship their god (or choose not to worship at all.) All are free to practice their religion as they see fit. Accordingly, we should also be able to choose to be free of religion when it impinges upon public health or well being. Permitting religious beliefs to trump science is antithetical to our secular culture.
Wiki:
the document argues that religious beliefs should be respected as long as they do not jeopardize public health or safety. people are free to practice their religion, or not, as they choose. when religious beliefs conflict with science and public well-being, the well-being of society should take precedence. this means that parents should be able to raise their children in their chosen religion, but they should not be allowed to use their religious beliefs to forgo medical treatment or put their children at risk. the document also makes the point that giving priority to religious beliefs over scientific facts goes against the secular culture. it suggests that people should have the freedom to opt out of religion when it conflicts with public health and well-being. 

abbreviations and slang in the document:
- "to whatever degree" means to whatever extent
- "curtailed" means restricted or limited
- "god" refers to a deity or higher power
- "all are free" means everyone has the freedom to
- "as

Tweet: Thank you! I could not agree more. I was an avid reader as a child and have grown to be an avid reader as an adult, and I believe that being a good reader is like training for being a good listener and ultimately a good citizen of the world. Learning to enter into the worlds and personas of book characters and understand their motivations and desires is good practice for listening to the people you encounter in life and coming to understand their perspective and ideas, even if you do not agree with them or do not initially have much in common with them. Certainly, it is important for parents and teachers to have good tools that help them approach complex political topics with children. But there is no reason why it should result in giving children didactic, joyless fiction.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of reading for children, and how it can shape them into good listeners and ultimately good citizens. it discusses the benefits of entering into the worlds of book characters and understanding their perspectives, which can translate to listening to and understanding the people they encounter in life. the document also advocates for using fiction as a tool to approach complex political topics with children, rather than resorting to didactic, joyless fiction. it emphasizes the value of providing children with good reading materials and not underestimating their ability to comprehend and engage with complex subjects.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags are expanded as follows:
- i could not agree more -> i could not agree more
- avid -> enthusiastic
- didactic -> intended to teach
- #goodcitizen -> good citizen
- #goodlistener -> good listener
- #complextopics -> complex political topics

Tweet: Bring back the drachma. If the Greek economy is slack, they can devalue the drachma to encourage foreign tourists and investment. They can also control their own destiny -- the basic concept of democracy which they created. Having Germany dictate how their government and economy should run doesn't make sense either for Germany or Athens. A Greece free of the Euro would be a happier and more prosperous Greece. The Euro is currently designed for industrial super powers like Germany, not for fun, sun-loving, life affirming Greece.
Wiki: the document argues for greece to bring back the drachma, its former currency, in order to have more control over its economy. it suggests that a weaker drachma could attract more foreign tourists and investment. the document also emphasizes the importance of greek democracy and criticizes germany for dictating how greece should run its government and economy. it claims that greece would be happier and more prosperous without the euro, as the currency is more suited for industrial superpowers like germany rather than a country like greece, known for its enjoyable lifestyle.

Tweet: "One of the main pillars of Syriza's economic program is the creation of 300,000 new jobs for the unemployed under a direct public employment scheme." Anyone who thinks that expanding public employment in Greece is a good idea should migrate to Greece. There are already more public employees in Greece than just about anywhere else in the world and you propose to put more people on the public payroll? As it is, many government employees do not have any meaningful assignments and you want the Greek government to hire more people? What you are actually proposing is a massive expansion of welfare payments to the unemployed in Greece except that you claim to have given these people a job and so instead of social welfare you want the world to think of it as job creation. Here is a freebie for you: playing with words do not change economic realities. Greece cannot afford it and it is precisely such policies that created this mess in the first place.
Wiki: the main pillar of syriza's economic program in greece is to create 300,000 new jobs for the unemployed through a direct public employment scheme. however, the idea of expanding public employment in greece is criticized as there are already a large number of public employees in greece compared to other countries. critics argue that many government employees do not have meaningful assignments and hiring more people would only lead to a massive expansion of welfare payments to the unemployed, rather than creating actual jobs. the document suggests that playing with words does not change economic realities and that greece cannot afford such a policy, as it was policies like these that contributed to the current economic situation in greece.

Tweet: I went back to school in my mid-40s and earned a PhD. As a middle-aged, overweight female in a highly competetive field, I found most internships automatically closed to me. I finally had to accept one that paid less than $200 per month--and I had to move 1000 miles from home (renting an apt.) to take it. I learned a lot, and returned home to a good career in my field (after a 2nd lowly-paid year elsewhere--but at least that covered rent). I do understand that the internship site had financial problems. But I am very much aware that I was able to take that internship ONLY because I was a married woman with a husband who worked, and money in the bank. That should not be the norm.
Wiki: at the age of 40, i went back to school and earned a phd. as a middle-aged, overweight woman in a highly competitive field, i found that most internships were automatically closed to me. i ended up accepting an internship that paid less than $200 per month and had to move 1000 miles from home to take it, renting an apartment in the process. i learned a lot from this experience, and eventually returned home to a successful career in my field. however, i had to endure another year of low pay before i could afford my rent. i do understand that the internship site had financial problems, but i am very much aware that i was only able to take that internship because i was a married woman with a working husband and money in the bank. this should not be the norm for college students. #phd #internship #overweight #competitivefield #lowpay #financialproblems #marriedwoman #workinghusband #collegestudents

Tweet: Abuse of birthright citizenship is not restricted only to undocumented immigrants. I see many H-1B holders (possibly with pending green card applications, but that's irrelevant) get married and have children in the US. Their children get US passports. This is a calculated move to take advantage of birthright citizenship. In some cases, they get married to people who aren't even in the US, bring the spouse over legally on H-4, and have children here.
Wiki:
the document discusses how the abuse of birthright citizenship is not limited to undocumented immigrants. it mentions that h-1b visa holders, who may have pending green card applications, are also taking advantage of birthright citizenship by getting married and having children in the us, allowing their children to obtain us passports. it also points out that some h-1b holders are marrying individuals who are not in the us, bringing them over on an h-4 visa, and having children in the us to exploit birthright citizenship. 

abbreviations explained:
- h-1b: a non-immigrant visa that allows us companies to employ foreign workers in specialty occupations
- h-4: a dependent visa that allows the spouse and children of an h-1b visa holder to enter and stay in the us

slang explained:
- undocumented immigrants: individuals living in a country without proper legal documentation
- green card: a permit allowing a non-citizen to live and work permanently in the us

Tweet: I learn quite a lot from NYT comments, often and in particular from thoughtful comments by authors who think differently from me. I find them valuable. I think the Times' general level of commentary is good. This in part results from the Times' curating its comments, which filters the merely shrill or ad hominem screeds. I recognize this also introduces curatorial bias, but for me, the reduction in noise is welcome. I hope the Times continues to solicit reader commentary. I think its system is working well.
Wiki:
the document expresses that the author finds valuable knowledge by reading the comments section of the new york times (nyt). they appreciate thoughtful comments from authors who have different perspectives and feel that the general level of commentary is good. the nyt curates its comments to filter out offensive or irrelevant content, which the author appreciates despite acknowledging the potential for bias. they hope the nyt continues to solicit reader commentary and believe that the current system is working well.

expand:

nyt - the new york times
ad hominem - attacking an opponent's character rather than answering their arguments
curatorial bias - potential for bias in the selection or presentation of comments
shrill - high-pitched and piercing
hashtags: none

Tweet: I urge Mr. Stankiewicz to do his due diligence--required by any good journalism major--and perform some research. Two major studies in the last decade have shown that student evaluations are wholly flawed ways of evaluating learning. In fact, there is some evidence for a negative correlation between student reviews and learning. In other words, the more students dislike a professor, the better those students do in similar classes down the road. Why? Because those professors challenge students to push past their comfort zones and rigid patterns of thinking. Oh, and if you're going to use that erroneous consumer metaphor, then at least get it right: professors are not the product--the student mind is the product, and preparing it for engagement in civil society is the endpoint.
Wiki:
the document is urging mr. stankiewicz to conduct research on the flaws in using student evaluations to assess learning. it cites two major studies that have shown student evaluations are not reliable for evaluating learning, and in fact, there may be a negative correlation between student reviews and learning. this means that students who dislike a professor may actually perform better in future classes. this is because these professors challenge students to think beyond their comfort zones. the document also criticizes the use of the consumer metaphor and emphasizes that professors are not the product, but rather, they prepare students' minds for engagement in civil society.

- mr. = mister
- #professor = professor
- due diligence = necessary research
- consumer metaphor = comparison to consumerism

- two major studies in the last decade have

Tweet: Another tragedy of the commons. For newspapers, restricting access to paid subscribers would probably end this problem, or ameliorate it enough. Tweet: While the government wants us to eat healthy, it is very true that organic foods are outrageously priced for the small amount of food we recieve. Yes, when going to McDonald's and getting 5 things off of the dollar menu you get more bang for your buck. However, that is one reason why America is in such bad shape literally and figuratively. Obviously organic products are healthier for you than genetically enhanced ones. The cows that produce the normal milk we drink are fed steroids to be able to produce more milk than naturally possible. Therefore, we are not consuming 100% pure milk. That can cut down the natural nutrients we would be recieving if everyone housed their own cow. So, this article couldn't be any more incorrect by saying that America is worse off consuming organic products. If everyone decided to trade out a bag of Lay's for some all natural vegetable chips, consumption sizes would be cut down and health could be improved.
Wiki: the document argues that while the government encourages healthy eating, organic food is often too expensive for the small portion sizes it offers. it acknowledges that it can be more cost-effective to buy fast food, but warns that this contributes to america's poor health. it states that organic products are healthier than genetically modified ones, as conventional milk often contains steroids from the cows' feed. it suggests that consuming organic products could improve health by reducing portion sizes and increasing nutrient intake.

Tweet: As an academic for more than 50 years, I say, especially around grading time, that every university should require two things: minimal competence in a (new) foreign language, and performance on a musical instrument. You can cheat or get around the requirements for all kinds of other academic subjects, but you either speak French in public, or you can't. You either play the Bach Invention, or you can't. Simple. You can't cram it, you can't cheat. Besides the obvious benefits of the learning processes in both of these activities, the study of each is a valuable exercise in integrity. Yes, I'm serious.
Wiki:
the knowledge from the document suggests that every university should require minimal competence in a new foreign language and performance on a musical instrument for admission. the author, an academic for more than 50 years, emphasizes the importance of these requirements, stating that you can't cheat or get around them like other academic subjects. the study of a foreign language and musical instrument is seen as a valuable exercise in integrity, in addition to the obvious benefits of the learning processes in both activities.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document expanded into complete phrases and sentences:
- "you can't" becomes "you cannot"
- "i'm" becomes "i am"
- "the bach invention" becomes "the musical composition by bach"
- "yes, i'm serious" becomes "yes, i am serious"

Tweet: An incredible amount of time can be lost to technical issues with online classes (and with computers in classrooms). The discussion board doesn't open, links are broken, my browser won't open this or that page, the teacher can't find the file, we can't submit our work because the files are too big, students can't figure out how to make/open/save files, printers run out of ink, presentations disappear, and on and on and ON. One of these semesters I want to do research to see if using computers really does save time in the classroom. I suspect that it's not as much time as everyone seems to think.
Wiki:
the document discusses the significant amount of time that can be lost due to technical issues with online classes and computers in classrooms. examples of these issues include difficulty accessing the discussion board, broken links, browser malfunctions, inability to open or submit files, printer problems, and disappearing presentations.

additionally, the author expresses a desire to conduct research to determine if using computers actually saves time in the classroom, as they suspect that the time saved may not be as much as commonly believed. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- on = and on and on = and on and on and on
- #onlineclass = online class
- #computers = computers

Tweet: Yes I'm wired and also have a Kindle and Netflix. Nevertheless I'm a heavy library user and can't imagine living in a community without these resources. Tweet: The chef's vision, blah, blah, blah. Every so often at at otherwise decent restaurant, the chef of the moment under salts the food. Just plain and simple, they miss the mark. I understand, that happens, the food doesn't turn up on the table just as the chef intended when the dish was created. I am talking about a case in which the executive chef, were she tasting the food herself, would consider it under seasoned. In such a case when I am spending $38 on an entree, would the restaurant prefer I send it back and refuse to pay, or eat it and grumble about it on Yelp, or simply shake a little salt on it and be happy and tip well? It is the restaurant's choice. In addition, salt is not cinnamon. It is an absurd comparison. An under salted dish is unpalatable. A dish with less than optimal cinnamon is still fine.
Wiki:
the document discusses the issue of under-salted food in restaurants. it mentions that sometimes chefs unintentionally under-salt their dishes, which can result in the food being unpalatable. it raises the question of how customers should handle this situation - should they send the dish back, eat it and complain online, or simply add extra salt themselves? the document emphasizes that salt is not like cinnamon, as an under-salted dish is not enjoyable, while a dish with less cinnamon is still acceptable. it suggests that it is ultimately up to the restaurant to decide how to handle the situation. overall, the document highlights the importance of properly seasoning food with salt in restaurants.

In such a case when I am spending $38 on an entree, would the restaurant prefer I send it back and refuse to pay, or eat it and grumble about it on Yelp, or simply shake a little salt on it and be happy and tip well? It is the restaurant's choice. In addition, salt is not cinnamon. It is an absurd comparison. An under salted dish is unpalatable. A dish with less than optimal cinnamon is still fine.
Wiki:
the document discusses the issue of under-salted food at restaurants. the author argues that it is the chef's responsibility to ensure that the food is properly seasoned, and that under-salted dishes are unpalatable. the author questions whether it is better to send the dish back, complain on a review site like yelp, or simply add salt and move on. they emphasize that salt is not like cinnamon, and under-salted food cannot be fixed as easily. the author's viewpoint is that the responsibility lies with the executive chef to ensure that the food is properly seasoned before it reaches the table.

Tweet: Even the comments on the Washington Post are appalling. While one might think there would be some intelligent commentary accompanying news articles in that respected venue, a relatively small posse of regulars-on both sides of the political spectrum-seize every chance to hurl utterly unrelated partisan insults at one another. Sometimes I think the Post just republishes the same comment section day after day. And then I kick myself for wasting my time looking for signs of intelligent life. The Times, on the other hand, does a great job of moderating.
Wiki:
the document highlights the poor quality of comments on the washington post's website, where regular commentators from both sides of the political spectrum engage in partisan insults rather than intelligent discourse. the author is disappointed in the lack of thoughtful discussion and suspects that the same comments are being republished daily. in contrast, they praised the times for its effective moderation of comments.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- "i kick myself": i regret my actions
- "the post": the washington post
- "the times": the new york times
- "#intelligentlife": the presence of thoughtful and meaningful discussions on the internet

Tweet: Those already born here would, practically, have to be grandfathered if there were any changes. Reviewing the citizenship of people already born here would result in endless paperwork and heavy expenses, and would force us to make difficult moral decisions, some of which we would undoubtedly get wrong. I don't think that a constitutional amendment is actually necessary to clarify that the meaning of the Constitution is not something that it clearly was not intended to be, though. Defining the meaning of "under the jurisdiction of the United States" to exclude those who entered the country illegally or are here on short term travel visas should only require a law saying as much. The courts could strike it down, I suppose, but it's far from clear that they should, and their decision would have to explain some interesting contradictions between their position and contradictory aspects of past immigration laws. I think that the current problem is due to a lack of clarity from Congress, not due to actual demands of the Constitution.
Wiki:
the document discusses the issue of birthright citizenship in the u.s. it argues that those already born in the country should not have their citizenship status changed, as this would lead to extensive paperwork and high expenses. it suggests that defining the meaning of "under the jurisdiction of the united states" to exclude those who entered the country illegally or are on short term travel visas should only require a law, not a constitutional amendment. the document also points out the lack of clarity from congress on this issue. it suggests that the current problem is due to this lack of clarity, not actual demands of the constitution.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- here would = those already born here
- grandfathered = have their citizenship status changed
- i don't think = it's far from clear that
- i suppose = i guess
- the courts = the courts of law
- could strike it down = could reject it
- #birthrightcitizenship = birthright citizenship

Tweet: I've been host to two declawed cats while trying to find them a home (They came to me this way, it would never be my choice to do this). During their stay, one of them managed to kill two birds quite efficiently without claws. (They wiggled their way through the air conditioner). I didn't see him do it to know his methods, but I know it was him. Just last week, my toothless cat killed a bird that got in the same way. He killed it with one blow of his paw. He didn't use his claws to bring it down; just one blow and it was dead. I will only leave this piece of information, for I could write a book on declawing cats and the pain and problems it causes. There are plenty of safe alternatives to declawing; people need to research, and learn to live with animals instead of adapting them to fit our needs.
Wiki:
the document describes the experiences of the author caring for two declawed cats, who were able to kill birds despite their lack of claws. the author emphasizes that they do not support declawing cats, and urges people to research and find safe alternatives instead of altering animals to fit their needs.

expand:
- "i've": i have
- "i didn't": i did not
- "i will": i will
- "#declawing": the act of removing a cat's claws, often for the convenience of the owner

Tweet: I love national parks. Growing up in India, unspoiled green spaces were really foreign, and National Parks are America's best idea for generations to come. I visit Mt Ranier National Park several times as it is almost in my backyard. I am struck by the damage that visitors can inflict on the fragile wild flower meadows in their eagerness and zeal to enjoy the beauty. While better funding and visitor resources such as mass transportation could help, something we can all do is volunteer at a NP for a few days a year. This will go a long way in relieving the already stretched NP resources and the benefit to the volunteer citizen is priceless. Picking up trash, pulling weeks, cataloging wildflowers, roving the meadows helping visitors, etc. can help give back to our country's best idea and recharge our batteries all in one act!!
Wiki:
the document discusses the love for national parks, particularly mt ranier national park, and the impact of overcrowding on these natural spaces. the author suggests that volunteering at national parks can help relieve the strain on resources and minimize the damage caused by visitors. the document advocates for better funding and visitor resources to address the issue of overcrowded national parks, as well as the importance of citizen volunteers in preserving these natural spaces.

abbreviation expansion:
np - national park

slang expansion:
none

hashtag expansion:
none

Tweet: In our 40 and some years of marriage, we have had 9 cats, and declawed all of them. Our cats are strictly indoor cats and most of them have lived 10 plus years (One even lived to 20!) without any of the behavioral problems described in this article. Our first cat destroyed our furniture and did not respond to all the behavior modification hints in these articles. If people are not allowed to declaw, I fear even more cats will be euthanized. We love our cats, and I don't think declawing them was an awful thing.
Wiki:
the document describes the author's experience of having 9 indoor cats over 40 years of marriage, all of which were declawed. they claim that their cats have lived long and healthy lives without any behavioral problems. they argue that their first cat destroyed furniture and did not respond to behavior modification techniques, leading them to declaw the cat. the author expresses fear that if declawing is not allowed, more cats will be euthanized. they believe that declawing their cats was not an awful thing and they love their cats. 

the slang "cats" is used to refer to pet cats and "euthanized" refers to the practice of putting animals to death so they do not suffer. the hashtag "#declaw" is used to discuss declawing cats.

Tweet: Monopolies as monopolies are always dangerous which is why when one is permitted it must be under the tight control of the government and it must be by law committed to the betterment of the customer's interests and those of the public. Once a monopoly is permitted it is no longer a typical corporations competing with others. It is by definition the only place that a consumer can turn for that product or service thus its power to abuse that situation is massive and must be strictly controlled. It's price structure cannot be allowed to be government only by the corporations interests and the way it conducts its business must be a matter of public scrutiny. Google is no different....it has already shown its monopolistic tendencies by freezing out other content and preferring serve results thst are beneficial to it and its partners thus depriving users of intimations that may be beneficial to them. My preference would be not to allow any monopolies and to break up any that occur through mergers or other corproate transactions.
Wiki:
the document argues that monopolies are always dangerous, which is why they must be tightly controlled by the government and committed to serving the customers' and public's interests by law. once a monopoly is permitted, it no longer has to compete with other corporations and can abuse its power as the sole provider of a product or service. this means its pricing and behavior must be strictly regulated. google, for example, has already shown monopolistic tendencies by favoring its own content and partners over others, depriving users of potentially beneficial information. the preference expressed is not to allow any monopolies and to break up any that occur through mergers or other corporate transactions.

Tweet: The Internet would be a vastly different place if we could somehow do away with anonymity. But would it actually be a better place? In our very polarized world, many people are understandably reluctant to speak out on controversial issues, unless they can do so anonymously. If we want to know what people really think, we need to let them speak anonymously. So long as there has been written communication, people have had that ability, and maybe that right. Before that, people threw rocks under cover of darkness to get their point across. I understand the temptation to demand that people use their real identities, but it seems almost impossible to do in the real world. Even if you ask for a scan of my driver's license, you can't be sure it is really my license, or be sure that it has not been altered.
Wiki: the document discusses the impact of anonymity on the internet, suggesting that it allows people to speak out on controversial issues without fear of repercussions. the author believes that it is important to let people speak anonymously in order to truly understand their thoughts. they acknowledge the difficulty of verifying real identities online, even if asked for official identification. the document implies that anonymity in the comment section can encourage more open and honest dialogue. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document: 'real world' is expanded to "the actual physical world", 'scan' is expanded to "a digital scan", 'driver's license' is expanded to "a government-issued driver's license", and 'get their point across' is expanded to "express their opinions effectively".

Tweet: It may have made sense once upon a time but not anymore. I am liberal thinker and I don't mean to say that we need to deport people in mass or not have systems in place to care for newborns of any status who happen to be born here. But citizenship should be a priveledge that is applied for by families or legal representation in exceptional circumstances, and it should be earned thorugh a process by which it is clear the person (or family) is well invested in our culture and economy. I have two daughters born in Switzerland, neither of whom were offered Swiss citizenship at birth because the simple fact of their birth didn't make them Swiss. Under the current system it is simply too easy to take advantage of the current law and use automatic citizenship to take more than is earned. Again, I am not saying we shouldn't be a compassionate country, and how a new system is implemented would be a lengthy, difficult task, but it definitely should change.
Wiki:
the document argues that birthright citizenship should no longer be automatically granted and that citizenship should be considered a privilege that must be applied for and earned, particularly in exceptional circumstances. the author, a liberal thinker, believes that the current system can be taken advantage of and that citizenship should be earned through a process that shows investment in the culture and economy of the country. the author uses the example of their own daughters, who were not offered citizenship in switzerland at birth, to support their argument. the document calls for compassion in rethinking the current system of birthright citizenship, acknowledging that implementing a new system would be a difficult and lengthy task. 

the complete phrases for abbreviations in the document are:
- mass: mass deportation
- swiss: switzerland
- #changes: changes to the current system of birthright citizenship.

Tweet: When I went to college a decade ago, the priced i paid for a single dorm room was less than a shared off-campus room. I did live in an older building with communal bathrooms, my room was tiny with a bed, desk, dresser and a small closet. Not only that, it gave my parents peace of mind that people in my building were enrolled students, opposite gender friends aren't supposed to stay overnight and an RA on every floor. At night if I needed to go somewhere on campus and felt unsafe, I could call the university for someone to walk with me. Obviously it you cannot afford to live outside of your home, that's that but for people to claim off campus housing is cheaper and everyone does it is plain wrong.

Tweet: Hold on. Reporting concerns to police is not very effective if the police are not very well trained to respond. Tweet: "Unfortunately the new government has an agenda of welfare populism, suspicious to any kind of market-reforms and protective of vested interests." That is misleading. Tweet: This reads like parody. Rate My Professors is an organized venue...with a chili pepper icon to evaluate professors' hotness, a techno-bureaucratic set of sliding scales to place people on a scale of 1-5, and rarely a serious or self-reflective comment about content, pace, or intellectual challenge. Ge real. It's a place to vent. And that venting can go either direction, too: students will sing the praise of one teacher, and assail another. Their are very few middle reviews. And why is that? Because the forum is self-selecting, and--through its rationalist design--it encourages yes or no evaluation. Is that what we want? Students who are encouraged to judge everything as either black or white?
Wiki:

Tweet: According to the Mexican constitution, Article 30- one way for Mexican nationality is - Those born in a foreign country of Mexican parents; of a Mexican father and a foreign mother; or of a Mexican mother and an unknown father; So if Trumps immigration plan begins with deportation for those from Mexico, it would in fact be deporting Mexican citizens...Mexico doesn't recognize them as American citizens. They are subject to the jurisdiction of Mexico.

Tweet: Publishing and newspapers are old industries. Publishing has fed too long from the labors of writers and readers while too seldom adding true value. Newspapers have been lean and efficient, they juat aren't capable of satisfying the demand curve of today's public. Telecommunications and transportation behaved similarly to publishing and they underwent dramatic restructuring. The music production industry is well on its way toward completing a shake up. It isn't pretty, but it is too late for publishing to control their future. Ten years ago they might have had more of a say in the direction the sector is going; it is now pre-ordained.
Wiki: the document suggests that publishing and newspapers are outdated industries that have relied too much on the work of writers and readers without adding enough value. newspapers have been efficient but cannot meet the needs of today's public. similar to publishing, the telecommunications and transportation industries have undergone significant restructuring, and the music production industry is also going through a shake up. it is too late for publishing to control its future, as it should have made changes ten years ago. now, the direction of the sector is already determined.

Tweet: Having been born "Her Majesty's Loyal Subject (albeit Colonial-hence no longer one), I would like to see Charles become King before he reaches his mother' s age. It's just not fair. I think Charles would be a reasonably good Monarch. His biggest problem is Camilla. I'm going to be brutally honest, and expect to get some flak as a result. Dianna was undoubtedly the Queen of Hearts, a star with a capital S, gorgeous, charismatic and blessed with incredible ability for empathy. However as Eliabeth has proven beyond doubt, one does not need to be a star to be a good monarch. Camilla is no Dianna, but she is, like it or not infinitely more suited to be Queen of the Realm then Dianna could ever hope to be.
Wiki:
the document expresses a desire for charles to become the king before he reaches the age of his mother, queen elizabeth ii. the writer acknowledges that william may be more popular, but believes it is unfair to bypass charles after he has been loyal for over 40 years. the writer thinks charles would be a reasonably good monarch, but recognizes that his biggest problem is camilla. the writer also acknowledges the popularity and charisma of princess diana, but believes that one does not need to be a star to be a good monarch, as queen elizabeth ii has proven. the writer believes that camilla is more suited to be queen than diana ever could have been.

Tweet: As Truman stated so many years ago, "It has become an operational and at times a policy-making arm of the Government. This has led to trouble and may have compounded our difficulties in several explosive areas." Indeed, the CIA/NSA has become an all powerful, unaccountable, unconstitutional fourth wing of government in control of the Executive and running our foreign policy to the detriment of the world and of our basic rights as citizens. The CIA has always been above the law, uncontrollable and unaccountable. It is responsible for more crimes against humanity than any other organization or government, orchestrating civil wars, coups, establishing brutal dictatorships from Guatemala to Chile to Iran, training and overseeing death squads and torture around the globe. It is past time to abolish this monstrous institution along with its other faces; NSA, NATO, USAID and put intelligence gathering back in the military with heavy, independent oversight to prevent abuse. It is time to prosecute those responsible for international crimes and human rights abuse. It is also telling that the Times, know to be connected to the CIA, didn't have former CIA analyst Ray McGovern in this conversation.
Wiki: in summary, the document criticizes the cia (central intelligence agency) and nsa (national security agency) for becoming an all-powerful, unaccountable, and unconstitutional fourth branch of government. it argues that these agencies have been responsible for orchestrating civil wars, coups, and establishing brutal dictatorships, as well as training and overseeing death squads and torture around the globe. the document calls for abolishing these institutions and putting intelligence gathering back in the military with independent oversight to prevent abuse. it also suggests prosecuting those responsible for international crimes and human rights abuse. additionally, it criticizes the times, a newspaper known to be connected to the cia, for not including former cia analyst ray mcgovern in a conversation.

Tweet: Right on! The watchword for any business, restaurants included, should generally be "the customer is always right." This is especially true with regard to tastes, and appreciation of flavors. People do not all experience the same food the same way and for an egotistic chef to imagine he has the right to determine how much salt should be put on something is ridiculous. The chef doesn't know best for everyone. So keep the salt and pepper shakers. They are the ubiquitous best flavor enhancers around--the very reason they are ubiquitous in any GOOD restaurant IMHO!
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of prioritizing the customer's preferences in the restaurant industry, especially when it comes to tastes and flavors. it argues that not everyone experiences food in the same way and that chefs should not be egotistical in determining the right amount of seasoning for dishes. the document suggests keeping salt and pepper shakers on the table as they are the best flavor enhancers in a good restaurant, in the author's opinion.

imho = in my humble opinion

Tweet: I wonder how Ms Howell and others who insist it's their right to deny medical care to their children because they "are committed to following in Christ Jesus' steps of relying on God's power alone for healing" feel about others with different religious beliefs which dictate that they give their daughters in "marriage" to pedophile cult leaders, or who insist that their god requires that all girls be genitally mutilated according to the dictates of their belief system? We actually prosecute people who do such things. Why should a person who risks a child's life under the guise of a "Christian" belief be exempt? While enlightened people have existed for milennia, the Age of Reason officially began in the 18th century. When will we enter the 21st century?
Wiki: the document expresses frustration and incredulity towards individuals like ms. howell who use their religious beliefs to deny medical care to their children, believing in relying on god's power alone for healing. the writer questions how these individuals would feel towards those with different religious beliefs that condone harmful practices such as giving their daughters to pedophile cult leaders or practicing genital mutilation. the author suggests that just as we prosecute people who engage in such harmful practices in the name of their beliefs, those who risk a child's life under the guise of "christian" belief should not be exempt from accountability. the author also calls for a shift towards a more enlightened and rational approach to these issues, urging us to move into the 21st century.

Tweet: The most insightful writing to be found in almost any article occurs in the comments. Rarely is there a significant article that is neither debunked nor enhanced by the best of the comments. I have actually started checking whether comments are enabled before I read an article - and NOT reading it if they are disabled. To me, disabling comments is a sign of weakness and/or dishonesty on the part of the author and/or the publisher. It shows a fear of dissent, a fear of being scrutinized and/or challenged. Perhaps there is an underlying insecurity about not being viewed as an authoritative voice. The solution to repugnant comments isn't to ban all comments. The solution is mechanisms (which have existed for ages) that filter, sort, and hide comments at the pleasure of the user.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of the comment section in articles, stating that the most insightful writing can often be found there. the author expresses a preference for articles with enabled comments and views disabling comments as a sign of weakness or dishonesty on the part of the author or publisher. they believe that disabling comments shows a fear of dissent and a fear of being scrutinized or challenged. the author suggests that the solution to dealing with repugnant comments is not to ban all comments, but rather to use mechanisms that filter, sort, and hide comments at the user's discretion.

expansion:
- abbreviations: not (negation), isn't (is not), the (a specific), and/or (and or or), etc (et cetera)
- slang:  "to me" means "in my opinion", "ban" means "prohibit", "pleasure" means "desire or will"
- hashtags: none.

Tweet: "Assuming an unpaid internship is mutually beneficial and entered into freely by both parties, should such arrangements be illegal? " Just because we young people constitute a "willing party" when entering into an internship doesn't mean we are actually "willing". We simply have no choice. After all, for the ambitious among us, what's the alternative? Unless you have your sights on a career in venture capitalism/finance/etc., non-remunerated internships are all we know.
Wiki:
the document argues that assuming an unpaid internship is mutually beneficial and entered into freely by both parties, it questions whether such arrangements should be illegal. the author contends that just because young people are seen as "willing" when entering into an internship, it does not necessarily mean they are actually willing. they often have no choice and the alternative for those with ambitions is limited. the document suggests that non-remunerated internships are common for those pursuing careers in venture capitalism, finance, etc.

the document uses abbreviations, slang, and hashtags such as "etc.", "willing party", "non-remunerated", and "among us". these should be expanded into complete phrases and sentences for clarification: "etc." should be expanded to "and so on"; "willing party" should be expanded to "someone who agrees voluntarily"; "non-remunerated" should be expanded to "unpaid"; and "among us" should be expanded to "within our group".

Tweet: A great idea that I have implemented in my own case over 5 or more years of commenting. Have I been called names? So what? I agree that it might be wise to permit exceptions. But I fear the exceptions would quickly begin to swallow the rule. I take anonymous comments less seriously than ones that disclose the poster's name -- though, granted, it is not always easy to tell them apart.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of implementing a specific idea in commenting over the course of at least 5 years, even if the commenter has been called names. the idea also suggests that while it may be reasonable to allow exceptions, doing so could result in the rule being disregarded. additionally, the document states that anonymous comments are taken less seriously than those with a disclosed poster's name, although it can be difficult to distinguish between the two.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document:

- "i've": i have
- "so what?": it doesn't matter.
- "granted": although it is true
- "comment section": the area for leaving comments on a post or article.

Tweet: How is bashing and belittling Amazon Publishing a debate? I fail to see anything more here than the usual 'let's smear Amazon because we must stay dogmatic about modern publishing.' Absolutely ridiculous. Referring to their editors as Chimpanzees is beyond low and trying to say that you're not is more than back-handed. And why must one automatically assume that they'll dominate the publishing industry -- especially if all they are interested in is widgets and algorithms? Inconsistent to say the least, especially if everyone else is so damn good. Seriously biased article and extremely flawed logic. If taking these kind of subtle but bratty gibes at Amazon makes someone feel better and gets them a few handshakes over their afternoon lunch in mid-town Manhattan, then I guess that's likely the real end result. Bashing someone for the sake of it is myopic at best and most reader's won't come away with anything but a negative point of view.
Wiki:
the document is criticizing the unfair bashing and belittling of amazon publishing as a debate. the author sees this as a smear campaign and believes it is ridiculous. they find it unfair to refer to amazon's editors as "chimpanzees" and argue that assuming amazon will dominate the publishing industry is inconsistent, especially if all they focus on is "widgets and algorithms." they think the article is biased and has flawed logic. the author believes that taking subtle jabs at amazon only serves to make the person doing so feel better and gain some recognition. they conclude that bashing someone for the sake of it is short-sighted and will leave most readers with a negative impression.

meaning of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- "chimpanzees" refers to editors at amazon publishing.
- "widgets and algorithms" refers to amazon's focus on technological aspects as opposed to traditional publishing methods.
- "mid-town manhattan" refers to a location where high-profile business meetings often occur.

Tweet: The late Edward Abbey had a novel idea: allow anyone into a national park if travelling under their own steam -- walking, biking, skiing, etc. After all, getting out of the car is the best way to enjoy nature. As for the understandable complaints about children and the elderly not being able to travel in our parks under such a rule, Abbey replied that the kids will have their chances later (and we'll have preserved the parks for them), and the elderly had their chances when younger.
Wiki:
the document suggests the idea of allowing anyone to enter a national park if they are using their own physical means of travel such as walking, biking, or skiing, in order to better enjoy nature. edward abbey addressed concerns about restricting access for children and the elderly, stating that kids will have opportunities to visit the parks in the future, and the elderly had their chances when they were younger. 

abbey's suggestion is to open up access to national parks to anyone traveling without a motorized vehicle, as he believes that getting out of the car is the best way to truly appreciate nature. he acknowledges concerns about excluding children and the elderly, but assures that they have or will have opportunities to experience the parks in different ways.

Tweet: Having access to videos of depositions that are also stenographically transcribed, I have seen firsthand that the human error rate is high. But why wouldn't it be? There are not many of us who have the concentration level to type precisely what people say for hours and hours at a time. Recordings are accurate, but the problem is that in order to cite them in a brief, they must be stenographically transcribed.
Wiki:
the document discusses the challenges of accurately transcribing depositions, indicating that the human error rate is high when stenographically transcribing videos. the author suggests that it is difficult for individuals to maintain the concentration level required to type precisely what people say for long periods of time. the document also highlights the need for stenographic transcription in order to cite recordings in a brief.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document expanded:
- 'i have seen firsthand' is expanded to 'i have personally witnessed'
- 'but why wouldn't it be?' is expanded to 'but why would it not be?'
- 'recordings are accurate' is expanded to 'recordings provide accurate information'
- 'in order to cite them in a brief' is expanded to 'to reference them in a legal document'
- 'stenographically transcribed' is expanded to 'translated into stenographic text'

Tweet: It is impossible to get a good sampling from polls. Poll takers are like telemarketers; they invade the privacy of our homes, especially when we are busiest. If I answer the phone at all, I am apt to be less than polite to the person who is bothering me. I have strong political opinions but the poll takers will never hear them because I don't want to answer a stranger's probing questions. What kinds of people are being sampled? I am not alone in my feelings about intrusive phone calls, so it is none of us. Although I have had a few illegal calls on my cell phone, those without landlines are not included in most samples. The skewed sampling is giving greater weight to the candidate whose fans are willing to be bothered by a poll. What does that say about his qualifications for the job of president? Nothing.
Wiki: the document argues that it is impossible to obtain an accurate and fair sampling from polls due to the intrusive nature of poll takers, who are compared to telemarketers invading the privacy of people's homes. the author personally feels bothered by these invasive phone calls and is often less than polite when receiving them. they believe that individuals who are willing to participate in polls are not representative of the population as a whole, and those without landlines are often excluded from samples. this skewed sampling may give greater weight to certain candidates, regardless of their actual qualifications for the job of president. the author's conclusion is that polling is not an effective method of gauging the true opinions and preferences of the general population.

Tweet: Why are the Euro-zone members so reluctant to call it quits? It was a noble experiment, it had to be tried, but it failed miserably. Why keep punishing ordinary Europeans in order to save a fatally flawed idea? Let it go. Each country must return to individual currencies. Not doing so will lead to greater and greater misery which in turn will lead to violence and loss of life. It's not worth it. Time to admit that the elite economists and politicians failed Europe. Now the people of Europe must take back their lives. Get rid of the Euro and all the hateful feelings it has engendered in what had been a remarkably peaceful and prosperous group of nations.
Wiki: the document argues that the euro-zone members should abandon the euro and return to individual currencies. it suggests that the euro was a failed experiment and holding onto it is only causing suffering for ordinary europeans. the author believes that keeping the euro will lead to greater misery and even violence. they argue that it's time for the people of europe to take back control and get rid of the euro, which has caused hateful feelings and division among the nations. the document uses strong language to emphasize the negative consequences of sticking with the euro.

Tweet: No two people have the same sense of taste nor does any one person have a consistent sense of taste given variables such as response to environmental allergies and recovery from colds. To say that salt is not offered at the table is Bloomberg Nannyish at minimum and downright control freakish. I long ago sought to reduce the salt in my diet and my taste has adjusted over time, but I have not eliminated salt nor do I intend to. Most baked or roasted poultry dishes are horrible without some added salt and there are other foods that cry out for it- popcorn is a good example. Having worked in healthcare for 27 years I have no illusions about the harm that a high sodium diet can have on some people. However, it is also possible to wisely reduce salt intake and still enjoy it in some foods. As the taste is highly subjective and individual I cannot agree with Mr Sbragg.
Wiki:
this document argues that people have different taste preferences and that a consistent sense of taste is influenced by factors such as environmental allergies and recovery from colds. the writer criticizes the idea of not offering salt at the table as controlling and advocates for the enjoyment of salt in moderation. they mention their own experience of reducing salt in their diet but still enjoying it in some foods. the writer acknowledges the potential harm of a high sodium diet but argues that it is possible to wisely reduce salt intake while still enjoying it in certain foods. they disagree with mr. sbragg's opinion on the subject of salt.

Tweet: As a five year old, I watched the young Queen take up royal duties, after the death of her beloved father. It ignores the facts to imply that all she knows is horses. Having lived through some of the more catastrophic changes on this planet, political as well as economic and personal; bringing a country back from the ruins, and having been forced to make some very tough decisions, which impact millions of people, not just a few paragraphs... Her Royal Highness, has probably, more wisdom than all journalists combined.

Tweet: Muslim women blathering on about solidarity, or the feminism implied by the head scarf, or whatever, are of course free to blather on. Tweet: In my seven decades living in this nation, I'll bet that over a hundred of books on dieting have appeared on the New York Times bestseller list of books. Forgetabout them! Expect it and just realizee that it happened... And immediatly resume your healthy eating pattern. So, you like creamy cheese cake, chocolate, a rare prime sirloin steak... Have them -- infrequently and in moderation. There was a book by a Dr. Tarnow: "The Scarsdale Diet.' It sold a zillion copies and brought the physician fame and fortune. It also caused his death. So, don't say I didn't warn you.
Wiki:

overall, the document stresses the importance of a balanced,

Tweet: I fully agree with everything you've said and would like to add one further point which comes to mind after having recently observed a proceeding in New York Supreme Court in Manhattan. There was a court reporter at work on that case along with an audio system for the benefit of those in the courtroom. Their juxtaposition had me thinking about the need for both several times throughout the day, and I concluded that the audio system would do just fine on its own -- so long as the participants are reminded to speak clearly enough for recording. There were times when I was pretty sure that the judge was relying on the court reporter's good sense of hearing to make a complete transcript and may not herself have heard everything that was said. So, even if court reporters are someday replaced by recording devises, they may still be needed to act as recoding engineers of sorts to ensure a faithful transcription.
Wiki:
the document discusses the use of court reporters or stenographers in the courtroom. the author observed a court proceeding in new york supreme court and noticed the juxtaposition of a court reporter and an audio system. the author concluded that the audio system alone could suffice if participants speak clearly enough for recording. however, there were instances where the judge may have relied on the court reporter's good sense of hearing to make a complete transcript. the author suggests that even if court reporters are replaced by recording devices, they may still be needed to ensure a faithful transcription.

abbreviations expanded:
- i (i)
- new york supreme court (nysc)
- manhattan (manh)
- there was (there was)

slang expanded:
- devises (devices)
- may not (may not)

hashtags expanded:
- #courtstenographer (court stenographer)

Tweet: Of course students should be challenged to learn another language at college. Proficiency in a second (or third) language is beside the point. The actual learning process enforces a discipline that incorporates several facets of adult education - logical thinking, memorization, multimedia exposure (video, audio, in-person interaction, etc). Learning a language creates good study and education habits.
Wiki:
the document argues that college students should be required to learn another language. proficiency in a second or third language is not the main goal; rather, the learning process itself promotes discipline and incorporates various facets of adult education such as logical thinking, memorization, and exposure to multimedia. learning a language also helps develop good study and education habits.

in other words, it is important for students to be challenged to learn another language during college, even if they are not expected to become fluent in it. the process of learning a language encourages discipline and incorporates different elements of adult education, such as logical thinking, memorization, and exposure to various forms of media including video, audio, and in-person interaction. furthermore, learning a language can help students develop good study habits and improve their overall education experience.

Tweet: I taught in an honors pre law program, and another prof won the student popularity contest ( $5000) pretty much every year. Of course, he gave high and easy grades (>3.8/4) using the same tests/answers for 30 years. Our pragmatic but not too bright (or honest) chair also thought the student popularity poll really measured excellence in teaching.
Wiki:
the document describes a situation where a professor in an honors pre-law program consistently won a student popularity contest, earning a $5000 prize every year. however, it is implied that this professor achieved this by giving high and easy grades (>3.8/4) using the same tests and answers for 30 years. the chair of the program is described as pragmatic but not too bright or honest, as they believed that the student popularity poll accurately measured excellence in teaching.

the knowledge from this document implies that the professor may not be truly deserving of the high ratings they receive in the student popularity contest, as they achieve them through grading leniency and not necessarily superior teaching. this suggests that the "rate professor" system may not always accurately reflect the quality of a professor's teaching, as it can be influenced by factors such as grade inflation and popularity contests rather than genuine educational merit.
