Tweet: Libraries are a place for word literate people to visit in the increasingly computer literate wasteland. In a world where we are increasingly ROTFL and LMAO in twitterese or emailese (sorry to make up these proto-language names), some people just want to read a book while surrounded by other books. We want to check them out of the library and bring them back and repeat the process. We are still in love with the comfort of the printed page on paper. If all you are using it for is computer access, stop. Get a cheap android tablet, go to McDonalds, buy lunch and a coffee, get the password from the manager and surf away. Next time you are there, sit in the browsing section and read something other than your electronic reader.
Wiki:
the document highlights the contrast between word literate people who still value printed books and the increasing prevalence of computer literacy. it emphasizes the desire of some individuals to read physical books in the company of other books in a library setting. the document suggests that those who only use libraries for computer access should consider getting a cheap android tablet and utilizing wi-fi at places like mcdonald's instead. it also encourages individuals to take the time to actually read something in the library instead of just browsing on electronic devices.

rofl: rolling on the floor laughing
lmao: laughing my a** off
twitterese: a style of writing typically used on twitter
emailese: a style of writing typically used in emails
 hashtags: a word or phrase preceded by a hash sign (#), used to identify messages on a specific topic.

Tweet: RateMyTeacher.com, a corollary to RateMyProfessor.com, brings out the crazies and the malcontents. Over the past 12-15 years, the comments posted about me are often by disturbed students. Three times I've had to write the site to dispute a student's comments: One who said I knew nothing (I'd written a book on the subject), one who wrote because he was disgruntled about the way I tried to differentiate tests (mandated by the school), and another who commented that I was depressed (far from the truth) -- whom I doubt was even my student! I think the site is dangerous and invites trolling by students with severe misconceptions, those unhappy about grades, and those with gripes that would be better expressed in a face to face discussion. These posted comments affect a teacher's reputation and ability to find another job. I dread looking at the site to see what's there -- but on the other hand, I do look to see if there are comments that need to be removed because they are vicious or false.
Wiki:
the document discusses ratemyteacher.com, which is similar to ratemyprofessor.com. the author claims that the comments posted about them on the site are often made by disturbed students. they have had to dispute comments three times, once because a student said they knew nothing despite having written a book on the subject, another because a disgruntled student didn't like the way they differentiated tests (which was mandated by the school), and a third who commented that the author was depressed, which they believe was not even their student. the author finds the site dangerous and thinks it invites trolling by students with severe misconceptions, those unhappy about grades, and those with gripes that would be better expressed in a face-to-face discussion. they believe that these posted comments can affect a teacher's reputation and their ability to find another job. they dread looking at the site but also do so to see if there are comments that need to be removed because they are vicious or false.

Tweet: Most restaurant food is already too salty. I'd rather they salted their food LESS and let us control our salt at the table. I don't use table salt, myself. I lightly season my food and then if others want more salt they can have it. Salt should be treated as an adjunct. Food should be seasoned with spices. The salt is there to increase those flavors, not to be a flavor in and of itself. At least that's how it worked in my restaurant, and that's what I do at home now that I'm retired.
Wiki: in the document, the author suggests that most restaurant food is already too salty and they would prefer if restaurants salted their food less, allowing customers to control their own salt at the table. the author personally doesn't use table salt and lightly seasons their food, preferring that others can add more salt if they desire. they believe that salt should be used as an adjunct, with food being seasoned primarily with spices. the purpose of salt is to enhance the flavors of the food, rather than being a dominant flavor itself. this approach is how the author operated their restaurant and how they currently season their food at home now that they are retired.

Tweet: This lack of pay is not limited to high school or college internships. It is found throughout the business world. People are encouraged to blog for a major media organization not for pay, but for "the exposure," only to see that media organization sold to another company for hundreds of millions of dollars. Workers age 50 and over, who still have much to contribute, are thrown out of jobs in a subtle form of age discrimination and are then expected to work for free as part of their "retraining" to ease into a new profession that might pay thousands less in the end. Another poster on here mentioned volunteer workers who put in long hours while the heads of those charities reap huge salaries and benefits. The trend toward free labor is another indication of our moral decline. We have to take a stand. People, when you get up tomorrow morning and look at yourself in the mirror, repeat these words: "I WILL NOT work for free."
Wiki:
the document highlights the issue of unpaid work and lack of compensation in various aspects of the business world, not just limited to high school or college internships. it mentions how people are encouraged to blog for a major media organization without pay, under the pretense of "exposure," only to see the organization being sold for a significant amount. it also discusses how workers over 50 are often let go from their jobs and then expected to work for free as part of their "retraining" for a new profession. the document also mentions the exploitation of volunteer workers and the disparity in salaries and benefits between them and the heads of charities. overall, it calls for a stand against working for free.

in the context of college students, this lack of pay and exploitation of labor can be particularly detrimental as they are often in need of financial support and experience to build their careers. the emphasis on "exposure" without compensation is essentially asking them to work for free. the pressure to take on unpaid internships

Tweet: I have had 7 cats over the past 25  years--all rescues. I don't adopt kittens, only cats that are more than 9 months old, simply because there are so many adult cats who are surrendered. I have tried, with each cat, to train them to use a scratching post, put aluminum foil on couch arms, etc etc. NOTHING has worked (and being older cats, they were not amenable to having their nails clipped). All that banning declawing will do is force more and more cats into shelters. My cats have had no litter box issues, no aggression issues, and frankly, while I wouldn't declaw a cat older than 5 yrs, I have no guilt in declawing a young adult cat that then is an indoor-only pet. I understand it is painful but it is certainly less horrible than abandonment, the stress of being surrendered to a shelter (and really, there is a very low chance in many states for that adult cat to be adopted), and/or euthanasia.
Wiki:
the author has had 7 cats over 25 years, all of which were rescues. they only adopt cats over 9 months old because there are so many adult cats in need. they have tried to train their cats to use a scratching post and tried other methods to prevent scratching furniture, but nothing has worked. they believe that banning declawing will result in more cats being surrendered to shelters. they argue that their cats have had no litter box or aggression issues, and while they wouldn't declaw a cat older than 5 yrs, they have no guilt in declawing a young adult cat that is an indoor-only pet. they understand that declawing is painful, but they believe it is less horrible than abandonment, shelter surrender, or euthanasia.

expansion:
- yrs: years
- etc: et cetera
- declawing: the surgical removal of a cat's claws
- amenable: open and responsive to suggestion
- hashtags: a word

Tweet: Reality check for those so far removed that have no idea what the issue is: Women come to the U.S. on temp visas or illegally to give birth in order to have the child become an American citizen. In some cases they stay, and in others they leave with the American child. Those that leave will eventually reap the benefits of American citizenship without ever contributing to it. It's become status symbol for foreign nationals to have children with the blue and gold passport. This is reality; and I'm sure the founding fathers didn't have this in mind when the constitution was adopted.
Wiki:
the document is highlighting the issue of birthright citizenship, where women come to the u.s. on temporary visas or illegally to give birth in order to have the child become an american citizen. some of these women stay in the country, while others leave with their american child. those who leave will eventually benefit from their child's american citizenship without having contributed to the country. the document suggests that having a child with an american passport has become a status symbol for foreign nationals. it also raises the concern that this was not the intention of the founding fathers when the constitution was adopted.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags have been expanded and summarized as necessary.

Tweet: First, I'd like to point out that the original question makes no sense. The behavior is aberrant, not the murder charges. However, I'm sure those of us who object to the aberrant behavior of our police forces surmise that events, like this one, have happened thousands of times, all over this country, without video evidence. Yes, there should be a federal database that goes back, in time, to at least the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

Tweet: The system is out of balance, and it's the national industries with their very different output levels which thrives this diversion. There is a lot of tax-payer money which is trying to counter this, but the money, which is on account of the governments are just peanuts. The german industry is steamrolling the rest of europe, and for this devastation everyone has to pay, first of all the german tax-payers. Just look at france, their demise is now on the lever. Where should this end ? A few countries with a workforce of 50 Mio is liable for producing the need of 350 Mio citizen ? But the main problem are political and social issues. This is a conundrum, the moral hazard - unlike the US every country is liable for their own efficiency. Germany can try to drag along the rest of europe, but one reason for a success is our global competitiveness and we may fail to maintain this - to say the european economy as whole has rightly become global insignificant.
Wiki:
the document discusses how the system is out of balance, with national industries, especially the german industry, thriving and causing a diversion in output levels. it mentions that tax-payer money is being used to counter this, but the amount is inadequate. the german industry is dominating the rest of europe, and this is negatively impacting other countries, such as france. the document questions whether it is fair for a few countries with a workforce of 50 million to produce for the needs of 350 million citizens. it also highlights the political and social issues that contribute to this imbalance. it emphasizes the moral hazard, where every country is responsible for its own efficiency, unlike in the us. it mentions that germany's success is due to its global competitiveness, which it may struggle to maintain. the document concludes by stating that the european economy has become globally insignificant.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- mio: million
- us: united states

Tweet: It's heartbreaking to think of children suffering because of denial of treatment - or protection against disease - from a religion they did not choose. We respect religious belief, but that respect should not extend to medical neglect of children any more than it extends to child sacrifice. There are limits on parental rights and religious freedom, and they should come into play when children are put at risk.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes that it is distressing to imagine children enduring pain and harm because their parents deny them medical treatment or protection against disease due to their religious beliefs. while it is important to respect religious beliefs, this respect should not allow for the neglect of children's medical needs any more than it allows for child sacrifice. the document asserts that there are boundaries to parental rights and religious freedom, and these boundaries should be considered when the health and safety of children are at risk.

Tweet: "Continuing with the I.M.F.-E.U. imposed budget austerity measures risks condemning Greece to several more years of economic misery." Tweet: I have bought organic food and have never noticed that it tasted any better than the non-organic variety. I just paid more for it. Organic food is found in large supermarkets, whereas better food is found in local market with local produce. Plus I never got sick from either one - more important is the country it comes from. I avoid anything from Mexico. I just think Organic food is over-hyped and over-priced. It is not worth the extra money.

Tweet: It never occurred to have our four cats declawed. Their claws are part of them and scratching is what cats do. Tweet: With all due respect, Judge Kopf, digital recording technology cannot capture when somebody is not speaking loud enough, clear enough, or speaks with a thick accent. A court reporter is able to interrupt and clarify for an accurate record. And there is no technology that can replace a real time reporter, who can provide an instantaneous translation, which results in immediate resolution of an issue that might otherwise delay a proceeding and enables judges to speed up their dockets, and lawyers to move on to their next case, which will speed up the judicial system as a whole, therefore saving money, if that indeed is your ultimate goal.
Wiki: the court stenographer is an essential part of the judicial system as digital recording technology cannot capture certain aspects of spoken language, such as low volume, unclear speech, or thick accents. the court reporter is able to interrupt and clarify for an accurate record in these situations. additionally, there is no technology that can replace the real-time reporting and instantaneous translation provided by a court stenographer, which can lead to immediate issue resolution and faster proceedings. this ultimately speeds up the judicial system as a whole, saving money.

Tweet: Simply said the Queen is not going to step down. Upon ascending to the throne she made a vow to serve her people until her death. Words and the people who spoke them truly meant something at that time and still do to people of her generation. Queen Elizabeth came to the throne during a very difficult period for her people and the world and she helped lead her nation from those days to today always as a constant source of pride and inspiration. And it appears that the qualities that made her a loved and inspirational leader skipped a generation bypassing her son, Charles, and now appears rooted in her grandson, William. So I say save the questions about stepping down for Charles for the day after he ascends to the throne.
Wiki: queen elizabeth ii made a vow to serve her people until her death, and this commitment still holds true for her generation. she became the queen during a difficult time and has been a constant source of pride and inspiration for her nation. it seems that the qualities that made her a beloved leader have skipped a generation and are now seen in her grandson, william. therefore, any questions about stepping down should be saved for charles for the day after he ascends to the throne.

Tweet: Rate my Professor is essentially an internet scam to generate site traffic. I am sorry to see it getting this kind of free publicity in a serious paper like the NYT. Rate my Professor is a for-profit site. You can even post a review of someone without ever having taken a class with that person or on a class that the professor never taught. Try it. Most universities have systems for the evaluation of faculty. (I would be surprised if any do not.) They ensure that only students who actually took the class participate in the evaluation process.
Wiki: the document criticizes 'rate my professor' as an internet scam to increase website traffic. it expresses disappointment in seeing the website gain attention in a reputable newspaper like the new york times. the document suggests that 'rate my professor' is a for-profit website where anyone can post a review about a professor, even if they have never taken their class or if the professor never taught that class. the document encourages trying this out. most universities have their own systems for evaluating faculty, ensuring that only students who have taken the class participate in the evaluation process. it also suggests that it would be surprising if any university did not have such a system in place.

Tweet: Some people become addicted to alcohol, but after the fiasco of Prohibition, the United States learned that we were better off legalizing and controlling access to it. Gambling has been legalized in most states, and regardless of the current attempts to block it, Americans today already have access to Internet based gambling. The regulations that currently restrict the banking system from dealing with Internet gamling sites should be eliminated. Regulations should be established to protect consumers. The resulting legal activity should be taxed to pay for the necessary oversight agencies, and to provide assistance for those who can't simply enjoy gambling as entertainment and sport.

Tweet: Most Americans have the same attitude about languages other than their own, as they have about those people who might speak them--fear [and eventually hate]...Although I was educated in what seems like the last ice age, instruction in foreign language began in earnest in middle school and graduating with a bachelor's degree required competency in both a classical (Latin, Greek, Hebrew) and a modern language (French, Spanish, or Italian). Tweet: The only solidarity the hijab shows is with that most ancient of patriarchal male control strategies, shifting the burden of morality, family and male honor, etc., onto the shoulders of female modesty. It is no different from Orthodox Jewish married women having to cover their hair, or the in the Middle Ages married women in Europe were expected to wear a coif to cover their hair, and is nakedly an attempt to confine women's sexual nature in as small a space as possible. It stands in relationship to footbinding and to female genital mutilation, albeit at another point on the bellcurve of control of women and control of female sexuality. If you insist on sacrificing yourself on this altar to show ethnic solidarity, don't be surprised when people conclude that Islam is still stuck in the past. As Rhett Butler once famously said to Scarlett in "Gone with the Wind" when she refused to abandon black mourning clothes for a husband she not only didn't love, but despised, "How closely women clutch the chains that bind them!" Find another way to announce your religious/ethnic identity. Your daughters deserve a better message.
Wiki: the document argues that the hijab symbolizes patriarchal control over women's modesty and sexuality, similar to other historical practices like orthodox jewish women covering their hair and european married women wearing coifs. it compares the hijab to forms of female oppression such as footbinding and female genital mutilation, and suggests that insisting on wearing it for ethnic solidarity perpetuates a backwards view of islam. the author encourages finding other ways to express religious and ethnic identity that do not involve sacrificing women's autonomy. the statement "how closely women clutch the chains that bind them!" reflects the author's belief that women should not feel obligated to adhere to oppressive traditions.

Tweet: As a Creative director and published author I received 15% commission on every book sold and did quite well. Today I can publish my ebook myself and of course edit it after I write it and spell check it as well. Now I can earn 70% on every ebook sold. That allows me quite a bit of leeway in promoting my ebook. Tell me more why I should use an author agent who takes a commission and a publisher who makes a lot of money from my writing? By the way, they never gave authors extra money when they submitted the manuscript electronically saving publishers money by not having to enter text into a computer from typewritten pages-they kept the savings. Well one reason is I may miss the advance on signing most of my rights away on a contract.
Wiki:
the author is expressing their experience as a creative director and published author, where they used to receive a 15% commission on every book sold. they now have the option to self-publish their ebook, allowing them to earn 70% on every ebook sold. they question the need for an author agent who takes a commission and a publisher who makes a lot of money from their writing, especially as publishers did not provide additional compensation for submitting manuscripts electronically, leading to cost savings for the publishers. the author also mentions the potential loss of an advance by signing away most of their rights on a contract.

with regards to amazon, the author may be considering self-publishing on the platform to take advantage of the higher commission rates and the ability to retain control over their work, rather than using a traditional author agent and publisher.

That allows me quite a bit of leeway in promoting my ebook. Tell me more why I should use an author agent who takes a commission and a publisher who makes a lot of money from my writing? By the way, they never gave authors extra money when they submitted the manuscript electronically saving publishers money by not having to enter text into a computer from typewritten pages-they kept the savings. Well one reason is I may miss the advance on signing most of my rights away on a contract.
Wiki:
the document explains that as a creative director and published author, the author received a 15% commission on every physical book sold. however, with the ability to now publish ebooks independently, the author can earn a higher commission of 70% on each sale. this allows for more flexibility in promoting the ebook. the author questions the need for an author agent, who takes a commission, and a traditional publisher, who profits heavily from the author's writing. the author highlights the fact that publishers did not compensate authors for saving money by submitting their manuscripts electronically instead of through typewritten pages. the document also mentions the potential downsides of signing away rights in a contract.

- contract: a legally binding agreement

Tweet: I would tend to agree: Poll results (no matter how ill formed the poll questions) create a public narrative that exists outside of any rigorous definition of reality. This is very much like the artificial Red State / Blue State divide, when in fact most states are clearly purple. But polls tell us Texas is full of tea party nuts, and Massachusetts the lair of well meaning but totally impractical socialists and Harvard pontificators. And ne'er the twain shall meet. This is, of course, a dangerous way to conduct public dialogue, and I lay a lot of the blame on the press, which refuses to call the idiocy of some of these polls out. The fourth estate needs to step back and find some voices of reason.
Wiki:
the document suggests that poll results, despite their poorly constructed questions, create a public narrative that does not accurately reflect reality. this is comparable to the artificial red state/blue state divide, when in reality most states are a mix of both. polls often portray texas as full of tea party supporters and massachusetts as a hub of impractical socialists and intellectuals, creating a false dichotomy. the document argues that this is a dangerous way to conduct public dialogue, and places blame on the press for not criticizing these polls. it calls for the media to find more reasonable voices in public discourse.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- "ne'er the twain shall meet" = "the two shall never meet"
- "lair" = "den" or "home"
- "the fourth estate" = "the media"
- "idiocy" = "foolishness" or "stupidity"
- "step back" = "reconsider" or "

Tweet: I watch enough cooking competitions (on TV) to realize that 4 chefs at a table will not all agree as to the quality and complexity of the seasoning upon the palate. Now add 2 or three courses, and remove the trained palates from diners who may be there for reasons other than the chef's concoction, and you may realize that salt and pepper belong on the table to satisfy the the varying palates of those paying to dine. I like a bit of salt on my salad, especially on tomatoes or the bread which is put on the table. At home in the shaker, we use salt that has the lowest amount of sodium (approx. 280mg per serving) and we have a grinder as well. I rarely add salt without taking a bite first. I have also had dishes where I wish i could remove salt from a dish. Leave it on the table. Those with health concerns and have minimal will power, ask to have it removed from the table.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of placing salt and pepper on the dining table to accommodate the varying tastes of diners. the author mentions that even trained chefs may not agree on the quality and complexity of seasoning, and this is further complicated by the different preferences of diners. the author personally prefers to add a bit of salt to their salad, especially on tomatoes or bread. at home, they use salt with the lowest amount of sodium and rarely add salt without tasting the food first. they believe that salt and pepper should be left on the table for those who wish to use it and that those with health concerns and minimal willpower can ask for it to be removed. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- tv: television
- mg: milligrams

Tweet: With the costs of education FAR outpacing inflation, I wonder what these unpaid interns have to do to keep their heads above water? (Those who aren't lucky/rich enough to have parental support, that is). Of course, the price inflation of education accident. It's due to the government policy of underfunding public education. Coming from a disadvantaged background, I was simply unable afford to take on unpaid work during and after college, regardless of how much it might have helped my future career to do so. Thus I was at a disadvantage compared to peers at my college. This doesn't really sound like a level playing field, does it??? One additional point: The emphasis on internship experience on resumes allows employers an easy way to ascertain which candidates are likely to come from wealthier backgrounds...making it easier for employees to discriminate in terms of social class and race (since certain races are more likely to be represented in the disadvantaged group). Not fair. And we wonder why there are no jobs out there? Employers are filling lots of them for free.
Wiki: the document discusses the financial difficulties faced by college students, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds, in the context of unpaid internships. the author questions how students can afford to work for free, attributing the high cost of education to government policies and underfunding of public education. the author, who was unable to take on unpaid work during and after college, feels at a disadvantage compared to peers. they argue that the emphasis on internship experience allows employers to discriminate based on social class and race, ultimately affecting job opportunities. the author suggests that employers are able to fill positions with unpaid interns, contributing to the lack of jobs in the market. the author expresses frustration with the lack of a level playing field in the job market for college students, and raises concerns about social class and race discrimination in hiring practices.

Tweet: I find most restaurant food too salty. I know this not so much from the taste but the way my body reacts afterwards. I often wake up in the middle of the night with extreme dry mouth after eating out. Since there are some people who should have little to no salt in their diets for health reasons, I'd prefer to see chefs go very lightly with the salt and then let people add salt if they wish.
Wiki:
the document suggests that the author finds restaurant food too salty based on their body's reaction after eating out. they often wake up in the middle of the night with extreme dry mouth, indicating excessive salt intake. the author suggests that chefs should go lightly with the salt to accommodate those who need to limit their salt intake for health reasons, and allow people to add salt to their dishes if they wish.

- i'd = i would
- chefs = chefs
- go very lightly = use a small amount
- add salt = sprinkle salt
- if they wish = if they want to

Tweet: I prefer to know how many people are responding to a Times article in a manner that would please Nazi's and racists and homophobes. I prefer to know why they think such horrifying things, and how deeply they feel about it. And I really appreciate seeing how people hasten to tell them they are seriously wrong. I don't feel that I am in any danger of absorbing horrific ideas simply by hearing them. I would call that a bogus social theory. The converse of the idea that social engineering of permissible ideas is a good thing, is that people respond better if only exposed to approved ideas. That's just as bad.
Wiki:
the document expresses a preference for being able to see the number of people responding to an article in a way that would please nazi's, racists, and homophobes. the author wants to understand why they hold such views and how deeply they feel about them. they also appreciate seeing others quickly correct them when they express such beliefs. the author disagrees with the idea that being exposed to these ideas will lead to them being absorbed, calling it a bogus social theory. they also criticize the concept of social engineering of permissible ideas and believe that people respond better when exposed to a variety of ideas, not just approved ones.

abbreviations and slang: 
- 'i'd' = i would
- 'don't' = do not
- 'isn't' = is not
- 'bogus' = false or fake
- 'hasten to tell them' = quickly correct them
- 'w/o' = without
- 'horrific' = horrifying

Tweet: I'm confused. When, in the process of procreation, does a parent automatically become an expect in medical or educational fields? I'm always amazed when otherwise uninformed parents think they know better than physicians, or think they know more about education than teachers? Does buying a good set of cookware turn you into a professional chef? Does buying a car turn you into an expert mechanic? They don't, and merely having the ability to procreate doesn't turn a parent into someone who can make informed medical decisions.
Wiki: the document is addressing the fallacy that becoming a parent automatically makes someone an expert in medical or educational fields. it argues that just as buying cookware doesn't make someone a professional chef, and buying a car doesn't make someone an expert mechanic, the ability to procreate doesn't make a parent capable of making informed medical decisions. it's a misconception for parents to think they know better than physicians or teachers simply because they have children. this emphasizes the importance of seeking advice and guidance from trained professionals in the fields of medicine and education.

Tweet: I think the concept of rating professors online (like just about any other form of public ratings) is ludicrous. To think that students attending a college where they are to be judged by a professor and given a grade for a class should be taken as fair and impartial in rating that professor's performance makes ZERO sense. Even worse, of course, are people who go out to eat and suddenly find themselves qualified to write for Gourmet Magazine. I read these reviews occasionally but NEVER take them seriously. Still, complaining will do nothing to stop this from occurring. Such are the times we live in and nothing is going to turn back the clock HOWEVER I, for one, think the concept is pretty repulsive and anyone or any institution that takes these ratings seriously is, by my definition, a person not to be taken seriously.
Wiki:
the document argues that the concept of rating professors online is absurd, similar to other forms of public ratings. it points out that students, who are graded by professors in college, cannot be fair and impartial in rating their performance. it also criticizes people who write reviews after dining out, likening them to suddenly becoming food critics. the document expresses disbelief in those who take these ratings seriously and acknowledges that complaining will not change the situation. it concludes by stating that the concept is repulsive, and anyone or any institution that takes these ratings seriously is not to be taken seriously. overall, the document expresses strong disapproval of the "rate professor" concept.

Tweet: According to the Centers for Disease Control, childhood obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. The percentage of children aged 6-11 years in the United States who were obese increased from 7% in 1980 to nearly 18% in 2012. Similarly, the percentage of adolescents aged 12-19 years who were obese increased from 5% to nearly 21% over the same period. Now, more than one-third of American children and adolescents are overweight or obese. The obesity epidemic is linked to screen time, to kids sitting on their butts looking at screens all day, to the lack of outdoor activity and exercise. Mind and body are interactive systems and without a healthy body, there can be no healthy mind. How many yougn people these days are depressed, or hyperactive, or otherwise suffering from some mental disorder --- and how many would benefit from fresh air and exercise and time in the natural world? Mr. Bergman does not even begin to address childhood and adolescent obesity in his screed based only on personal anecdote.

Tweet: According to the Centers for Disease Control, childhood obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. The percentage of children aged 6-11 years in the United States who were obese increased from 7% in 1980 to nearly 18% in 2012. Similarly, the percentage of adolescents aged 12-19 years who were obese increased from 5% to nearly 21% over the same period. Now, more than one-third of American children and adolescents are overweight or obese. The obesity epidemic is linked to screen time, to kids sitting on their butts looking at screens all day, to the lack of outdoor activity and exercise. Mind and body are interactive systems and without a healthy body, there can be no healthy mind. How many yougn people these days are depressed, or hyperactive, or otherwise suffering from some mental disorder --- and how many would benefit from fresh air and exercise and time in the natural world? Mr. Bergman does not even begin to address childhood and adolescent obesity in his screed based only on personal anecdote.
Wiki: childhood obesity has increased significantly in the past 30 years, with more than one-third of american children and adolescents now being overweight or obese. this is partly due to the lack of outdoor activity and exercise, as well as excessive screen time. the document implies that physical exercise is important for maintaining a healthy mind and body, and suggests that spending time in the natural world can benefit mental health. the writer criticizes mr. bergman for not addressing the issue of childhood and adolescent obesity in his personal anecdote.

Tweet: Separating internships as a special class of poorly paid work seems almost pointless. If MacDonald's can't employ a cashier who's willing to work for less than minimum wage (or for free), why can ABC do it for an intern? The only reason for an exception would be if the intern is there for true training purposes and not for the employer's immediate benefit. Clearly, most interns are there to supply grunt labor, whether or not they actually get a chance to show their stuff. Also, the kind of large corporations who hire rafts of interns can certainly afford to pay them minimum wage to escape all legal scrutiny. These firms could still take comfort in knowing that minimum wage isn't nearly enough to live on.
Wiki: the document argues that treating internships as a separate category of poorly paid work is almost pointless. it questions why companies like macdonald's can't employ a cashier for less than minimum wage or for free, while other companies are able to do so with interns. it suggests that the only valid reason for an exception would be if the intern is there for genuine training and not for the immediate benefit of the employer. it also points out that most interns end up doing grunt labor, regardless of whether they get the chance to showcase their skills. furthermore, it mentions that large corporations who hire many interns can afford to pay them minimum wage in order to avoid legal scrutiny. the document also emphasizes that minimum wage is not enough for interns to live on. it suggests that unpaid internships may not be justifiable and that all interns should be paid at least the minimum wage.

Tweet: Yesterday in the UN there were speeches and debates about recognizing Palestine as a member country. This is an entity that has no attributes of a country: no demarcated territory, no army, no domination of its land, no constitution, no postal system, etc. Taiwan is a country. It has been for many years. We need to have Taiwan in the UN. And it was in the UN. Except it was booted out because of the bullying of Communist China. The only time this has ever happened was with Taiwan. Taiwan, not Palestine, needs to be recognized for what it is, a true, independent, democratic state. The US and the rest of the democratic world should immediately recognize Taiwan and honor all treaties with it.

Tweet: Not subject to the jurisdiction of the United States suggests, for example, people born in embassies, which are extraterritorial. Jurisdiction in this context is a territorial concept: i.e. where the laws can be applied. Immigrants, Legal and Illegal, tourists, students, etc. present in the united states while pregnant who deliver a child in the United States are subject to the Jurisdition of the U.S. by virtue of that presence.
Wiki:
the document explains that individuals born in embassies, which are considered extraterritorial, are not subject to the jurisdiction of the united states. jurisdiction in this context refers to the territorial concept of where laws can be applied. it also states that immigrants, both legal and illegal, tourists, students, etc. who are present in the united states at the time of giving birth are subject to the jurisdiction of the u.s. by virtue of that presence.

birthright citizenship refers to the right to citizenship for anyone born in the territory of a country, regardless of the nationality of their parents. this document suggests that individuals born in embassies, which are extraterritorial, are not subject to the jurisdiction of the united states and therefore may not be eligible for birthright citizenship in the u.s.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document expanded:
- u.s. (united states)
- etc. (et cetera)

Tweet: We definitely need libraries!! It was my safe sanctuary when I was chased as a kid by bullies on my way home from school. We definitely need both printed books and Internet access, and digital books accessible from home, too. However, everyone cannot afford the digital devices so public access from the library is necessary. We would be wise to put a library within walking distance of every American, and keep the library open 24/7. The library is the most valuable resource for lifelong learning.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of libraries as a safe sanctuary, providing both printed books and internet access. it emphasizes the necessity of public access and the need for libraries to be within walking distance of every american and remain open 24/7. the library is seen as the most valuable resource for lifelong learning.

Tweet: "The lawsuit against Hearst claims that unpaid internships exacerbate class divisions, because some people can afford to work free and others cannot. But the same could be said of almost any opportunity that allows students from wealthier backgrounds to enhance their human capital more effectively than students from less privileged backgrounds." So....let me get this straight. You are suggesting that we unravel a century of progress in developing and enforcing fair labor and wage laws and protections for young workers, all because life isn't fair? Of course life isn't fair. Some individuals will always have more advantages than others. This does not give us license to actively make the playing field LESS level.
Wiki: the document argues that the lawsuit against hearst claiming that unpaid internships exacerbate class divisions because some people can afford to work for free, while others cannot, can also be applied to many other opportunities that allow students from wealthier backgrounds to enhance their human capital more effectively than students from less privileged backgrounds. the writer disagrees with this argument, stating that it is not a reason to unravel fair labor and wage laws and protections for young workers. they point out that the fact that life isn't fair does not justify making the playing field even more unequal. they believe that individuals should not actively contribute to worsening the inequalities in opportunities and advantages between people from different backgrounds.

Tweet: Fletcher has got it exactly right. The best solution would be for both Elizabeth and Charles to abdicate and turn the Firm over to William and Kate. But since that will not happen, let's postpone until we're left with no choice the ascension of Charles--and even worse, Camilla. The thought of boring, stuffed-shirt Charles as king for decades is bad enough, but having Camilla shoved front and center would be a nightmare come true, even without the formal title of queen. Imagine-year after year of pictures of the two puttering in their garden with their little spades and shooting grouse at Balmoral. Oh, the horror, the horror-made even worse by knowing that Will and Kate are having to lie low. Of course, knowing the media's attention will gravitate anyway toward the young and vibrant, I feel a tinge of sympathy for the sad fate awaiting Charles and Camilla.

Tweet: I am a lifelong reader of the NYT and its comments sections are invaluable to me. As others have said, I often learn as much from the comments as I do from the original article; and I enjoy and appreciate the points of view of other informed readers, even those with whom I disagree, without wading through pages of muck. Yes, I know the NYT's heavy moderation is time-consuming and expensive -- but I believe it has paid off. I would spend much less time reading the NY Times if it did not have its thoughtfully moderated comments. Personally, I think this is a major reason why, unlike so many established newspapers, the NYT seems to be thriving in today's digital world with its online editions.
Wiki:
the document expresses the author's deep appreciation for the new york times' (nyt) comments section, which they find invaluable for gaining additional knowledge and diverse perspectives on the articles. the author believes that the comments section contributes significantly to their enjoyment and understanding of the content. they recognize the heavy moderation by the nyt is time-consuming and expensive, but they believe it has paid off. they argue that the thoughtfully moderated comments are a major reason for the nyt's success in the digital world. the author mentions that they would spend much less time reading the ny times if it did not have its carefully moderated comments.

expansion:
- nyt: new york times
- slang: the document does not contain any slang or hashtags.

Tweet: "Nonfiction can be frighteningly raw. While fiction comforts us with the knowledge that actors are delivering lines crafted by writers, reality television offers no protective cover. Here, even lives are at risk. We must face ourselves and each other." Reality TV shows have become so popular simply because it intrigues us as humans to see how other interact. We watch reality to for entertainment that it has to offer yet is the raw that nothing can seem to conforms us. Its so contradicting with itself that it amuseses us. Reality TV makes us confront with exactly what our society has become. Many say is trash but if is trash then we must reevaluting how our society is today as a whole. If critics seems that reality TV is trash is not worth our time i beg the differ that it is. It opens our eyes of what is out there and the problems we should be dealing with instead of setting them aside to be ignore. No reality TV makes it for us not ignore it anymore but confront it beause we cannot hide behind our lies anymore.
Wiki:
the knowledge from the document is that nonfiction in television can be confrontational and uncomfortable because it presents real-life situations without the protective cover of actors and scripted lines. reality tv shows have become popular because they intrigue us as humans and offer raw entertainment that nothing else can replicate. it is contradictory and provocative, making us face the realities of our society. critics may call it trash, but it forces us to reevaluate our societal values and confront the problems we often ignore. reality tv opens our eyes to what is out there and challenges us to no longer hide behind lies.

- tv: television
- reevaluting: reevaluating
- amuseses: amuses
- i: i
- begs the differ: i beg to differ
- don't: do not

- #society: societal values
- #tv: television

Tweet: Mr. Lackman says Europe will not agree to end its disastrous austerity policies toward Greece for fear that they will have to do so elsewhere. That's a feature, not a bug. Austerity has been bad for Europe as a whole; it's led directly to the third recession in 7 years, and the risk of a long-term stagnation far below economic potential. The defiance by Greek voters should serve as a wake-up call not just for the Irish, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian and French, but for the Germans, Dutch and Finns as well: austerity is killing Europe, and should be abandoned immediately.
Wiki:
the document states that europe is unlikely to end its harmful austerity policies towards greece because they fear that they will have to do the same for other countries. this is seen as a deliberate aspect of the policy, not a mistake. austerity has had negative effects on the european economy, leading to a third recession in seven years and the risk of long-term stagnation. the defiance shown by greek voters should be a wake-up call for other european countries, as well as for germany, the netherlands, and finland. the document calls for an immediate end to austerity policies, as they are believed to be causing harm to the european economy.

Tweet: For some reason farmers (and fisherman) view making a profit as a right. Why should the rest of us support them? Farms are no more required for national security than are supermarkets or restaurants. If those businesses can survive in a free market, so can farms. In a time when unemployment is so high and our infrastructure is crumbling, giving money to farmers is disgraceful. The fact that most subsidies actually go to large agro-business and wealthy farmers is even more galling.

Tweet: I've been an intern at several places and can say that while there are educational elements to them, interns are mostly given grunt work to assist paid employees. After my experience, I have decided I will never be an intern and/or work for free again. A lot of people are fooled into believing that based on their grades and/or standing in school, there is no other way to get your foot in the door. That is not true. As a mediocre student, I was able to find a paid position where I worked, got paid, and just as well received the same educational value I would have received if I was unpaid. In my opinion, interns should receive minimum wage. Granted, they have no experience, minor if not any qualifications, and generally no practical knowledge. However, they use their limbs and their brains just as any paid employee. This would be most fair, and would certainly boost the United States economy.
Wiki:
the document describes the author's experience as an intern and their belief that interns are mostly given low-level tasks to help paid employees. the author has decided that they will never work as an intern or work for free again. they believe that people are misled into thinking that being an intern is the only way to start their career. the author, who was a mediocre student, was able to find a paid position that provided the same educational value as an unpaid internship. they believe that interns should be paid at least minimum wage, as they work just as hard as paid employees. the author also believes that providing fair pay to interns would benefit the economy of the united states.

abbreviations and slang:
- i've been: i have been
- i will never: i will not ever
- and/or: and or
- a lot of: many
- based on: because of
- no other way: another option
- got paid: received payment
- just as well: equally

Tweet: As an American Latino I do not at all like the separation between ' us ' and everyone else. We are one nation. Why are we so quick to say Latino families should be afforded higher education? How, in this age of political correctness, is that okay? Are we going to run around wearing Brown Pride shirts next? If white folk decided to have ' white only ' forums or ' white only ' college programs that would be labeled racist and exclusionary. We Latinos separate ourselves ENOUGH by insisting on very little to zero assimilation in our communities and on being Latin in everything we say, do, read and watch. We even teach our children to shun away from saying they are Americans like its a bad thing. College is NOT a right. As such, we shouldn't to get a free ride just because we happen to speak Spanish at home. It's an archaic way of thinking and not what the American Dream is supposed to be. I do not support segregation in any form. It creates animosity and we have enough of that already. I don't agree with the all black institutions or the Nedro college fund either.
Wiki: the author of the document is expressing their disapproval of the separation between latino families and everyone else. they question the idea that latino families should be given special privileges for higher education. the author believes that this goes against the idea of equality and inclusion, and would be considered racist if it were done by white people. they argue that latino communities already separate themselves by not assimilating and by emphasizing their latin culture. the author does not believe that college is a right and thinks that it is outdated to expect a free ride just because someone speaks spanish at home. they believe that this segregation creates animosity and goes against the american dream. they also disagree with all-black institutions and the nedro college fund.

Tweet: " Congress should delay the law for a year..."? Tell that to my niece whose 17 month old toddler has just been diagnosed with a rare disease that will need years of medical care. Obviously those who seem to be objecting to the new health care law have never faced what 30 million people face in our country every day. For them another year's delay is life or death.

Tweet: Declawing is never a reasonable alternative,mutilating cats does not keep them in their homes just check any non kill animal shelter and see how many declawed cats have lost their homes for litterbox avoidance and aggression caused by the pain of those stumps. Tweet: One of the useful roles a comment sections can serve: an immediate correction mechanism from the general public when an author is demonstrably wrong on the facts. For example, another news site ran an article decrying the fact that none of the presidential candidates had bothered to pay any attention to New York's public housing projects. Within about 15 minutes of the story being released, commenters were putting up links to stories about Bernie Sanders visiting New York's public housing projects about 10 hours earlier, a rebuttal that many readers might have been unaware of had the comment section not existed. And the New York Times' centralized moderation system isn't the only way to get real legitimate debate going, with evidence and logic being thrown around (along with the occasional entertainment like parody song lyrics or poetry).
Wiki:
the document highlights the importance of comment sections as a tool for the general public to immediately correct factual errors made by authors. it gives an example of a news article falsely claiming that none of the presidential candidates had paid attention to new york's public housing projects, and how commenters quickly responded with evidence of bernie sanders visiting the projects. this demonstrates how comment sections can provide a platform for legitimate debate, evidence, and logic to be shared, as well as entertaining content like parody song lyrics or poetry.

- "bernie" expanded to "bernie sanders"
- "ny" expanded to "new york"
- "the occasional entertainment like parody song lyrics or poetry" expanded to "occasional entertainment such as parody song lyrics or poetry"

Tweet: The CIA reminds me by its recent actions of the old joke, "Military Intelligence is a contradiction in terms." To the extent that the CIA has become militarized and lawless, (which is the real reason that the prison at Guantanemo was established, so that torture could take place without the oversight of U.S. law) it has become a detriment to the nation, and a blot on the United States' reputation. We should disband the CIA and assign its responsibilities to civilians who will obey the laws and understand the consequences of covert actions to our foreign relations. The State Department should be well up to the task. Faulty intelligence leads to lost wars and continual embarrassment for the politicians who rely on it. The CIA should have no ties to the Department of Defense, so that operations can be unfettered by a military mindset.
Wiki: the document criticizes the central intelligence agency (cia) for its militarized and lawless actions, particularly regarding the establishment of the prison at guantanamo for the purpose of carrying out torture without oversight. the author believes the cia has become a detriment to the nation and tarnishes the united states' reputation. the suggestion is to disband the cia and transfer its responsibilities to civilians within the state department, as they are more likely to obey the laws and understand the consequences of covert actions on foreign relations. the document also emphasizes the need for the cia to have no ties to the department of defense, in order to prevent operations from being influenced by a military mindset. the mention of the old joke "military intelligence is a contradiction in terms" implies skepticism about the effectiveness of military intelligence. overall, the document calls for a reform of the cia and a transfer of its duties to a more law-abiding and diplomatic entity.

Tweet: Student feedback, in my opinion is a good thing as long as there is mechanism to lift the veil of anonymity when libel is claimed. One area reviews likely address is large differences in difficulty and approaches to the same class. "rate professor" stands for evaluating and providing feedback on a professor's performance.

Tweet: The new Greek govt must do 2 things. One is to negotiate a decrease (or restructuring to longer payment terms) of its debt. That is the immediate problem. The new Govt. may or may not be able to do this. That will depend on how the negotiations go with the creditors. Simultaneously, and very importantly however, Greece must undergo serious economic reforms. For example the creation of a land registry, a stop to political vote buying by politicians, a stop to corruption, the creation of an apolitical statistical service, a non-pollitcal civil servant based on merit instead of cronyism, etc. Does the new Govt show any signs of this (beyond rheteric)? Absolutely not. There are no signs that a land registry will be created, that merit will be the basis of a civil service, that a non-political statistical service will be created or that an effective tax collection agency will be set up. Hence this latter task will not be accomplished.
Wiki: the document discusses the priorities of the new greek government, which is to negotiate a decrease or restructuring of its debt and to implement serious economic reforms. these reforms include creating a land registry, stopping political vote buying and corruption, establishing an apolitical statistical service, and basing the civil service on merit. the document expresses doubt that the new government is showing any signs of taking action beyond rhetoric, and concludes that without these reforms, the economic situation in greece will not improve. abbreviations, slang and hashtags in the document have been expanded to complete phrases and sentences for clarity.

Tweet: This reading of the 14th amendment would first of all outlaw all dual citizenship, since to be a citizen of a country means to owe allegiance to it. Wiki:

Tweet: I seldom read any column or analysis that does not allow comments. I join the others who say they often get more info and insight from the comments than the original piece. Moderating, at this stage in publishing, seems essential to diminish the troll effect. I would suggest a stated policy of allowing only one or two comments per article would also help. One need only go to WaPo to see why. Most comments sections contain over 1,000 posts and are filled with individuals posting scores of comments. Another idea would be to increase moderating and charge a higher subscription rate for the privilege of commenting. One could continue to allow all to read the comments, just charge for writing them. I would be willing to pay a few bucks a month more.
Wiki:
the document highlights the value of comments sections in providing additional information and insight, as well as the need for moderation to prevent trolling. the suggestion is made to only allow one or two comments per article to prevent overwhelming comment sections. it is also proposed to increase moderation and charge a higher subscription rate for the privilege of commenting. the author expresses a willingness to pay a few extra dollars per month for this privilege.
expansion:

Tweet: When did having 75% of the students passing a course with a C or better become a good thing? I think that a 75% passing rate is not good. Did anyone work with these students to understand why only 75% of them passed? How much did the 75% who passed understand? Were they able to apply what they had been taught on line? I've taken online courses and they were not well designed, flexible, or conducive to having a discussion. This holds true for a set of courses I took 5 years ago and for several I've taken in the last year. Having an on line course available in conjunction with a live course would be great. Then the students can go over it to see what they've missed, ask questions if that doesn't help, and refer back to it when their notes aren't enough to recall the subject matter to mind. But exclusive reliance upon on line courses is foolish.
Wiki: the document questions the idea that a 75% passing rate in a course is a good thing, and suggests that it may not be. it raises concerns about whether the students who passed truly understood the material and were able to apply it. the author also criticizes the design and effectiveness of online courses, and suggests that a combination of online and in-person courses would be better. they express the belief that relying solely on online courses is unwise.

Tweet: And then what? Absent genetic testing of all children, we will see a market for US citizen fathers to stand as parent on the birth certificate for mothers without legal status. And what about the kids. How do we conclusively determine to what jurisdiction other than the US they owe allegiance too. This reasoning creates a number of problems.
Wiki: the document discusses the potential consequences of not conducting genetic testing on all children, particularly those born to mothers without legal status in the us. it predicts that there may be a market for us citizen fathers to falsely claim parentage on the birth certificates of these children. this could create complications in determining the children's allegiance to jurisdictions other than the us. the document is raising concerns about the issue of birthright citizenship and the potential for fraud and legal complications in determining a child's nationality and rights.

Tweet: I write as professor emeritus from a well-known institute of higher education. For over 4 decades I taught marketing research which is inherently involved in measurement. I know from teaching this subject and conducting research, measurement is a very complex and unforgiving process and is as good ad the instrument and its administration. As much as I believe that good measurement of performance is very valuable to faculty members, I also believe that much of this measurement is done carelessly and unscientifically. Consequently, you are more likely to see extreme results and some that do not make the intended sense at all. One of the best compliments I received from a student was in the form of what he or she must have thought to be highly critical, and I quote: "The worst teacher I have ever had. He did not teach me anything, I had to read the book myself." Read it once more if you like and think about it, this is what we call measurement?
Wiki: the document, written by a professor emeritus from a well-known institute of higher education, discusses the complexity of measurement in marketing research. the author emphasizes the importance of good measurement in evaluating faculty performance but criticizes the careless and unscientific approach to measurement. the author also shares a student's criticism, which they see as a form of measurement. the document criticizes the 'rate professor' system, as it often leads to extreme and nonsensical results. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document are expanded as follows: 'i write as professor emeritus from a well-known institute of higher education.' Tweet: Ryan Radia writes like someone who is a newbie to Android. He could get better informed by following XDA-Developers, AndroidCentral, or a similar group of people who understand Android. Mr. Radia could also visit the PlayStore and look at all the applications, like Titanium Backup, that require root access to function. App Quarantine Pro, would let you lock down crapware so that it does not run down your battery, slow your device, or spy on you. You cannot use sophisticated spyware blockers because that interferes with Google, the device manufacturers and the networks from selling your personal data. Google, the device makers, and the networks, collude to prevent people from actually owning their devices. If they really belonged to us, we would be able to install software to backup them up to an external hard-drive. We would be able to decide which applications to uninstall. We would be able to decide upon the rules applications have to follow when they are on our devices, not the "take it or leave it" practices we have at present.
Wiki: this document criticizes ryan radia for his lack of knowledge about android and suggests that he could become better informed by following online communities like xda-developers and androidcentral. it also recommends that he explore the playstore and look at applications like titanium backup that require root access. the document also discusses app quarantine pro as a way to lock down unwanted software and mentions the limitations of spyware blockers. it highlights the collusion between google, device manufacturers, and networks to prevent users from fully owning their devices, including the ability to back them up to external hard drives and uninstall applications. it criticizes the current "take it or leave it" practices in place.

Tweet: I learned cursive in grade school back in the 80's and I haven't stopped using it since. It's a skill I am grateful I have. As kids, we took pride in our handwriting...today...I don't think kids know what a pen is. That's sad. I look at some handwriting from pretty high level professionals and it's atrocious. People don't even write whole words anymore. To me, this speaks to standards, which I believe were effectively lowered forever when spellcheck was invented. Soon the question will be asked...do children need to write at all...can't they just text the answers to their teachers? I, for one, look forward to the beautifully handwritten notes I get from friends and remember them much more than emails and text messages. Please, let's not lower the standards on handwriting too.
Wiki:
the document highlights the value of learning cursive handwriting in grade school and the importance of maintaining this skill. the author expresses concern about the decline in handwriting standards due to the reliance on technology such as spellcheck and the preference for typing over writing. there is a fear that future generations may not see the importance of handwritten notes. the author advocates for maintaining high standards in handwriting and preserving the art of writing by hand.

the author states that they learned cursive in grade school in the 1980s and have continued using it since. they are grateful to have this skill and believe that as children, they took pride in their handwriting. they lament the fact that kids today may not even know what a pen is, and are troubled by the declining handwriting standards. the author is also concerned about the impact of technology on handwriting and wonders if children will even need to write at all in the future. they emphasize the value of handwritten notes and express a desire to maintain high standards in handwriting.

Tweet: Odd for me to say this since I am (a) so deeply committed to technology and computers and type super fast (>100wpm), and (b) have really bad handwriting -- but I cannot imagine not writing in cursive. Writing in print is impossible. It is so slow as to be like using a early (not even late) generation dial-up modem. And for me at least, writing does stimulate thinking in a way that nothing else does. I took all my college and law school exams in writing, even though we were allowed to type them. For me at least, not being able to write really really fast would greatly lessen my capabilities. Indeed, I've even thought about taking a short-hand class since my writing is just for me, not anyone else.
Wiki:
the document highlights the author's strong preference for writing in cursive, despite being deeply committed to technology and computers and having bad handwriting. they feel that writing in print is too slow and that writing stimulates their thinking in a way that nothing else does. they even took all their college and law school exams in writing, even though they were allowed to type them. they believe that not being able to write fast would greatly lessen their capabilities and have considered taking a shorthand class. 

the author values the speed and fluidity of cursive writing, and they feel that it is essential for their academic and professional performance. they also believe that writing by hand is a unique and important part of their thinking process.

Tweet: Well stated. This is the essence of what teaching is about, beyond basic preparation of material for the whole class. It's hard to understand why this isn't more obvious to people, especially educated people who have benefited from great teachers in their career. While online tools have much to offer to complement the learning experience when used well, the only reason to see them as a substitute for real teaching is as a major (low quality) cost savings for the masses. And a homogenization of education to serve the needs of big corporate providers of educational materials.
Wiki: the document emphasizes that the essence of teaching goes beyond simply preparing material for the whole class. it argues that this should be obvious, especially to educated individuals who have benefited from great teachers. the document suggests that while online tools have their advantages, they should not be seen as a substitute for real teaching, as this would be a low quality cost-saving measure and would lead to a homogenization of education to serve the needs of big corporate providers of educational materials. overall, the best way to approach teaching is to prioritize the human connection and individualized learning experience over cost-cutting and standardization.

Tweet: Then why do German voters continue to elect politicians that support the Euro and punish those that don't? If every friendship ended where money was involved, there could be no friendship between, for example, the former East Germany and the West. Fortunately, many Germans want to help the Mediterranean. They vacation there, they buy their olive oil from them. What's not to like?

the document suggests that german voters continue to elect politicians who support the euro and penalize those who do not because they want to maintain friendships and economic relationships within the european union. the author points out that many germans want to support the mediterranean countries by vacationing there and buying their products, indicating a sense of solidarity and mutual benefit. overall, the document implies that german support for the euro and the european union is driven by a desire for intercultural and economic connections.

Tweet: Great quote from a friend of mine who now lives in Germany (where they have real labor laws and a better economy, social services, etc): "People who don't have to work for a living shouldn't meddle with those of us who do." 'Nuff said.

Tweet: Tactile is necessary, along with virtual. Much of the digital landscape, aside from e-books, gets taken out of context, condensed, regurgitated as pull quotes, whether proofread/fact-checked or not. Tweet: I disagree. For some of us, such as runners who go out in the sweltering heat for a long distance run in the desert, replenishing the salt and electrolytes lost during the run is a matter of health and recovery, not merely a flavoring option. I can understand that sedentary people and some chefs might blanch when the see me salting my food at a restaurant. But I'd like them to realize that I am doing so almost as a medicinal application and would prefer they reserve judgment until they've run a dozen miles in my shoes.
Wiki: the document argues that for some people, like runners who endure long distance runs in extreme heat, replenishing lost salt and electrolytes is essential for health and recovery, not just a matter of taste. the author understands that sedentary people and some chefs may be surprised to see them adding salt to their food at a restaurant, but they want others to understand that they do it as a medicinal practice. the author would like others to reserve judgment until they have experienced running long distances in their shoes. the document does not mention 'place table', so there is no relevant information to summarize. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags are not used in the document.

Tweet: I disagree. For some of us, such as runners who go out in the sweltering heat for a long distance run in the desert, replenishing the salt and electrolytes lost during the run is a matter of health and recovery, not merely a flavoring option. I can understand that sedentary people and some chefs might blanch when the see me salting my food at a restaurant. But I'd like them to realize that I am doing so almost as a medicinal application and would prefer they reserve judgment until they've run a dozen miles in my shoes.
Wiki: the document emphasizes the importance of replenishing salt and electrolytes lost during long distance runs in hot environments for runners. the author explains that salt is not just a flavoring option, but a matter of health and recovery in such situations. they express understanding that sedentary people and chefs may be surprised to see them salting their food at a restaurant, but they want others to understand that they are doing so for medicinal reasons and ask for them to reserve judgment until they have experienced a similar situation. the author wants others to realize the importance of salt for rehydration and recovery during intensive physical activity.

Tweet: Count me a longtime fan of the 14th Amendment of the US Constitution, for its breadth and scope that encompasses the greatest of American values: not just defining citizenship, but setting forth states' obligations, due process, equal protection of the laws, This was the Amendment that required the states to follow the Bill of Rights. Brown v Board of Education, civil rights laws, privacy rulings, women's rights, gay rights, disability protections, they all flow from the 14th. Start tinkering, and you're risking a lot more than the status of some native-born children.
Wiki:
the document expresses support for the 14th amendment of the us constitution, as it encompasses important american values such as citizenship, states' obligations, due process, and equal protection of the laws. the amendment requires states to follow the bill of rights, and has influenced important legal decisions related to civil rights, privacy, women's rights, gay rights, and disability protections. it warns against tinkering with the amendment, as it could jeopardize the status of native-born children.

Tweet: Back in the day I recall getting my midterm and paper back while taking the final. The prof did not give me my paper during the exam because I had done poorly and he did not want me to lose my concentration. Nice guy. When I finally got the paper from him and he told me how bad it was I had to hold my tongue because he could still have failed me. Of course if I had known I was doing poorly in the class I would have gone to his office and asked him how I could improve. Ask what I was doing wrong. He had done nothing wrong and it was common for profs to do the minimum of work. I am so glad there is a forum now where people can be called out on their sloppy efforts.
Wiki:
the document describes a personal experience of receiving a poor grade on a midterm paper and being given feedback during a final exam. the writer expresses appreciation for the professor's consideration in not giving the paper during the exam to avoid distraction. however, they also express the desire for more proactive feedback and communication to understand their performance and improve. the writer also criticizes the attitude of some professors and expresses gratitude for forums where students can hold educators accountable.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- profs: professors
- glad there is a forum now: satisfied with the existence of a platform for discussion and feedback
- sloppy efforts: work that is not done carefully or thoroughly

Tweet: I would no more declaw a cat than fly to the moon on gossamer wings! There's another option, which some consider to be more humane, and that is to cut the muscles or whatever that allow the cat to retract its claws. They just flop in or out, depending on the position of the cat. PLEASE explain to me why this form of torture is more humane than declawing. I could never maim, hurt, torture or kill any animal. My cat is a strictly indoor creature, she has all of her claws and a nice big scratching post/cat tree. She has NEVER ONCE scratched on anything but that. I taught her to do that. It is NOT impossible to train a cat!
Wiki:
the document argues against declawing cats, stating that it is a form of torture and inhumane. the alternative suggested is to cut the muscles or whatever that allow the cat to retract its claws, which some consider to be more humane. the author emphasizes that they could never maim, hurt, torture, or kill any animal, and that it is possible to train a cat to use a scratching post or cat tree. they also express that their cat, who has all of her claws, has never scratched on anything other than the designated scratching post. 

explanation of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- i would no more declaw a cat than fly to the moon on gossamer wings! = i would never declaw a cat, it is as unlikely as me flying to the moon on delicate wings!
- please = please
- cat tree = a tall structure for cats to perch and scratch on
- #torture = the act of causing severe pain or suffering
