Tweet: This is an excellent column and just underscores the need for better training and supervision. The Philadelphia police superintendent, Charles Ramsey, who used to be in charge of Washington D.C. police, recently asked the Justice Department to review the Philly police and make recommendations. Ramsey saw that better procedures and training in D.C. ended up dramatically reducing firearms use by police and saving lives. The whole incident in South Carolina also just underscores the need to have cameras wherever police are operating, because the word of police officers simply cannot be trusted when their career or promotion is on the line. Despite the oath, police officers are human beings and no more or less likely to tell the truth.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the need for better training and supervision in the police force. philadelphia police superintendent, charles ramsey, who previously led the washington d.c. police, has requested the justice department to review the philadelphia police and make recommendations. ramsey observed that improved procedures and training in d.c. significantly reduced the use of firearms by police and saved lives. the recent incident in south carolina further highlights the importance of having cameras at all police operations, as the word of police officers cannot always be trusted when their career or promotion is at stake. despite taking an oath, police officers are human and may not always tell the truth.

Tweet: "Just as there are good and bad refrigerators, there are good and bad professors." Really? Anonymous on-line evaluations have been shown to be spurious. This is supported by published research and personal experience. Student evaluations of courses are strongly correlated to grade. Glaringly obvious when most variables are removed; e.g., comparing physics course sections covering identical material, taught by the same professor, in the same semester, and with the same assessment measures. NB, physics has the advantage that grades are based on scores, not potentially subjective measures, hence it was not the case that students' grades were influenced by the instructor's impression of them. More accurate measures are evaluations by trained, paid, identified peers and students. Education is a big investment - use evaluation tools that are robust, not junk.
Wiki: the document argues that anonymous online evaluations of professors have been found to be unreliable, based on both published research and personal experience. it points out that student evaluations of courses are strongly linked to the grade received, and suggests that this correlation is particularly evident when other factors are controlled for, such as comparing physics courses taught by the same professor with the same material and assessments. the document also emphasizes the importance of using evaluation tools that are more accurate, such as assessments provided by trained, paid, identified peers and students, rather than relying on potentially flawed anonymous online evaluations. the passage also suggests that education is a significant investment and should use robust evaluation measures rather than unreliable ones.

Tweet: Why no mention of the great communal living alternative, near-campus co-op housing? All the benefits of living in groups (diverse population and late night discussions included) and lower costs thanks to the residents taking on much of the upkeep of the building, cooking of the communal meals, etc. There are small co-op houses of under 20 and large ones with closer to 200 students. The best are part of co-op systems where the houses can benefit from economies of scale, residents are actually owners during their time at the house, and afford to hire some professional staff -- but students can have a good experience even with less-formalized independent group houses that are run co-operatively though they may technically be rental houses.
Wiki:
the document discusses the benefits of living in near-campus co-op housing, including a diverse population, late-night discussions, and lower costs due to residents taking on building upkeep and communal meal cooking. there are small co-op houses with under 20 residents and large ones with closer to 200. the best co-op houses are part of systems where they benefit from economies of scale, residents are owners during their time at the house, and can afford to hire professional staff. students can have a good experience in less-formalized independent group houses that are run cooperatively. this information applies to individuals who do not identify as a muslim.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags translated:
- co-op: cooperative
- etc.: et cetera

Tweet: 1) Except for updates and corrections to the story, authors who get involved in the comments section of their articles are not doing themselves any service. 2) It may come as a surprise, but authors of articles are not omniscient. Comment sections usually bring out pertinent points and perspectives that the author omits. 3) It is important, especially for social and politics issues to understand not only the content of an article but what the opinion of the public is toward the article that can be particularly important, and more relevant than any poll. 4) The internet is, by nature, interactive. If you present topics of current interest and don't give people the ability to interact with them, people will go elsewhere to where they can. 5) Most people want to have a discussion about issues that of importance to them, few simply want to sit and be lectured to.
Wiki: the document highlights the importance of authors engaging with the comment section of their articles, as it provides valuable perspectives and points that the author may have overlooked. it emphasizes the significance of understanding public opinion, especially for social and political issues, and the need for interaction and discussion on current topics of interest. it also points out that most people want to have a conversation about important issues rather than being lectured to. for college students, this means that they should actively participate in discussions and be open to different perspectives and viewpoints. they should also consider public opinion when forming their own opinions on social and political issues. additionally, they should seek out opportunities for interaction and discussion on topics that are relevant to them. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags have not been used in the document provided.

Tweet: There is nothing in this excellent comment with which I would want to disagree. However, I also want to add that a place with books, whether it is my house or a library, is a vital resource that brings benefits not to be found on the Internet (I am a technologist, by the way). Our local library was been closed for a couple of years for a major renovation and to save money (no good alternative was offered or created in the community). Not having a library is like losing the heart of the community. I find libraries superior to the Internet for what most people believe they get best online: random access to information and facts. Online, I don't come across things for which I am not searching. In a library, it is all there before me, waiting. Just walking through the reference room can lead to unexpected discoveries, diversions and, on occasion, new directions. We need both books and electronic information. Whoever imagined we needed to choose?

Tweet: As someone who was permanently disabled due to a Christian Science upbringing, I wholeheartedly support this call to eliminate religious loopholes in child protection laws. Tweet: The research on this issue is clear, which the Yale provost might read ---picking up a second language in college is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, for adult learners ---that is not to say that there are students who do have a talent for second language acquisition, but most of us do not. Now having said that, the odds of learning a second language increase dramatically at the elementary level. We have a habit, when discussing educational matters, of aiming curricular reforms at high school and colleges, when, we should be focused on the age groups where learning a second language is optimum---so, instead of Yale, we should be looking at enlarging dual language programs at the K - 8 system.
Wiki:
the document states that it is very difficult, if not impossible, for adult learners to pick up a second language in college. it mentions that while some students may have a talent for it, most do not. however, the odds of learning a second language increase dramatically at the elementary level. the author suggests that instead of focusing on high schools and colleges, we should be enlarging dual language programs at the k-8 system.

in the comment section, we can expand abbreviations, slang, and hashtags into complete phrases and sentences. for example, "k-8" can be written as "kindergarten through 8th grade". "yale" can be written as "yale university". this will help provide clarity and understanding for readers who may not be familiar with the original abbreviations and slang used in the document.

Tweet: Perhaps the reason more students pass online courses is the content and standards are less rigorous than in a traditional classroom. In Texas, EVERY high school class is offered as an online option -- including art, speech, science with a lab, and (wait for it) physical education! As a teacher, I am disappointed that these courses replace meaningful interaction, critical thinking, and problem solving with worksheets and rote memorization. Maybe some online courses are engaging, but not the ones I have seen. This trend (like many these days) is an insult to good teachers.

Tweet: Imagine that I were the first person to discover that water molecules are made up of two hydrogen atoms covalently bonded to an oxygen atom. Should I be allowed to patent the molecular formula for water? Should everyone who uses water after that point or does research on water have to pay me a nickel? See how absurd that sounds? To me, the gene debate is no different. If I assemble a new molecule that did not exist before, like the buckyball, I own the rights to it. But if I merely discover what the molecule looks like, I can't claim ownership of that.
Wiki: the document is discussing the issue of patenting genetic information and molecular formulas. it argues that the act of discovering something like the molecular formula for water, or the structure of a molecule like the buckyball, should not give the discoverer the right to patent it. this is because it is seen as absurd to claim ownership over something that already exists in nature. this position aligns with the democratic value of fairness and equal access to resources, as it suggests that genetic information and molecular formulas should be open and accessible to everyone, rather than being owned and controlled by a few individuals or corporations. it also advocates for a more open and free exchange of scientific knowledge and information.

Tweet: When I am confronted by religious practitioners passionately arguing for absolute religious freedom I have lately started to pose questions of them rather than argue. For example, how should we deal with a religious group that practices cannibalism? Among those societies that have practiced it, there has been a sacred and even reverential set of beliefs built around sharing in the admirable qualities of the person whose flesh is shared. Supposedly wine becomes blood and bread becomes flesh during Communion. I am met with incredulous stares when I mention this. It could never happen, I am told. When I press on further and ask about female genital mutilation, which IS practiced in certain cultural/religious cultures today, I am met with silence. My point is that there are limits to religious freedom even if we don't codify them. These limits seem to be that religious freedom ends when harm to others starts and no amount of sincere, passionate belief in some deity can overcome them. We know intuitively what we as a society are willing to accept and harming children is not among them. What we do to ourselves as adults is one thing. Losing a child unnecessarily harms us all.
Wiki: the document discusses the limits of religious freedom, particularly in cases where harm to others is involved. the author poses questions about how to deal with religious practices such as cannibalism and female genital mutilation, arguing that religious freedom should not extend to practices that harm others. the author emphasizes that harming children is not acceptable in society, and that religious freedom should not be used to justify such harm. when it comes to the topic of 'hijab', the document suggests that while individuals should be free to make choices about their own clothing and religious expression, these choices should not extend to harming others. abbreviations and slang have been expanded for clarity and include phrases such as "communion" and "female genital mutilation".

Tweet: I wonder of what use my comments would be without that I stood by them. Do I honestly have any crucial wisdom to impart upon the world that would be of such benefit that even doing so anonymously would be of service to the community? Or does it just make me feel good to spew? But truthfully - the reaction given by the readership here - anonymous or not - has got to be a reasonable barometer of the feelings of the community, whether or not an individual feels comfortable posting as a person, or only as a glyph. And there is value in that for us all.
Wiki:
the document reflects on the value of anonymous comments and the impact they can have on the community. it questions whether the author has any important wisdom to share, and whether anonymity serves any purpose. it suggests that the reaction of the readers, whether anonymous or not, reflects the feelings of the community and holds value for everyone.

Tweet: The main problem with Rate My Professor as a reliable guide to the quality of the instructor is statistical: the proportion of students who post anything is tiny; and they are not necessarily representative. Those who post ratings are more likely to be those with strong views. They may even have a specific purpose in posting, such as boosting or trashing the instructor. Yet given the total number of students most professors teach (about 1000 over ten years), the responses of a few dozen are a poor guide to anything.

Tweet: The lede to the story asks, "Are murder charges against a patrolman an aberration or an example of how police use deadly force too easily?" The premise is wrong, setting up a false dichotomy. Tweet: I'm saddened that cursive is not considered important. Both my school-age boys (8th and 10th grade) have horribly illegible printing habits. They sometimes cannot read cursive. Tweet: While I understand the desire to protect those addicted to gambling, the simple truth is that gambling addicts are already gambling online, without any oversight or regulation. The illegality of it isn't stopping that. Legalization would bring a huge underground industry into the open. Furthermore, the negative opinions make it sound like every computer in America will be wired into an online casino. School and workplace computers will certainly not be able to do that without detection by supervisors, and parents can keep their kids away by making sure they don't have access to credit cards. The simple fact is that millions of Americans enjoy gambling and do so responsibly. If we're going to keep it illegal because a small minority can't control themselves, then I guess we better get busy outlawing alcohol, tobacco, and fast food too.
Wiki:
the document argues that while it is important to protect those addicted to gambling, the reality is that gambling addicts are already gambling online without any oversight or regulation. the illegality of online gambling is not stopping this behavior, and legalizing it would bring the underground industry into the open. the document also addresses concerns that the negative opinions on online gambling make it seem like every computer in america will be wired into an online casino, but argues that school and workplace computers would not be able to do this without detection by supervisors, and parents can prevent their children from accessing it by making sure they don't have access to credit cards. finally, the document points out that millions of americans enjoy gambling responsibly and suggests that keeping it illegal because a small minority cannot control themselves would justify outlawing alcohol, tobacco, and fast food too.

Tweet: I can't speak to the ways the student vote affects national politics, but it can have a ruinous effect on the local community. The politically liberal university city I live near is dominated -- and made barely functional -- by both the votes of both current college students and the never-grow-up graduates who stick around after leaving school. Too many of the students vote for what they think sounds cool. They don't think about or care about the consequences. It's easy to vote for a new tax or bond when you aren't the ones paying for it. It's just so cool to vote for a city or county politician who advocates for free everything -- more subsidized housing and shelters for the homeless and drug treatment centers and...on and on -- when every summer you return to your mom and dad's comfortable home in a leafy suburb far, far away. Voting should be tied to one's legal address, period. And for dependent children, that legal address should be where mom and/or dad, or legal guardians, live.
Wiki: the document argues that the student vote in a politically liberal university town can have a detrimental effect on the local community. the author believes that many students and never-grow-up graduates vote for what they think sounds cool without considering the consequences, as they are not the ones paying for it. they advocate for tying voting to one's legal address, especially for dependent children. this content could be related to a reality show by highlighting how the voting behaviors of college students and recent graduates impact the local community, potentially creating drama and conflict. for clarity, the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document could be expanded into complete phrases and sentences.

Tweet: Nick, homeschooled kids are part of society. They just don't go to public school, same as private school kids. In my state, the state athletic organization that oversees high school sports created guidelines for homeschooler participation in high school sports. They must meet academic and other requirements that enrolled kids must meet, but as long as they do, they are eligible. The overseeing organization realized that excluding homeschoolers was indeed discriminatory, and set about creating a system within which they could participate. In other states, there are laws on the books that require schools to allow homeschoolers to participate in school activities. My daughter was very involved in sports, and very talented at it, and she took advantage of both elite leagues and her high school teams (she was an enrolled student, not a homeschooler). The elite leagues are available to those who can make the teams, true, and most serious athletes participate in them. It's the lack of programs for the average kid after the age of 14 that's a problem. Also, even those who can make the elite teams can't always afford the fees.
Wiki:
the document discusses how homeschooled kids are indeed part of society and should be allowed to participate in school activities, such as high school sports. some states have created guidelines for homeschooler participation in high school sports, ensuring they meet academic and other requirements. in some cases, laws require schools to allow homeschoolers to participate in school activities. the lack of programs for average kids after the age of 14 is a problem and the fees for elite leagues can be prohibitive.

in relation to 'declawing cat', the document does not directly discuss this topic, so there is no specific knowledge to summarize. it does, however, provide a perspective on the inclusion of homeschooled kids in school activities. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags are not used in the document.

Tweet: I agree wholeheartedly. It's true that I was in college a long time ago, but living in a dorm was mostly a great experience. And the parts that weren't great were good for my maturing process. Tweet: I am not a statistician, but from what I see on media, there is a relation between race and shootings. It's only the black victims that get the media attention, and it only happens to men, never women, who get into a fight with the cops. There should be a community education program to teach the young black men how to behave when a cop stops them. The black priests should educate their congregation good manners better before accusing others of racism.
Wiki:
the document implies that there is a perception of a connection between race and police shootings, with the belief that only black men receive media attention for these incidents. it suggests implementing a community education program to teach young black men how to behave when encountering the police, and for black priests to educate their congregation on good manners before accusing others of racism.

expand the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- "media" means the news and entertainment outlets that provide information to the public.
- "cops" is a slang term for police officers.
- "community education program" refers to a program aimed at educating and raising awareness within a specific community.
- "congregation" in this context means the members of a church or religious community.

Tweet: I'm an academic advisor in natural sciences at a big university; day after weary day I advise students with below average grades who have unrealistic expectations and cannot accept the fact that - contrary to what they've been told all of their lives - they cannot be a scientist or doctor. Virtually every day I advise one or more students with "B" averages in math, chemistry and biology who persist in the belief that they will get into medical school, all the while accumulating massive debt and wasting time. I don't even really have the hope that one day they will wake up; I forget who said that "most people can't stand too much reality."
Wiki:
the document describes the frustration of a academic advisor in natural sciences at a university who continuously advises students with below average grades and unrealistic expectations. many of these students believe they can still become scientists or doctors, despite their grades, accumulating debt and wasting time. the advisor feels that these students cannot accept the reality that they may not achieve their dreams.

expanding the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document into complete phrases and sentences:

- b averages: "b" grades in math, chemistry and biology
- medical school: the advisor is referring to students who want to get into medical school
- massive debt: refers to the large amount of student loan debt these students are accumulating
- wasting time: the advisor believes that these students are not using their time effectively
- wake up: the advisor does not have hope that these students will realize the reality of their situations.
- can't stand too much reality: indicates that most people struggle with accepting harsh truths.

Tweet: With an increase in insurance mergers, and the most recent Aetna/Anthem failed merger due to the FTC, there has been a substantial decrease in competition within the insurance sector. Lack of competition is bad for consumers because there are less players fighting for your business, so it is easier to raise, and keep prices high. Obamacare has also made it impossible for insurance companies to price policies based on pre-existing conditions, which is forcing actuaries to increase insurance costs across the board. Aetna has lost hundreds of millions of dollars on it's Affordable Care Act arm and is dropping the option in 11 out of the 15 states where it was offered. If insurance companies keep getting strangled by the government, there will be a sharp decrease in the participation rate of the Affordable Care Act and the Gov't may be left on the hook to provide policies (socialism) although I'm not sure what would happen if private participation drops off a cliff. If the trend continues, AFA is not sustainable.
Wiki:
the document discusses the impact of insurance mergers and government regulations on the insurance sector. it highlights the decreased competition in the insurance industry, leading to higher prices for consumers. the failed aetna/anthem merger, the effects of obamacare on insurance pricing, and the financial losses incurred by aetna are also mentioned. the document states that the affordable care act (afa) is not sustainable if the current trends continue.

expansion of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- ftc: federal trade commission
- aetna/anthem: aetna and anthem
- obamacare: the patient protection and affordable care act
- ftc: the federal trade commission
- afa: affordable care act
- gov't: government

Tweet: In my experience, those with trust funds could afford to work the unpaid internships that lead to full-time jobs. Those who can't afford to work for nothing, whose parents do not support them while they are doing unpaid work, can't get in at the bottom level of companies that hire 'interns' and in this way -- money = opportunity is put in the hands of those with capital.
Wiki:
the document argues that people with trust funds have the financial means to take on unpaid internships, which often lead to full-time job offers. on the other hand, those who can't afford to work for free, because their parents don't financially support them, are unable to access these entry-level opportunities. this essentially means that money equals opportunity, and it gives an advantage to those with capital.

with respect to 'coop accommodation', this highlights the potential financial barriers that some people face in trying to access opportunities in the workforce, including housing. as a result, individuals who can't afford to work for free may also struggle to find affordable housing, making it even more difficult for them to enter certain industries or professions.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- 'coop' refers to cooperative accommodation
- 'interns' is in quotation marks to imply that these positions may not necessarily provide valuable learning experiences
- 'money = opportunity' emphasizes the idea that financial resources can provide access to opportunities

Tweet: When I visit NY, I spend time on the North Fork of Long Island, known for its many conventional wineries. The landscape is beautiful. Now, if there are no benefits to organic farming, how come so many of the vineyards have huge signs with skull and crossbones that say: "do not enter, pesticides are dangerous"? Every time I pass by I wonder about the high incidence of breast cancer in Long Island, and I wonder about the farm workers working on the vines, and I wonder about the need to post these signs if it is all so very safe.
Wiki: the document discusses the author's experiences visiting the north fork of long island, known for its many traditional wineries. they wonder about the high incidence of breast cancer in long island and the potential impact of pesticide use on farm workers and the environment. the writer questions the need for warning signs about the dangers of pesticides if organic farming has no benefits. #ny refers to new york, and #longisland refers to the region in new york.

Tweet: If my coreligionists, let's say religion XYZ, was seen everyday, everywhere, as perpetrators of massacres and other inhuman brutality, and here in the US I went about displaying all the outward signs that I am proud of my religion no matter what, it is all but natural and logical that other people not belonging to my religion, XYZ, will look askance at me, even possibly hate me and harm me. This is not rocket science - why do the hijab-wearers find it so difficult to understand? I have often seen immigrant women, possibly from Ghana, Nigeria, etc., go about in very colorful non-western dresses and I almost always admire them. And I believe most people admire these colorfully-dressed people even though they are obviously non-Caucasian immigrants from Africa. And the reason is simple: when we see these different-looking people, we do not immediately associate them with some sub-human brutes in other parts of the world. Unfortunately, the hijab makes most of us do exactly that, notwithstanding what the Koran says or does not say about the almighty requiring the women to wear it as symbol of their piety.
Wiki:
the passage discusses the difficulty faced by individuals who wear the hijab in being accepted and admired in society. it compares the perception of hijab-wearers to how immigrants from africa are often admired for their colorful non-western dresses, and argues that the hijab often leads people to associate them with negative stereotypes, despite what the koran may say about their religious practice. in relation to unpaid internships, the passage suggests that just as individuals are judged and discriminated against based on their appearance, so too are they affected by societal biases in terms of employment opportunities.

- xyz: a placeholder for a specific religion
- us: united states
- non-western: not following western cultural norms
- immigrant: a person who comes to live permanently in a foreign country

Tweet: If more learn to code, then the United States will maintain it's leading position on the world stage, resulting in English continuing to be the only language worth knowing. Tweet: These are good points, but in our current climate they remain academic. Duty to protect statutes are a first step, but they are only as good as the individuals who enforce them. It all comes down to money. Law enforcement can be trained to assess for potential harm, but that training would cost money. Therapists are increasingly underpaid and overworked due to budget cuts. Mental health agencies could launch public awareness campaigns to teach communities about warning signs, but that costs money. Add to this the fact that mental illness still carries a huge stigma, making it unlikely that young people will seek the right kind of help. College campuses are also ill-equipped or unwilling to address serious issues on their campuses. It all adds up to a ticking time bomb. As long as the mentally ill and those who treat them are marginalized, we can't expect to make much headway with regard to prevention.
Wiki: the document is highlighting the challenges and barriers in effectively addressing mental illness and protecting individuals in our current society. the duty to protect statutes is a positive step, but ultimately dependent on the individuals who enforce them. many of the proposed solutions, such as training law enforcement and launching public awareness campaigns, require funding. additionally, therapists are facing challenges due to budget cuts, mental illness stigma is still prevalent, and college campuses are ill-equipped to address mental health issues. all these factors contribute to a concerning situation. in the context of modern men, it is important to recognize that mental health issues affect individuals regardless of gender. the challenges and barriers described in the document apply to all individuals who struggle with mental illness and the professionals who treat them. #mentalhealth #awareness #stigma #prevention.

Tweet: Mr. Kornbluth asserts that CIA agents are dedicated individuals whose only goal is to serve and defend the country. That statement is as empty as a whiskey barrel at an Appalachian stomp festival. How does one serve the country? Do you serve the country by violating its fundamental principles with torture, even if it yields, which it didn't, helpful information? Are you defending the country by inciting terrorist groups who use your crimes as recruiting tools? The CIA missed the collapse of the Soviet Union. It missed the 9/11 attack; it led us into a war with Iraq by supporting false intelligence; it missed the upheavals in Egypt, Libya and Syria. In the end, it is probably true that the CIA has the interests of the country as their objective. The question is: How do they define those interests? It seems very clear their definition is consistent with the Barry Goldwater/ Neocons/Dick Cheney dictum: Excess in defense of liberty is no vice. And this, of course, profoundly and utterly misses the point.
Wiki:
the document criticizes mr. kornbluth's assertion that cia agents are dedicated individuals whose only goal is to serve and defend the country, calling it empty and likening it to a whiskey barrel at an appalachian stomp festival. the author questions how one serves the country and argues that the cia's actions, such as torture and inciting terrorist groups, are not in line with the country's fundamental principles. the cia's failures in predicting major events such as the collapse of the soviet union, the 9/11 attack, and the upheavals in egypt, libya, and syria are also highlighted. the author suggests that the cia's definition of the country's interests aligns with the barry goldwater/neoconservative/dick cheney dictum, "excess in defense of liberty is no vice," which they believe misses the point.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- cia: central intelligence agency
- 9/11: september 11
- iraq

Tweet: The Stanford study revealed many issues. Having read newspaper articles about it ,brought me to the conclusion like many issues we pursue with herd mentality, Organic products may have just been a good marketing scheme. I kind of compare it to Drug manufacture advertising, after FDA approval, as if we all of a sudden we have a simple solution to complex problems. Drugs like organic produce, usually turn out to be questionable. Both cattle and humans are full of Antibiotics, problem is we consume meat from cattle. If feed lots don't protect cattle from disease they would cost us more as many would be sick and bring less profit when butchered. Point is Organic food is all about making money. Few people have the space or time to grow anything. We delegate those duties to corporate farming so it shows up nicely packaged at the supermarket with a label few can understand. I found people were not fooled by organic foods and drug raised cattle and chickens just confused many times.
Wiki:
the knowledge from the document about the stanford study and organic food industry suggests that people often follow trends and fads without fully understanding the underlying issues. this herd mentality leads to the belief that organic products are a good marketing scheme, similar to the advertising of drugs after fda approval. both organic produce and drugs may not always live up to their claims, and the use of antibiotics in both cattle and humans raises concerns. the document also highlights the commercialization of organic food, with corporate farming taking over the responsibilities of growing and packaging produce for the supermarket. people are not easily deceived by organic foods and the confusing practices of raising cattle and chickens for meat. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document expanded:
- fda: food and drug administration
- cattle: domesticated bovine animals
- antibiotics: medication to prevent and treat bacterial infections
- lol: laugh out loud
- omg: oh my god 
- #organicfood: hashtag for posts about organic food

Tweet: I teach college students. I am rated. I don't mind at all. In fact, when I was going to grad school, I checked the ratings, and even added my own rating of especially good profs. Students actually do know who is a good teacher and who is not. It's not always who gives the easy A. Those teachers are often dismissed just as easily. The teachers who are valued are still -- even now -- the ones who actually teach and stretch the minds and abilities of students. These will alway be considered the best teachers. Always. Students are not as clueless as you may think.
Wiki:
the document "i teach college students. i am rated. i don't mind at all." highlights the importance of student ratings for college professors, and the belief that students can accurately assess the quality of their instructors. the author mentions checking ratings when they were in grad school and adding their own ratings of particularly good professors. they emphasize that good teachers are not necessarily the ones who give easy a's, as those teachers are often dismissed by students. the most valued teachers are those who actually teach and challenge their students. the document also concludes that students are not as clueless as some may think.

as for expanding abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document:

- abbreviations:
    - i = i
    - prof = professor
    - a = grade of a

- slang:
    - gonna = going to
    - alway = always
    - clueless = unaware or unknowledgeable

- hashtags:
    - #collegestudents = college

Tweet: I won't be wearing a head scarf in solidarity and I won't be wearing an Orthodox jewish woman's shetl or wig. Singling women out as temptation for men and forcing them to cover themselves with loose clothing, modest clothing and head covers is sexist. It perpetuates a world where women are sex objects and exist for men. Let the men walk around in burkas,wigs and hijabs. Women have spent enough centuries doing that. It's their turn.
Wiki:
the document argues against the practice of singling out women as temptations for men and forcing them to cover themselves with loose and modest clothing, including headscarves. it condemns this practice as sexist and perpetuating a world where women are only seen as sex objects and exist for men. the author suggests that if this is the case for women, then men should also be forced to cover themselves in burkas, wigs, and hijabs. the author argues that women have spent enough centuries conforming to societal expectations, and it is now their turn to step out of this oppressive tradition.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- 'burkas' refers to a burqa, a garment that covers the body and face worn by some muslim women.
- 'hijabs' are headscarves worn by muslim women.

Tweet: Unpaid internships=unpaid, period. They only benefit rich kiddies whose parents can pay their way, and squeeze out other people. When I was in law school, I was offered an "unpaid internship" at a large quasi-governmental agency. The train fare alone out to Virginia each day would have cost me $7.50 each day each way roundtrip, and I wouldn't even get reimbursed for that. When I had to turn them down, I got chided for "throwing away a great learning opportunity." Zoom fast forward to the dotcom days, where I had to compete against "unpaid interns" (usually heavily tattooed/pierced partners of others in the firms). Cleaning up their messes was always a treat...NOT. The ONLY internships that should be allowed are those that are done for real academic credit at an accredited university, with hours that take the student's class into account. Everything else is just exploitation.
Wiki: the document argues that unpaid internships are unfair and only benefit wealthy young people whose parents can afford to support them financially. the author shares their own experience of being offered an unpaid internship they couldn't afford to take, and later having to compete with "unpaid interns" who were not taking their responsibilities seriously. the author suggests that only internships that offer real academic credit and consider the students' class schedules should be allowed, and everything else is simply exploitation. in regards to 'reality show garbage', the use of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document should be expanded for clarity and professionalism.

Tweet: Until recently I was a frequent contributor to the comment section of my local newspaper. When I began contributing I had hoped for intelligent and meaningful discussion and debate concerning the subject. What I had found was a medium consisting of contributors who, by appearances, thrive on belittling and disparaging attacks on those who don't share their beliefs. After a few years, I removed my profiles due to the increasing belittlement and disparagement of posters who may disagree with ones opinion. These forums appear, to me, nothing more than an electronic school yard full of anonymous bullies who have little to offer to any debate or discussion. I welcome the moderation the NY Times offers the readers and contributors to the online comments. Regards, Dan
Wiki:
the document reflects dan's negative experience with online commenting, as he found the platform to be filled with belittling and disparaging comments. dan welcomed the moderation provided by the ny times for online comments. he had hoped for intelligent and meaningful discussion but found the medium to be full of anonymous bullies. dan decided to remove his profiles from the platform due to the increasing negativity.

Tweet: Obviously i am not using my legal name. I only comment on the NY Times which supposedly is moderated. I did at one time use my real name with no problems. Tweet: Thank you, Mr Johnson. I would remind people that "New Does Not Equal Better." People often make the mistake of assuming everything that is new is better. And one need only look to the universally hopeless and laughable car designs of the 21st Century to realize that cars of the 1960s and 1950s, designed by our "uncool" fathers and grandfathers and great grandfathers, were far superior and "cooler" than those designed by people today who think they are so cool. There is a movement in this civilization towards degradation of the soul, propagated by the 21st Century American corporation, which has been described as having emptiness and degradation at its heart. If publishing loses to Amazon, this will be another manifestation of the reality of the current march towards a world of aesthetic, and therefore spiritual, degradation. That is a future we have to look forward to.

Tweet: There are layers upon layers of sports organizations that accommodate home schooled kids - high school varsity should not be one of them. These kids have the opportunity to compete athletically in local recreation leagues, travel teams, AAU teams, and elite regional teams. High school sports should be about building athletic excellence and also about developing a sense of pride and comraderie in a placef that's that's truly the center of their existence for 4 short years. After all, should we then allow kids in private schools, boarding schools, or local religious schools to compete for varsity spots in their local public school? After they all pay taxes, but what do the school colors really mean to them?

Tweet: Why exactly should the government be responsible for "creat[ing] genuine opportunity for millions of rural people"? People who live in rural areas are entitled to the same welfare and food stamp benefits as people in cities. There are certainly areas of deep poverty in rural areas, but why single these areas out for special treatment? Furthermore, I wonder if "genuine opportunity" will ever exist in many sparsely populated areas. What sorts of opportunity would you recommend? Cities exist for a reason; they allow people to gather so that commerce can occur. Unless everyone in rural America intends to rely solely on farming, I fail to see much possibility for economic opportunities. The government should not subsidize a system that is fundamentally unworkable and that will always be dependent on such subsidies for survival.
Wiki: the document argues that the government should not be responsible for creating genuine opportunities for millions of rural people. it questions why rural residents should receive the same welfare and food stamp benefits as urban dwellers, and whether genuine opportunities can exist in sparsely populated areas. the document suggests that economic opportunities are limited in rural areas and that government subsidies are not a viable solution. it also implies that rural america should not rely solely on farming for economic survival. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags should be expanded as follows: "i wonder if 'genuine opportunity' will ever exist in many sparsely populated areas." = "i wonder if 'genuine opportunity' will ever exist in many sparsely populated areas."

Tweet: I once got a summer job near the House of Seven Gables, in Salem, in the hall of records, deciphering and keying in old deed books, from the 1700's. At the end of the summer, they threw away my work, because no one had the patience to read ancient cursive and copy it, when they realized they could instead just scan. Cursive writing, through most of history, was very far removed from your beautiful, cherished, letters. It was used by underpaid recorders, of other people's transactions. The novelty of the letter 's' written as 'f', etc., wears off quickly. However, Kate Gladstone's arguments for teaching children to read cursive, and to write hybrid, which takes little time, can confer big benefits later in life. Those who have gone through these steps learn better how to summarize, as they take notes, even if eventually on only keyboards. A side benefit is that they can appreciate cursive, and the history it sometimes cradles.
Wiki:
the document highlights the experience of working in the hall of records near the house of seven gables in salem, where old deed books from the 1700s were being deciphered and keyed in. the author's work was eventually discarded because it was realized that scanning the documents was a more efficient method. cursive writing was commonly used in historical records, but the author argues that it was not as beautiful as commonly believed. however, the document also mentions the benefits of teaching children to read cursive and write in a hybrid style, as it can lead to improved note-taking skills and an appreciation for cursive and its historical significance.

expand abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

- hashtags: #s = letter 's' #f = letter 'f'

Tweet: It would be much easier to dismantle or close down the C.I.A. instead of reforming a humongous bureaucratic para-military-intelligence organization that has lost its basic mission statement. That is, collect and analyze material/information from foreign countries, friends or foes, and provide the political leadership with useful intelligence material to defend and protect the national security of the United States. The CIA involved in war crimes and torture comes at no surprise to any person over 40 living in Africa, Asia and Latin America. During the cold war, the agency was the main instrument of foreign policy used by the White House to destabilize unfriendly third world governments or fight proxy wars against the Soviet Union. Torture techniques were honed during that time. What to do with the CIA? downsize that humongous dysfunctional organization, retrain its personnel to do real intelligence data collection to protect the national security of the US. That is all.
Wiki:

Tweet: My company pays interns $10 an hour, and they often are required to do very menial work. That said, interns who show eagerness and promise may be offered full time positions with the company. For-profit companies should absolutely pay their interns. The small investment is an incredible bargain when you consider it a screening tool for potential employees. Several full-time members of my department started out as interns. I can say from experience that it's a far better screening tool than a job interview, and worth every penny. I think unpaid internships are fine, but in limited circumstances--for example, if the student is still in college and can get academic credit. In this case, though, you'd want to make sure that the student is getting training and is not forced to do menial tasks. I had some internships like this in college and they were very beneficial. I also think that non-profit organizations should be able to offer limited unpaid internships. In all other circumstances, internships should be paid, and interns should at least receive minimum wage. If for-profit organizations can hire unpaid interns, there's too much potential for abuse.
Wiki:
the document discusses the importance of paying interns at for-profit companies, stating that the small investment in paying interns is worthwhile for the potential of finding valuable employees. the author recommends that internships should be paid at least minimum wage, and unpaid internships should only be considered in limited circumstances, such as for college credit. the author also believes that non-profit organizations should be able to offer limited unpaid internships. however, they warn against the potential for abuse if for-profit organizations are allowed to hire unpaid interns.

expansion of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

- they often are required to do very menial work: they are frequently asked to perform simple and unskilled tasks.
- for-profit organizations: companies seeking to make a profit
- should at least receive minimum wage: should, at a minimum, be paid the legal minimum wage.
- too much potential for abuse:

Tweet: I love libraries! They are a great place to just hang out and be in touch with history and knowledge of the present and past. Often they offer classes and lectures and great places to study. And, sometimes the librarians are real cute as well! I use them differently today than in the past, however. I actually belong to several libraries now as a full time RVer so that I can access books on my Kindle. Yes! That most remarkable Amazon device that has allowed me to build my own library with nearly 1000 mostly free books in my Kindle Fire. At age 76, I look upon this as my personal treasury, a repositary of the wisdom of the ages. In summary, I think it's great that we have physical libraries as well as devices like the Kindle that allow us to access books from anywhere on the globe with relative ease. It's great that libraries have adapted and made changes in this computer age that benefit their surrounding communty. Bravo to libraries and librarians!

Tweet: "Mental health professionals are, as a group, politically liberal and strong defenders of civil liberties, so initiating an action that is likely to curtail a person's civil liberties is contrary to their mindset." The new 'stop and frisk': Mental health professionals wait until someone from out-of-town walks into the regular emergency room at Cornell Medical Center to have a legitimate and timely prescription for a controlled drug script filled. They police-escort the person across the hallway to the Psychiatric emergency room; force strip the person; ship the person to WestChester in-patient for six days against the person's will; taking all the regularly-prescribed medicine away while declaring the person bi-polar which the person is not; Then tell the person they are free to find a way back to New York City, turning the person loose without the long-standing legitimate prescriptions. New York is receiving $8 Billion from the Federal Government to distribute to providers who the providers view as having a serious mental illness and/or substance abuse problem which could cause the person to harm him/herself or others. Good intentions veered very, very wrongly.
Wiki: the document describes a concerning situation in which mental health professionals are initiating actions that curtail a person's civil liberties by forcing them into in-patient treatment against their will. the incident involves a college student from out-of-town who went to cornell medical center to get a prescription filled for a controlled drug. the student was then taken to the psychiatric emergency room, forcefully stripped, diagnosed as bi-polar (which they are not), and sent to an in-patient facility for six days without their regularly-prescribed medication. this action was taken in the context of new york receiving $8 billion from the federal government to distribute to providers for individuals with mental illness or substance abuse problems. this incident is concerning and suggests that good intentions may have led to harmful outcomes.

Tweet: Besides agreeing with many of the critical comments here, I woul dadd that a fundamental problem is that the ratings never seem to go away--a bad rating in 2005 or 2007 is stiil there in 2015, though it may no longer have any relevance--either because the teacher has improved or simply moved on--and some of the comments can be very personal and stinging, bad enough in the short term but sickening to see present 10 years after the fact of teh class. Tweet: No one knows whether a "real-looking" name on a comment is authentic, nor do they agree on even what makes a name "real-looking". Furthermore, there is actually very little agreement on whether an idea is offensive merely because of the way it is expressed, or whether certain ideas should be considered so offensive that they may never be expressed in even the most cultivated verbiage. The writer's premise that anonymity produces bad ideas and vulgar expression appears highly doubtful. I submit that the quality of the idea being discussed is the only thing that matters, and that there will never be a consensus on that evaluation. If quality is too low (as in the bulk of what appears on Twitter), individuals are free to consider the idea poor or the manner of expression deficient. Openly airing all ideas still appears preferable to me to confining discourse to speakers who only express the right ideas, and who do so with a prescribed minimum of elegance. It's a superstition, but I'll stick with Justice Brandeis' axiom that "sunshine is the best disinfectant."
Wiki:
the document discusses the authenticity of "real-looking" names on comments and the subjective nature of what makes a name "real-looking". it also mentions the debate over whether an idea is offensive based on its expression and whether certain ideas should be deemed so offensive that they can never be expressed in a refined manner. the writer questions the notion that anonymity leads to bad ideas and vulgar expression. they believe that the quality of the idea is the most important factor and that there will never be a consensus on its evaluation. they prefer open discourse to confining speech to those who express the "right" ideas with a minimum level of elegance. the writer supports the idea that "sunshine is the best disinfectant," as proposed by justice brandeis.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- "i'll" = i will
- "real-looking" = appearing authentic
- "verbiage" = language or diction
- "twitter" = a social media platform

Tweet: Let me begin by saying that I grew up in farm country (cash grain - corn/soybeans) and I own farm land and annually receive farm subsidy payments. I would make a few points. First, most of the people who expound about farmers and farming have no idea what they are talking about. Second, I have heard about giant farms who receive huge subsidies all my life, so I presume it must be true, but it simply doesn't exist in the corn/soybean area I am familiar with. Third, there have been dramatic boom/bust cycles in crop prices the past few years, but this has been driven by speculators in the commodities markets, and currency manipulation (China). Fourth, farm products such as corn and soybeans are one of the few items that this country still exports in large amounts, so you had better be careful what you do. Finally, having said that, there has not been a recession in farm country - the farmers are doing quite nicely, and there is no reason that crop payments for corn and soybeans should continue.
Wiki:
the document is about the author's personal experience growing up in farm country, owning farm land, and receiving farm subsidy payments. they make several points: (1) people who talk about farmers and farming often don't understand it, (2) giant farms receiving huge subsidies do not exist in the corn/soybean area the author is familiar with, (3) dramatic boom/bust cycles in crop prices are driven by speculators in the commodities markets and currency manipulation, (4) farm products like corn and soybeans are important exports for the country, and (5) despite economic fluctuations, farmers in farm country are doing well and there is no reason for crop payments to stop.

abbreviations/slang/hashtags:
- cash grain: refers to crops that are grown for cash, such as corn and soybeans
- corn/soybeans: refers to the types of cash crops that are commonly grown in farm country
- subsidies: financial assistance given by the government to support farmers

Tweet: Comments are a useful and frequently informative part of online news; they should be encouraged but much more closely monitored. For openers, commenters should be allowed only one comment per article to avoid these ubiquitous back and forth , witless arguments which often clog the comments section. Obscene, vulgar and personal attacks should be edited out, but care must be exercised. Many subjects almost demand strong comments which some may find offensive, but do not really cross the line. Some are clearly at the far left, right, or some other extreme, but often bring out ignored, but important points of view. In addition, many articles and editorials contain claims that are either wrong or at best distorted, despite usually high standards of editorial review. Comments are essential for correcting these problems. Some blogs, like Prof Juan Cole usually contain thoughtful, informed and useful information. Others seem to call forth the the worst forms of trolls, bullys, idiots and haters. Proper monitoring, I believe can correct the abuses and allow a very important part of the internet to thrive.
Wiki:
the document suggests that comments on online news articles can be informative and should be encouraged, but they need to be closely monitored. to avoid endless and meaningless arguments, commenters should only be allowed to make one comment per article. obscene, vulgar, and personal attacks should be removed, but it's important to be careful because some topics may provoke strong comments that some people find offensive, although they don't necessarily cross the line. comments are also important for correcting factual inaccuracies in articles and editorials. some blogs, like professor juan cole's, contain thoughtful and useful information, while others attract negative behavior such as trolling, bullying, and hateful comments. proper monitoring, the document asserts, can address these issues and allow this important aspect of the internet to flourish.

abbreviation expansion:
- prof: professor
- i: i

slang expansion:
- trolls: individuals who post inflammatory or off-topic messages online
- bullys: people who intimidate and harass others
- idiots: people

Tweet: I am fully insured on my own and help finance Obamacare too. And I don't regret. Such obligations are imperative for a civilized society and a nation. These obligations pale in comparision with,( like all citizens do),the benefits, advantages and rights I enjoy at the same time. In fact, what I want is a far less complicated, straight-forward, far more liberal and universally applicable health care system that is at least comparable to what are obtaining presently in France,UK and Scandinavia.I don't mind the personal costs,no one should, I believe.It is the basic minimum that any nation should render to its citizens.And it could prove to be quite cheaper than whatever provided by any insurance company and far more efficient, if wisely administered. Anyway, I personally believe, ofcourse buttressed by my own calculations and ratified by my intellectual friends, that the rich are indeed the free loaders in any society, extracting far higher benefits from it than what they themselves contribute.But they make the maximum noise and grossly distort the reality for denying the middle class and the poor what they richly deserve-- through rational logic and by canons of progressive civilizations.

the document expresses the author's support for being fully insured and helping to finance obamacare. they believe that such obligations are necessary for a civilized society and that the benefits they receive far outweigh the personal costs. they advocate for a simpler and more universally applicable healthcare system, similar to those in france, the uk, and scandinavia. the author also believes that the rich are the ones who benefit the most from society while making the most noise about their contributions, unfairly denying the middle class and the poor what they deserve. they also mention that their beliefs are supported by their own calculations and the opinions of their intellectual friends.

Tweet: The top two reasons cats are turned into shelters are house soiling and aggression (biting). It is a well-known fact that declawed cats are deprived of their main form of defense (claws), and resort to biting. Additionally, it is painful for many declawed cats to dig in a litter box. Hence, house soiling. Shelters I have volunteered at have quite a few declawed cats come in due to these reasons, declawing being the source of these issues. Pet owners who want to declaw a cat should not have a cat--period. If you want to protect your furniture, do not own a cat. Cats naturally scratch. If dog owners don't want their animal to jump on their couches or beds, do they remove a dog's leg? If dog owners don't want a dog to bark, is debarking humane? It's the same thing as declawing a cat. Just don't have one.
Wiki:

Tweet: This is definitely a fluff 'issue', but very entertaining. My hypothesis is that people partner best with someone who's relatively compatible on the maintenance spectrum. As a low-maintenance type of gal, the sort who can get ready for an evening out in under 20 minutes (and that includes the shower), I would not be able to tolerate a guy who had 'manny-pedis' and facials. The very idea would make me cringe. Many years ago in my 20s I went on a few dates with a guy who had more hair grooming products than I did; it just didn't work out. I've been married 15 years now to a handsome guy who is clean but doesn't primp or spend time worrying about grey hair or wrinkles. The only scent he gives off is from his deodorant and soap, and that's fine by me.

Tweet: In our community, the most elegant, welcoming and practical buildings are our libraries. In the 9 years I have lived here, two libraries have been built and one redesigned and refurbished. Like the comments about the need for internet access among the poor, libraries ARE so much more. They have become a cultural, community hub for education, community activism, art, music, video and social interaction. One library has attracted the local gardening society to create and maintain a butterfly garden with many native plants that are marked for people to learn about them. Another group has offered to create a meandering walking path around the expanse of the building for reflection and a chance to walk in beauty outdoors. In many ways, I see our libraries becoming a sort of secular ministry -- feeding the souls as well as the minds of people. They are far from obsolete -- they are becoming more relevant and essential than ever before!
Wiki:
the knowledge from the document is that libraries in the community have become elegant and practical buildings that serve as cultural and community hubs for education, activism, art, music, and social interaction. they are not just about internet access for the poor, but also provide opportunities for gardening, outdoor reflection, and learning about native plants. the document suggests that libraries are like a secular ministry, feeding the souls and minds of people and are more relevant and essential than ever before.

Tweet: This is from the study that this writer Christie Wilcox cited about Organic farms being less "efficient." "We found crop yields to be 20% lower in the organic systems, although input of fertilizer and energy was reduced by 34 to 53% and pesticide input by 97%. Enhanced soil fertility and higher biodiversity found in organic plots may render these systems less dependent on external inputs." With the reduction in energy and pesticides they seem pretty efficient to me. All organic practices are not equal. Organic systems that "stack" crops like growing mushrooms beneath orchards or ducks and fish being raised along side rice patties are way more "efficient" than conventional. Science does prove organics are healthier and safer. The irony of that recent Stanford paper is that it showed there are less antibiotic resistant bacteria on organic meat and less pesticide residue on produce. Produce grown in biologically active soil, which is achieved using organic soil building methods, does have more testable ultra-trace minerals. Scientists are only now understanding how important these minerals are to human health. The holes in Christie Wilcox's argument are far and wide.
Wiki:
the document discusses a study on organic farming, citing lower crop yields but also lower input of fertilizer, energy, and pesticides. the study found that enhanced soil fertility and higher biodiversity in organic plots may make these systems less dependent on external inputs. it also mentions that not all organic practices are equal, and stacking crops or integrating animals can make organic farming more efficient. the document also highlights the health and safety benefits of organic farming, as well as the importance of biologically active soil. it criticizes christie wilcox's argument, claiming there are many holes in it.

Tweet: Goofy beyond belief. Religious beliefs are just that...beliefs. To whatever degree a religious practice is benign, it should be allowed. When the practice impinges upon public health or safety, it must be curtailed for the benefit of the entire society. Our tradition is not to concern ourselves with how people worship their god (or choose not to worship at all.) All are free to practice their religion as they see fit. Accordingly, we should also be able to choose to be free of religion when it impinges upon public health or well being. Permitting religious beliefs to trump science is antithetical to our secular culture.

Tweet: "One of the main pillars of Syriza's economic program is the creation of 300,000 new jobs for the unemployed under a direct public employment scheme." Anyone who thinks that expanding public employment in Greece is a good idea should migrate to Greece. There are already more public employees in Greece than just about anywhere else in the world and you propose to put more people on the public payroll? As it is, many government employees do not have any meaningful assignments and you want the Greek government to hire more people? What you are actually proposing is a massive expansion of welfare payments to the unemployed in Greece except that you claim to have given these people a job and so instead of social welfare you want the world to think of it as job creation. Here is a freebie for you: playing with words do not change economic realities. Greece cannot afford it and it is precisely such policies that created this mess in the first place.

Tweet: I went back to school in my mid-40s and earned a PhD. As a middle-aged, overweight female in a highly competetive field, I found most internships automatically closed to me. I finally had to accept one that paid less than $200 per month--and I had to move 1000 miles from home (renting an apt.) to take it. I learned a lot, and returned home to a good career in my field (after a 2nd lowly-paid year elsewhere--but at least that covered rent). I do understand that the internship site had financial problems. But I am very much aware that I was able to take that internship ONLY because I was a married woman with a husband who worked, and money in the bank. That should not be the norm.

Tweet: I learn quite a lot from NYT comments, often and in particular from thoughtful comments by authors who think differently from me. I find them valuable. I think the Times' general level of commentary is good. This in part results from the Times' curating its comments, which filters the merely shrill or ad hominem screeds. I recognize this also introduces curatorial bias, but for me, the reduction in noise is welcome. I hope the Times continues to solicit reader commentary. I think its system is working well.
Wiki:
the document suggests that the author learns a lot from thoughtful comments on the new york times (nyt) articles, especially from those with different opinions. they find the nyt's overall level of commentary to be good, partly due to the curation of comments to filter out noise and personal attacks. they acknowledge that this curation may introduce bias, but they appreciate the reduction in unwanted content. they hope that the nyt continues to encourage reader commentary, as they feel the current system is effective.

expansion:
- nyt: the new york times
- ad hominem: arguing against the person rather than their argument
- curatorial: relating to the curation or organization of content
- bias: prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another
- noise: irrelevant or unwanted information
- soliciting: asking for or trying to obtain something
- system: a set of principles or procedures according to which something is done; an organized scheme or method.

Tweet: I urge Mr. Stankiewicz to do his due diligence--required by any good journalism major--and perform some research. Two major studies in the last decade have shown that student evaluations are wholly flawed ways of evaluating learning. In fact, there is some evidence for a negative correlation between student reviews and learning. In other words, the more students dislike a professor, the better those students do in similar classes down the road. Why? Because those professors challenge students to push past their comfort zones and rigid patterns of thinking. Oh, and if you're going to use that erroneous consumer metaphor, then at least get it right: professors are not the product--the student mind is the product, and preparing it for engagement in civil society is the endpoint.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the need for mr. stankiewicz to conduct thorough research, as it is required for a good journalism major. it mentions that two major studies in the last decade have found that student evaluations are not suitable for evaluating learning. in fact, there is evidence that there is a negative correlation between student reviews and learning, meaning that students who dislike a professor actually perform better in similar classes in the future. this is because those professors challenge students to push past their comfort zones and rigid patterns of thinking. additionally, it criticizes the use of a consumer metaphor and asserts that professors are not the product, but rather, the student mind is the product, and the endpoint is preparing it for engagement in civil society.

when it comes to 'computer generated imagery', this document does not provide any specific information or knowledge. it is solely focused on the flaws of using student evaluations to evaluate learning and the role of professors in challenging and preparing students for engagement in civil society.

Tweet: Another tragedy of the commons. For newspapers, restricting access to paid subscribers would probably end this problem, or ameliorate it enough. Non-subscribers could solve math problems or the like before being given access to make comments, one problem solved per comment made. Skin needs to be in the game or there are no rules.
Wiki:
the document suggests that implementing a restriction on access to content for non-paying subscribers could potentially solve or improve the issue of excessive and inappropriate commenting on online platforms. non-subscribers could be required to complete a task, such as solving math problems, before being able to make comments, with one task being solved per comment made. the document also emphasizes the importance of having a stake in the platform in order to establish and enforce rules.

with regard to the issue of 'kid glued to phone screen', the document suggests that implementing these access restrictions for non-paying subscribers may help reduce the amount of inappropriate content and comments that children are exposed to online. furthermore, it suggests that children could also be required to complete tasks before accessing certain content or making comments, helping to monitor and control their online activities. it also encourages parents to take an active role in monitoring and setting limits on their children's online activities.

Tweet: While the government wants us to eat healthy, it is very true that organic foods are outrageously priced for the small amount of food we recieve. Obviously organic products are healthier for you than genetically enhanced ones. The cows that produce the normal milk we drink are fed steroids to be able to produce more milk than naturally possible. Therefore, we are not consuming 100% pure milk. That can cut down the natural nutrients we would be recieving if everyone housed their own cow. So, this article couldn't be any more incorrect by saying that America is worse off consuming organic products. If everyone decided to trade out a bag of Lay's for some all natural vegetable chips, consumption sizes would be cut down and health could be improved.

Tweet: As an academic for more than 50 years, I say, especially around grading time, that every university should require two things: minimal competence in a (new) foreign language, and performance on a musical instrument. You can cheat or get around the requirements for all kinds of other academic subjects, but you either speak French in public, or you can't. You either play the Bach Invention, or you can't. Simple. You can't cram it, you can't cheat. Besides the obvious benefits of the learning processes in both of these activities, the study of each is a valuable exercise in integrity. Yes, I'm serious.
Wiki: the document argues that every university should require students to demonstrate minimal competence in a new foreign language and performance on a musical instrument. it emphasizes that these requirements cannot be cheated or crammed, unlike other subjects, and are valuable exercises in integrity. the author suggests that these requirements can address wealth inequality by providing all students with equal opportunities to develop these skills. the author's point about integrity in learning may also suggest that these requirements can help level the playing field for students from different socioeconomic backgrounds who may not have had equal access to language or music education. the use of phrases like "i'm serious" reinforces the author's conviction in the importance of these requirements.

Tweet: An incredible amount of time can be lost to technical issues with online classes (and with computers in classrooms). The discussion board doesn't open, links are broken, my browser won't open this or that page, the teacher can't find the file, we can't submit our work because the files are too big, students can't figure out how to make/open/save files, printers run out of ink, presentations disappear, and on and on and ON. One of these semesters I want to do research to see if using computers really does save time in the classroom. I suspect that it's not as much time as everyone seems to think.

Tweet: The chef's vision, blah, blah, blah. Every so often at at otherwise decent restaurant, the chef of the moment under salts the food. Just plain and simple, they miss the mark. Tweet: I've been host to two declawed cats while trying to find them a home (They came to me this way, it would never be my choice to do this). During their stay, one of them managed to kill two birds quite efficiently without claws. (They wiggled their way through the air conditioner). I didn't see him do it to know his methods, but I know it was him. Just last week, my toothless cat killed a bird that got in the same way. He killed it with one blow of his paw. He didn't use his claws to bring it down; just one blow and it was dead. I will only leave this piece of information, for I could write a book on declawing cats and the pain and problems it causes. There are plenty of safe alternatives to declawing; people need to research, and learn to live with animals instead of adapting them to fit our needs.
Wiki:
the document provides a personal account of hosting two declawed cats and witnessing their ability to kill birds despite not having claws. it strongly condemns the practice of declawing cats and advocates for safe alternatives, urging people to research and adapt to living with animals instead of forcing them to fit human needs. the author recounts the cats' successful bird killings and emphasizes that declawing causes pain and problems for cats. the document also includes a brief mention of the author's toothless cat killing a bird with one blow of its paw, without using its claws. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
i've = i have
it would = it would never be
i didn't = i did not
i know it was him = i am sure it was him
#declawingcats = declawing cats
#research = research
#safealternatives = safe alternatives

Tweet: I love national parks. Growing up in India, unspoiled green spaces were really foreign, and National Parks are America's best idea for generations to come. I visit Mt Ranier National Park several times as it is almost in my backyard. I am struck by the damage that visitors can inflict on the fragile wild flower meadows in their eagerness and zeal to enjoy the beauty. While better funding and visitor resources such as mass transportation could help, something we can all do is volunteer at a NP for a few days a year. This will go a long way in relieving the already stretched NP resources and the benefit to the volunteer citizen is priceless. Picking up trash, pulling weeks, cataloging wildflowers, roving the meadows helping visitors, etc. can help give back to our country's best idea and recharge our batteries all in one act!!
Wiki:
the document describes the love for national parks and the awareness of the damage caused by visitors to the fragile environment, particularly the wildflower meadows. the author suggests that better funding and visitor resources, such as mass transportation, could help protect the parks. additionally, the author encourages volunteering at a national park for a few days a year to alleviate the strain on park resources. this can involve activities such as picking up trash, pulling weeds, cataloging wildflowers, and assisting visitors, and can benefit both the park and the volunteer. restricted access to certain areas of the national park may be necessary to protect the delicate ecosystems and prevent further damage.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
np - national park
mt. ranier - mount rainier
weeds - garden nuisances
etc. - and so forth 
#nationalparks #volunteering #environmentalprotection
