Tweet: The Internet would be a vastly different place if we could somehow do away with anonymity. But would it actually be a better place? In our very polarized world, many people are understandably reluctant to speak out on controversial issues, unless they can do so anonymously. If we want to know what people really think, we need to let them speak anonymously. So long as there has been written communication, people have had that ability, and maybe that right. Before that, people threw rocks under cover of darkness to get their point across. I understand the temptation to demand that people use their real identities, but it seems almost impossible to do in the real world. Even if you ask for a scan of my driver's license, you can't be sure it is really my license, or be sure that it has not been altered.
Wiki:
the document discusses the impact of anonymity on the internet and whether it would be a better place without it. it argues that many people are reluctant to speak out on controversial issues unless they can do so anonymously, and that allowing anonymity enables people to express their true thoughts. the document also mentions the difficulty of verifying someone's real identity in the online world, even if they provide official documents.

in terms of seasoning food, the document may suggest that just as anonymity allows people to express themselves freely, seasoning allows food to bring out its true flavors. it could be compared to allowing food to speak for itself, without the need for excessive embellishment.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags are expanded as follows:
- "i understand the temptation" becomes "i understand the temptation to demand that people use their real identities."
- "it seems almost impossible to do in the real world" becomes "it seems almost impossible to implement in the real world."
- "id" becomes "identification"
- "th

Tweet: It may have made sense once upon a time but not anymore. I am liberal thinker and I don't mean to say that we need to deport people in mass or not have systems in place to care for newborns of any status who happen to be born here. But citizenship should be a priveledge that is applied for by families or legal representation in exceptional circumstances, and it should be earned thorugh a process by which it is clear the person (or family) is well invested in our culture and economy. I have two daughters born in Switzerland, neither of whom were offered Swiss citizenship at birth because the simple fact of their birth didn't make them Swiss. Under the current system it is simply too easy to take advantage of the current law and use automatic citizenship to take more than is earned. Again, I am not saying we shouldn't be a compassionate country, and how a new system is implemented would be a lengthy, difficult task, but it definitely should change.
Wiki:
the document expresses a belief that citizenship should be seen as a privilege that is earned, rather than something that is automatically granted at birth. the writer suggests that the current system can be taken advantage of and that citizenship should be applied for in exceptional circumstances. they also emphasize a need for individuals to be well invested in the country's culture and economy in order to earn citizenship. the writer is against mass deportation and wants a compassionate approach to be taken, but believes that the current system is too easy to exploit. they also mention their experience with their daughters not being offered swiss citizenship at birth, showing that they have personal experience with the current system. the document aims at addressing issues of immigration and citizenship, and does not exhibit any explicit prejudice. however, the emphasis on "our" culture and economy could potentially raise questions about exclusionary attitudes based on nationality or ethnicity. 

abbreviations and slang: 
- i am = i am
- i don't = i do not
- we shouldn

Tweet: Single payer is the obvious solution. We have a single payer system here in the Czech Republic. I can choose my doctor. I receive good care quickly. I had elective surgery one time, received it within a week. The system works. The US system does not, and will not, even under ObamaCare, because of the for-profit insurance industry.
Wiki:
the document argues that a single payer system, like the one in the czech republic, is the obvious solution for healthcare. the author praises the ability to choose their own doctor and receive good care quickly in the czech system. they highlight their positive experience with elective surgery, receiving it within a week. the author criticizes the us system, including obamacare, due to the for-profit insurance industry.

there is no direct mention of amazon in this document.

Tweet: When I went to college a decade ago, the priced i paid for a single dorm room was less than a shared off-campus room. I did live in an older building with communal bathrooms, my room was tiny with a bed, desk, dresser and a small closet. Not only that, it gave my parents peace of mind that people in my building were enrolled students, opposite gender friends aren't supposed to stay overnight and an RA on every floor. At night if I needed to go somewhere on campus and felt unsafe, I could call the university for someone to walk with me. Obviously it you cannot afford to live outside of your home, that's that but for people to claim off campus housing is cheaper and everyone does it is plain wrong.
Wiki:
the summary of the document is that a decade ago, the price for a single dorm room was less than a shared off-campus room. the dorm room was in an older building with communal bathrooms, and the room itself was small with basic furniture. however, living on campus provided a sense of security for the parents, with enrolled students as neighbors, regulations on overnight visitors, and resident advisors on every floor. additionally, the university offered escort services for students who felt unsafe at night. the author disagrees with the notion that off-campus housing is cheaper and more popular for everyone.

expanding the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document:
- ra: resident advisor
- i: i
- isn't: is not 
- #offcampushousing 
- #studentsafety

Tweet: Hold on. Reporting concerns to police is not very effective if the police are not very well trained to respond. Very few police departments have the funds (or priorities) to provide special training for dealing with mentally ill/disturbed people. Tweet: This reads like parody. Rate My Professors is an organized venue...with a chili pepper icon to evaluate professors' hotness, a techno-bureaucratic set of sliding scales to place people on a scale of 1-5, and rarely a serious or self-reflective comment about content, pace, or intellectual challenge. Ge real. It's a place to vent. And that venting can go either direction, too: students will sing the praise of one teacher, and assail another. Their are very few middle reviews. And why is that? Because the forum is self-selecting, and--through its rationalist design--it encourages yes or no evaluation. Is that what we want? Students who are encouraged to judge everything as either black or white?
Wiki:
the document criticizes rate my professors for its superficial and often unhelpful evaluations of teachers. the author points out that the site's chili pepper icon for rating professors' hotness and its use of a sliding scale for ratings don't lead to meaningful feedback on content, pace, or intellectual challenge. the author questions whether the site's design encourages binary evaluations and whether this is beneficial for students. they also note that there are very few middle-of-the-road reviews, and highlight that the forum is self-selecting, leading to polarized opinions. the document suggests that the site can be a place for students to vent, which can result in both positive and negative reviews of teachers.

Tweet: Publishing and newspapers are old industries. Publishing has fed too long from the labors of writers and readers while too seldom adding true value. Newspapers have been lean and efficient, they juat aren't capable of satisfying the demand curve of today's public. Telecommunications and transportation behaved similarly to publishing and they underwent dramatic restructuring. The music production industry is well on its way toward completing a shake up. It isn't pretty, but it is too late for publishing to control their future. Ten years ago they might have had more of a say in the direction the sector is going; it is now pre-ordained.
Wiki:
the document argues that the publishing and newspaper industries have failed to add significant value to their products and have been unable to keep up with the demands of the public. it compares their situation to that of the telecommunications and transportation industries, which underwent dramatic restructuring, and the music production industry, which is currently undergoing a shake-up. the document suggests that it is too late for publishing to control its future and that it may have been possible to do so ten years ago. this relates to the individual right of the industry to adapt and shape its own future.

Tweet: The most insightful writing to be found in almost any article occurs in the comments. Rarely is there a significant article that is neither debunked nor enhanced by the best of the comments. I have actually started checking whether comments are enabled before I read an article - and NOT reading it if they are disabled. To me, disabling comments is a sign of weakness and/or dishonesty on the part of the author and/or the publisher. It shows a fear of dissent, a fear of being scrutinized and/or challenged. Perhaps there is an underlying insecurity about not being viewed as an authoritative voice. The solution to repugnant comments isn't to ban all comments. The solution is mechanisms (which have existed for ages) that filter, sort, and hide comments at the pleasure of the user.
Wiki:
the document argues that the most valuable insights in any article are often found in the comments section. the author believes that disabling comments is a sign of weakness or dishonesty, and shows a fear of dissent or being challenged. the document suggests that repugnant comments should not result in a ban on all comments, but rather the use of mechanisms to filter and hide comments based on the user's preferences.

- #scalia: this hashtag is referring to the late supreme court justice antonin scalia.

Tweet: How is bashing and belittling Amazon Publishing a debate? I fail to see anything more here than the usual 'let's smear Amazon because we must stay dogmatic about modern publishing.' Tweet: It is impossible to get a good sampling from polls. Poll takers are like telemarketers; they invade the privacy of our homes, especially when we are busiest. If I answer the phone at all, I am apt to be less than polite to the person who is bothering me. I have strong political opinions but the poll takers will never hear them because I don't want to answer a stranger's probing questions. What kinds of people are being sampled? I am not alone in my feelings about intrusive phone calls, so it is none of us. Although I have had a few illegal calls on my cell phone, those without landlines are not included in most samples. The skewed sampling is giving greater weight to the candidate whose fans are willing to be bothered by a poll. What does that say about his qualifications for the job of president? Nothing.
Wiki: the document expresses the idea that it is difficult to obtain an accurate sampling from polls. the author compares poll takers to telemarketers, stating that they invade the privacy of homes, particularly when people are busy. the author acknowledges having strong political opinions but does not want to share them with poll takers. they also mention that people without landlines are often not included in polls, leading to skewed sampling that may favor certain candidates. the author questions what this skewed sampling says about a candidate's qualifications for the job of president. in summary, the document highlights concerns about the invasion of privacy and the potential bias in polling methods.

Tweet: Why are the Euro-zone members so reluctant to call it quits? It was a noble experiment, it had to be tried, but it failed miserably. Tweet: No two people have the same sense of taste nor does any one person have a consistent sense of taste given variables such as response to environmental allergies and recovery from colds. To say that salt is not offered at the table is Bloomberg Nannyish at minimum and downright control freakish. I long ago sought to reduce the salt in my diet and my taste has adjusted over time, but I have not eliminated salt nor do I intend to. Most baked or roasted poultry dishes are horrible without some added salt and there are other foods that cry out for it- popcorn is a good example. Having worked in healthcare for 27 years I have no illusions about the harm that a high sodium diet can have on some people. However, it is also possible to wisely reduce salt intake and still enjoy it in some foods. As the taste is highly subjective and individual I cannot agree with Mr Sbragg.
Wiki:
the document discusses the individual variability in people's sense of taste and the importance of salt in food. it argues that avoiding salt completely is unnecessary and compares it to controlling behavior. the author believes that although salt should be reduced in some cases, it is still enjoyable in certain foods. the document also mentions the potential harm of a high sodium diet but emphasizes that it is possible to wisely reduce salt intake and still enjoy it. the author disagrees with mr. sbragg's opinion on this matter. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document:
- mr.: mister
- nannyish: resembling a nanny or nanny-like in behavior
- control freakish: excessively controlling
- sbragg: no expansion provided

expanded phrases and sentences:
- no two people have the same sense of taste, nor does any one person have a consistent sense of taste given variables such as response to environmental allergies and recovery from colds. to say that salt is not offered at the table

Tweet: As a five year old, I watched the young Queen take up royal duties, after the death of her beloved father. In 1953, her government was still struggling with the aftermath of the wholesale destruction and devastation of Britain and the loss of a whole generation of young men....Governing a country is no easy task. It ignores the facts to imply that all she knows is horses. Having lived through some of the more catastrophic changes on this planet, political as well as economic and personal; bringing a country back from the ruins, and having been forced to make some very tough decisions, which impact millions of people, not just a few paragraphs... Tweet: Most restaurant food is already too salty. I'd rather they salted their food LESS and let us control our salt at the table. I don't use table salt, myself. Tweet: This lack of pay is not limited to high school or college internships. It is found throughout the business world. People are encouraged to blog for a major media organization not for pay, but for "the exposure," only to see that media organization sold to another company for hundreds of millions of dollars. Workers age 50 and over, who still have much to contribute, are thrown out of jobs in a subtle form of age discrimination and are then expected to work for free as part of their "retraining" to ease into a new profession that might pay thousands less in the end. Another poster on here mentioned volunteer workers who put in long hours while the heads of those charities reap huge salaries and benefits. The trend toward free labor is another indication of our moral decline. We have to take a stand. People, when you get up tomorrow morning and look at yourself in the mirror, repeat these words: "I WILL NOT work for free."
Wiki:
the document discusses the widespread issue of unpaid labor, which is not limited to high school or college internships, but is also found in the business world. people are often encouraged to work for free for the promise of exposure, only to see the organization they work for being sold for a large sum of money. older workers are also affected, as they are often forced out of their jobs and expected to work for free as part of their retraining for a lower paying profession. the document emphasizes the moral decline in society and calls for people to take a stand against working for free.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded into complete phrases and sentences:
- "i will not work for free" should be repeated in the mirror every morning.
- age discrimination is a subtle form of discrimination.
- the trend toward free labor is an indication of our moral decline.

Tweet: The system is out of balance, and it's the national industries with their very different output levels which thrives this diversion. There is a lot of tax-payer money which is trying to counter this, but the money, which is on account of the governments are just peanuts. The german industry is steamrolling the rest of europe, and for this devastation everyone has to pay, first of all the german tax-payers. Just look at france, their demise is now on the lever. Where should this end ? A few countries with a workforce of 50 Mio is liable for producing the need of 350 Mio citizen ? But the main problem are political and social issues. This is a conundrum, the moral hazard - unlike the US every country is liable for their own efficiency. Germany can try to drag along the rest of europe, but one reason for a success is our global competitiveness and we may fail to maintain this - to say the european economy as whole has rightly become global insignificant.
Wiki: the document highlights the imbalance in national industries within europe, with the german industry exerting dominance over other european countries. it mentions the inadequate efforts of governments to address this imbalance using taxpayer money, pointing out that the german industry is benefiting at the expense of other european countries, particularly france. the author questions whether it is sustainable for a few countries with a workforce of 50 million to produce for 350 million citizens. they argue that this imbalance is exacerbated by political and social issues, and that each country is responsible for its own efficiency, unlike the situation in the united states. the document suggests that germany's success is based on its global competitiveness, but this could potentially decline, rendering the european economy globally insignificant.

Tweet: Rate my Professor is essentially an internet scam to generate site traffic. I am sorry to see it getting this kind of free publicity in a serious paper like the NYT. modern men should be cautious when using websites like rate my professor, as it may not provide accurate or reliable information. it's important for modern men to consider the source and legitimacy of online reviews and ratings to make informed decisions about professors and classes. they should also be aware of the evaluation systems in place at their universities to ensure the credibility of feedback on faculty members.

Tweet: Most Americans have the same attitude about languages other than their own, as they have about those people who might speak them--fear [and eventually hate]...Although I was educated in what seems like the last ice age, instruction in foreign language began in earnest in middle school and graduating with a bachelor's degree required competency in both a classical (Latin, Greek, Hebrew) and a modern language (French, Spanish, or Italian). Tweet: The only solidarity the hijab shows is with that most ancient of patriarchal male control strategies, shifting the burden of morality, family and male honor, etc., onto the shoulders of female modesty. It is no different from Orthodox Jewish married women having to cover their hair, or the in the Middle Ages married women in Europe were expected to wear a coif to cover their hair, and is nakedly an attempt to confine women's sexual nature in as small a space as possible. It stands in relationship to footbinding and to female genital mutilation, albeit at another point on the bellcurve of control of women and control of female sexuality. If you insist on sacrificing yourself on this altar to show ethnic solidarity, don't be surprised when people conclude that Islam is still stuck in the past. As Rhett Butler once famously said to Scarlett in "Gone with the Wind" when she refused to abandon black mourning clothes for a husband she not only didn't love, but despised, "How closely women clutch the chains that bind them!" Find another way to announce your religious/ethnic identity. Your daughters deserve a better message.
Wiki:
the document argues that the hijab expresses solidarity with patriarchal male control over female modesty, morality, and honor. it compares the hijab to orthodox jewish married women covering their hair and the historical practice of european married women wearing a coif. it suggests that the hijab is an attempt to restrict female sexuality. the document also compares the hijab to footbinding and female genital mutilation in terms of controlling women and their sexuality. it warns against sacrificing oneself to show ethnic solidarity and advises finding another way to express religious and ethnic identity. it emphasizes the importance of sending a better message to future generations. in this context, the document seems to be critical of the practice of wearing the hijab.

- "gone with the wind" refers to the classic novel and film.
- "how closely women clutch the chains that bind them!" is a quote from the character rhett butler in "gone with the wind."

Tweet: As a Creative director and published author I received 15% commission on every book sold and did quite well. Today I can publish my ebook myself and of course edit it after I write it and spell check it as well. Now I can earn 70% on every ebook sold. That allows me quite a bit of leeway in promoting my ebook. Tell me more why I should use an author agent who takes a commission and a publisher who makes a lot of money from my writing? By the way, they never gave authors extra money when they submitted the manuscript electronically saving publishers money by not having to enter text into a computer from typewritten pages-they kept the savings. Well one reason is I may miss the advance on signing most of my rights away on a contract.
Wiki: the author is explaining that as a creative director and published author, they used to receive a 15% commission on every book sold, but now that they can publish their own ebook, they can earn a 70% commission. they question why they should still use an author agent and publisher, who take commissions and make a lot of money from their writing. they mention that publishers used to save money by not having to enter typewritten manuscripts into a computer, but authors did not see any extra money from these savings. they also note that signing a contract with a publisher can mean giving up most of their rights and missing out on an advance payment. #authorlife #publishingindustry #commission #ebookpublishing

Tweet: I would tend to agree: Poll results (no matter how ill formed the poll questions) create a public narrative that exists outside of any rigorous definition of reality. This is very much like the artificial Red State / Blue State divide, when in fact most states are clearly purple. But polls tell us Texas is full of tea party nuts, and Massachusetts the lair of well meaning but totally impractical socialists and Harvard pontificators. And ne'er the twain shall meet. This is, of course, a dangerous way to conduct public dialogue, and I lay a lot of the blame on the press, which refuses to call the idiocy of some of these polls out. The fourth estate needs to step back and find some voices of reason.
Wiki:
the document suggests that poll results, no matter how poorly constructed the poll questions are, shape a public narrative that may not accurately reflect reality. this is similar to the artificial red state/blue state divide, when in reality most states are a mix of both. polls create the perception that texas is full of tea party supporters and massachusetts is full of impractical socialists and harvard intellectuals, perpetuating a polarized view of the country. the document blames the press for not calling out the idiocy of these polls and suggests that the media needs to find voices of reason to conduct public dialogue in a more responsible manner.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- ne'er = never
- twain = two
- the fourth estate = the media
- tea party nuts = supporters of the tea party movement
- lair = home or base
- hashtag = symbol used on social media to mark a keyword or topic
- voices of reason = rational and responsible individuals

Tweet: I watch enough cooking competitions (on TV) to realize that 4 chefs at a table will not all agree as to the quality and complexity of the seasoning upon the palate. Now add 2 or three courses, and remove the trained palates from diners who may be there for reasons other than the chef's concoction, and you may realize that salt and pepper belong on the table to satisfy the the varying palates of those paying to dine. I like a bit of salt on my salad, especially on tomatoes or the bread which is put on the table. At home in the shaker, we use salt that has the lowest amount of sodium (approx. 280mg per serving) and we have a grinder as well. I rarely add salt without taking a bite first. I have also had dishes where I wish i could remove salt from a dish. Leave it on the table. Those with health concerns and have minimal will power, ask to have it removed from the table.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes the importance of having salt and pepper on the table in restaurants to satisfy the varying palates of diners. the writer personally prefers to add salt to their salad, especially on tomatoes and bread, using salt with the lowest amount of sodium and rarely adding it without tasting first. they also acknowledge the need for people with health concerns and minimal willpower to have salt removed from the table.

as for 'farm subsidy', this document does not directly address the topic. however, it highlights the importance of catering to the preferences and needs of consumers, which can relate to the agricultural industry and the subsidies provided to farmers. the document also emphasizes the individual choices and consumption habits of diners, which can be influenced by various factors including agricultural practices and subsidies.

Tweet: With the costs of education FAR outpacing inflation, I wonder what these unpaid interns have to do to keep their heads above water? (Those who aren't lucky/rich enough to have parental support, that is). Of course, the price inflation of education accident. It's due to the government policy of underfunding public education. Coming from a disadvantaged background, I was simply unable afford to take on unpaid work during and after college, regardless of how much it might have helped my future career to do so. Thus I was at a disadvantage compared to peers at my college. This doesn't really sound like a level playing field, does it??? One additional point: The emphasis on internship experience on resumes allows employers an easy way to ascertain which candidates are likely to come from wealthier backgrounds...making it easier for employees to discriminate in terms of social class and race (since certain races are more likely to be represented in the disadvantaged group). Not fair. And we wonder why there are no jobs out there? Employers are filling lots of them for free.
Wiki:
the document discusses the high cost of education and the challenges faced by unpaid interns, particularly those without parental support. the author attributes the rising costs of education to government policies that underfund public education. they also mention their personal experience of being unable to afford unpaid work during and after college, which put them at a disadvantage compared to their peers. the author argues that this creates an unfair playing field and allows for discrimination based on social class and race. they also mention that the emphasis on internship experience on resumes may favor candidates from wealthier backgrounds. the document suggests that these factors may contribute to a lack of job opportunities. 

expand the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

Tweet: I find most restaurant food too salty. I know this not so much from the taste but the way my body reacts afterwards. I often wake up in the middle of the night with extreme dry mouth after eating out. Since there are some people who should have little to no salt in their diets for health reasons, I'd prefer to see chefs go very lightly with the salt and then let people add salt if they wish.

Tweet: I prefer to know how many people are responding to a Times article in a manner that would please Nazi's and racists and homophobes. I don't feel that I am in any danger of absorbing horrific ideas simply by hearing them. I would call that a bogus social theory. Tweet: I think the concept of rating professors online (like just about any other form of public ratings) is ludicrous. To think that students attending a college where they are to be judged by a professor and given a grade for a class should be taken as fair and impartial in rating that professor's performance makes ZERO sense. Even worse, of course, are people who go out to eat and suddenly find themselves qualified to write for Gourmet Magazine. I read these reviews occasionally but NEVER take them seriously. Still, complaining will do nothing to stop this from occurring. Such are the times we live in and nothing is going to turn back the clock HOWEVER I, for one, think the concept is pretty repulsive and anyone or any institution that takes these ratings seriously is, by my definition, a person not to be taken seriously.
Wiki:
the document expresses a strong dislike for the concept of rating professors and restaurants online. the writer believes that it is unfair for students to judge their professors and for restaurant patrons to think they are qualified to write professional reviews. the writer also feels that taking these ratings seriously is repulsive and anyone who does so should not be taken seriously. they acknowledge that complaining will not change the situation but still find the concept ludicrous.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

- gourmet magazine: a publication known for its high-quality food and wine reviews and articles
- zero sense: no logical reasoning
- repulsive: extremely distasteful and unpleasant
- #ratingprofessors: referring to the practice of rating professors online
- #publicratings: evaluations given by the general public
- #foodreviews: assessments of restaurants and their food
- #collegegrading: the process of evaluating students' work at college
- #sucharethetimeswelivein: acknowledging the current cultural and societal norms

Tweet: According to the Centers for Disease Control, childhood obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. The percentage of children aged 6-11 years in the United States who were obese increased from 7% in 1980 to nearly 18% in 2012. Similarly, the percentage of adolescents aged 12-19 years who were obese increased from 5% to nearly 21% over the same period. Now, more than one-third of American children and adolescents are overweight or obese. The obesity epidemic is linked to screen time, to kids sitting on their butts looking at screens all day, to the lack of outdoor activity and exercise. Mind and body are interactive systems and without a healthy body, there can be no healthy mind. How many yougn people these days are depressed, or hyperactive, or otherwise suffering from some mental disorder --- and how many would benefit from fresh air and exercise and time in the natural world? Mr. Bergman does not even begin to address childhood and adolescent obesity in his screed based only on personal anecdote.

Tweet: Separating internships as a special class of poorly paid work seems almost pointless. If MacDonald's can't employ a cashier who's willing to work for less than minimum wage (or for free), why can ABC do it for an intern? The only reason for an exception would be if the intern is there for true training purposes and not for the employer's immediate benefit. Clearly, most interns are there to supply grunt labor, whether or not they actually get a chance to show their stuff. Also, the kind of large corporations who hire rafts of interns can certainly afford to pay them minimum wage to escape all legal scrutiny. These firms could still take comfort in knowing that minimum wage isn't nearly enough to live on.
Wiki:
the document argues that treating internships as a separate category of low-paid work is not justified. it questions why companies like macdonald's cannot employ a cashier for below minimum wage or for free, while other companies can do so for interns. it suggests that the only exception for unpaid internships should be if the intern is there for true training purposes and not for the immediate benefit of the employer. it also points out that most interns are used for grunt labor, even if they do not get a chance to showcase their skills. the document also mentions that large corporations who hire many interns can afford to pay them minimum wage to avoid legal issues. finally, it emphasizes that, despite this, minimum wage is still not enough to live on.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document have been expanded into complete phrases and sentences below:

- macdonald's: refers to the fast-food restaurant chain mcdonald's.
- abc: refers to a generic company or employer.
- #intern: refers

Tweet: Fletcher has got it exactly right. The best solution would be for both Elizabeth and Charles to abdicate and turn the Firm over to William and Kate. But since that will not happen, let's postpone until we're left with no choice the ascension of Charles--and even worse, Camilla. The thought of boring, stuffed-shirt Charles as king for decades is bad enough, but having Camilla shoved front and center would be a nightmare come true, even without the formal title of queen. Imagine-year after year of pictures of the two puttering in their garden with their little spades and shooting grouse at Balmoral. Oh, the horror, the horror-made even worse by knowing that Will and Kate are having to lie low. Of course, knowing the media's attention will gravitate anyway toward the young and vibrant, I feel a tinge of sympathy for the sad fate awaiting Charles and Camilla.

Tweet: While it's true that many unmoderated comments sections can become sewers (the NY Daily News section was an absolute cesspool...), moderated comments sections like those The Times actually make a tremendous contribution to both reader understanding of the issues and our political process. I would also stipulate that allowing anonymous comments can indeed be problematic, and that commentators should be willing to disclose their identity when expressing their opinion - and thus expose themselves to the potential scrutiny that goes along with doing this.

in relation to 'hijab', the document suggests that discussions about the hijab should take place in a moderated and respectful environment, where commentators are accountable for their statements. this ensures that the conversation remains productive and respectful.

Tweet: Mr. Lackman says Europe will not agree to end its disastrous austerity policies toward Greece for fear that they will have to do so elsewhere. That's a feature, not a bug. Tweet: For some reason farmers (and fisherman) view making a profit as a right. Why should the rest of us support them? Tweet: I've been an intern at several places and can say that while there are educational elements to them, interns are mostly given grunt work to assist paid employees. After my experience, I have decided I will never be an intern and/or work for free again. A lot of people are fooled into believing that based on their grades and/or standing in school, there is no other way to get your foot in the door. That is not true. As a mediocre student, I was able to find a paid position where I worked, got paid, and just as well received the same educational value I would have received if I was unpaid. In my opinion, interns should receive minimum wage. Granted, they have no experience, minor if not any qualifications, and generally no practical knowledge. However, they use their limbs and their brains just as any paid employee. This would be most fair, and would certainly boost the United States economy.
Wiki:
the document discusses the experience of being an intern and the realization that interns are often given menial tasks to assist paid employees. the author has decided not to be an intern or work for free again, and believes that many people are misled into thinking that it's the only way to gain experience in their field. the author argues that it's possible to find paid positions even as a mediocre student, and suggests that interns should be paid at least minimum wage for their work. it is also suggested that paying interns would benefit the economy.

Tweet: One of the useful roles a comment sections can serve: an immediate correction mechanism from the general public when an author is demonstrably wrong on the facts. For example, another news site ran an article decrying the fact that none of the presidential candidates had bothered to pay any attention to New York's public housing projects. Within about 15 minutes of the story being released, commenters were putting up links to stories about Bernie Sanders visiting New York's public housing projects about 10 hours earlier, a rebuttal that many readers might have been unaware of had the comment section not existed. And the New York Times' centralized moderation system isn't the only way to get real legitimate debate going, with evidence and logic being thrown around (along with the occasional entertainment like parody song lyrics or poetry).
Wiki:
the document discusses the usefulness of comment sections as mechanisms for immediate corrections from the general public. it provides an example of how commenters were able to quickly correct an author's factual error in an article about presidential candidates' attention to new york's public housing projects. this serves as evidence that comment sections can facilitate real debate and provide evidence and logic to support or refute claims made in an article. additionally, it highlights the value of comment sections in bringing attention to important information that may have been overlooked by the original author.

expansion of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- "bernie sanders" instead of "bernie"
- "new york times" instead of nyt
- "legitimate" instead of "real"
- "supermarket" does not appear to be a relevant expansion, as it is not mentioned in the original document.

Tweet: The CIA reminds me by its recent actions of the old joke, "Military Intelligence is a contradiction in terms." To the extent that the CIA has become militarized and lawless, (which is the real reason that the prison at Guantanemo was established, so that torture could take place without the oversight of U.S. law) it has become a detriment to the nation, and a blot on the United States' reputation. We should disband the CIA and assign its responsibilities to civilians who will obey the laws and understand the consequences of covert actions to our foreign relations. The State Department should be well up to the task. Faulty intelligence leads to lost wars and continual embarrassment for the politicians who rely on it. The CIA should have no ties to the Department of Defense, so that operations can be unfettered by a military mindset.

Tweet: The new Greek govt must do 2 things. One is to negotiate a decrease (or restructuring to longer payment terms) of its debt. That is the immediate problem. The new Govt. may or may not be able to do this. That will depend on how the negotiations go with the creditors. Simultaneously, and very importantly however, Greece must undergo serious economic reforms. For example the creation of a land registry, a stop to political vote buying by politicians, a stop to corruption, the creation of an apolitical statistical service, a non-pollitcal civil servant based on merit instead of cronyism, etc. Does the new Govt show any signs of this (beyond rheteric)? Absolutely not. There are no signs that a land registry will be created, that merit will be the basis of a civil service, that a non-political statistical service will be created or that an effective tax collection agency will be set up. Hence this latter task will not be accomplished.
Wiki:
the document is discussing the actions that the new greek government must take. it states that the immediate problem is negotiating a decrease or restructuring of the country's debt, which will depend on the negotiations with creditors. it also emphasizes the need for serious economic reforms, such as creating a land registry, stopping political vote buying and corruption, establishing an apolitical statistical service, and basing the civil service on merit rather than cronyism. however, it criticizes the new government for not showing any signs of implementing these reforms beyond rhetoric, and predicts that this task will not be accomplished.

as for "home schoolers", the document does not mention them, so i cannot provide a summary or expansion on that specific topic.

Tweet: When did having 75% of the students passing a course with a C or better become a good thing? I think that a 75% passing rate is not good. Did anyone work with these students to understand why only 75% of them passed? How much did the 75% who passed understand? Were they able to apply what they had been taught on line? I've taken online courses and they were not well designed, flexible, or conducive to having a discussion. This holds true for a set of courses I took 5 years ago and for several I've taken in the last year. Having an on line course available in conjunction with a live course would be great. Then the students can go over it to see what they've missed, ask questions if that doesn't help, and refer back to it when their notes aren't enough to recall the subject matter to mind. But exclusive reliance upon on line courses is foolish.

Tweet: I learned cursive in grade school back in the 80's and I haven't stopped using it since. It's a skill I am grateful I have. As kids, we took pride in our handwriting...today...I don't think kids know what a pen is. That's sad. I look at some handwriting from pretty high level professionals and it's atrocious. People don't even write whole words anymore. To me, this speaks to standards, which I believe were effectively lowered forever when spellcheck was invented. Soon the question will be asked...do children need to write at all...can't they just text the answers to their teachers? I, for one, look forward to the beautifully handwritten notes I get from friends and remember them much more than emails and text messages. Please, let's not lower the standards on handwriting too.
Wiki:
the document expresses a sense of nostalgia for the art of cursive handwriting, which the author learned in grade school in the 80s and has continued to use. they are grateful for this skill and feel that it is a lost art in today's society, where children seem to have little appreciation for handwriting. the author is concerned about the declining standards of handwriting, particularly in the professional world, and attributes this decline to the invention of spellcheck. they fear that handwriting may become obsolete as technology advances, and emphasize the value of handwritten notes over electronic communication. the document concludes with a plea to maintain high standards for handwriting.

Tweet: Odd for me to say this since I am (a) so deeply committed to technology and computers and type super fast (>100wpm), and (b) have really bad handwriting -- but I cannot imagine not writing in cursive. Writing in print is impossible. It is so slow as to be like using a early (not even late) generation dial-up modem. And for me at least, writing does stimulate thinking in a way that nothing else does. I took all my college and law school exams in writing, even though we were allowed to type them. For me at least, not being able to write really really fast would greatly lessen my capabilities. Indeed, I've even thought about taking a short-hand class since my writing is just for me, not anyone else.
Wiki: the document suggests that writing in cursive is important for the individual, despite being deeply committed to technology and having fast typing skills. the writer finds that writing in print is too slow and prefers the speed and stimulation of thinking that comes with cursive writing. they also believe that writing enhances their capabilities and have even considered taking a shorthand class. overall, the document implies that cursive writing is healthier for the individual's cognitive processes and overall abilities, despite the prevalence of technology.

Tweet: Count me a longtime fan of the 14th Amendment of the US Constitution, for its breadth and scope that encompasses the greatest of American values: not just defining citizenship, but setting forth states' obligations, due process, equal protection of the laws, This was the Amendment that required the states to follow the Bill of Rights. Brown v Board of Education, civil rights laws, privacy rulings, women's rights, gay rights, disability protections, they all flow from the 14th. Start tinkering, and you're risking a lot more than the status of some native-born children.
Wiki:
the document praises the 14th amendment of the us constitution for its comprehensive coverage of american values, such as defining citizenship, setting forth the obligations of states, due process, and equal protection of the laws. it asserts that this amendment required the states to follow the bill of rights and serves as the foundation for important legal decisions related to civil rights, privacy, women's rights, gay rights, and disability protections. it warns that any changes made to this amendment could have far-reaching consequences, particularly for native-born children.

expand:

- brown v board of education: a landmark supreme court case that ruled segregation in public schools unconstitutional.
- civil rights laws: legislation designed to protect the rights of individuals from discrimination based on race, gender, or other characteristics.
- privacy rulings: legal decisions addressing the right to privacy and limits on government intrusion.
- women's rights: the movement for women's equality and protection from discrimination.
- gay rights: the fight for equal rights and protections for lgbtq+ individuals.

Tweet: I would no more declaw a cat than fly to the moon on gossamer wings! There's another option, which some consider to be more humane, and that is to cut the muscles or whatever that allow the cat to retract its claws. They just flop in or out, depending on the position of the cat. PLEASE explain to me why this form of torture is more humane than declawing. I could never maim, hurt, torture or kill any animal. My cat is a strictly indoor creature, she has all of her claws and a nice big scratching post/cat tree. She has NEVER ONCE scratched on anything but that. I taught her to do that. It is NOT impossible to train a cat!
Wiki:
the document argues against declawing cats and suggests an alternative method of cutting the muscles that retract the cat's claws. the author believes that this method is more humane and emphasizes the importance of not causing harm to animals. the author also mentions that they have trained their cat to use a scratching post and believes that it is possible to train a cat. this perspective on animal welfare can be related to the concept of women's rights, as it is about advocating for the well-being and rights of living beings. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- i would no more declaw a cat than fly to the moon on gossamer wings! (i would not declaw a cat, and that's as likely as flying to the moon on delicate wings!)
- please explain to me why this form of torture is more humane than declawing. (please explain to me why this method of harming animals is considered more humane than declawing.)
- hashtag: #woman's right

Tweet: Privatization of state asserts means that German businessmen can buy those asserts at a fraction of their real value and make Greece a German colony. Lachman has served the interests of the world's financial elites whose motto (Adam Smith, bk 3) is "everything for ourselves and nothing for other people." Those German businessmen and firms spent hundreds of millions of euros bribing Greek officials to buy German weapons including a set of submarines that never went to sea and are now rusting ashore--Merkel's masters want them paid for though the debt be odious. A major NY bank enabled a Greek government to disguise huge borrowings as investments; those debts too are odious. There's a story: Merkel went to Greece; the customs official asked "Nationality," Merkel answered "German." "Occupation" asked the customs officer, Merkel replied "no, I'm just here for the weekend."Lachman warns "leaving the euro would almost surely result in a massive run on the Greek banks, which would plunge the country into economic and financial chaos." Where does he think Greece is now? Oh yes, reparations for the German occupation of Greece during WWII?
Wiki:
the document discusses the potential consequences of the privatization of state assets in greece, which may result in german businessmen buying these assets at a fraction of their value and essentially turning greece into a german colony. the author, lachman, believes that this serves the interests of the world's financial elites and highlights the corruption involved, such as german businessmen bribing greek officials to buy german weapons and a major ny bank enabling the greek government to disguise borrowings as investments.

the document also mentions the potential repercussions of greece leaving the euro, warning that it could lead to a massive run on greek banks and plunge the country into economic and financial chaos. there is also a reference to the issue of reparations for the german occupation of greece during wwii.

- ny: new york

slang:

- "greece is now?": a sarcastic

Tweet: The pathway to a career in medicine is designed to benefit specific areas of medicine. To be considered for admission to medical school, candidates must spend significant time and effort on research. This results in substantial free labor for tens of thousands of researchers. Also this effort is focused on research rather than more specifically to areas such as serving the community, which has a lesser role. International medical school graduates also spend months and sometimes longer demonstrating their skills to obtain a residency position. This is another area that can be abused as the stakes are high and there are few protections against abuses. Health professional associations and corporations preparing candidates for standardized tests have a great design that benefits them well, but fails to deliver the health professionals needed.
Wiki:
the document explains that the pathway to a career in medicine is structured to benefit specific areas of medicine. in order to be eligible for admission to medical school, candidates must dedicate a significant amount of time and effort to research, which results in the provision of substantial free labor for tens of thousands of researchers. the focus on research as a requirement for admission means that efforts to serve the community have a less significant role. additionally, international medical school graduates must spend months, sometimes longer, demonstrating their skills to secure a residency position, which can be exploited due to the high stakes and lack of protections against abuses. the document also criticizes health professional associations and corporations for designing standardized test preparation in a way that benefits them, but fails to produce the needed health professionals.

birthright citizenship, slang for the legal right of anyone born in a country to be a citizen of that country, is not referenced in the document. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags are not used in the document.

Tweet: The ACA is what we have and what we were able to generate. While it is far from perfect and single-payer would likely be better, we need to try and make it work. Obama should get some credit for making any in-roads in this nasty, contentious climate. And older healthcare advancements came together in piece-meal improvements so there is reason to hope we can move towards single-payer, or least incremental improvement and coverage.
Wiki:
the document acknowledges that the affordable care act (aca) is not perfect, and a single-payer system would likely be better, but it's what we have and what we were able to create. it suggests that efforts should be made to make it work instead of completely discarding it. it also gives credit to obama for making progress in the challenging political climate. the document expresses hope that the healthcare system can move towards a single-payer system or at least make incremental improvements in coverage.

for a college student, this means that the current healthcare system, the aca, is not perfect, but it's important to understand and work within its framework. it would be beneficial to learn about the system and advocate for improvements while also making use of the available resources. it also suggests keeping an open mind about potential future changes to the healthcare system.

the document uses the abbreviation "aca" to refer to the affordable care act. the slang phrase "making it work" means to find a way to make something
